award_title: Miniaturized Enhanced Position and Azimuth Determining System
research_keywords: Navigation,Fusion,survey,Pads,Inertial sensors,Gyroscope,targeting,GPS
abstract: To address the Marines need for a miniaturized inertial survey system which can meet or exceed the current Improved Position and Azimuth Determining System (IPADS) performance requirements with significant reductions in form factor and weight, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop the new Miniaturized Enhanced Position and Azimuth Determination (MEPAD) system based on novel complementary blending of state-of-the-art small form factor inertial sensors combined with optimized Kalman filter fusion algorithms. The innovative tightly integrated architecture allows precise and timely Survey Control Point (SCP) azimuth determination and maintaining of position knowledge while traversing a common Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid. In Phase I, POC will develop the proposed MEPAD system architecture and subsystem components requirements. The optimized algorithms will also be developed, modeled, and simulated incorporating the hardware noise specifications to demonstrate the feasibility of MEPAD. POC will provide the details on the hardware/software required and provide an estimate of the size and weight, and prepare a preliminary plan to develop and evaluate a prototype MEPAD system in Phase II. In Phase II, POC plans to build and evaluate MEPAD against the current IPADS performance specifications. A plan for Phase III transition to the Marine Corps will be developed.

award_title: Miniaturization of GPS Alternative Survey Equipment
research_keywords: Robust Estimation,celestial navigation,Inertial navigation,GPS-degraded navigation,sensor fusion,precision survey,Optimal Estimation
abstract: Accurate surveys of both position and azimuth are critical components of the artillery mission. These requirements must be met in all operational environments, including situations where GPS signals are degraded or denied. Currently, these requirements have been met using the Improved Position and Azimuth Determining System (IPADS). Unfortunately, the IPADS is based on older navigation sensor technology which results in a heavy and power-hungry system and limits the total mission effectiveness of the system. To address this need, we propose to develop a Compact Optimal Multi-Sensor Position and Attitude Survey System (COMPASS). COMPASS is an innovative approach that seamlessly combines state-of-the-art sensors, an optimal robust nonlinear fusion engine, and a modular system architecture which enables us to meet or exceed IPADS performance while greatly improving the system SWAP (under 10 lbs total sensor weight). This order-of-magnitude improvement in SWAP not only enables single-Marine operation, it opens up a new set of use cases, including the possibility for dismounted operations. COMPASS offers Marines a system that is lightweight, intelligent, and mission effective.

award_title: High-Speed Amphibious Assault Vehicle Hull
research_keywords: Adaptive hull structure,amphibious assault vehicle,Planing hull
abstract: To facilitate assault operations, the Marines need an amphibious vehicle that can quickly move troops and equipment between ships and the shore. However, due to an increased level of sophistication in the anti-ship weapons available to potential adversaries, Navy ships must remain far from shore during assault operations (i.e., many tens of miles). This creates a need for assault vehicles that can achieve high speed in the water. Current displacement hull-based assault vehicles do not provide the desired high-speed capability. The need that is addressed in this proposal is the development of an adaptive hull structure for amphibious assault vehicles that can achieve high speed. We have developed an innovative planing hull concept that also incorporates an adaptive propulsion system that meets the requirements for low-speed operation in shallow water and high-speed operation in deep water when in the planing mode. In Phase I of the project, the Creare team will develop its innovative hull concept by conducting computational fluid analysis and finite element analysis to validate our design concepts. We will also develop hydrodynamic scaled models that will facilitate tow tank testing at the start of Phase II.

award_title: Mobile Platform for the Fuels Asset Maintenance Management System (FAMMS)
research_keywords: FAMMS,Security,MAXIMO,Asset Management,web,Mobile,Information Assurance,Fuels
abstract: Progeny will provide a secure mobile platform that combines a hardware device with software applications that integrates with IBM MAXIMO EAM utilizing the Maximo Integration Framework (MIF). Our true innovation for this effort will be to create applications to run in the Android, iOS, Blackberry, and Windows mobile platforms by converting the mobile web application into native applications. The applications will provide the ability to access and process work orders while offline. These native applications will be converted from the web application by utilizing Apaches Cordova. This method will provide the ability to develop the application once, and maintain a single set of source code but have the ability to deploy that application across various platforms. This will also ensure that the user experience will be the same across each platform. Finally, Progeny has a proven track record of managing Certification and Accreditation packages from the creation of those packages, to guiding those packages through the approval process, and finally maintaining that packages security posture through the applications life cycle.

award_title: Materials Development for Affordable Maritime Compatible Radio Frequency Materials
research_keywords: RF reflection,Composite,RF Transmission,Magnetic,Radome,Maritime,RF material,absorber
abstract: The primary objective of this Phase I SBIR is to develop and demonstrate a State-of-Art Multi-Functional RF Material System applicable to a multitude of Navy Sea, Air and Land platforms that is producible in large quantities, affordable, maintainable, and sustainable. The proposed Multi-Functional RF Material System can be tailored to provide low to high dielectric and magnetic properties and low to high electric and magnetic loss, while maintaining the strength and stiffness of a conventional structural composite system. The true multi-functional nature of the material will also result in a system solution that will require less volume and will be lighter compared to current solutions. Finally, these material systems will utilize high volume composite pre-preg manufacturing techniques to keep the cost comparable to standard composite pre-preg systems in use today.

award_title: Shipboard Radar Cross Section/Radio Frequency (RCS/RF) Verification of Airborne Platform
research_keywords: Shipboard,handheld,radar cross section,air to air,Radio Frequency,ship to air
abstract: The Radar Cross Section (RCS) and Radio Frequency (RF) performance are vital elements of the platforms mission effectiveness yet inspecting and verifying their performance while shipboard has proven to be impractical due to the operational impact, cost and logistics footprint of previous methodologies. Therefore, these vital elements may go uncharacterized while deployed at sea, drawing question to the readiness level and thereby reducing confidence that the platform is fully mission capable.SCI will investigate and determine the feasibility of enhancing the InfiniScan RCS measurement tool to also perform RF assessment, thereby providing a dual-use capability which is directly suited for shipboard operation.SCI will investigate the feasibility of satisfying the shipboard to air verification requirement stated in this solicitation by adapting the Dynamic REal-time Agile Measurement system to be based on board a ship rather than as a ground to air verification system.SCI will investigate the feasibility of satisfying the air to air verification requirement stated in this solicitation by leveraging the small form factor, high speed, low power and advanced processing building blocks while and enhancing their capability to be integrated in a pod based air to air verification system.

award_title: Shipboard Radar Cross Section/Radio Frequency (RCS/RF) Verification of Airborne Platform
research_keywords: RF,handheld,RCS,Probe,imaging
abstract: With the increasing complexity of RF apertures and signature requirements on modern air platforms, in-field verification is a critical need for the US Armed Forces. In particular, the unique operating environment of Navy ships increases the need, technical difficulty, and logistical hurdles of performing such verifications at sea. IERUS Technologies proposes to develop a unique, reconfigurable RF probe system for handheld and robotically controlled use. The probe shall be capable of measuring defects in both LO treatments and RF apertures and overall vehicle RCS, supporting inspections at both Tier 1 and Tier 2 levels with the same unit. The proposed system is both affordable and supports quick measurements with 3D imaging capability to remove clutter such as landing gear or other below-deck obstructions via post-processing. Whether handheld or robotically manipulated, the proposed sensor provides a simple and dynamic measurement capability, virtually eliminating the need for dedicated diagnostic facilities. IERUS will provide the Navy a unique shipboard measurement capability with straightforward extension to off-ship diagnostics as well.

award_title: Shipboard Radar Cross Section and Radio Frequency Performance Verification of Low Observable Airborne Platforms
research_keywords: RF Performance Verification,ultra-wideband radar,Low Observable (LO),Stealth/LO Verification,Radar Cross Section (RCS) Measurement,High Resolution Imaging Radar,Radar Cross Section (RCS) Verification,Portable radar
abstract: Current and, more importantly due to increasing threat capabilities, future US Navy (USN) low-observable (LO) aircraft require operational repair and LO performance verification well beyond all other USN airborne assets. Maintaining high-fidelity LO characteristics is particularly challenging in operational environments and even with best maintenance-practices, insidious radar cross section (RCS) hotspots in the aircrafts radar signature can develop and compromise mission lethality as well as aircraft and warfighter survivability. Within this research program, the STAR Dynamics SARBAR handheld, X band, real-time, real-aperture LO imaging radar system design will be optimized and refined to produce ultra-wideband (UWB) high-resolution, two-dimensional (2D), spotlight-radar images on flight and hanger decks providing visualization and recording of 2D images, for unprecedented operational, at-sea LO-verification and survivability assurance. Similarly, surface-to-air LO-verification technologies will be evaluated and design-enhanced for operational implementation, based on STARs existing, demonstrated, and validated, Ground-To-Air RCS System (GTARS) radar tracking/imaging technology that measures radar LO signatures of aircraft in dynamic, operational airborne environments, generating calibrated radar images to provide maintainers with otherwise unavailable LO-verification data. Lastly, this research effort will provide a baseline design configuration for a compact, affordable UWB airborne LO-verification radar capable of critical, real-time, in-flight GO/NO-GO LO verification of LO aircraft.

award_title: SiC-Based High Voltage Capacitor Charging Innovations
research_keywords: Power converter,Railgun,Capacitor charger,SiC,Silicon Carbide,high voltage
abstract: Under this SBIR, Diversified Technologies, Inc. (DTI) will build on its proven EMRG Compact Power Converter design (N113-181), incorporating advanced power devices to take advantage of their improved wide bandgap performance, and allowing continuous duty-cycle operation. Front-end conditioning and switching arrangements will be developed to accommodate various input voltages including 650-1100 VDC, 6.5 kVDC, and 4160 VAC. DTI will also examine designs to utilize higher voltage MVDC power sources in the 10-20 kVDC range, as described in the PMS 320 Naval Power Systems Technology Development Roadmap. To support a broader range of applications, we will investigate architectures that will allow bi-directional power conversion between battery and capacitor energy storage. As with our previous effort, DTI will design, build, and deliver a power converter unit in Phase II meeting all prototype performance requirements, for integration and testing at Navy Railgun facilities.

award_title: SiC-Based High Voltage Capacitor Charging Innovations
research_keywords: Capacitor charger,Pulsed Power,power density,SiC,High Frequency,MV Distribution System
abstract: Electromagnetic Railguns (EMRG) require high-voltage supplies to power pulse-forming-networks (PFN) through charging/discharging of High Voltage (HV) capacitors. Existing high-output-voltage power converters have inadequate power densities for shipboard applications. Additionally, most commercial high-output-voltage converters dont accept input voltages in the range of projected Navy power systems, and arent compatible with the shipboard environment (shock, vibration, etc.) requirements. Navy capacitor charging is very different from commercial applications with higher power levels, continuous operation at high repetition rates, high ramp rates and/or steep changes in power profile, posing challenges to the prime movers and system stability. RCT Systems will develop an innovative, advanced, high power density silicon carbide (SiC) based, modular and scalable capacitor charging converter capable of charging 325kJ capacitor(s) from zero to 6.5-10kVDC in 5 seconds at repetition rates up to 10 charges per minute. Advanced circuit and control techniques will be used to achieve charging profiles with low peak to average power ratios. Mechanical design aspects for shipboard environment (packaging, thermal, shock, vibration, EMI/EMC) will be examined. Since multiple chargers are used in the EMRG application, the system design aspects related to the interface with the shipboard Medium Voltage (MV) distribution system will be provided, focused on the 4160VAC case.

award_title: SiC-Based High Voltage Capacitor Charging Innovations
research_keywords: Capacitor charger,multi stage converter,3 MW/m3 power density,High voltage converter.
abstract: The Navy is currently developing a Pulsed Power System (PPS) to power an Electromagnetic Railgun (EMRG). The PPS uses a capacitor bank as the source of the very high current required by the EMRG for operation. EMRG requirements necessitate the use of a high power density (>3MW/m3) DC/DC converter capable of a 10 capacitor recharge rate per minute.  This capacitor bank is comprised of 325 kJ capacitor rep-rate modules which must recharge to 10kV from the ships 650-1100 VDC power.   The capacitor bank charger must have a peak-to-average power ratio of no more than 1.1 over the charge cycle.  There are no direct commercial solutions to this capacitor bank charger application.   In this Phase I SBIR we propose to develop a high energy density capacitor charger that has a 3MW/m3 power density that is accomplished by having SiC based multiple DC-DC converter stages that are initially paralleled then connected in series as the capacitor voltage rises, and to oil fill the charger to minimize the volume required to meet the voltage isolation and corona elimination requirements.    The successful development of this technology will enables the EMRG while reducing the overall size and weight of the weapon system.

award_title: Multi-analyte chemical sensor array for underwater explosives detection
research_keywords: Explosive trace detection in seawater,marine environment,ROV,sensor array,multi-parametric sensing,porous silicon,nanocomposite.
abstract: In this Phase I project, we will define and develop a concept for a multi-analyte sensor system to detect explosive threat compounds of interest at operationally relevant concentrations in seawater.    Explosives trace detection and classification will be performed by Emitechs novel technology, which involves  smart nanocomposites and multi-parametric electro-optical sensing. We will conduct a feasibility analysis and provide the conceptual design of a compact sensor array for underwater real-time detection and classification of nitro- and peroxide- based explosives. The design of a water-vapor conversion module will be selected and preliminarily tested using simulating breadboards. The number of sensory elements will be determined and the flow cell will be modified accordingly.  Also, with high-level assistance from SubChem Sensor System, Inc. (our subcontractor), all necessary equipment/software for integration of the sensor array into an ROV platform will be assessed and conceptually designed.        During the 6-months of the Phase I option, we will contribute to the continued progress of the project for a successful transition to Phase II.  This time will be spent initiating the transition from a conceptual design to a fabricated package.      A working prototype will be fabricated, tested and optimized during Phase II project performance.

award_title: Trace Multi-Analyte Chemical Detection System for Underwater UXO Applications
research_keywords: UUXO,Underwater,unexploded ordnance,trace chemical,Raman,SERS
abstract: Navy Explosive Ordnance Disposal (EOD) response teams encounter a variety of underwater explosive threats including limpet mines, naval mines, underwater improvised explosive devices (UW-IEDs) and other UXO. If successful, the proposed trace chemical/explosive sensor system will provide improved classification and identification of suspect underwater targets in missions for which acoustic and/or visual imaging alone are not effective. The envisioned chemical sensor package will be capable of being integrated into a man-portable remotely operated vehicle (ROV). The goal of this project is to expand the existing trace chemical detection capability to include TNT and other nitro-based underwater UXO analytes of interest, such as RDX, PETN and HMX, as well as home-made explosive (HME) compound such as ammonium nitrate, triacetone triperoxide (TATP), and hexamethylene triperoxide diamine (HMTD). The current state-of-the-art is a single analyte sensor for detection of TNT, which only partially addresses the Navys requirement to detect the full range of explosive threats. The team will define and develop a concept for a multi-analyte sensor system to detect explosive threat compounds of interest at operationally relevant concentrations in seawater.

award_title: Low Power, Rapid Detector of Trace Underwater Explosives
research_keywords: Underwater explosives,Ordnance,trace detection,Raman spectroscopy,SERS
abstract: The current state-of-the-art for an underwater unexploded ordnance (UUXO) detector is a single analyte sensor for detection of TNT, which only partially addresses the Navys requirement to detect the full range of explosive threats. Because of the low solubility of explosive compounds in water, the concentration of explosives near UUXO is likely to be extremely low. Furthermore, once the explosive compound is released, it rapidly mixes in the surrounding water. Prevailing currents make the explosive concentration highly localized and non-uniform, requiring good sensor time response to avoid averaging out of the plume signal. Furthermore, chemical and biological interferents in the seawater can introduce bias and complicate the analysis. For these reasons, analyzers with superb sensitivity, time-response, and multi-analyte sensitivity are required for this application. Mainstream Engineering proposes a system that is a multi-analyte sensor system to detect explosive threat compounds of interest (both nitro-based and peroxide-based) at operationally relevant concentrations in seawater. In addition, the sensor will be compact, low-power, and ruggedize for a marine environment about an autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV).

award_title: VERBENA: Versatile Backpressure-Enabled Network Architecture
research_keywords: Condition-based maintenance,CBM,Energy Command and Control,EC2,backpressure,Routing,NETWORK,Architecture
abstract: The Navy requires a reliable wireless networking capability that can continuously collect Condition-Based Maintenance (CBM) data from vehicles at the tactical edge. A robust, automated CBM network could enable commanders and maintenance leaders to have a dashboard view of the health of their assets. Moreover, this network could also deliver Energy Command and Control (EC2) messages that provide the remaining fight status of vehicles.    WPL, Inc. proposes to work with Silvus Technologies, Inc. and Lockheed Martin to develop, prototype, and demonstrate a network architecture for the autonomous collection of CBM and EC2 information. Our VERsatile Backpressure-Enabled Network Architecture (VERBENA) provides an autonomous publish-subscribe data collection service that is effective even in Disconnected, Intermittent, and Limited-bandwidth (DIL) environments. VERBENA can be implemented at the Data Link and Networking Layer of a standalone mobile ad hoc network or at the Application Layer of an existing tactical communications network.

award_title: New Condition Based Maintenance and Energy Command and Control Network Architectures for the Naval Expeditionary Force
research_keywords: CBM,Condition-based maintenance,network,Architecture,Energy Command and Control,cross domain,vehicle health,RFID
abstract: Research Proposed: Research is proposed to develop an innovative transfer method and network architecture for autonomously uploading condition based maintenance (CBM) and energy command and control (C2) data to CBM data warehouses. This novel approach will also allow for operation over limited bandwidth links, including real-time visibility of data from remote locations.   Problem Statement: Capturing CBM data in an efficient and timely manner is key to maintaining accurate predictions of vehicle health. Current solutions require manual connection or wireless links with insufficient data transfer rates for the CBM data.  Additionally, they can pose cross-domain data transfer issues and lack of visibility of real-time data over wireless tactical data links.  Plan/Process Outline: A flexible architecture will be designed for autonomously uploading CBM data over radios including bandwidth-limited and disrupted networks. With approaches in pre-processing, support for limited bandwidth networking, and passive RFID tags for autonomous upload triggering, this architecture will allow for automatic upload in garrison or when forward deployed, and will support real-time presentation of data via a remote dashboard application. Where applicable, cross-domain data diode capability will be used to support transfer of CBM data to other network domains, allowing for communication with secure tactical networks.

award_title: New Condition Based Maintenance and Energy Command and Control Network Architectures for the Naval Expeditionary Force
research_keywords: CBM,HUMS,MANET,DDS,SOA,Energy Command and Control,cross domain,vetronics
abstract: The proposed COndition-based Maintenance and health & usage MOnitoring Network System (COMMONS) addresses the need to provide an effective data collection, analysis, and reporting framework for tactical ground vehicles.  Robust and efficient distributed service provisioning over MANETs requires enhanced support for service advertising, discovery and invocation, due to network dynamics as well as resource constraints of wireless links.  Current service discovery protocols are mainly targeted towards fixed wired infrastructure or relatively stable cellular wireless networks.  Many of these protocols create significant traffic overhead, are not scalable in a wireless environment, rely on central infrastructure, or perform badly when connectivity becomes intermittent.  COMMONS integrates resilient data communication technologies, such as MANET routing. DDS messaging middleware, service oriented architecture (SOA), to provide an autonomous disruptive tolerant mobile communication platform for tactical vehicles.

award_title: Superconductor Sensitive High Dynamic-range Receiver
research_keywords: superconductor,Analog-to-Digital Converter,electronic warfare,Signals intelligence,DIGITAL-RF,Delta ADC,Long-range Communications,over-the-horizon
abstract: Superconductor analog-to-digital converters (ADC) offer discriminating advantages in both bandwidth and fidelity due to very high sampling rates and quantum-accurate digitization based on counting of magnetic flux quanta. Multiple digital-RF receiver systems incorporating superconductor ADCs have been in operation for over four years in field-ready configurations at Government laboratories. We propose to develop heavily oversampled lowpass ADCs to deliver extremely high dynamic range in the low-end of the spectrum (20 MHz). This will be accomplished by simultaneously advancing the quantizer resolution and sample rate using newly available advanced fabrication process nodes. In addition, we propose advanced digital signal processing techniques to further improve signal-to-noise ratio. We have created a detailed roadmap for developing ADCs with increasingly higher performance during Phase I (Base and Option) as well as Phase II. Leveraging the strong design infrastructure developed during the last two years, we propose to complete the first new ADC milestone (design, fabrication, and testing) in Phase I Base itself while developing and simulating detailed circuit models for the next milestone, which will be completed in Phase I Option. Also in Phase I, we will refine the digital post-processing algorithms for the improved ADCs using models and measured data.

award_title: Many Octave, Ultra-Sensitive Low Frequency Receivers
research_keywords: Analog-to-Digital Converter,derivative-sampling,filter-bank,Reconstruction,delta-sigma,superconductor,Semiconductor,high-pass filter
abstract: The proposal aims at developing super-resolution (26-bits) analog-to-digital converters (ADCs) having an instantaneous bandwidth of 20 MHz by using "derivative-sampling" that breaks the Shannon-Nyquist criteria of sampling. Derivative sampling would sample the signal and its higher-order derivatives at sub-Nyquist to achieve larger bandwidth and resolution. The sub-Nyquist samples of the signals and its derivatives would then be digitally processed using digital filter-banks to generate the requisite samples at Nyquist rate. The derivative of the signals will be generated by using various order high-pass filters. Thus to achieve the desired performance the proposal would build high-pass filters and ADCs. The proposal will explore 3 different architectures, viz., 1. Semiconductor high-pass filters and semiconductor ADC, 2. Super-conductor high-pass filters and ADC, and 3. Hybrid, i.e., Superconductor high-pass filters and semiconductor ADC. The best of the three architectures would then be designed, fabricated, and tested in the later phases.

award_title: Augmented Reality Technologies for Training: A Video-See-Through, Helmet Mounted Display
research_keywords: Augmented Reality (AR),Virtul Reality(VR),Heads-up-display (HUD),Helmet-mounted-display (HMD),Trainig,games
abstract: Commercial virtual reality, and video-relay augmented reality head worn displays do not meet the requirements needed to perform Augmented Reality Training of Marines for call-for-fire and close-air-support situations. Trex Enterprises proposes an Augmented Reality Technology Helmet-Mounted Display (ART-HMD), which includes low-cost components combined with low-latency (< 5msec) electronics for data transmission and overlay of computer generated data with stereo camera imagery, an optically enhanced inertial head tracker and a RF-based precision geolocation system, which provides accuracy of 30cm. The ART-HMD includes a display with field of view (FOV) of 100 degrees, two user-removable and user replaceable low-light EO/IR sensors and embedded optically-enhanced inertial head tracker with nominal accuracy of three mils. The device attaches to Marine Corp helmet night vision goggle rails. It has a capacity to transmit its video stream to an external device and to receive and display an externally sourced video stream, and to display its camera imagery overlaid with real time imported imagery. Under the Phase-I program, Trex will define system hardware and software requirements; demonstrate optically enhanced inertial head tracker, design and fabricate a brassboard, demonstrate a low-latency video relay, fabricate and demonstrate low-latency electronics, design a Phase II prototype and develop CAD design package.

award_title: Holographic Enabled Display System for Force-on-Force Marine Training
research_keywords: HMD,Holographic Waveguide
abstract: Creative Microsystems Corporation (CMC) proposes to develop the Holographic Enable Display System (HEDS) for force-on-force Marine training. The system will leverage several CMC technologies, such as the holographic imageguide display and small form factor low light cameras, to produce a high resolution, foveated helmet mounted display for augmented and virtual reality in training exercises. The system will include embedded processing, head tracking and removable low light camera modules. CMC will use adapt its existing technology for head mounted displays and mobile image processing to produce the required performance of a Marine training HMD with wireless connectivity.

award_title: Simulating Training Results to Understand Differing Effects of fidelity on Learning (STRUDEL)
research_keywords: Fidelity,Simulation,Simulators,Sensory cues,Training Systems,Cognitive Modeling
abstract: The Navy uses intelligent tutoring systems (ITSs) coupled with training simulations to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of training for a wide variety of operational tasks. These training simulations require significant cost and effort to develop. Unfortunately, the lack of evidence-based design guidelines for critical decisions such as fidelity leads to simulations that are developed in an ad hoc manner. This practice risks ineffective training at significant expense. Instead, developers need scientifically validated methods and tools for understanding and choosing the optimum level of fidelity for training simulations. To address this issue, this project will design and demonstrate the feasibility of Simulating Training Results to Understand Differing Effects of fidelity on Learning (STRUDEL). STRUDEL includes a model of how simulation fidelity, trainee experience, and task interact to produce different learning outcomes, along with tools to understand how the model applies to existing training problems or training solutions.

award_title: Fidelity Levels for Optimal Training Effectiveness (FLOTE)
research_keywords: Simulator fidelity,Training Effectiveness,Layered Fidelity Framework,Training objectives,Performance Measurement,Objective evaluation,Subject Matter Expert evaluation,Simulator cost-effectiveness
abstract: A critical capability of simulation-based training environments is the degree to which they present a faithful representation of reality. However, there is a scarcity of scientifically-sound tools and methodologies to assess when increased fidelity will lead to better mission effective performance, and thus substantiate associated high costs that often accompany the development of certain simulator features. To address this gap, the Fidelity Levels for Optimal Training Effectiveness (FLOTE) system will be developed to assess the training value of high-cost simulator features that have uncertain or inconclusive expected utility based on subject matter expert (SME) input. As part of the FLOTE system, SME judgments will be fused with more objective data via mini-experiments. The result will be a summary of what is known about the features, including the current levels of uncertainty, such that the decision-makers are better positioned to make smart investments and, therefore, reduce costs while maintaining optimal training for Warfighters.

award_title: Read Out of Single Photon Cryogenic Array Detectors Via Energy Efficient Digital Means
research_keywords: Delta-Sigma ADC,FLASH ADC,Digital-RF Receiver,THz imaging,Data Link
abstract: HYPRES, Inc. manufactures and sells a broadband digital radio receiver system, already present in several US Naval and other military facilities.  This digital receiver is built around a fast superconducting analog-to-digital converter (ADC), which has low noise, low power, broad bandwidth, and high linear dynamic range.  A similar superconductor ADC can be closely integrated with cryogenic sensor arrays (such as microwave kinetic inductance bolometers or MKIDs for single-photon imaging), enabling both reduction in system power and scaling to large imaging arrays.  During Phase I, HYPRES will customize the ADC designs for different MKID array sizes, develop semiconducting and superconducting signal conditioning amplifiers, and simulate system performance.  The first customized ADC will be fabricated and demonstrated in Phase I option. During Phase II, HYPRES will work with an established detector laboratory to integrate the ADC with a system testbed for the MKID array and demonstrate its performance.  Similar ADCs can be applied to digitize other cryogenic sensor outputs for imaging arrays, such as transition edge sensors (TES), superconducting nanowire single-photon detectors (SNSPD), and superconducting tunnel junctions (STJ).

award_title: Advanced Swarm System Interface Software Toolkit (ASSIST)
research_keywords: Swarm systems,human swarm interfaces,mission displays,Human Factors,planning automation
abstract: Advanced supervisory control tools are needed for managing large teams of swarms. To address this need, we will design and demonstrate Advanced Swarm System Interface Software Toolkit (ASSIST) for efficient and effective multi-level awareness and proactive management of swarm systems. ASSISTs rich decision-support interfaces will convey key critical information to enable awareness, projection, and effective control inputs across multiple scales of system resolution and abstraction. First, we will expand prior analyses of swarm operations to characterize operators need for observability and directability of automated planning tools. Second, we will leverage this analysis to design a set of novel interface techniques that enhance the operators situation awareness and projection of swarm system behaviors across multiple perspectives and levels of abstraction. These interfaces will extend common interface methods from real-time-strategy games to address specific swarm system challenges. We will also adapt advanced swarm algorithms to better support the operator in understanding when and how interaction should happen with system entities. Finally, we will extend in-house software tools to rapidly prototype ASSIST swarm supervisory control interfaces. We will use these prototypes to demonstrate and evaluate our approaches and to deeply explore the complexities of supervising swarm systems.

award_title: Human Interaction &amp; Visualization Environment (HIVE) for Swarms
research_keywords: Human-swarm interface,swarming systems,User Interface,collaborative autonomy
abstract: Swarming systems are an emerging technology offering new offensive and defensive capabilities, flexibility, and cost-effectiveness for military and commercial unmanned systems. Swarm communication limitations, emergent behaviors, decentralized control, and control of vehicle groups present challenges for human operators interacting with swarms and for the design of swarm systems and user interfaces. In this SBIR, Pacific Science & Engineering (PSE) is addressing these issues by identifying the key human cognitive and perceptual challenges in swarm operations, and engaging in systematic user interface design to develop a Human Interaction & Visualization Environment (HIVE) for Swarms that specifically mitigates those challenges. The HIVE interfaces will integrate concepts and research from ongoing unmanned vehicle control system interface and autonomy efforts, to leverage relevant work and align with development efforts for transition.

award_title: ISHIS: Interface System for Human Interaction with Swarms
research_keywords: Human Swarm Interaction,visualization,Cognitive engineering,Ecological Interface Design,Delegation,Swarm Behavior Shaping,Conditional Control,Restricted Communications
abstract: SIFT will partner with Katia Sycara and Michael Lewis to develop an Interface System for Human Interaction with Swarms (ISHIS), including a prototype user interface and a simulation and testbed to enable adaptation and experimental validation of its performance in multiple contexts.  Our focus will be on human status awareness and commanding abilities to enable behavior shaping and swarm management for swarms of 100 to 1000 members performing Naval surface and subsurface missions in environments where communications (both human-swarm and intra-swarm) may be severely restricted, information uncertain and where swarm members may be lost.  We will build on previously validated approaches to swarm and multi-UAV control to develop Human-Swarm Interactions (HSIs) to command tunable swarm shaping behaviors, while providing status-conveying interface components and decision aids for the operator to issue these commands in effective ways.  We will also support novel conditional commanding of swarms, which is critical to many militarily useful swarm behaviors. In Phase 1, we will proceed through scenario selection and interaction requirements definition, to HSI design and experimental testbed, hypotheses and methodology definition and will complete a cognitive walkthrough of our proposed design and scenarios illustrating interaction coverage and acceptable performance time for human usability.

award_title: Orientation Independent Refrigerant Phase Separator
research_keywords: Phase separation,Two-Phase Thermal Management,Vortex Separator
abstract: Advanced Cooling Technologies, Inc. (ACT) proposes the development of an orientation independent, momentum-driven vortex separator for use with shipboard two-phase thermal management systems.  This separator will produce sufficient fluid rotational speed to generate a centrifugal acceleration field within the liquid phase that is orders of magnitude higher than gravitational acceleration.  This will allow for a stable liquid-vapor interface within the separation chamber despite changes in the local acceleration environment due to ship roll.  The inlet and separation chamber design will be optimized to produce the necessary centrifugal acceleration field with minimal pressure drop.  In Phase I, a subscale prototype will be fabricated and testing.  Scaling of the Phase I prototype to higher flow rates will be evaluated analytically.

award_title: Gravity-assisted Inertial Phase Separator (GIPS)
research_keywords: TPPA,vortex separation,gravity-assisted separation,Two-Phase,Phase separation,centrifugal separation
abstract: Paragon proposes the Gravity-assisted Inertial Phase Separation (GIPS) concept to meet the Navys need for a robust phase separation technology that operates in the dynamic motion environment of a sea going vessel. This compact concept uses an actively driven two-stage approach to separate liquid out of a mixed phase inlet without introducing any additional pressure drop nor complicated supporting architecture in a two-phase pumped cooling loop. It draws minimal power by harnessing gravity in the first stage and superimposing it with vortex driven inertial forces to separate the bulk of the liquid while guaranteeing a wetted liquid outlet. The second stage employs a mechanical centrifugal action based upon the proven rotary separation technology developed by our implementation partner, Honeywell. The combination of these stages provides a robust, low power, highly reliable phase separation technology that can simplify high performance cooling system design and ensure liquid-only supply to the refrigerant pump.  Paragon brings to this effort its expertise in thermal control systems and two-phase hardware development, and through its partnership with Honeywell a large portfolio of commercial research in two-phase cooling technologies, high reliability sensors, valves, pumps and other hardware fundamental to such systems.

award_title: Compact, Lightweight Shipboard Refrigerant Phase Separator
research_keywords: electronics cooling,Two-Phase Cooling System,Two-Phase Pumped Loop,Liquid-Vapor Phase Separator,Thermal Management
abstract: Two-phase refrigerant pumped-loop systems are a promising approach to efficiently and effectively remove heat from high-power density electronics, sensors, and weapon systems of future warships.  One of the key technical challenges of these new thermal systems is maintaining the flow stability and system reliability under the dynamic motion of a ship.  To address these challenges, we propose to develop a refrigerant liquid-vapor phase separator whose performance is insensitive to roll and the dynamic motion of a ship. The innovative phase separator will help eliminate long two-phase flow transfer lines, enhance the condenser performance and prevent vapor from entering the refrigerant pump, and thus enhance the system reliability.  The phase separator is much more compact and has a much lower total mass and refrigerant holdup than a conventional gravity-assisted phase separator. The proposed phase separator builds on Creares proven gravity-insensitive phase separator technology developed for aircraft vapor compression systems and spacecraft pumped-loop systems.  In Phase I, Creare will design, build, and demonstrate a proof-of-concept phase separator.  In Phase II, Creare will build and characterize a phase separator for a potential 100 kW two-phase pumped loop demonstrator and the deliver phase separator to the Navy for further performance characterization.

award_title: A Software Tool to Aid Informatics Based Material Development for Gas Turbine Engines
research_keywords: data capture,data quality,Material Development,gas turbine,Informatics,ICME
abstract: Informatics-based material development is becoming increasingly important as the physics-based multi-scale methods are not sufficiently matured to correlate complex structure-property-processing relationships for materials with 12-15 components.  However, informatics-based methods require large quantity of good quality material data that are typically downloaded manually from the material databases.  The proposed work in Phase I will initiate development of a software tool-kit that will capture, manage and analyze material property data from material databases.  In Phase I, CFDRC will evaluate the capabilities of existing data scraping software to handle material data and their ability to be integrated with external analysis tools.  We will also develop and verify a code for determining data quality of captured property data from material databases.  The technique will be applied to analyze materials and property data relevant to a specific part of a typical marine gas turbine engine.  In Phase II an API based customizable software tool-kit will be developed that the Integrated Computational Materials Engineering (ICME) community can use to aid material development.

award_title: Computational Tools to Enable Development of Alloys and Coatings for Advanced Gas Turbine Engines
research_keywords: High Entropy Alloys,Superalloys,Integrated computational materials engineering (ICME),CALPHAD,Marine gas turbines,Engine hot section components,oxidation,Uncertainty Quantification (UQ)
abstract: QuesTek Innovations LLC, a leader in the field of Integrated Computational Materials Engineering (ICME), proposes to develop an ICME analysis tools for marine gas turbine engine material optimization. QuesTek will build upon its licensed and previously developed HEA and Ni-based superalloy databases to assess the thermodynamic and kinetic descriptions of hot section materials. Using experimental data from the literature and previous alloy optimization programs, QuesTek will assess the accuracy of these databases and models and quantify their uncertainty. The tool will be developed and applied to HEA and Ni-based superalloy materials, examining processing/structure and structure/properties interactions, including phase stability, processing parameters, resultant microstructures, precipitation growth simulations, and strength models for these alloy systems. Phase II efforts will further develop the tool to enable automatic ICME gap and error detection using additional statistical methods to uncover missing and inaccurate data in ICME models and databases. Other key material properties of turbine materials (e.g. corrosion resistance, CMAS infiltration) will be evaluated Phase II. Successful ICME tools designs will be incorporated into commercial ICME tool packages in Phase III. Rolls Royce Corporation and GE Aviation, two of the worlds leading manufacturers of turbine engines, will provide feedback and guidance on key ICME goals.

award_title: Electrochemical Modeling of Anodic Metal-Rich Primers
research_keywords: Computer-Aided Engineering,galvanic corrosion,electrochemical interactions,metal-rich primer,Composites
abstract: We propose a methodology for modeling and computationally optimizing anodic metal-filled primers using extensions of approaches that we already employ for corrosion analysis.  Modeling will be developed using Star CCM+, a Computer Aided Engineering (CAE) platform from CD-Adapco. We presently use this for corrosion analysis when we need to incorporate computational fluid dynamics to take the variable electrolyte geometry explicitly into account.  The model of the primer will be built using a combination of CAD and image processing software in conjunction with Computational Fluid Dynamics and electrochemical modeling, to explicitly take into account the 3-D geometry, electrochemistry and electrolyte behavior in the resin.  Because Star CCM+ is available to NAVAIR on the DoD Highly Parallel Computing (HPC) Platform, Corrdesa will build models that NAVAIR can modify and use for optimization.  To make the modeling accessible to M&P engineers, Corrdesa will also supply a simplified GUI, and engineering tools based on extensions of Corrosion Djinn and relationships derived from the full CAE model.  In order to fully understand the electrochemistry and the effects of geometry, metal pigment size, primer morphology, etc. we will use a combination of Elsyca CorrosionMaster and modifications and extensions of Corrdesas Corrosion Djinn.

award_title: Development of a Toolkit for Electrochemical Modeling of Metal-rich Primers
research_keywords: Electrochemical modeling,Coatings,metal-rich primers,Al-Mg primers,anodic coatings,cathodic protection
abstract: Corrosion resistant coatings which are based on metal-rich primers are of huge interest to Navy and DoD, since they promise an alternative for the chromium coatings  which are toxic and carcinogenic. The development of such coatings and their application to DoD assets is currently impacted by the lack of fundamental understanding of these coatings and their protection behavior. Under this SBIR, Advanced Cooling Technologies, Inc. (ACT) proposes to develop a physics-based toolkit for electrochemical modeling of the interactions between the material system comprising of the metal-rich primer, substrate surface and the environment. The framework will leverage existing electrochemical models for corrosion chemistry and take into account all the interfaces matrix/particle, primer/substrate, and primer/topcoat. In Phase I, ACT will develop the preliminary framework necessary for capturing the electrochemical interactions and demonstrate sample results for their feasibility. Efforts would be made to match the simulation outcome to measurement data supplied by NAVAIR and open literature.

award_title: Accurate Electrochemical Model for Accelerated Development of Anodic Metal-Rich Primers
research_keywords: Metal-rich,primer,coating,model,Electrochemical,galvanic,Corrosion
abstract: The cost of corrosion for Navy and Marine Corps aircraft is approximately $2.6B per year with the majority of corrosion damage caused by galvanic corrosion.  Traditional chromate primers, in addition to being environmental and health hazards, have not been effective in decreasing the corrosion cost and do not protect from galvanic corrosion.  Recently developed metal-rich primers (MPRs) have been identified as promising replacements for chromate primers with the capacity to protect from galvanic corrosion.  MRPs are highly customizable, however lack of understanding of the effects of the many tunable formulation/particle options on coating properties and corrosion protection has limited their development and use.  An accurate electrochemical and generalizable coating model is needed to enable new and improved protective materials that are less costly to design and faster to transition to market.  Luna proposes to develop a finite element method model in Phase I to focus on the electrochemical interactions of the MRP with a substrate by considering the galvanic throwing power of the MRP.  It will be expanded in Phase II into a comprehensive coating modeling tool for Al-rich and Zn-rich primers that accounts for topcoat effects, degradation with time, defects, and presence of galvanic couples.

award_title: Controllable Metal Additive Manufacturing System
research_keywords: Femtosecond fiber laser,Laser Additive Manufacturing,laser 3D manufacturing,Microstructure,pulsed laser,laser subtractive manufacturing,
abstract: This Navy SBIR Phase I proposal presents an unprecedented laser additive manufacturing system for metal parts with integrated functions of AM & SM and feedforward control, by using a single femtosecond (fs) fiber laser. It provides unique capability in manipulating microstructures to tailor the performance of the parts. It is the enabling technology for manufacturing high strength, high density and high hardness metal components. With our successful history in AM and SM processing, this proposal has a great potential to succeed. A proof of concept demonstration will be carried out and samples will be delivered at the end of Phase 1. Prototypes with various types of components in compliant with the aerospace system requirement will be delivered at the end of Phase II.

award_title: Scalable Adaptive Laser Array for Additive Manufacturing (SALAAM)
research_keywords: Metal Additive Manufacturing,Energy Source,Material Processing,Microstructure,defects,residual stress,fiber-array laser source
abstract: The proposed Scalable Adaptive Laser Array for Additive Manufacturing (SALAAM) concept is based on emerging high-power coherent fiber array and adaptive beam control technologies that have been under development by the Optonicus for DoD (directed energy) applications for almost a decade.  In the SALAAM approach, the multiple beams for LAM are generated in a coherent fiber-collimator array system that is composed of a densely packed array of adaptive fiber-collimators, with integrated capabilities for individual precision beam pointing and steering using Optonicus-developed fiber-tip x-y position control modules.  The proposed SALAAM energy source with multiple laser beams and feedback sensors provides a new breakthrough advanced spatiotemporal control of energy flux for AM in metals.  This development will also provide first transitioning of the DoD high energy laser weapon technology to industrial applications including additive manufacturing and advanced laser material processing with multi-kW class laser systems (dissimilar material joining, welding, cutting, etc.).

award_title: Advanced Micro-Induction Energy Source and Controls for Quality Metal Additive Manufacturing
research_keywords: additive manufacturing,3D Printing,in-process inspection,Non-destructive evaluation,real-time process control for additive,quality control for additive,high-frequency induction heating,
abstract: It is becoming apparent that Additive Manufacturing (AM) systems energy sources have inherent shortcomings that must be overcome to achieve DOD-qualified part fabrication. An ideal AM energy source should have the ability to couple the heating mechanism to the characteristics of the feedstock; it must have in-process inspection capabilities that can track critical parameters; and it must provide feedforward process control capabilities. Micro-Induction Sintering/Melting (MIS/M) is a new additive manufacturing technology developed by Grid Logic that is based on high-frequency induction heating. It permits sintering and melting of metallic powders and wires. The company has demonstrated an ability to tune the MIS/M signal to the characteristics of the feedstock and to achieve a very high degree of heating control. Grid Logic proposes to develop an MIS/M print head operating at multiple frequencies to address the need for an improved AM energy source. This improved AM energy source could significantly improve consolidation efficiency, provide thermal gradient and temperature control. It would include both inspection and closed-loop process control capabilities needed for quality AM production.

award_title: CoALA: Multi-layered framework for developing and harnessing collective expertise
research_keywords: Crowdsourcing,intelligence analysis,Team Training,Peer assessment,Social Network Analysis,Collaboration platform,Performance Assessment,personalized learning
abstract: The wisdom of the collective is increasingly being regarded as a force that can be harnessed for creative problem solving. Collective expertise has been demonstrated to solve problems that have challenged experts for years. However, current platforms are limited to simple models of task distribution and collaboration. There is little technology support for crowdsourcing complex, collaborative, time-critical problems. The issue of training such large, distributed teams also remains a challenge. This proposal seeks to advance the state of the art with a platform to develop and harness multiple layers of collective expertise for collaborative problem solving. This multilayered approach makes it possible to tap into the skills of a large crowd, while simultaneously providing increased levels of trust and expertise through a layer of community sourcing. This enables a high degree of flexibility in finding the right mix of skills for each problem. The platform addresses the challenges of optimal task allocations, schedule and budget management, and efficient performance assessment. Furthermore, the platform supports an apprentice-based training model where the crowdsourcing mechanism is leveraged to provide personalized learning experiences. Phase I will result in a detailed system design and the development of a proof-of-concept prototype to demonstrate feasibility.

award_title: System for Group Learning and Optimization of Collaborative Workflows (GLOW)
research_keywords: Rapid training,team management/optimization,Adaptive learning,collective expertise,Decision-making,assessment and evaluation,PROBABILISTIC PROGRAMMING,Market-based optimization
abstract: The Navy must train and deploy effective teams in a variety of complex domains, from intelligence analysis to field medicine. For example, intelligence analysts preparing the battlespace need a team of experts to interpret a variety of multi-INT sources and incorporate local socio-cultural context, and field medicine often requires a team of doctors skilled in a variety of disciplines. Training individual personnel in all the skills and knowledge required by these missions would be cost-prohibitive and inefficient. Instead, teams are constructed to optimize their collective expertise. To construct these teams, the Navy needs a team development system that manages task and learning assignments to dynamically construct teams with the expertise to achieve evolving mission objectives. To meet this need, we propose to design and demonstrate a system for Group Learning and Optimization of Collaborative Workflows (GLOW). GLOW constructs teams that have the collective expertise required to address complex mission tasks through a combination of dynamic task and personnel ecosystem models, task and learning assignment optimization, and tools for effective team communication and collaboration. Probabilistic predictive models evaluate potential contributors, and a simulated market algorithm distributes tasks and learning assignments to balance personal development and mission requirements.

award_title: Scalable Platform for Collective Online Learning and Development of Collective Expertise
research_keywords: Rapid training,Adaptive learning,collective expertise,Decision-making,assessment and evaluation
abstract: We propose to develop computational models and tools for rapid training and development of collective expertise. We will enhance the currently available online courses offered by NovoEd to develop approaches that automatically optimize the learning ecosystem by considering parameters of content, peer interaction and collaboration, as well as the instructor and mentors to maximize group performance.  Phase I of the project includes computational modeling and design of experiments for studying and optimizing group formation and dynamics in online courses, as well as using peer feedback for increasing incentives for collaboration.

award_title: Low-Temperature Packaging Process for MEMS Fuzes
research_keywords: MEMS packaging,fuzes,wafer bonding
abstract: Miniature munitions fuzes comprising microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) sensors packaged with energetic materials are sought for improving fuze reliability, volume, and cost.  For some munitions, MEMS fuses may reduce unexploded ordnance rates by an order of magnitude and provide space for extra propellant or explosive to increase range or effect.  Creare proposes to develop a wafer-level packaging approach suitable for low-cost, high-volume production of MEMS fuzes.  The approach uses conventional MEMS packaging approaches and equipment where possible to minimize development efforts and cost, but it also necessarily includes developing new low-temperature wafer bonding processes that are safe for energetic materials and sensitive MEMS devices.  In this Phase I project, we will use our preliminary packaging processes and materials concepts to formulate a wafer-level packaging approach for MEMS devices and energetic materials specified in Navy MEMS fuze concepts.  We will model the thermal and strength properties of a baseline package design to show compatibility with energetic materials constraints and package performance requirements and also perform a rudimentary demonstration of a low temperature silicon wafer bonding approach.  In a Phase I Option, we will begin developing wafer layouts for future MEMS fuze package prototypes to be developed, fabricated, and tested in Phase II.

award_title: Trans-wafer laser packaging technology for sensitive MEMS devices
research_keywords: laser bonding,wafer packaging,mid-infrared lasers,low-temperature processing
abstract: The proposed objective of this proposal is to develop and demonstrate a robust, high-throughput laser bonding technique universally applicable to wafer-level joining of silicon with various other materials including silicon, polymers, glasses, ceramics and metals. This unique approach utilizes optical transparency of Si to mid-infrared laser light. Using our patented experimental technique and unique process knowledge in laser-matter interactions, optical energy can be deposited with overall low thermal impact on wafer, and featuring high spatial selectivity by ultra-precise tailoring of spatial and temporal laser characteristics. We will provide numerical models for linear and non-linear light interaction with semiconductors, and heat transfer in multi-layer wafer materials. Experimental studies will provide proof of concept for bonding of Si with Si and other material combinations.

award_title: Smart Weather InstruMentS (SWIMS)
research_keywords: Autonomous Mobile Marine Vehicle,Smart Meteorological Station,Autonomous Surface Vehicle
abstract: The US Department of the Navy (DoN) is developing ocean environment sampling systems, which can operate autonomously for a long period of time sending real-time in-situ data without the help of an expensive dedicated ship. Ocean sampling systems should be able to measure environmental parameters such as, pressure, temperature, humidity, wind speed, and wind direction at the air-sea boundary layer for accurate weather forecasts and climate predictions. We propose Smart Weather InstruMentS (SWIMS) system to measure environmental parameters at the ocean surface as well as in the stable atmospheric layer at the air-sea interface. SWIMS is an autonomous mobile surface buoy and tethered blimp for atmospheric measurements. A novel wave generated jet propulsion system propels the SWIMS buoy system. An automated winch system inside the surface buoy will deploy the airborne meteorological sensor platform.   We will transmit all the geo-registered meteorological data to a ground station via a satellite communication link. SWIMS uses a Behavior based autonomy software architecture onboard the surface buoy platform. We will use re-chargeable batteries with the help of solar panels to power the system for a long period of time.

award_title: Autonomous Mobile Marine Meteorological Station
research_keywords: Atmospheric Boundary Layer,Autonomous Surface Vehicle,radiosonde measurements,atmospheric flux,Microclimate,sea surface exchange,Evaporative duct,near-surface meteorology
abstract: Aret Associates proposes developing a non-expendable solution to solve the challenge of autonomously measuring the atmospheric boundary layer. Arets reusable atmospheric profiler (RAP) combines elements of kite, unmanned aerial systems, and oceanographic launch and recovery techniques to measures temperature, pressure, humidity, wind speed and direction, and aerosol concentration from a few meters to 1000 meters above the ocean surface. In combination with a commercial unmanned surface vehicle as a base station, Arets unique RAP design comprises an Autonomous Mobile Marine Met Station (AM3S) system. The resulting AM3S system is designed for routine and directed measurements of the marine ABL providing an autonomous sampling capability similar to ocean buoys, floats, and gliders. Its measurements are suitable for atmospheric flux calculations using bulk formulations as well as Monin-Obukhov similarity theory (MOST) based profile methods.

award_title: Mobile Marine Meteorological Measurement System
research_keywords: Unmanned surface vessel,unmanned air vehicle,unmanned air system,air-sea interaction,Meteorological,atmosphere,weather,Sonde
abstract: An autonomous air-sea interaction measurement system is needed to support data collection for the DoDs naval operations.  Timely and accurate characterization of the air-sea interaction is needed to improve DoD operational capabilities.  Air-sea interactions are important inputs for weather forecasting, understanding electro-optical propagation, and predicting the operation of ballistic weapons such as the EM railgun over water targets.  Current air-sea interaction data are sparse since they are typically obtained from sensor packages on passing ships.  Further, existing profiling systems are not well suited for autonomous deployment due to size, power, and cost.  We propose a marine drone-sonde system that is accurate, compact, covert, easy to deploy, and capable of operating autonomously for months at a time.  The marine drone-sonde system comprises a commercially available unmanned surface vessel (USV) and Creares small multi-rotor drone that supports a suite of compact atmospheric sensors.  In Phase I, we will demonstrate the feasibility of our proposed approach through design, analysis, and testing of critical system components.  In Phase II, we will develop, test, and validate a prototype of the system and demonstrate its performance and value in a field test.

award_title: Cryogenic Cooling to Reduce Antenna Size for Multi-band Satellite Antenna Applications
research_keywords: Cryogenic LNA,Multi-Band Antenna,composite antenna,SATCOM
abstract: As a figure of merit for the receive performance of an antenna and receiver system, Gain over Temperature (G/T) drives the signal to noise performance of the communications system. In order to decrease antenna size and maintain G/T, the T term, which is the system noise temperature, must be lowered. We propose to study the feasibility of installing a C-band cryogenic cooled LNA with improved noise performance. We will concept a new, smaller antenna and define the weight savings realized with a smaller antenna and radome. If awarded the Phase I option, we will develop concept antenna pedestal designs with the optimal blend of composite and metal structures. The final size and weight budget will be used to develop concepts for alternate placement of the new multi-band antennas on the targeted ship class superstructures, out of the downwash zones of our latest naval aircraft.

award_title: Wideband Communications Enabled Through Shipboard Troposcatter
research_keywords: NLOS,CBSP,Shipboard communications,BLOS,NMT,A2AD,TROPOSCATTER,C-band
abstract: To address the Navys need for a shipboard troposcatter system, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a new Wideband Communications Enabled Through Shipboard Troposcatter (WEST) system. WEST is based on state-of-the-art tropospheric RF propagation analysis and hardware-accelerated algorithms to control the existing shipboard CBSP C-band antenna and modem. Specifically, the innovation in the WEST system design will compensate for ship-to-ship motion dynamics in sea states up to at least World Meteorological Organization (WMO) level 5 (rough). As a result, WEST offers up to 100 Mbps throughput at bit error rate of 10^-5 or better, and directly addresses the PMW/A-170 requirements for reuse of existing Commercial Broadband Satellite Program (CBSP) and commercial-off-the-shelf troposcatter modem systems. In Phase I, POC will determine the technical feasibility of the WEST troposcatter control algorithms to increase communications capability for shipboard application reaching technology readiness level (TRL) 4. In Phase II, POC plans to develop, demonstrate and validate a WEST prototype which can maintain at least 10 Mbps throughput. By the end of Phase II, the WEST technology will reach TRL-5-6 and be ready for initial testing for potential transition to Navy Multiband Terminal (NMT) and the Wideband Antijam Modem System (WAMS).

award_title: Electromagnetic Inspection System for Rapid Quantification of Pyrrhotite in Concrete Aggregate
research_keywords: pyrrhotite,Sensor,oxidation,sulfate,aggregate,Concrete,Sulfide
abstract: The presence of the minerals pyrrhotite in concrete aggregate can reduce the structural integrity and life expectancy of a concrete structure by as much as 90%. In Canada and the Northeast U.S., pyrrhotite-rich aggregate has had a devastating effect on the housing sector, causing approximately $1 billion in damages in the past decades. As a large consumer of concrete for a multitude of construction and repair jobs around the world, the U.S. Navy may face significant costs associated with pyrrhotite related concrete corrosion. To minimize facilities maintenance and sustainment costs, there is a need for a method for detecting and quantifying the presence of pyrrhotite in source aggregate and formed structures to assess existing structural integrity and prevent pyritiferous aggregate from ever being used. Existing diagnostic methods must be carried out in a lab, are overly expensive, and highly time consuming. To meet the needs of the Navy, Luna will develop a portable, compact, robust, electromagnetic sensing system capable of providing rapid, near real-time diagnostics of pyrrhotite concentration in aggregate and formed concrete structures in harsh, field environments.

award_title: Novel Pyrrhotite Detection Method in Concrete Aggregate
research_keywords: Compact Sensor,Spectral Analysis,Spectrometer,In-situ Concrete Analysis,Pyrrhotite Sensing,spectroscopy
abstract: We propose to study and develop laser-based detection techniques, which will result in creation of a hand-held portable measurement system for the rapid detection of pyrrhotite in raw aggregate and hardened concrete in the field. Spectral characterization of pyrrhotite and related and associated minerals will be performed, and algorithms developed which process the data to provide high sensitivity detection and concentration analysis of pyrrhotite in aggregate samples. The detected chemical fingerprint of the various mineral species will be used to identify species. A conceptual model for a ruggedized, small, field ready instrument that utilizes these techniques will be described. As an option, that system will be designed in detail in preparation for a preliminary design review, prior to construction of a breadboard system for in-situ testing in Phase 2.

award_title: Novel Pyrrhotite Detection Method in Concrete Aggregate
research_keywords: Nondestructive Testing,aggregate,NMR relaxometry,Pyrrhotite detection,concrete deterioration
abstract: Pyrrhotite is an iron sulfide mineral found in diverse rock types. Its presence in the aggregate used for concrete construction can produce damaging effects associated with oxidation of pyrrhotite in the presence of water and oxygen. Available methods of detecting pyrrhotite do not suit routine field applications. This project will develop a portable test system based on NMR relaxometry principles for nondestructive field detection of pyrrhotite in aggregate and concrete. NMR relaxometry provides information on the physico-chemical environment within solids with different pore system characteristics. Background studies of soil and the work on aggregate and concrete conducted in the course of preparing this proposal have demonstrated that the presence of pyrrhotite produces distinct and quantifiable effects on the NMR relaxation parameters. The proposed Phase I project will tailor the design and operation conditions of a portable NMR to suit the targeted application. A systematic experimental program will be planned and implemented in order to devise a test protocol and data analysis procedures for accurate and reliable detection and quantification of pyrrhotite in aggregate and concrete. The results will be used to assess the potential of the approach to meet the targeted requirements of the development effort.

award_title: Analysis Tools for Managing Commercial Off-The-Shelf (COTS) Obsolescence
research_keywords: obsolescence monitoring,AUTOMATED ANALYSIS,Ontology,CANES,inference,Predictive
abstract: Performing reactive, run to obsolescence based end of life remediation and risk mitigation is expensive and difficult to perform given the restrictions of ship deployment schedules and available funding. Significant risk to ship capability and safety is further ensued when obsolescence is reached while equipment is at sea and unavailable for upgrade. The government has defined common practices to mitigate those risks while lowering the overall total cost of ownership. Activities such as parts list monitoring and screening can minimize risk by consistently cross checking ship equipment configurations against Government Industry Data Exchange Program discontinuance notifications. These practices, as well as the others defined within the ARINC 2000, are presently not automated by technology and require significant effort by personnel to implement. These processes can be automated through an open source solution which performs automatic software-based analysis of the remaining life cycle of shipboard equipment, tracking of COTS obsolescence, creation of mitigation and compatibility solution planning, and visualization of what if analysis business decision analysis. Our approach will perform this assessment through the integration of four innovative techniques for accomplishing data collection, data storage, automated software learning techniques, and web server generated analysis presentation.

award_title: Large Aperture Multi-Wavelength 360 Degree Single Pixel Camera with Compressive Sensing Using Integrated Sparse Image Target Detection and Classificat
research_keywords: sparse,classification,detection,compressive,Representation,sampling,Compressed,sensing
abstract: Multispectral long range imaging with detection and classification can satisfy the requirement for this topic. Conventional approaches using this method have required expensive, bulky optics, and computer resources that were greedy in speed and memory and power. Recent advances is compressive sensing and compressive processing have resulted in the ability to use the inherent ability of compressive detectors to under-sample to great advantage to reducing detector bulk, cost and data processing. In this proposal the simplicity of the single pixel imaging camera is exploited to provide a simple and robust multispectral operation directly on the compressed data through compressive processing. This results in not only a simple multi-spectral camera design, but also highly optimized compressive detection and classification techniques can be used directly on the compressed data set. It proposed that Busek design a single pixel camera that has the ability to image passively in the visible, NIR, and Far IR wavelength. It is also to perform as a ranging camera in the near IR using LIDAR. The system proposed by Busek will result simpler yet more effective method of passive target identification and classification using these techniques.

award_title: Hiawatha Shipboard Long Range Detection and Identification System
research_keywords: Target imaging and identification,Non-RF emitting targets,unintended emissions,Dark targets,Passive targets,digital signal processing,RF Sensor
abstract: Nokomis will use its Hiawatha detection system to provide robust and ruggedized identification and tracking capability for water- and air-borne targets of interest. The Hiawatha System utilizes an ultra-sensitive RF sensor to detect, identify, and track electronic targets by monitoring and leveraging their RF emissions including non-intended RF emissions from so-called dark targets. Previous Nokomis work has demonstrated highly accurate detection, identification, and geo-location of electronic targets from vehicle and airborne platforms, including unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and unmanned underwater vehicles (UUVs) at ranges up to 15 km by leveraging unintended RF emissions. Targets of interest to this application include small watercraft, Unmanned Arial Vehicles (UAV), and the proliferating variety of small form factor autonomous systems all which provide small boresight targets for detection. The proliferation of electronic systems onboard these types of targets, however, make them excellent candidates for detection through unintended RF emissions. Most automatically steered or autonomous targets utilize GPS information to navigate, and while not active RF emissions, the GPS connection and associated system electronics provide an electronic signature that Hiawatha can detect.

award_title: Curved (Convex) Surface Global Positioning System (GPS) Antenna Design for Submarine Launched Ballistic Missile (SLBM) Trident D5 Flight Test Reentry
research_keywords: antenna,frpa,Trident II,GPS,CRPA,reentry,ballistic missile,circular error probability
abstract: Current Navy reentry flight test bodies use a commercial GPS antenna to demonstrate the capability to capture GPS data during flight. These are not integrated in a manner representative of the actual reentry body. Development of GPS antennas that may be incorporated onto tactical Navy reentry platforms, such as the Trident II D5 will result in an additional navigation system and improved guidance. FIRST RF proposes the integration of a GPS antenna for incorporation on the curved aft closure of the Trident II D5 reentry body. The antenna will be compatible with the integration requirements and environments, while still providing good sky coverage and efficient operation for satellite signal reception. The antenna will incorporate innovative material science and robust mechanical packaging techniques to enable compatibility with the thermal and vibration environments on board the Trident II D5. The FIRST RF solution is applicable to a variety of reentry and hypersonic platforms.

award_title: Rounded Convex Curved Conformal Low-Profile GPS CRPA (1000-393)
research_keywords: conformal antenna,GPS CRPA,reentry vehicle,Trident,dual-band antenna,additive manufacturing,Direct Write,low-profile antenna
abstract: SI2 Technologies, Inc. (SI2) will enable more accurate trajectory GPS data to be measured on Trident II D5 flight test reentry bodies with our innovative convex , conformal, dual-band GPS antenna CRPA. The conformal GPS CRPA will be integrated with the convex curved aft closure plate on the flight test reentry bodies. The proposed aperture is based on SI2s novel conformal GPS antenna architectures and proven additive manufacturing techniques. Our proposed solution uses conformal apertures to meet the platform requirements.In the PH I Base, SI2 will simulate and optimize planar GPS aperture performance. We will also simulate the performance of a conformal version of the aperture and develop a manufacturing plan for the conformal GPS aperture technology. SI2 will validate the electromagnetic design and additive manufacturing approach via fabrication and test of planar (base) and conformal (option) proof of concept hardware demonstrators to demonstrate TRL 4 at the conclusion of the PH I program. In PH II, we will refine and optimize performance of the conformal dual-band aperture and will also work to integrate it with the GPS receiver electronics to develop a full system solution.

award_title: Curved (Convex) Surface Global Positioning System (GPS) Antenna Design for Submarine Launched Ballistic Missile (SLBM) Trident D5 Flight Test Reentry
research_keywords: GPS,antenna,Thermal Protection System
abstract: IERUS Technologies proposes to leverage our existing re-entry vehicle antenna technology to develop a high performance, dual-band GPS antenna for the Navy ENTB vehicle and, in the future, the JTA and CPGS programs. IERUS's existing design was developed with re-entry vehicles in mind and covers the full GNSS band, which satisfies the bandwidth requirements for the C/A and P(Y) codes at L1 and L2. On a related program, IERUS has developed re-entry vehicle antennas directly utilizing the vehicle's own thermal protection system (TPS) as a radome to include performance through hot and cold environments and in the presence of the post-reentry char layer. As applicable, this design approach will be incorporated into the GNSS design suitably modified for installation and operation on the curved aft closure plate of the vehicle.
