IERUS will perform design to include full-scale vehicle modeling to assess gain coverage and phase ripple, addressing requirements solidified post-award. During Phase 1, IERUS will also fabricate and perform VSWR and pattern testing on prototype elements, mitigating risk early in the program.

award_title: Curved (Convex) Surface Global Positioning System (GPS) Antenna Design for Submarine Launched Ballistic Missile (SLBM) Trident D5 Flight Test Reentry
research_keywords: Anti-Jam (AJ),Plasma,reentry body,Conformal,Navigation,Missile Defense,Antenna array,Global Positioning System (GPS)
abstract: Capturing GPS data during reentry flight tests will reduce the effort required to recreate a trajectory after flight. In order to test a more representative reentry body, an antenna will be designed that accounts for a rounded aft surface. Toyon Research Corporation proposes designing a conformal antenna that operates at L1/L2 GPS frequencies with sufficient bandwidth to support military codes. The antenna gain pattern will be customized to maximize the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of the GPS signal in the presence of plasma. Maximum SNR will be achieved by optimizing the antenna pattern in such a way as to increase the available GPS signal while decreasing reflections from the plasma. Design challenges will include accounting for antenna-to-plasma interactions and changing material properties due to high reentry temperatures. Toyon will also develop specialized GPS acquisition and tracking algorithms for an advanced receiver that will provide capabilities that are not currently available to military and civilian systems. Toyons team has direct experience with designing and building flight-qualified antennas, GPS receivers, navigation algorithms, and reentry bodies and systems.

award_title: Beyond Line of Sight (BLOS) High Data Rate Communications
research_keywords: omnidirectional coverage,TCDL,Low Cost Array,UAV,Networking,Man-Portable Array,BLOS Communications
abstract: In this Phase I effort, FIRST RF will develop and evaluate concepts enabling Beyond Line of Sight (BLOS) communications using field deployable multi-band antenna arrays. The novel multi-band array topology allows for a compact and light weight system to be fielded that operates over S-Band, C-Band, and Ku-Band, has a 360 field of regard in azimuth, and can maintain a 20 Mb/s data link over each band at distances up to 70 nmi for longer than 8 hours continuously at Ku-Band and 23 hours at S-/C-Band. Low weight is maintained by fielding a passive aperture with a wide elevation pattern which allows for a ground-to-air relay allowing the system to operate in SATCOM-denied environments. The antenna system also has the benefit of a narrow azimuth radiation pattern conducive to point-to-point communications and networking waveforms minimizing the probability of intercept. The system is designed to be radio agnostic, allowing for a variety of commercial and military-grade radios to be integrated with the antenna system allowing for future-proof compatibility with the advanced transceivers currently under development. FIRST RF proposes an innovative approach that leverages innovative array architecture to provide a frequency-diverse communications node that uses airborne relays to facilitate BLOS communications.

award_title: Beyond Line of Sight Mesh Networking (BLOSMNET)
research_keywords: AN/PRC-117G,Communications,ship-to-shore,beyond line of sight,high data rate
abstract: The United States Navy (and Armed forces in general) currently uses radios such as AN/PRC-150 and AN/PRC-117G to provide beyond line of sight (BLOS) communications capabilities to the ships and other vehicles. These radios use high frequency communications and satellite communications to provide beyond line of sight communications. These essential links supplement line of sight communication radios and provide low data rate links. With increasing need for situational awareness and reconnaissance, high data rate communications are essential (e.g., high-def and low-def imagery and video link between unmanned surface vehicles (and remote multi-mission vehicles) and littoral combat ships to support mine-countermeasure operations).

award_title: Anti-jam Network for High-throughput Communications Over-the-horizon using Relays (ANHCOR)
research_keywords: BLOS Communications,MANET,anti-jam,MIMO,dynamic spectrum access
abstract: Ship-to-shore communications in contested environments call for robust links that can achieve high data rates at beyond-line-of-sight (BLOS) ranges in the presence of jamming attacks. Silvus proposes to develop an Anti-jam Mobile Ad-hoc Network (MANET) by leveraging its high-throughput MANET and research portfolio in MIMO interference suppression and dynamic spectrum access technology. MANETs provide the flexibility to relay data through any radio in the network, enabling BLOS ranges that can scale according to the mission requirements. The proposed ANHCOR prototype is targeted at unmanned aerial, surface and ground vehicles as relays; the requisite low Size Weight and Power (SWaP) will be achieved by leveraging Silvus UAV-proven Streamcaster radio platform.

award_title: Intranasal Cooling for Encephalopathy Prevention (ICEP)
research_keywords: Transnasal cooling,CoolStat,Brain Cooling,Transnasal
abstract: This work will validate a new method to quickly and safely cool the brain and body in a combat setting to help those with traumatic brain injury (TBI). Cooling the brain reduces edema (swelling), which has been shown to improve survival rates and brain function. Current techniques that try to provide early cooling for TBI are impractical in the combat setting, have potential safety risks or they are not effective in cooling. We are currently developing a device for use in a commercial hospital environment for treating fever and cooling post-ischemic events, such as cardiac arrest. This simple device uses no active chemicals or other potentially harmful materials. We believe that it can be modified such that it can be used in a combat setting, at the event site. We will demonstrate the safety and cooling efficacy of our existing device in a pig study. We will also examine the commercial device to assess the level of effort to harden it for use in a combat setting.

award_title: ICEPICC- Intranasal Cooler for Encephalopathy Prevention in Combat Casualties
research_keywords: intracranial edema,neurotrauma,cryogenic therapy,therapeutic normothermia,encephalopathy,nasopharyngeal cooling,Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI),prophylactic hypothermia.
abstract: DoD personnel are at increased risk of traumatic brain injury (TBI) in both wartime and peacetime training incidents. Post-injury swelling (edema) is a common physiological complication of TBI which can result in added physical damage to the brain, increasing the risk of mortality, chronic encephalopathy (brain damage), and long term disability in personnel suffering TBI. Studies have demonstrated that rapidly lowering brain temperature can reduce the incidence and severity of intracranial edema as well as mortality and complications during treatment and recovery. Several approaches for achieving cooling have been successfully demonstrated in human and animal studies, but few options currently are on the market and none of these technologies are particularly well suited for military implementation. To fill this operational gap, Vivonics is proposing to develop ICEPICC (Intranasal Cooler for Encephalopathy Prevention In Combat Casualties), an intranasal cooling system based on forced cold-air convection, which is simple and well suited to the military environment because it is easily operated and supported in a wide range of settings and has shown to provide effective cooling.

award_title: Intranasal Cooling for Encephalopathy Prevention (ICEP)
research_keywords: medical sensing,Closed Loop Control,Intracranial Pressure (ICP),Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI),Android,device,wireless connectivity,Perfluorocarbon (PFC)
abstract: Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) is the signature injury of current conflicts accounting for approximately 20-25% combat casualties. Commercially, it is the primary cause of worldwide morbimortality in people under 45 years old. In the USA, TBI is estimated to be 1.5 million cases annually, resulting in over 50,000 deaths which is similar to European numbers. Today, a specific prehospital treatment remains lacking and clear clinical strategy is controversial. Cell damage is not only produced by the initial trauma itself but by a series of resultant pathophysiological mechanisms that are initiated almost immediately and perpetuate the damage caused by the initial trauma.This effort will design a hypothermic delivery system which includes nasopharyngeal PFC cooling with closed loop control in a lightweight, mobile package for first responders. Closed loop control will be based on non-invasive vital signs measurements. Technology today presents innovative methods to obtain a variety of efficacy measures available including heart rate complexity, cardiac output, EEG, EEG, r-SO2 and dynamic trending of state assessment. Connectivity between current USN/Marine wearable medical sensing platforms and a novel therapy for TBI suggest a pre-hospital solution specifically for the POI environment.

award_title: Intranasal Cooling for Encephalopathy Prevention (ICEP)
research_keywords: Traumatic Brain Injury,neurotrauma,cryogenic therapy,Therapeutic Hyperthermia,intracranial edema,neurorecovery,nasopharyngeal cooling,encephalopathy,Cryogenics
abstract: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a growing issue on the modern battlefield as well as training facilities. The brain experiences damage, inflammation, and termination of cell functions when a patient has a TBI. Infection, usually accompanied by an increase in temperature, can exacerbate the after-effects. Studies have shown that cerebroprotection such as quickly cooling the brain can reduce long term effects of brain trauma. The key to therapeutic hypothermia is in the ability to reduce the brains temperature while maintaining a normal 37C in the extremities and core. Often times these injuries are a result of a blast or in conjunction with other peripheral injuries, and the body must maintain its temperature to repair elsewhere. Wolf has conceptualized a non-invasive, therapeutic, neuroprotective solution that can quickly cool the brain temperature while actively monitoring the patients core temperature and thereby regulating the device. The concept is lightweight, portable, and adaptable to all patient sizes and body types. Wolfs cryogenic intranasal cooler utilizes proven chilling technology and readily available materials to maintain a low end user cost. The device is modular and components will be easily field serviced if damaged.

award_title: Driver Performance Monitoring through Electronic Trip Tickets
research_keywords: Android applications,vehicular data,Database,Performance Monitoring.,Training,driver analysis,ground vehicles
abstract: Research Proposed: Research is proposed to develop an innovative system for capture, storage and analysis of vehicular data from which driver proficiency metrics can be extracted, for the purpose of identifying aptitude and deficient performance. This novel approach will allow for seamless integration into numerous tactical vehicles, and provide an intuitive, actionable analysis user interface for rapid assessment by the Motor Transport Officer or Commander.Problem Statement: While airborne platforms can ensure pilot experience through mission-specific simulation hours, Marine Corps tactical vehicle drivers have often not been trained and certified by the Motor Transport School. As a result, drivers can be deployed with insufficient training, leading to a higher risk of accidents.Plan/Process Outline: Using Commercial off the Shelf components, a vehicle-agnostic system will be designed for real-time capture and storage of vehicular data, along with integral location, acceleration, velocity and temporal data. This system will support analysis and correlation of captured data, as well as other mission-specific and situational data, in a graphical, actionable format, with support for export to alternate systems for data sharing across the Department of Defense. A standards-based, open XML format will be used for data storage, leading to increased sharing across agencies.

award_title: Driver Performance Monitoring through Electronic Trip Tickets
research_keywords: SAE J1939,Driver Safety,Condition-based maintenance,Fuel conservation,Driver performance monitoring,trip tickets,TACTICAL VEHICLES
abstract: Thousands of DoD personnel drive US Government vehicles each day. Their driving behavior has direct impact on fuel costs, maintenance costs and most importantly, human safety. Reducing costs and avoiding mishaps depends, therefore, upon the governments ability to effectively train drivers, monitor their driving behavior, and identify drivers in need of remedial training. Currently, the Marine Corps has limited means to assess the capability or experience level of an individual to operate ground tactical or commercial vehicles.Fortunately, modern vehicles contain sophisticated Electronic Control Units (ECU) with accessible bus interfaces. These interfaces produce data that can be used, with appropriate algorithms, to assess driver behavior, fuel consumption, and maintenance needs. In addition, access to location (via GPS chipsets) and motion dynamics (via 3-axis accelerometers) is available at low cost through ubiquitous tablet, cell phone devices, and related chipsets. Location information and motion dynamics can be fused with ECU-provided information to provide even more accurate assessments.

award_title: Driver Performance Monitoring Through Electronic Trip Tickets
research_keywords: Driver Safety,Driver performance monitoring,Electronic Trip Tickets,Vehicle Accident Reduction
abstract: Phase I will complete a study & analysis of fielding a Driver Performance Monitoring capability where vehicle and driver performance data is collected, stored, and analyzed on ~20 mobile devices, with data synchronizing to a common Command workstation for full analysis with a simple user interface by the Motor Transport Officer or Commander. Indicators of deficient performance would lead to focused remediation to improve skills in a driver simulator with the goal of reducing accidents to prevent personal injury and equipment damage.

award_title: Electronic Ticket Reporting Individual Performance System (E-TRIP) for Tactical Vehicles
research_keywords: Performance assessment algorithms,E-TRIP,Android Devices,SAE J1939,Driver performance monitoring,TACTICAL VEHICLES,CAN Data Logger
abstract: Ground tactical vehicle mishaps resulted in damaged or destroyed government property, huge cost in medical treatment, deaths, and permanent disabilities of the personnel involved. Efficient monitoring operators driving skill and performance on ground tactical vehicles becomes critical to the safety and effectiveness of military vehicle training and operations. We propose to leverage miniature Commercial-Off-The-Shelf (COTS) electronics devices such as a Controller Area Network (CAN) data logger/streamer and a low cost Android tablet/smartphone with GPS and accelerometer sensors, to record the naturalistic driving data during the trip, report the data to a computer server, and automatically detect critical incident events or risky driving behaviors for driver performance assessment. This system will enable a simple point and click query or filtering by the Motor Transport Officer or Commander to identify fully qualified or deficient drivers for mission operation or training purpose. Phase I program is to demonstrate the feasibility of the E-TRIP approach through laboratory and vehicle tests. In Phase II, we will develop the prototype E-TRIP system, and validating the system performance through large scale fielded vehicle tests.

award_title: Reconfigurable Flexible and Expandable Display System
research_keywords: electrophoretic display,sunlight readability,OLED display,Flexible Display,touchscreen
abstract: To address the USMCs need for a collapsible electronic paper technology acting as a plug-in screen to a laptop device, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a new Reconfigurable Flexible and Expandable (REFLEX) Display system based on a novel hybrid integration of flexible EPD and OLED display with smart-display features such as glove-friendly touch interaction, battery power management, and POCs core expertise in military-qualified display systems. Specifically, the innovations in hybrid tiled EPD and auxiliary OLED support the collapsible form-factor and built-in processor for disconnected operation. As a result, REFLEX offers sunlight and low-light readability, enabling Marine Maintainers to view schematic diagrams, drawings, etc. at the point of maintenance, and to access full-motion video through standard interfaces including USB, VGA, and HDMIall while complying with MIL-STD-810, which directly address the USMC requirements. In Phase I, POC plans to develop and demonstrate the feasibility of REFLEX concept through material testing and modeling, leading to a prototype. In Phase II, POC will fabricate and test up to three prototype systems based on Phase I results and assess prototype capabilities to meet USMC requirements, proceeding directly to Phase III transition with low-rate initial production of evaluation devices and follow-on acquisition strategy.

award_title: Collapsible Electronic Paper Display
research_keywords: tiled display,foldable display,e-paper
abstract: Marines Maintainers using the Electronic Maintenance Support System (EMSS) to perform logistical support are currently constrained to the small liquid crystal display (LCD), which is ruggedized Panasonic CF-19 Toughbook known as the electronic maintenance device (EMD). Though it is very useful, the human factors of reading schematics optimized for presentation on paper sizes up to 22 in x 34 in (ANSI D Standard paper size) can be extremely challenging, leading to eye strain, mental fatigue, and cognitive impairment. This can result in an increase of errors, delay of completing their tasks, and/or possible occurrences of injuries due to human factor shortcomings. Creative Microsystems Corporation (CMC) proposes to develop a large, foldable display based on existing display and interface technologies. The effort will leverage existing displays and technology along with CMC's proven abilities to adapt off-the-shelf components for compact, multi-component and mobile displays systems.

award_title: Deep Learning for Clutter Reduction in Multi-static Coherent Active Sonar Systems
research_keywords: Multi-Static Sonar,Deep Learning,Bayesian estimation
abstract: Enhanced contact screening for MAC missions will be accomplished by adapting deep learning techniques developed by researchers for image processing to perform pattern recognition on the Bayesian target state estimator for MAC. The state estimate, a probability mass function encapsulating the existence of a target and its potential position and velocity, contains 225,000 data points for every ping. This information will serve as the input for a deep convolutional neural network which will label regions of the field as target, bottom clutter, ephemeral clutter, or empty. This labeled map will be used to reduce clutter by improving snippet scores, and increasing the speed with which persistent clutter is identified by MAC. Other improvements include an enhanced operator display and better ping control algorithms. Anticipated Benefits/Commercialization: clutter suppression, enhanced operator displays, improved ping control for Multistatic sonar with applications to image, speech and hyperspectral data.

award_title: Learned Approach to Sonar Signal Interpretation and Evaluation (LASSIE)
research_keywords: MIMO sonar,signal processing,Clutter Reduction,ASW,Deep Learning,Multi-static,target discrimination
abstract: Charles River Analytics proposes to design and demonstrate a Learned Approach to Sonar Signal Interpretation and Evaluation (LASSIE), a research program to compare the effectiveness of different types of deep learning (DL) in solving the problem of clutter reduction in MIMO sonar and to design an improved signal processing chain which is uniquely adapted for deep learning. LASSIE employs advanced probabilistic models to featurize and train deep neural networks. By combining a recurrent neural network with deep generative models, it is possible to discover representative probability distributions for non-target objects and thereby reject input which is non-conforming. The use of a generative model also has the advantage that novel environmental conditions can be discovered and trained without the need for experimental data collected in the field. Our approach includes echo synchronization and geolocation as well as a combination of unsupervised and supervised learning strategies for target detection.

award_title: Visionary Detection and Clutter Reduction
research_keywords: Deep Learning,Clutter Reduction,Multi-static,Active sonar
abstract: In this project, Daniel H. Wagner, Associates will reduce clutter in multi-static coherent active sonar by exploiting relationships between sonar detection and image processing to create the Visionary Detection and Clutter Reduction (VDCR) System. We will use Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) to replace the parts of a baseline signal processing chain which currently produce excessive clutter while retaining physics-based components which facilitate detection. Our use of DNNs will include matching of spectrograms representing sonar returns to spectrograms representing targets or clutter. We will also reduce bottom clutter by using DNNs to infer target depth. The ability to of DNNs to represent arbitrary continuous functions will be exploited to improve the normalization and thresholding of detection statistics.

award_title: Deep-Sonar: Spatial-Temporal Deep Learning for Sonar Systems
research_keywords: Multi-static Active Coherent (MAC) sonar system,Deep Learning,semi-supervised learning,Multiple Input Multiple Output (MIMO),Clutter Reduction,Unsupervised Learning,underwater communications
abstract: Air-deployed wide-area search sonar systems are widely adopted for military, scientific research, and civilian services. In the MAC sonar system, while MIMO increases data rate relative to SIMO, the clutter effect also increases and transfers from one mission environment to another. To address the critical need, Intelligent Automation Inc. (IAI) proposes the design and implementation of the Deep-Sonar system, which provides an unsupervised/semi-supervised spatial-temporal deep learning solution for the MAC sonar system. The Deep-Sonar system will provide a high-accuracy solution on analyzing MIMO sonar data in a flexible setting to identify targets in different (shallow or deep water) environments. We will prototype the proposed algorithmic workflow of Deep-Sonar and test it with representative scenarios in IAIs Ontology-based, Distributed, Composable Simulator that has been developed for Navy. We will demonstrate the feasibility of Deep-Sonar by evaluating its performance under realistic underwater scenarios with respect to different Tx/Rx configurations and clutter levels. Deep-Sonar will reduce the clutter from each ping by at least 25% by application of semi-supervised and unsupervised spatial-temporal deep learning to MIMO sonar data that will reduce the number of clutter events for 4 transmitters to 1 transmitter level.

award_title: Zero-HERO Inductive Link
research_keywords: Enhanced Guidance Systems,wireless power,Rocket Guidance,inductive coupling,data transfer
abstract: Triton Systems will develop an inductive link for use in Navy aircrafts to send configuration data to individual rockets within a launcher before launch. The proposed solution will remove the need for umbilicals on the current system and provide a wireless connectivity capability. During Phase I, Triton proposes to build a test model to demonstrate our systems capability to send wireless data to individual rockets using inductive coupling. The system will utilize advanced techniques in RF coupling for power and data transfer. During Phase II, a full scale design will be fabricated and demonstrated in appropriate environments to allow transition into the field for the US Navy.

award_title: Guided Rocket Inductive Link
research_keywords: Launcher,WIRELESS,inductive,rocket
abstract: The capabilities of the HYDRA-70 rockets in use with the US military have quickly outgrown those of the current generation of rocket launchers. These capabilities require that launchers provide pre-launch electrical power to wake-up guidance electronics, send data to the rocket including laser code settings for the laser seeker, initial conditions such as range to target and transfer alignment, fixed target image templates and mobile target parameters for the imaging seeker, and receive data from the rocket for command confirmation and guidance built-in test status checking. Launchers must also be capable of accepting signals from a MIL-STD-1760 interface, allow for arbitrary firing order, cockpit-selectable ripple or single fire, rocket inventory data, rocket presence detection, launcher service-life recording, and launcher built-in test. To meet the current and future launcher requirements of the US Navy, Luna proposes the development of a guided rocket inductive link system - Luna WInd (Wireless Inductive) Link. This wireless inductive link will accept signals from a MIL-STD-1760 interface and then wirelessly send commands to and from the rocket. The Phase I design will focus on creating a functioning prototype inductive link, and will conclude with the development of a Phase II transition plan and a laboratory demonstration.

award_title: Guided Rocket Inductive Link
research_keywords: ultra-short range,Power,MIL-STD-1760,communication,LAU-61,Inductive link
abstract: Under this Phase I effort, Stephens & Cross Research, Inc. (SCR) will demonstrate technical feasibility of a rocket inductive link using NFC technology with essential performance features of: bidirectional data communication, inductive energy harvesting and energy storage for operation during link and immediately after, and operation with conductive obscuration. Inductive link performance will be demonstrated analytically and experimentally with custom-designed antennas. The key innovation that underpins the proposed approach is a low-profile ferrite-backed reader antenna in each launcher tube, and a low-profile munition antenna and transponder embedded in the guidance section or warhead.

award_title: Guided Rocket Inductive Link
research_keywords: short range power transfer,rocket guidance programming,rocket fuze programming,LAU-61G/A wireless link,short range data link
abstract: A very short range wireless power and communication link from the cockpit to rocket via the LAU-61G/A Digital Rocket Launcher. The wireless link will enable programming rockets with fuze settings and targeting data without any change of rocket handling procedure.

award_title: OXYGEN MASK SENSORS TO INDICATE FIT, COMFORT AND RESPIRATION FUNCTION
research_keywords: oxygen mask fit,Extensometer,pulmonary function sensor,3D strain mapping,Metal Rubber sensor,spirometer,respiration rate sensor,Oxygen mask comfort
abstract: The objective of this SBIR program is to develop sensors to increase oxygen mask use by pilots and provide information about pilot respiration. NanoSonic will integrate two kinds of sensors into pilot oxygen masks to 1) determine comfort and fit, and 2) indicate respiration rate and pulmonary function. First, we will integrate stretchable piezoresistive Metal Rubber strain sensors into and onto the mask material to provide a measure of comfort, fit and seal. Strain levels corresponding to correct fit will be determined for each individual wearer and verified each time the mask is donned. Second, we will integrate an optical fiber respiration sensor into the mask so its exposed tip is near the nose of the wearer. By depositing a set of structured molecular layers on the tip of an optical fiber, the fiber can be used to measure changes in humidity associated with respiration. Change in humidity as a function of time during exhaling gives an indication of pulmonary activity along the respiratory airway. Used in this way, the unobtrusive fiber sensor can be used as a spirometer to determine airway resistance and provide an indication of pilot activity. NanoSonic will develop and deliver prototype sensors during Phase I.

award_title: Oxygen Mask Development to Improve and Facilitate Mask Discipline
research_keywords: Seamlessly integrates into existing oxygen systems,Increase pilots discipline and comfort in properly wearing the mask,hypoxia,High Performance Oxygen Mask Face-piece,Physiological Sensors wearable t
abstract: Sera Stars proposed innovation is to integrate the AVOX Systems Patented mask design: Design of face piece seal and supporting structure that distributes force on a wearer's face which is the subject of U.S. Patent Number 6,629,531, issued 7 October, 2003. This face-piece technology, referred to as the High Performance Oxygen Mask (HPM), design can be simply and seamlessly integrated into existing oxygen systems, improving the mask design to resolve complaints and eliminate pilot pain and discomfort and therefore significantly increase pilots discipline in properly wearing the mask. HPM face-piece design utilizes state of the art by integrating new mask design with modern manufacturing processes. By utilizing modern molding processes the soft face seal can be over-molded onto the mask frame, allowing for far greater control of the human/mask interface than the two-part legacy designs where as soft face-seals are held in place with a separate hard shell frame, such as on the old MBU-5/P, MBU-20/P and MBU-23/P mask design. Furthermore, by utilizing Liquid Injection Molding (LIM) processes, complex shapes of the face-piece and its over molding on the plastic shell can be controlled.

award_title: Oxygen Mask Development to Improve and Facilitate Mask Discipline
research_keywords: physiological sensors,Wearable Technology,Oxygen Mask,ERGONOMICS,comfort,hypoxia
abstract: Oceanit proposes to develop a solution to improve mask discipline and improve oxygen mask comfort.

award_title: LIGHTWEIGHT, HIGHLY BREATHABLE HYBRIDSIL DRYSUIT FABRICS WITH INSTANT WATERTIGHT SEALING
research_keywords: Self-sealing,Watertight,Ventilation,breathable,viscoelastic gel,waterproof,3D Pattern,flexible
abstract: Through the proposed Navy SBIR program, NanoSonic will create game-changing HybridSil drysuit fabrics that provide a previously unavailable combination of breathability and immediate, passive water tight sealing. NanoSonics drysuit fabric technology will afford equivalent breathability to state-of-the-art waterproof breathable fabrics (WB) yet instantly provide immersed Naval Aviators with a durable, watertight barrier. To meet this challenge, NanoSonic will design, synthesize, and empirically validate an innovative, lightweight (< 9.0 oz./yd2) tri-layered fabric ensemble that provides sufficient air exchange for evaporative cooling and yet instantly seals to a watertight state for > 6 hours. When this fabric ensemble is immersed, the differential pressure resulting from the air to water transition will provide a compressive force that transversely deforms / collapses micro patterned gel elastomers into a coalesced, watertight barrier that is both flexible and durable. When the compressive force is removed upon exiting from the water, the elastomeric resilience of the gel microarrays will enable complete restoration to their original pattern and restored waterproof breathable performance. NanoSonic has successfully developed state-of-art HybridSil Diver Armor drysuit materials that have completed multiple successful form, fit, and function NEDU evaluations with Navy Divers and will build from this experience to realize its Navy SBIR goals.

award_title: TouchAID Touchscreen Analog Input Device
research_keywords: Analog button,Aircraft Recovery,User Interface,touchscreen,Aircraft carrier,Landing Signal Officer,LSODS,LSO
abstract: US Navy carrier recovery operations are executed under any conditions. Margins of error are small, as failed approaches can lead to catastrophic consequences. Landing Signal Officers (LSOs) are Naval Aviators who facilitate the safe and expeditious recovery of aircraft aboard aircraft carriers. As technology has advanced, LSOs have better information and systems to guide aircraft to the deck; however, the Landing Signal Officer Display System (LSODS), which displays and configures this information has fallen behind. Specifically, the control interface used to navigate its deep and complex menus is unintuitive (in form and proximity to display outputs) and inefficient. To modernize the LSODS and enhance LSO performance through increased efficiency and lowered cognitive workload, Charles River Analytics and our partners at Carrier Landing Consultants propose to design and demonstrate a prototype system for a Touchscreen Analog Input Device (TouchAID). TouchAID is an overlaid screen bezel for the LSODS displays and a series of intelligently-located (based on LSO tasks and workflows) analog buttons that activate the touchscreen, while providing positive indication feedback through visual and haptic modalities. TouchAID provides buttons with the tactile response of traditional analog buttons, but overlaid on a touchscreen to map directly with display effects and provide reprogrammability.

award_title: Project TouchStone
research_keywords: Haptic,touchscreen,Feedback,Piezoelectric,ruggedized,tactile
abstract: The DOD seeks a touchscreen ruggedized with a reconfigurable physical button module for use in harsh environments such as a US Navy Aircraft Flight Deck. Current touchscreen systems do not provide sufficient tactile feedback for Navy personnel. Software buttons are easily reconfigurable, but the physical feedback for the user (vibrational/haptic) when pressing those buttons is often too low intensity to be felt through gloves and in high stress high vibration environments such as the flight deck. This makes using touchscreens challenging as the user does not know if software buttons were selected or not. Physical buttons provide sufficient mechanical feedback, but generally are difficult to reprogram. Many of the systems used by the flight crew are safety critical, so it is imperative that the user gets adequate feedback when software button selections are made, such that they can maintain focus and situational awareness on deck. A system is desired that integrates a physical button module that is reconfigurable, rugged, and programmable into a touchscreen display. Mid proposes to develop a novel clear touchscreen overlay, featuring a suspended piezo-electric array. The piezoelectric array suspension will provide intelligent haptic feedback balancing traditional mechanical button sensation and improved vibro-tactile stimulus.

award_title: Rugged Touchscreen Button with Positive Indication Feedback
research_keywords: Reconfigurable,touchscreen,positive indication feedback,Information systems,Button,Ruggedization
abstract: Our innovative Wearable Augmented Reality Controls with Haptic (WARC-H) feedback were originally developed for ruggedized use by warfighters within combat environments. This Navy project provides ideal opportunities to customize WARC-H versions for the Landing Signal Officer Display System (LSODS) Use Cases. Innovatively and uniquely WARC-H enables each user to visually see augmented reality semi-transparent forearm panels with controls (user selectable semi-transparent 2D/2.5D/3D controls that solve the longstanding lack of haptic feedback problems). Users intuitively receive dual haptic feedback from their forearms and fingertips as they use one hands fingers to press controls displayed on the other arms forearm panel. Our displays are developed per application by an integrated product team including our cognitive and human-factors scientists (4 Ph.D.s) working with the subject matter experts, and the software/hardware engineers. Mode changes to dynamically real-time reconfigure WARC-H (LSODS) applications on-the-fly are already provided as a simple flipping your wrist over gesture. Key benefits/advantages especially important for this projects LSODS Use Cases are based upon exploiting human users innate proprioception (knowing your limbs positions without visually looking) and haptic feedback including: Users being able to stay eye-on focused on the landing aircraft; while simultaneously enabling users to make control button selections WITHOUT looking.

award_title: Multifunctional Rugged Touchscreen Button with Positive Indication Feedback
research_keywords: touchscreen,Haptics,actuators,Button,electroactive polymers,Transparent Electrodes
abstract: This SBIR Phase I project will develop reconfigurable touchscreen buttons using low-cost electroactive polymer actuators that can generate strong, rich, quick and unambiguous haptic feedback to the user.

award_title: Additive Manufacturing Technology for Sonobuoy Applications
research_keywords: DIFAR,additive manufacturing,FDM,3D Printing,Sonobuoys,AM
abstract: Advances in Additive Manufacturing (AM) have enabled the possibility of incorporating printed components into full-scale production lines. Triton Systems will provide a feasibility study detailing the potential cost savings, performance benefits, and production flexibility that could be achieved through use of AM in the full-scale manufacturing process for Navy sonobuoys.

award_title: Additive Manufacturing Technology for Sonobuoy Applications
research_keywords: AN/SSQ-53F,Volume Manufacturing,3D Printing,DIFAR,additive manufacturing,Rapid Prototype,Sonobuoy
abstract: The advancements made in Additive Manufacturing (AM) in recent years suggest that, ultimately, this technology may provide a more cost-effective method of producing sonobuoy components than the methods currently employed. In this Phase I SBIR, Navmar Applied Sciences Corporation seeks to evaluate this prospect, assess existing and emerging production methods and materials, identify candidate sonobuoy parts for additive manufacturing, and ascertain when the use of AM technology may be economically feasible to support full-volume, high-rate production. Our goal in the performance of this SBIR project is to reduce sonobuoy weight and cost while improving performance. While AM may apply to a large number of sonobuoy components, the more complex and costly components may provide the best opportunity for innovative use of AM techniques and higher cost savings. In particular, NASC intends to study the application of AM to the fabrication of an improved DIFAR sensor. While NASC boasts a modest AM capability, our expertise lies primarily in development of expendable ocean systems and underwater acoustics. We will therefore solicit technical inputs from Fabrisonic and Solid State Ceramics, companies actively engaged in additive manufacturing, to leverage their production experience with metal components and piezoceramics, respectively, into the sonobuoy design.

award_title: Hybrid In-Process Additive Manufacturing for Sonobuoy (HIPAMS)
research_keywords: Cost Reduction,3D Printing,Rapid Prototype,Adaptive Manufacturing,Volume Manufacturing,Sonobuoy
abstract: Interlog Corporation proposes to develop a new Hybrid In-Process Additive Manufacturing for Sonobuoy (HIPAMS) Technology that innovatively manufactures multiple-material components in a single additive manufacturing (AM) platform with nondestructive evaluation (NDE) capability. The HIPAMSs multiple-material AM capability also enables to build/integrate electrical components and interconnects within/with structural elements. The proposed HIPAMS produces complete-AM sonobuoy with various types of material in a single AM platform. This innovation is possible because it is based on Interlog's proprietary point-by-point AM technology. The HIPAMS will provide mass/cost savings, reduction in integration and test flow timelines, and increased overall systems reliability. In Phase I, Interlog Corporation will demonstrate HIPAMSs feasibility as a streamlined, in-process sonobuoy AM system with a functional prototype and computer analysis/simulations as TRL-4 (component and breadboard tests in a laboratory environment).

award_title: Additive Manufacturing Technology for Sonobuoy Applications
research_keywords: Sonobuoy,Rapid prototyping,3D Printing,maritime robotics
abstract: Hydronalix, a world leader in maritime robotic rescue systems will team with the Materials Department Rapid Prototyping Center at Oklahoma State University to perform this program. The Phase I program will focus on the study to identify, develop, and qualify use of rapid prototyping 3D Printing technologies for reducing the cost to manufacture Navy sonobuoys by at least 10% but most likely a much larger reduction. The contractor team already has extensive experience in use of 3D printing and low cost composite extrusion and layup processes in its commercial EMILY product line and small autonomous mobile buoy surface sensor platform line. The contractor has qualified a number of commercially available 3D printing systems and materials for use in extreme maritime environments with use throughout the globe. The contract will utilize this expertise base to build on for application of low cost high performance sonobuoy production for U.S. Navy.

award_title: Advanced Arresting Gear Water Twister Diagnostics and Health Monitoring
research_keywords: Carrier,DIAGNOSTICS,AAG,Advanced arresting gear,Water twister,Physics-Based,Rotating Machinery
abstract: Mechanical Solutions, Inc. (MSI) is proposing to develop a man portable diagnostic tool (MPDT) for integrity assessments of the Advanced Arresting Gear (AAG) water twister. The system will allow for periodic monitoring of the full set of six water twisters on an aircraft carrier. The goal of the system is to provide advanced warnings to Sailors regarding structural and/or hydraulic failures of the water twisters to prevent catastrophic failures by performing properly-timed maintenance. MSI has previous experience with the water twister having performed testing at the Navys request in 2012 at the Lakehurst Jet Car Track Site (JCTS), and will utilize the understanding gained to provide a physics-based monitoring and diagnostic solution.

award_title: A Handheld HUMS for the AAG Water Twister
research_keywords: HUMS,AAG,Water twister,health and usage monitoring system
abstract: The Advanced Arresting Gear (AAG) water twister is an important component for future U.S. Navy launch and recovery capabilities, and innovative technologies are needed to ensure high performance and availability. Creare proposes to develop a handheld Health and Usage Monitoring System (HUMS) to identify incipient component degradation before failure so that preventive measures can be made before missions or personnel are put at risk. Our handheld HUMS can be used during actual arrestments, spin tests, or engineering investigations to quickly and easily assess water twister health. During Phase I, we will demonstrate feasibility by developing the necessary signal processing algorithms and equipment interface and by evaluating performance with representative operational data. During Phase II, we will refine the design, produce prototypes, and demonstrate capability in land-based and shipboard operational environments. Benefits of Creares approach include simplicity, portability, and prognostic ability to identify degradation prior to failure. Creares AAG water twister HUMS leverages our signal processing, algorithm, and hardware technologies already proven for machinery health monitoring and human physical activity classification. Due to the existing maturity of Creares prognostic algorithm technologies, we expect a Technology Readiness Level of at least 6 at the end of Phase II.

award_title: Advanced Arresting Gear Water Twister Diagnostics and Health Monitoring
research_keywords: Acoustic Emission,AAG Water Twister,structural health monitoring,Non-destructive evaluation
abstract: The arresting system is a critical component to ensure mission readiness and pilot safety during landing operations on an aircraft carrier. The Advanced Arresting Gear (AAG) water twister is the most critical mechanical component for absorbing kinetic energy from landing aircraft and as such it is necessary to ensure its reliability and health status. Issues have previously been identified with the design of the new AAG technology, specifically with the water twister, which has led to delays for system delivery and increased cost. A man portable diagnostic tool is desired to accurately and reliably assess the health of the water twister, for which no inspection tools have yet proven reliable. This proposal describes an acoustic emission (AE) inspection solution which will allow for detection, localization, and classification of damage within both the rotor blades as well as the stator plates. AE technology has had great success in early damage detection in a wide variety of rotating machinery applications. New, patent-pending shear sensitive AE sensors will be used to distinguish and isolate water-borne noise sources. Detection will focus on both cracking and corrosion damage, and advanced algorithms will be used to precisely identify damage location within the water twister.

award_title: Automated Code and Architecture Refactoring Software (ACARIS)
research_keywords: Automation,machine learning,artificial intelligence,Architecture,Mission Planning,,Refactoring
abstract: The current Joint Mission Planning System (JMPS) software is very powerful and essential to mission planning efforts in the field; however, a large part of the codebase is outdated legacy software which doesnt take full advantage of the hardware its running on. In order to use the JMPS software to its full potential, the Navy would benefit from a tool that could refactor low-level code and restructure the architecture of the JMPS system to better meet the requirements of modern computers and tablets. ATC-NY will develop Automated Code and Architecture Refactoring Software, ACARIS, to analyze the source code of an application, identify inefficient or poorly written code structures, and automatically refactors and/or multithreads these structures. ACARIS also analyzes the architecture of the application and identifies opportunities for refactoring the code to improve the architecture and transition to a more open, service-oriented architecture.

award_title: Transition of Mission Planning Software to a Next Generation Component Based, Open Architecture using Advanced Refactoring Technology
research_keywords: Mission Planning,artificial intelligence,machine learning,Refactoring,Feature Identification,Logistics,Service Oriented Architecture,Big Data
abstract: Timely and accurate dissemination of mission critical data is vital to ensure optimal execution of military operations in the battlespace. A significant number of critical systems  such as the Joint Mission Planning Systems (JMPS)  are wired tightly to non-centralized, individual platforms found in system of system networks. These planning systems are costly to maintain, and the ability to quickly evolve and scale software to support future mission planning is called into question. The need exists to augment and leverage existing technology capabilities embedded in software systems so that it can be dynamically repurposed to support multiplatform mission development, including mission planning for manned and unmanned aircraft. This proposal seeks to apply Big-Data techniques, especially Machine Learning coupled with Feature Identification, to the problem of rapidly obtaining critical mission planning information from disparate systems by utilizing machine learning to dynamically harvest data access algorithms and rapidly refactor them for use in mission planning.

award_title: Mission Planning Software- Next Generation
research_keywords: Mission Planning,Refactoring,artificial intelligence,Automation,machine learning,Software,ICAP,SparkPredict,Architecture
abstract: To address need to develop an advanced software refactoring algorithm, using artificial intelligence (AI) technology or other similar innovative development approach, to facilitatetransition of legacy mission planning software to a capabilities based, open architecture, next generation mission planning software suite supporting both manned an unmanned operations. PMATs proposed solution, Mission Planning Software - Next Generation, will evaluate and integrate multiple technologies to facilitate machine learning and AI technologies through combining PMAT's Intelligence Collaboration and Analytics Platform (ICAP) open architectural framework and data fusion capabilities with SparkCognition's machine learning and advanced algorithms solution SparkPredict(TM) solution. Research of the Mission Planning System - Next Generation will consist of four technical objectives needed to repurpose and integrate ICAP and SparkPredict(TM) to integrate real-time machine learning and AI aided advanced refactoring to support time dominate operational mission planning. These objectives include the development of a conceptual planning model, conceptual workflows, refactoring technology to support backwards planning, and prototype development. Each technical objective support the identification of associated operational risk and mitigation plans to support include feasibility prototypes and experiments.

award_title: Photonic Switch for Laser Power Distribution
research_keywords: fiber-port,Fiber-Optic,Laser,SWITCH,fiber-coupling,photonic
abstract: A very fast 1xN optical switch capable of handling high-optical power is proposed. It is designed for switching laser power from a central source to multiple outputs using photonic switch technology that does not have any mechanical moving parts. It is designed to have a very compact size and high-reliability operation suitable for airborne environment. The switching speed will be >10 W of optical power.

award_title: Photonic Switch for Infrared Laser Power Distribution
research_keywords: dispersion correction,non-mechanical,Photonic switch,infrared laser power distribution,liquid crystal polarization grating
abstract: The proposed effort investigates non-mechanical beam steering devices for application to infrared (IR) laser power distribution. The planned approach leverages recent advances Boulder Nonlinear Systems has made in wide angle beam steering based on liquid crystal polarization gratings (LCPGs). The photonic switch will ideally cover the wavelength range from 1.06 um to 5 um. BNS proposes to design and develop a switching technology that covers this range using three bands: 1.06 -1.8 um, 1.8-3 um and 3-5 um. For Phase I Boulder Nonlinear Systems, proposes to build photonic switching components and demonstrate coupling different wavelengths to the same output fibers. During the base effort two SWIR wavelengths will be tested. This will be extended to the MWIR during the Phase I Option. Efforts to mitigate wavelength dispersion, will also be explored. Finally we will design a prototype photonic switch to be implemented in Phase II.

award_title: Advanced Human-Machine Interface (HMI) for Dynamic Sensor Control
research_keywords: xxx
abstract: xxx

award_title: Advanced Human-Machine Interface (HMI) for Dynamic Sensor Control
research_keywords: Sensors,visualization,Sensor Resource Manager (SRM),Maritime Surveillance,autonomous control,Human Machine Interface (HMI),automated resource management
abstract: Toyon Research Corporation proposes to develop a human machine interface (HMI) for dynamically controlling a set of sensors which desire to locate and identify surface vessels to meet mission objectives. A key challenge for a sensor resource manager (SRM) is determining what is most valuable at the current time. The proposed HMI will allow a human operator to influence the operation of the SRM. This influence will come in the form of a set of specified controls that are possible for the operator such as the ability to increase the revisit rate on an object in track or the collection of identification information. Another key element of the HMI will be the display of information to the operator. This information should not overwhelm the operator and should be presented in a manner that allows the operator to selectively display various sources of information. Candidate information that should be displayed to the operator includes track information from a global fusion system, currently planned sensor schedules from an SRM, and the outputs of specific exploitation tools which provide additional insight beyond what is in the global fusion database.

award_title: Fiber Optic Concentric Stepped Ferrule
research_keywords: lens connector,concentric,lens terminus,Fiber Optic Ferrule,Stepped Ferrule
abstract: RC Integrated Systems LLC (RISL) proposes to develop a Fiber Optic Concentric Stepped (FOCS) Ferrule that can self-align the core of an optical fiber with the center of a lens of different outer diameter. Through use of a novel commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) materials and unique processing steps, the ferrules will meet all the Navy specifications including overall length of 10.00+.10 mm with a diameter of 1.58600005 mm, the larger cavity length of 4.0+0/-.2 mm with a diameter of 1.00+.03/-.00 mm, the smaller cavity diameter of 0.1255+0.001/-0.000 mm, and both cavities concentric to the outer diameter of the ferrule within 0.001 mm. The FOCS ferrule material has better performance in hardness and wear-resistance than zirconia ceramic. Use of low cost COTS materials, each ferrule will cost less than $40. In Phase I, RISL will develop the ferrule fabrication process and fabricate several ferrules for single mode fiber optic cable jumpers and demonstrate the FOCS feasibility. In Phase II, RISL will improve the design and process and fabricate at least 12 FOCS prototypes. RISL will measure the FOCS ferrules for accuracy and repeatability when tested for insertion loss within a range of optical fibers (e.g. 9/125 um, 50/125 um, 62.5/125 um).

award_title: Modular Multi-Platform Rotor Hub Fatigue Test Rig
research_keywords: UAV testing,Rotor shaft,high speed hydraulics,Helicopter fatigue testing,rotor hub,rotor craft fatigue testing,Dynamic Component Testing
abstract: The established methodology for fatigue testing rotorcraft dynamic components is time consuming and expensive. Multiple, unique, custom designed test fixtures are required. In order to reduce the time and expense of testing rotorcraft hubs and shafts a modular, multi-platform, easily reconfigurable test fixture is desired. This new test system should also be capable of greater load cycles application rates to reduce testing time.Dayton T Brown, Inc. (DTB), a leader in aircraft system engineering and testing services, has developed a comprehensive solution that will meet these requirements. DTBs solution will be easily reconfigurable in order to test rotor hubs and shafts from many different rotor configurations. The system will also be capable of applying loads at increased rates to reduce test times. The baseline configuration utilizes a movable reconfigurable platform to mount the test items and apply the test loads in an accelerated fashion.Benefits of this system would be a reduction in test time and costs for both government and commercial rotorcraft manufacturers. Especially with the numerous UAV rotorcraft platforms being developed, the reduction of costs in this area will speed time to market for innovative rotorcraft of the future.

award_title: Complete Rotor Head Fatigue Test Rig
research_keywords: Rotor Head,Test Stand,Fatigue Test,Safe Life,Fatigue,Rotorcraft,Modular Test System
abstract: Rotorcraft components must be fully vetted prior to flight certification to establish fatigue life limits. Rotor components typically are grouped into sub-assemblies and fatigue tested separately under simulated flight loads. While this is a fairly simple approach, fatigue testing sub-components may result in certain load cases not being transferred properly through the system. According to the Navy, many current test rigs, along with the software for loads input, are mechanically complicated and developed for each individual platform, increasing costs associated with fatigue tests, with each easily costing in the order of millions to conduct. They desire an innovative rotor head fatigue test stand capable of testing main rotor head assemblies as one unit for multiple platforms, with easy transition, including both 4 and 3 bladed rotor head systems such as H-1, H-60, V-22, and MQ-8B. Mid proposes to leverage its experience in designing, building, and maintaining custom test rigs to perform life cycle test, as well as its decades of rotorcraft related research and development to build a custom test rig to meet the Navys requirements.

award_title: Modular Multi-Platform Rotor Hub Fatigue Test Rig
research_keywords: Fatigue Test,modular test rig,Rotor hub test rig,Dynamic Components,multiple rotorcraft platforms,Safe-Life,dynamic loading,advanced sensors
abstract: We address main issues concerning the design of modular multi-platform rotor hub fatigue test rig in a systematic way by identifying constraints that current typical hub tests experience. Our design approach starts with decoupling the centrifugal force (CF) from rest of the blade load components, such that each blade load component can be accurately generated in the test rig. The location of CF loading point close to the blade attachment point to the hub arm minimizes the effect of blade bending on other blade load components as well as the overall test rig size. Multi-platform feature comes from the capability of relocating actuators along the blade axis for a new platform test. Our proposed design will allow each and all hub arms to be simultaneously tested as valid test specimens. We also propose developing a kinematic simulation model to optimize the location of the loading and sensing points. We plan to build a scaled hub test rig, and to use highly advanced automated feedback control system and sensors such as the non-contact optical Direct Strain Imaging technology. We propose to develop high fidelity spectrum editing tool and multi-axial test data analysis tool as well to support testing.

award_title: Modular Multi-Platform Rotor Hub Fatigue Test Rig
research_keywords: Rotor Head,Test Rig,Fatigue,Fatigue Test,Rotorcraft,Modular Test System,Safe Life
abstract: Rotor system components must be tested prior to flight certification to assess fatigue life. Developing custom test rigs for each different rotor hub due to their varying sizes and numbers of blades is the most costly approach. Safe, Inc. (Safe) has proposed a single test rig design with modular elements that can be reconfigured to address any rotor assembly or component. Hydraulic actuators can be moved into different locations and orientations for any combination of centrifugal, bending, and torsion loads. The hydraulic system accommodates differing numbers of actuators and load ranges. The control and data acquisition software also reconfigure to operate one or many actuators at different loads, independently or in unison, while measuring strain and load data. The rig will address all combinations of test items and loads such that reconfiguring for a different test does not require a new structural assessment of the rig. Safes team has prior experience developing hydraulic test equipment, as well as related experience designing aerospace hardware for structural loads including vibration-induced fatigue. The commercialization strategy describes how to transition the rig from development into production using marketing and manufacturing approaches that Safe has successfully used in the past to commercialize SBIR technology.

award_title: Electrically Small, Materials-Enhanced VHF/UHF Antenna for High Power Transmit Applications (1000-402)
research_keywords: lightweight magnetic materials,metamaterials,advanced electronic attack,Ultra Wideband,electrically small antenna,High Efficiency Antenna,Low cost manufacturing,High Power Antenna
abstract: SI2 Technologies will design an ultra-wideband high efficiency transmit antenna for high power, volume constrained airborne applications. The SI2 design will utilize previous research and state-of-the-art advances in metamaterials, lightweight magnetic materials, and low cost manufacturing techniques resulting in a polarization diverse transmit antenna maximizing radiation efficiency and bandwidth given the electrically small volume.In Phase I, SI2 will perform a detailed trade study evaluating antenna topologies, novel materials advancements and methods to incorporate ferrites, dielectrics, metamaterials, and wideband matching networks to maximize antenna bandwidth and efficiency. Additionally, simulations of potential antenna designs will be performed first in free space, and then in a representative environment consisting of a metallic ground plane in close proximity to the antenna. Finally, SI2 will design and build an antenna demonstrator for VSWR and low-power radiation pattern testing. Initial high power testing will also be performed to determine potential modes of failure at high power.In Phase II, SI2 will improve upon the concept from Phase I depending on the results obtained during the Phase I pattern and power testing. The antenna design will be modified for integration into the desired platform to conclude with on-platform testing, for both low and high power.

award_title: Compact, Broadband, Efficient and High Power Transmit Antenna for Airborne Electronic Attack Platforms
research_keywords: Large Ground Plane Coupling,High Power,Broadband,electrically small antenna,Mismatch Loss,Low Frequency
abstract: Space Micro teamed with SDSU, will develop an Airborne Electronic Attack (AEA) antenna capable of operating simultaneously at very high frequency (VHF) and ultra-high frequency (UHF) while being electrically-small, efficient, and capable of high power handling. Current constraints on antennas for AEA systems in VHF and UHF bands are the size and impedance. This translates to shorter mission durations, aerodynamic drag, greater power consumption, and unfocused radiated energy. The antenna will accept and radiate more of the power from its source to its intended target versus reflecting it back to the source and damaging it.

award_title: Compact, Broadband, Efficient and High Power Transmit Antenna for Airborne Electronic Attack Platforms
research_keywords: UHF and VHF,electrically small antenna,Airborne Jamming,installed performance,Broadband Antenna,High-Power Radio Frequency Jamming,Electromagnetic Maneuver Warfare,airborne electronic attack (AEA)
abstract: Since the final third of the 20th century, Navys airborne electronic attack (AEA) capabilities have grown to serve a unique and critical role in protecting our militarys spectral dominance. However, in the nearly 50 years since the first AEA payloads were deployed, few substantive modifications have been made to the original system hardware or design, leaving the current fleet of AEA systems in increasingly urgent need of modernization. This obsolescence is compounded by the persistent increase in both the sophistication and the capability of our enemies RF systems. In order for Navys AEA fleet to provide another half century of effective service, significant updates are required to enhance the performance and integration of next-generation AEA payloads.FIRST RF proposes a novel AEA antenna architecture adapted from proven (TRL-9) FIRST RF technologies that are specifically tailored to meet all of the performance and integration challenges associated with next-generation AEA systems. This background provides a uniquely low-risk path to meeting the objectives of the proposed Phase I program.

award_title: Low Cost In-Flight Bladder Relief Device
research_keywords: bladder relief,in-flight urination,aircrew urination,aircrew dehydration,Urine collection device,aircrew hydration
abstract: Triton Systems will apply our material design, medical systems and wearables expertise to develop a low cost in-flight bladder relief system for both male and female pilots. The bladder relief system allows the user to safely urinate in-flight without fear of leaks or resulting discomfort. The Triton bladder relief system will significantly increase pilot effectiveness with minimal cost.

award_title: In-Flight Bladder Relief
research_keywords: incontinence,aircrew urination,aircrew dehydration,in-flight urination,bladder relief,Urine collection device,aircrew hydration
abstract: The AMXDmax is a fully automatic, hands free bladder relief system designed for use in fixed and rotary wing aircraft. The system was designed to allow pilots to be hydrated during mission (in accordance with mandatory regulation for aircrew of military aircraft) and to remain fully clothed and secure in their seat harness at all times. Omni Measurement Systems, Inc., holds the US Patents for this type of system. Though the AMXDmax is effective in meeting the system requirements for urination, the cost per flight for the consumable products is currently too high for them to be considered disposable. To reach these requirements, Omni will design fully disposable, low cost consumables and implement self-cleaning capabilities on any reusable components.

award_title: In-flight Disposable Aircrew Bladder Relief System with Novel Effective and Comfortable Human Interface
research_keywords: bladder relief system,adult diaper,incontinence,DISPOSABLE,adult urinary incontinence device,Portable,aircrew disposable bladder relief system,adult bladder relief
abstract: Materials and Technologies Corp. (MATECH) will further the design (from the functional prototype presented here), demonstrate the effectiveness, and thoroughly characterize a new aircrew active bladder relief system with low-cost disposable crew components. There is currently no fully satisfactory approach for aircrew to relieve their bladder during flight, especially for female crew. MATECHs system is compatible with all current fighter and aircraft, has greatest possible component commonality between male/female versions, it is self-contained, comfortable, unobtrusive, inconspicuous, and compatible with current suits, gear and survival equipment without modifications. MATECHs crew body interfaces are of a novel anatomical design and made of biocompatible polymers for excellent seal and comfort. The small and simple device is comfortable for extended wear and will be worn under the flight suit. The device uses a smart modular pumping device with full and leak sensors for fail-safe and rugged operation. It empties into a pressure compensated bladder capable of unpressurized flight up to 50,000 ft. Power will be supplied by a self-contained rechargeable source also worn by the aircrew. In Phase II MATECH will build an air-worthy prototype. At the end of the program MATECH will have production-ready units available and a manufacturing plan in place.

award_title: Media Efficacy Return on Investment Tool (MERIT)
research_keywords: effectiveness,mixed reality,decision support,AUGMENTED REALITY,House of Quality,Training,Return on investment,Media Analysis
abstract: Augmented Reality (AR) as a concept has been in existence since the 1960s, used in fighter pilot cockpits for some time augmenting pilot performance. AR has continued to see technological leaps in accessibility and affordability with systems such as Google Glass and the Microsoft HoloLens becoming available to the general public. Mobile-based AR is also on the rise as smart phones become ubiquitous in todays society, with apps like astronomy app Star Chart and the briefly wildly-popular game Pokmon Go. Despite these advances, however, AR as a whole is still largely underutilized in areas in which the enhancement of human performance can have the most benefit. This is because in many ways, AR is a technological solution without a clear set of general guidelines for what problems AR solves and to what efficacy. In order to address this innovation gap, Soar Technology proposes to develop the Media Efficacy Return on Investment Tool (MERIT). MERIT is a theoretical framework methodology and tool for quantitatively evaluating AR and other training solutions for a given training environment based on four factors: Task Factors, Training Media Factors, Return on Investment (ROI) Factors, and Training Efficacy Factors.

award_title: MIRAGE: Mixed and Immersive Reality Assessment Generation Engine
research_keywords: Training Effectiveness Assessment,AUGMENTED REALITY,Experimentation,Cost Analysis,Virtual reality,Navy Aviation Training,Performance Measurement,decision support tool
abstract: Although augmented reality (AR) is a promising technology, it has not yet made a substantial impact in the training domain. While there is a lot of research in specific low-level cognitive and perceptual tasking, the research results have not yet been shown to apply to the training domain, making it difficult to compare with other technologies. In response to these challenges, Aptima, Inc. proposes to design, develop, and commercialize the Mixed and Immersive Reality Assessment Generation Engine (MIRAGE), a quantitative analysis tool consisting of an experimental methodology, an AR testbed capable of emulating AR device characteristics within virtual reality environments, three comparative training solutions, and a decision support tool that automates data collection and provides analysis on experimental results. MIRAGE will provide to NAWCTSD researchers an experimental framework that will allow researchers to develop experiments to assess the impact of device characteristics and affordances. Researchers will be able perform effectiveness assessments using simulated AR head-mounted displays to determine the capability of AR now and to predict its feasibility in the future. MIRAGE will support automated data collection through system-based measurement, giving researchers the objective data they need to compare the effectiveness of AR training solutions with other comparable solutions.

award_title: Effectiveness Assessments of Mixed &amp; Immersive Reality for Aviation Training
research_keywords: Training efficiency,ROI,Training Effectiveness Evaluation,preflight checklist,Cost Effectiveness,AUGMENTED REALITY
abstract: QIC proposes to develop the TEE-TEST, a quantitative analysis tool that enables researchers and acquisitions personnel to make informed decisions about the utility of new training technologies prior to their implementation. To develop the TEE-TEST, our team will develop a training efficiency framework that combines approaches to evaluating training and cost effectiveness based on established, evidence-based best practices. This framework will be tested by conducting comparative analyses of three training prototypes (AR, mobile, and game-based) developed over the course of this effort. The findings of this research will inform the final TEE-TEST as well as address the gap in evaluations of AR technology for training. We propose to use Naval aviation preflight checklist training as a domain for our TEE-TEST training development. In addition to being a well-suited domain for comparison across mobile, AR, and game-based platforms, preflight training checklist execution is a critical issue for Navy pilots.

award_title: Stabilized Particles for Volumetric Energy Density Enhancement of Liquid Fuels
research_keywords: volumetric energy density,Fuel Additives,liquid fuels
abstract: There is currently a need to increase the range of platforms and weapons without altering the overall design of existing systems. This can be accomplished by using higher density fuels. However, current solutions of high energy density liquid hydrocarbon fuels have high viscosities and freezing points which limit their use in cold regions and at high altitudes. Advanced Cooling Technologies, Inc. (ACT) together with Penn State University (PSU) propose an innovative coating to stabilize energetic nanoparticles for addition to liquid fuels which can increase the volumetric energy density by 10%. During the Phase I program ACT will demonstrate the feasibility and performance of the proposed coating method and the addition of coated particles to fuel.

award_title: Novel Method for Production of High Energy Density Fuel
research_keywords: butadiene,Diels Alder,High Energy Density,hybrid process,ISOPRENE,cycloaddition,bioprocess,PINENE
abstract: Missile fuels require high volumetric energy density. The two leading fuel candidates are JP10 and RJ5. Both of these fuels are synthesized from cyclopentadiene, which is turn is produced from naphtha cracker. The primary purpose of naphtha cracker is to produce ethylene. In addition, naphtha is further produced from petroleum crude. Thus, the entire high energy density requirement of the DOD is catered by side product of another process and petroleum feedstock. The proposed innovation circumvents cyclopentadiene based chemistry. The feedstock for the proposed fuel synthesis scheme are naturally occurring as well as can be synthesized from renewable materials. The final product will exceed the net volumetric heat of combustion of JP10. The team will develop the overall scaleable process to produce such fuel. In addition, pertinent quantity will be supplied to the Navy for preliminary testing at the end of phase I.

award_title: RETAIN: Red Team Attack Injector
research_keywords: NETWORK,Resiliency,Emulation,Training,cyber-attack,Agents
abstract: To combat the growing sophistication and frequency of cyber-attacks, the nations cyber-warriors must train vigilantly. Computer network defense (CND) training currently takes place either on operational networks or in virtual (or simulated) environments. The major drawback to using virtual environments is that they lack a sufficient amount of realism. Virtualized systems are frequently overly-simplified mock-ups of operational systems and lack the fidelity necessary for optimal, effective training. Training on operational networks provides a full-fidelity environment and enables the warfighters to train as they fight; however, the attackers are placed under significant restrictions to protect the operational network, since they cannot disrupt or damage network resources in the course of the exercise. ATC NY will develop the Red Team Attack Injector (RETAIN), a training system for emulating cyber-attacks on operational networks and restoring systems to normal operation at the conclusion of the exercise.

award_title: Computer Network Defense Trainer
research_keywords: emulations,network intrusion,Malware,computer network defense,Cyber Security
abstract: In this Phase I SBIR, MIKEL Inc. will develop emulations of common cyber threats that can be safely and securely deployed on operational networks and systems to train battle staffs and computer network defense personnel to succeed in contested cyberspace environment. The solution will advance todays state-of-the-art where realistic training on real operational networks is limited by the risk that a command is willing to tolerate to accommodate training. Live red teams produce realistic results, but are limited in their availability and the scope of what they can accomplish given real-world and exercise constraints. Cyber ranges or dedicated training facilities can create highly stressful training, but this training does not occur of the real operational network on which the staff and computer network defense personnel will operate. MIKELs solution will allow for software emulations to be introduced on real operational networks, supervised by a training coordinator. The solution will allow for the ability to update the threat database, to address emerging and theater-specific threats as needed.

award_title: Computer Network Defense Trainer
research_keywords: computer network defense,integrated training,cyber emulator,MODELING AND SIMULATION
abstract: Phase I will research and design enhancements to existing, government-owned cyber emulation software and protocols for CND effects generation, Command and Control (C2) of CND effects, an enhanced distributed simulation interface, and information assurance. Phase I will also introduce a CND Training Concept of Operations (CONOPS) that will make recommendations for how to adapt existing Navy training and exercise programs and processes to include CND training. At the conclusion of Phase I we will deliver a fully designed technical solution for CND training along with a CND Training CONOPS that, if implemented, will significantly improve integrated Navy CND training.

award_title: Metal-Encapsulated CNTs to Enhance Steel Wire Performance
research_keywords: Metal matrix composite,nanocomposite,Carbon nanotubes,arresting wire,Steel composite,CNTs
abstract: The Phase I proposal presented here details a procedure to produce metal encapsulated carbon nanotubes (CNTs) for integration into steel cabling for aircraft carrier arresting cables. The addition of CNTs traditional steel cabling has the potential to significantly improve cable strength and longevity. However, current methods for CNT integration struggle due to CNT aggregation and poor interfacial interactions between CNT and matrix. The proposed process is based on a simple, scalable, one-pot process that uses emulsion chemistry to coat a metal on the surface of the nanotubes. This coating will create an iron-coated CNT nanopowder which enhances the binding of CNT to the steel matrix, improves mixability, and limits aggregation. In addition, the emulsion chemistry enhances the matrix/CNT interface, improving both mechanical properties. The consulting investigator has previously developed the emulsion chemistry process for polymers, and together with Mainstream has developed a procedure to coat CNTs with copper for electrical wiring. The process will be adapted for coating CNTs with alternative metals and the coated CNTs will be leveraged with Mainstreams expertise in nanocomposite manufacturing.

award_title: Statistical Radar Signature Description of Small Sea Targets
research_keywords: Hydrodynamics,,Computational Electromagnetics,Radar Cross Section (RCS),Bragg scattering
abstract: XL Scientific and teammate Aret Associates propose to develop a software application to perform fast and accurate modeling of the radar cross section (RCS) of small sea targets within a dynamic ocean. The important aspects include polarization, beam-width and frequency of the radar, the height and elevation angle of the radar platform, and the ocean state including the orientation of the boat within the ocean.
