Analysis of equipment degradation failure trends will allow our software to automatically recommend corrective hardware maintenance prior to failure occurring. Progenys proposed solution will leverage automated data acquisition, big data storage techniques, and automatic analysis of hardware life remaining to recommend corrective maintenance prior to a failure occurring. Our true innovation for this effort will be the creation of an automated CBM+ algorithmic capability which automatically receives component fatigue assessments, invokes algorithms to calculate the impacts to dependent hardware, and recommends condition-based maintenance.

award_title: Automatic Acoustic Detection and Identification
research_keywords: acoustic sensor,Sound Reception Device,safe navigation
abstract: Signal Systems Corporation (SSC) proposes developing the Maritime Acoustic Sensing Unit (MASU) to provide situational awareness to manned and unmanned naval assets. The MASU leverages our innovative acoustic chambered design developed for robotic vehicles to provide a compact rugged, self-contained sensor capable of detecting, locating and classifying sounds.. We plan to demonstrate the capability of our compact sensor design to provide 360 detection, localization and classification of standard COLREGS signals out to one mile. We will improve our signal processing algorithms to detect and discriminate these sounds from non-navigational signals and develop a robust decision tree based classifier that will identify the signals to the operator. We will evaluate physical sensor design improvements to address the flow, wind, and platform noise effects, enabling us to meet the one mile detection range with good bearing accuracy.

award_title: Navy Acoustic Situational Awareness System
research_keywords: Microphone array,real time audio streaming,acoustic bearing,Acoustic situational awareness,Acoustic Detection,autonomous acoustic navigation,steerable acoustic array,maritime safety
abstract: The goal of this SBIR is the development of an automatic acoustic detection system to assist operation of unmanned surface vehicles by providing additional data regarding the operating environment shared with other vessels. Phase I research will result in the feasibility analysis of developing a Navy Acoustic Situational Awareness System (NASAS). New acoustic processing concepts and algorithms will be designed and tested for this application. Phase I is expected to result in the design of a modular acoustic detection and processing system that can be used by any ship in the ocean. McQ will also complete a preliminary system design that will identify the necessary hardware components and software modules required, the potential risks and mitigation solutions, and determine the feasibility of implementing this in Phase II. A commercialization plan will also be developed to identify other potential markets and customers for Phase III.

award_title: Cyber Threat Insertion and Evaluation Technology for Navy Ship Control Systems
research_keywords: Integrated Verification and Validation,Security Information Event Management (SIEM),Secure Supply Chain Management,Cybersecurity,Internet of Things (IOT),Hardware Assurance,hardware Trojans
abstract: We will create a proof-of-concept evaluation environment where white-hat hackers can create and test known and suspected Trojan circuits, evaluate their behaviors and impacts, and assess the Trojan circuits against various countermeasures. The appliance will be able to replicate or emulate, in hardware, a Trojan and its trigger in the context of a predetermined design; to discover methods to exercise, trigger, or expose that Trojan/trigger; to note the Trojans behavior and match it against the behavior of real circuits; and to evaluate that Trojan/trigger against countermeasures that would prevent it from disabling a semiconductor device.

award_title: Cyber Threat Insertion and Evaluation Technology for Navy Ship Control Systems
research_keywords: cyber threat,Cyber virus injection,firmware security,cyber intrusion,
abstract: Low-cost embedded FPGA devices rarely contain any cyber security measures. To combat this threat, the military is heavily investing in the development of a wide range of defensive tools. These tools require extensive redteam-style testing to assess efficacy. To address these challenges, Systems & Technology Research (STR) proposes to develop a Python toolkit that will inject malware code into the various stages of the Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA) synthesis process. We call this approach Cyber Redteam Injection Toolkit (CRIT). CRIT will be integrated with the vendor-specific toolchain and manipulate intermediate design checkpoint files to insert varying degrees of malware at various stages in the synthesis pipeline. CRIT consists of both the Python code to manipulate the checkpoint files, the firmware produced and the hardware used for testing. This combined hardware and software solution will enable testers to generate many permutations of malware and evaluate efficacy of defensive techniques under a range of observable performance degradations. Phase I will focus on framework generation and proof-of-concept malware insertion. Phase II will focus on increasing the sophistication of the inserted malware.

award_title: Methods for Measuring an Acoustic Arrays Straightness and for Autonomous Mechanical Straightening to Avoid Contact with Sea Bottom Under All Operatio
research_keywords: acoustics,Sonar,Towed Array
abstract: In operational use of towed arrays, environmental factors conspire to degrade the acoustic performance of the array. Overall improvements in performance will be the result of a systems approach that addresses the entire degradation equation. Triton Systems proposes a simple effective straightening approach that will work at all speeds and will have minimal acoustic impact on the array. During Phase I, the team will develop the concept into a preliminary design and demonstrate feasibility to straighten the array and avoid the bottom using hydrodynamic modeling and simulation of the system under a variety of ocean environments and ship movements. Specifications for straightness measurement components will be developed and feasibility demonstrated.

award_title: Towed Array Straightening and Depth Control Systems
research_keywords: Anti Submarine Warfare,speed-independent drag,array depth control,twin line array,SURTASS,Towed Array,SURVEILLANCE,array straightening
abstract: Surveillance Towed Array Sensor System (SURTASS) provide a critical Anti-Submarine Warfare (ASW) surveillance capability that helps the U.S. Navy maintain undersea dominance. During low speed operations, the unsteady nature of the tow environment causes the straightness (per line) and line-to-line separation of the array to deform from straight-line, constant separation cases which degrades the performance of the acoustic processing. As the tow speed decreases, the entire array sinks deeper and the tilt angle of the array increases, further degrading performance as well as putting the array at risk of damage from contacting the seafloor. Makai proposes to address the array straightness problem and bottom impact risks by developing two technologies, the SURTASS Array Straightening System (SASS) and the Depth Control Module (DCM) that can be clipped-on to existing TL29a arrays. Under the Phase I BASE effort, Makai will use CFD and high-fidelity and validated towed array modeling tools to design hydro-dynamically stable systems that meet the performance objectives and demonstrate a 1:2 scale prototype of SASS in waters off Makai Pier. In the Phase I OPTION period, interfaces with the twin-line array will be specified and the designs will be matured to support at-sea prototype demonstrations in Phase II.

award_title: Attack-Detection Application Memory Monitor (ADAMM)
research_keywords: real-time,cyber attacks,Memory Integrity,application monitoring,memory space,code analysis,Cybersecurity,buffer overflow
abstract: The current state of the art in cybersecurity technologies is insufficient to address the Navys strategic need to monitor the memory spaces of applications running with real-time performance constraints against corruption or sabotage by cyber-attacks. ATC-NY will fill this need by developing the Attack-Detection Application Memory Monitor (ADAMM), a kernel-based memory monitor that utilizes pre-execution code analysis alongside several passive and active memory protection techniques to verify the integrity of a running applications memory space on real-time UNIX systems with high availability requirements without harming its performance. Rather than naively treating the memory space of an application as being monolithic and entirely uniform, ADAMM performs static code analysis on the applications executable binary right before it begins running. This lets ADAMM significantly reduce the impact of its monitoring on run-time performance by applying particular and specialized monitoring strategies for each different section of the applications memory space.

award_title: Detecting Anomalies in Application Memory Space (DAAMS)
research_keywords: machine learning,application memory space defense,Anomaly Detection,systemic functional grammars,cyber attack detection,ensemble learning
abstract: Detecting cyber attacks before they have the chance to damage or compromise high-value or mission-critical systems is of critical importance to the US Navy. While there are many defenses available against cyber attacks, many are narrowly focused or usable only at certain levels of the software stack. In particular, application-level software is frequently the target of attacks, and can be extremely difficult to protect for a variety of reasons we will discuss. More specifically, attacks that operate on the memory space of applications are common, effective, and hard to detect using current approaches. Our system for Detecting Anomalies in Application Memory Space (DAAMS) will provide attack-detection capabilities for applications memory space that extend state-of-the-art anomaly detection techniques. We complement these anomaly detectors with an intelligent scenario generator that will generate a representative range of scenarios and inputs for the application to create offline learning data that will be used to learn how to detect normal and abnormal memory behavior during operations. This approach lets DAAMS detect memory-space anomalies without affecting the applications mission-time performance.

award_title: Small, High Performance Circulators Based on Ferrite Materials Compatible with MMIC
research_keywords: Ferrite,S-band,integration,circulator,RF,Radar,T/R modules,MMIC
abstract: The Navy needs innovative T/R modules to achieve performance enhancement, cost reduction, decreased size and MMIC integration. New techniques compatible with RF MMIC fabrication in Gallium Nitride (GaN) on silicon carbide (SiC) to form a purely passive circulator for S-Band operation and radar applications with a nominal bandwidth of 1.5 GHz are required. The process must be compatible with wafer-level semiconductor device fabrication and be consistent with automated integrated circuit fabrication and assembly. Metamagnetics, in partnership with a MMIC foundry will perform the research needed to develop small, passive, self-biased, S-band circulators based on ferrite material and advanced circulator design to reduce the size of the circulator and enable integration at the MMIC level. Reducing the size of the circulators not only enhances performance through the reduction of parasitics, but offers the potential to increase the density of arrays in future radar systems.Air and Missile Defense Radar is the primary transition platform for this technology and we will develop a roadmap to the transition of our MMIC-compatible circulator into foundry processes used to build AMDR T/R modules

award_title: Circulator Technology for Full Integration at the Monolithic Microwave Integrated Circuit (MMIC) Level
research_keywords: Flip-chip,surface acoustic waves,Microwave circulator,GaN integration,NiZn ferrite,RF components,spinwaves,Yttrium Iron Garnet
abstract: This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I program will demonstrate a novel chip-scale magneto-acoustic spin wave (MASW) circulator for use in S-band applications. The MASW concept is based on the velocity non-reciprocity of surface acoustic waves in Aluminum doped Nickel-Zinc ferrite. The program will first simulate and demonstrate the necessary concepts in a simpler, but no less critical device: a microwave isolator. Upon successful demonstration of the isolator, the circulator will be built and tested. The program will also demonstrate the ability to integrate the MASW with RFICs. The integration process will be demonstrated by solder bumping and flip-chipping the MASW onto a test chip. This will allow for measuring the performance of the MASW when integrated, taking into account the effects of the ball soldered connections. The combination of the demonstrated devices and their flipchip integration will result in integration with a GaN-based RFIC design to provide a low-cost, superior front end component in the Phase II program.

award_title: Agnostic Bi-Directional Data Exchange
research_keywords: Universal Gateway,data filtering,data exchange,Data transformation
abstract: The Navy requests an innovative and expandable data transportation scheme for the AN/UYQ-100 Undersea Warfare Decision Support System (USW-DSS) that translates bi-directional data exchanges between disparate and diverse data sources into a common language. We propose the use of the Universal Gateway (UGW), a product already in-use with the Navy, to provide data translation, data mediation and data filtering. The UGW will be integrated with key USW-DSS data models, formats and protocols to enable complex data exchanges per the needs of the program.

award_title: Design Tool and Methodology for Verification of Submarine Finite Element Models
research_keywords: software design tool,validation metric development,FE model validation,FINITE ELEMENT MODELING,Submarines,Structural analysis,Verification Testing
abstract: Shipyards are responsible for creating and analyzing finite element (FE) models of submarine pressure hulls and components under hydrostatic pressure loading, whereas the Navy technical community is responsible for reviewing the modeling and analysis. Modeling methodologies are often a source of disagreement between the shipyards and the Navy, which can require additional model development and analysis cycles before they are resolved, costing both time and budgetary resources. The Navy has identified the need for a test-validated design procedure that can be used by both the Navy and shipyards to perform agreed-upon model checks prior to technical review to reduce disagreements in modeling technique.ATA Engineering proposes developing a design tool consisting of a modeling procedures manual and accompanying software that will verify and document that structural models follow modeling best practices. In Phase I, ATA will compile best practices currently used by the shipyards, combine those with general FE best practices, and identify opportunities for process improvement. ATA will select several submarine structures for study and then conduct planning and preliminary feasibility demonstrations for the procedures manual, software development, and design tool validation analysis and testing to be conducted in Phases II and III.

award_title: Verification and Optimization of Advanced Finite Element Modeling Techniques for Complex Submarine Hull Structures
research_keywords: submarine,Methodology,Structure,FEA,Criteria,hull,pressure,tapers
abstract: Advances in finite element analysis (FEA) techniques have spurred debate in the Navy design community regarding the value of higher fidelity models with advanced element formulations in submarine pressure hull design. Higher complexity models can increase model accuracy, but the increased effort required to create higher fidelity models results in decreasing added value as subsequent levels of refinement are added. Cardinal Engineering proposes developing a design tool which dictates best practices for modeling and analyzing complex submarine pressure hull structures. The design tool will establish modeling criteria, backed by empirical data, to create cost-effective, technically accurate analytical models. The design tool will be developed through a comprehensive analysis and testing effort focused on specific geometries known to have introduced controversy between the design yards and the Navy during the design cycle. The geometries chosen will be examined computationally with an array of modeling methods of increasing levels of complexity. The analysis results will be compared to test data in order to provide assurance regarding the level of accuracy achieved by the analysis. Ultimately, the agreement between test and analysis will be used to establish the criteria defined in the design tool.

award_title: Verification and Optimization of Advanced Finite Element Modeling Techniques for Complex Submarine Hull Structures
research_keywords: Verification Testing,Complex Geometry,Standard Techniques for Finite Element Modeling of Complex Structures,Stress Concentrations,FINITE ELEMENT MODELING,FEM Guidelines and Procedures,Submarine Hull Structure,Structural Analys
abstract: In modern submarine design, the effort to produce more efficient, lighter and less expensive structures drives the analysis beyond simple historic empirical techniques towards a higher reliance on finite element modeling (FEM) analysis. The problem increases in complexity with the choice of FEM modeling techniques varying widely between different organizations in their choice of criteria such as element formulation, mesh density, assumptions, and boundary conditions. To solve this problem MTech will develop a Finite Element Manual to be used by NAVSEA and the Shipyards as a design tool to ensure FEM techniques are consistent and appropriate for the design detail. MTech will combine conventional techniques with innovative solutions to reduce US Navy cost and schedule. The MTech design tool will ensure equivalent tools are used, document common knowledge of best practices, provide accurate guidance and provide test verified techniques all while providing the analyst maximum flexibility.

award_title: Verification and Optimization of Advanced Finite Element Modeling Techniques for Complex Submarine Hull Structures
research_keywords: boundary conditions,element type,Manual,design tool,FINITE ELEMENT MODELING,Submarine Hull Structures
abstract: We M&J Engineering, Inc. (Please note that M&J Engineering is a certified SBA 8A firm since April 8, 2015.), along with our research partner, Thorton Tomasetti-Weidlinger Applied Science, propose to review current modeling standards, plan the development of new standards, create prototype software that implements and automates reviews of FEM model compliance with the standards, and begin to investigate new technology for model review and quality control. The new standards will address the highly detailed FEM models characteristic of complex submarine structures, whose geometry is represented by solid, rather than shell, elements. The standard or new design manual will define a set of parameters which can be used by shipyards when performing FEA. . The goal for the manual will be to provided specific directions regarding how complex geometries will be modeled. The manual will be validated against physical models

award_title: Verification and Optimization of Advanced Finite Element Modeling Techniques for Complex Submarine Hull Structures
research_keywords: Modeling Metrics,artificial neural network,Complementary Software Tool,Finite Element Analysis,Best Practices,Design Guide,Physical Testing,Submarine Hull Structure
abstract: The finite element method has been well-established for modern structural design and analysis. However, significant modeling choices must still be made in trying to achieve answers accurate enough for engineering decisions, but without unwarranted computational effort. This is especially true for high value complex submarine hull structures that are needed to protect Navy warfighters and enable successful missions. Using a rational series of models of varying fidelity, M4 Engineering will develop a comprehensive design guide of best practices and their temporal and spatial regions of applicability that can be utilized by the Navy and its contractors during their design and analysis activities. A comprehensive manual set giving specifications that will standardize submarine hull structure modeling best practices will be created. Artificial intelligence methods will be used to create a complementary software tool to provide an automated means for giving detailed modeling recommendations for specific designs. The design recommendations and the process for developing them will be validated via a companion experimental program that will be planned partially during Phase I for execution during later project phases.

award_title: Development of Explosive Feedstock for Commercial-off-the-Shelf (COTS) 3D Printers
research_keywords: 3D Printing,additive manufacturing,Explosives,powder bed fusion,microencapsulation,polymers,Binder Jetting,powder characterization
abstract: Traditional manufacturing methods for producing warheads, propellants, and pyrotechnic systems are timely and costly. Additive manufacturing (AM) approaches offer one path of alternative manufacturing technologies. Among various technologies, powder bed fusion (PBF) is one promising approach. Hewlett Packards Multi-Jet Fusion printers utilize a unique PBF process that presents a desirable solution to the objective of producing energetics parts by COTS technologies. Successful solids processing in a COTS powder bed fusion system requires very specific material properties, both in terms of powder handling properties as well as the associated inking/binder system. This proposal will focus specifically on nylon based PBX systems, for which HP existing multi-jet inking systems are currently optimized. New processing techniques will be explored to improve material characteristics of AM feedstocks, namely microencapsulation of colloidal HMX by spray drying and emulsion polymerization routes. Select optimal formulations will be chosen for final printing of a small scale printed explosive on an HP Jet Fusion machine, or related development test bed. Associated performance, safety characteristics, and cost analysis of final printed parts of these developed formulations will be assessed, against existing production technologies.

award_title: Development of Explosive Feedstock for Commercial-off-the-Shelf (COTS) 3D Printers
research_keywords: Filament,Propellant,Feedstock,TPE,explosive,pyrotechnic,ETPE,Nitramine
abstract: Capco will leverage its extensive explosives capabilities to develop flexible thermoplastic filaments consisting of energetic thermoplastic elastomers (ETPEs) mixed with high solid loadings of nitramines, pyrotechnics and strong oxidizers. Capco will also develop energetic filaments consisting of inert thermoplastic elastomers (TPEs) loaded with oxidizers for propellant applications. The developed filaments will be designed and tested for compatibility with commercial-off-the-shelf, FDM 3D printing systems. Emphasis will be placed on filament durability and flexibility, extrudability, adhesion, and cohesion. The best performing developed explosive filaments will be utilized for the additive manufacturing of energetic grains during this effort. Optimized filament formulations will be designed with the goal of meeting insensitive munition requirements and comparative testing with currently fielded U.S. Navy formulations. Filaments and test prints comprised of energetic materials will be delivered to NSWC-IH for evaluation at the end of the Phase I effort. Orbital ATK will provide Capco with ETPEs and consultation for this effort.

award_title: Development of energetic feedstock for COTS additive manufacturing
research_keywords: Propellant,pyrotechnic,additive manufacturing,3D Printing,energetic,Elastomer,explosive,binder
abstract: Lynntech proposes to produce an affordable energetic feedstock for use with commercial, off the shelf additive manufacturing tools. Lynntech will continue to use the traditional Navy technique of an elastomeric binder composite with an energetic material such as RDX. The traditional binder, HTPB has long been understood to provide desirable mechanical characteristics but is non-energetic reducing overall formulation performance. Energetic polymer chemistries also exist, and some of these provide similar mechanical performance to that of cured HTPB. Lynntech will explore these chemistries, as well as previously unexploited chemistries, to develop an optimized binder formulation and protocol for use in additive manufacturing processes to be tested during this Phase I effort.

award_title: Blended and Advanced Decision GUI Environment for Reasoning Support (BADGERS)
research_keywords: maintenance visualizations,Graphical User Interface (GUI),Decision Support System (DSS),Ecological Interface Design (EID),Cognitive Systems Engineering (CSE),integrated workspace,rule-based knowledge
abstract: Achieving operational availability of mission systems is challenging for naval shipboard maintainers, who analyze large amounts of maintenance data to determine how and when to address equipment repair and replacement needs. Current data is available through a set of disparate sources that insufficiently portray the criticality of correcting the malfunction or reveal interrelationships and overall operational impacts. This makes it difficult to efficiently and effectively select, prioritize, and schedule future maintenance activities. To address this, we propose to design and demonstrate a Blended Advanced Decision GUI Environment for Reasoning Support (BADGERS). The BADGERS decision-support system (DSS) will enable shipboard maintainers to analyze system status and predicted malfunctions, evaluate high-level mission impacts, and efficiently make maintenance decisions through intuitive and innovative data visualizations. This system will provide maintainers with an integrated workspace that provides observability for fixing the issue through rule-based maintenance knowledge, as well as ecological graphical user interfaces (GUIs) to assess the operational impacts and validate root causes of predicted system failures. We will take an iterative Cognitive Systems Engineering (CSE) approach and presented within a software Prototyping and Demonstration Environment (PDE) to allow for rapid integration to Navy systems.

award_title: DELPHI: Decision Engine and Learned Prognostics Human-machine Interfaces for Shipboard Maintenance
research_keywords: PHM,adaptive UI,HMI,Decision support system,visual programming,CBM+,Stochastic Simulation,Planning
abstract: For Condition Based Maintenance Plus (CBM+) and Prognostics and Health Management (PHM) programs to help the Strike Group (SG) Operational availability (Ao) and logistics efficiency, the Navy needs an effective decision support system (DSS). Visualization of the PHM data will enable the decision makers to easily interpret the results of the DSS and make decisions that are more consistent with maximizing Ao. An efficient data visualization tool should support interactive exploration/understanding of DSS recommendations and alternatives. A well-designed visualization system will adapt to the requirements of the user, expose patterns, trends, correlations, and provide multi-tiered results to support advanced decision-making. Intelligent Automation, Inc., and its collaborators propose to develop DELPHI, a Decision Support Engine and Learned Prognostics Human-machine Interfaces for Shipboard Maintenance. The key innovation of this proposal is to develop a data fusion center comprising of the following four components (1) Visual simulation based modeling tool (what-if scenarios); and (2) Stochastic optimization engine (to compute optimal policies) (3) Visualization engine (to optimally present context-aware information);and (4) Advanced visualization interfaces (responsive software that adapts to different interfaces). The first two push the state-of-the-art in decision support capabilities, whereas the other two improve the visualization.

award_title: 3D Image from Sensor Fusion
research_keywords: Sonar,UUV,video,video enhancement,AMNS,Structure from Motion,ROV
abstract: This proposal addresses the issue of improving operator-based mine identification for the Airborne Mine Neutralization System (AMNS) and other Unmanned Underwater Vehicle (UUV) platforms. There is a need for a near real-time software tool to generate 3-D structure using multiple looks from onboard video and sonar sensors. Aret Associates (Aret) proposes to address this solicitations requirements by developing and delivering EnhancerPro 3D, a near real-time, modular software tool based on Arets existing EnhancerPro tool. EnhancerPro 3-D provides Video Enhancement (VE) in turbid environments, IMU exploitation, when available, and Structure from Motion (SfM) 3-D Model Generation for video and sonar.

award_title: 3D Image from Sensor Fusion
research_keywords: Automated Sensor Calibration,Target Identification,Computer Vision,3D reconstruction,virtual 3D model,Structure from Motion,Real time processing,Data Fusion
abstract: Critical missions performed by the US Navy require accurate and efficient classification of objects in underwater optical video. This task is performed by a trained operator; however, the optical data is generally of poor quality (low contrast and/or low illumination), and when performed during missions the real-time video stream cannot be paused or rewound. These challenges can cause high-confidence object classification to take a considerably longer time than is desirable. On this effort, Toyon Research Corporation proposes to develop efficient algorithms implemented in a software application tool that will perform accurate 3D reconstruction of objects in underwater video. By leveraging and optimizing novel in situ sensor calibration algorithms, incremental sparse bundle adjustment, and efficient 3D reconstruction algorithms, the developed software will form accurate 3D models, display the models to the operator, and update the models as optical data from varying perspectives is collected. Furthermore, the algorithms will fuse the optical data with existing sonar data for increased accuracy and efficiency.

award_title: 1550nm Laser Module Assembly for Wide Aperture Array Sonar
research_keywords: High Power,laser oscillator,narrow linewidth,Low noise,acoustic sensing,coherent communications.,lidar
abstract: This Phase I proposal is to design and demonstrate a lower cost replacement Laser Module Assembly (LMA) for the Lightweight Wide Aperture Array (LWWAA) acoustic sensor system. We believe that our Virtual Ring laser Oscillator can offer a high-power, ultra stable, low phase noise and low-RIN 1550nm fiber laser that can meet and even surpass the currently deployed LMA based on the 1.3 micron Non-Planar Ring Oscillator (NPRO) at a lower cost, weight, power consumption and with better reliability.

award_title: Application of Telecommunications Laser Standards to Sonar Sensor Receivers
research_keywords: Optical Source,Semiconductor Laser,Reference cavity
abstract: The overall objective of this project is to develop an integrated, rugged, inexpensive cavity stabilized semiconductor laser which is based on typical telecommunications grade DFB or DBR semiconductor lasers for sonar applications. The approach is to take a cavity stabilized laser architecture that currently fits in a standard 19-inch rack and fit it into a standard telecoms grade 14-pin butterfly type package. To achieve this, a miniaturized version of a stabilized cavity will be developed that is suited for integration in such package in robustness, cost and form factor.

award_title: Ultra-Low Noise 1550 nm Laser Module Assembly for Sonar Sensor Receivers
research_keywords: semiconductor lasers,Laser Module Assembly,self-injection locking,LWWAA,1550 nm lasers,RIN,Whispering Gallery Mode Resonators,
abstract: OEwaves offers to advance the state of 1550 nm laser technology, and design and develop an LMA that will support current Lightweight Wide Aperture Array (LWWAA) operation while lowering the modules cost. We propose to use self-injection locking of a 1550 nm (C-band) semiconductor laser chip heterogeneously integrated with a high quality factor (Q) whispering gallery mode (WGM) resonator to improve the spectral properties of the laser and generate narrow linewidth light at telecom wavelengths, in a chip scale form factor. Additionally, this approach will result in a reduced cost packaged device. WGM resonators are useful for laser stabilization since they provide very high-Q and high finesse along with very small size and high immunity to environmental and field perturbations, such as temperature, vibration and acceleration. The solution proposed by OEwaves is to extend the design of our existing commercial laser architecture to produce a ruggedized laser package with lower RIN and higher power output.

award_title: Oil-less Deep Fryer
research_keywords: safety,food,oil,Frying,submarine,Galley,Grease,cooking
abstract: Triton Systems, Inc. proposes an oil-free fryer that will provide food quality superior to what is produced in a deep fat fryer without the use of cooking oil. Our system will provide the required throughput within available power and space constraints. The system will allow flexibility in placement in the submarine galley and will be designed to meet submarine specific usability concerns.

award_title: Oil-less Cooking Deep Fat Fryer (DFF) Replacement
research_keywords: Oil less Deep Fat Dryer,Navy Standard Core Menu,Deep Fat Fryer,Submarine Galley,jet impingement
abstract: There is an opportunity to develop a new solution for a reliable oil-less cooking deep fat fryer (DFF) replacement in the Ohio Replacement (OR) galley design that uses hot air jet impingement technology. The high heat transfer rate of hot air impingement has the potential to produce high volume throughput results with the best quality. Texas Research Institute Austin, Inc., (TRI/Austin) proposes to demonstrate the feasibility of an oil-less DFF replacement cooking appliance for Navy submarines through the use of high speed air impingement heat transfer techniques. TRI/Austin will establish technical feasibility by demonstrating that the oil-less deep fat fryer cooking appliance will meet the operational and environmental requirements. The technical hurdles will be addressed with laboratory environment testing and performance characterization through experimentation. The supportability, safety, and human factors concerns will be addressed along with estimates of size, weight, cost, and performance. The components will be tested to critical submarine vibrations and motion as outlined in MIL-STD-167/1 Type I equipment. A vibration scan will be performed through the frequency ranges at different input levels in all three axes. This will identify problem areas, if any, that will need to be addressed during Phase II.

award_title: Oil-less Cooking Deep Fat Fryer (DFF) Replacement
research_keywords: acrylamide,deep fat frying,aqueous potassium carbonate,Inductive Heating
abstract: Deep Springs Technology (DST) proposes a novel solid state cooking system to replace the legacy deep fat fryer currently aboard the Ohio Class Submarines. The proposed solid state system is consistent with requirements of the Navy and has significant advantages over other cooking technologies. Deployment of the proposed system will eliminate fire hazards associated with cooking oil; eliminate the need for aqueous potassium carbonate safety system to put out grease fires; reduce food preparation costs; reduce health risks associated with fried foods; and save space that would otherwise be devoted to carrying oil.

award_title: Broadband Sonar Digital Signal Processing (DSP) for Undersea Marine Life and Hazard Detection &amp; Classification
research_keywords: Broadband sonar processing,SURTASS,marine mammal vocalization,ACOUSTIC INTERCEPT,Auditory Cortex,Acoustic Classification,Continuous Active Sonar,marine mammal detection
abstract: Authorizations provided to the Navy for operation of the SURTASS LFA/CLFA active source require specific measures to be taken to avoid harming marine mammals. This generally includes searching the water column within 2 km of the SURTASS ship for the presence of marine mammals before going active. The current workhorse for this is the High Frequency Marine Mammal Monitoring (HF/M3) sonar. However, as the HF/M3 ages a replacement is necessary. A capable and cost-effective replacement can be provided by a COTS hardware solution that uses high-frequency broadband signal processing. In-Depth Engineering Corporation proposes the Wideband High-frequency Aquatic Life Echolocation System (WHALES)an innovative, low-cost, broadband, passive and active acoustic detection and classification system providing full spatial coverage over a wide frequency range. WHALES will be able to detect all source modulation types, including acoustic intercept sources, and will include an automated acoustic classification capability based on a model of the mammalian primary auditory cortex. The set of passive receive arrays will be paired with an active omnidirectional broadband projector operating around 25 kHz, well above the frequency band of the SURTASS system. The active source will enable detection and localization of non-vocalizing marine mammals, navigational hazards, divers, and UUVs.

award_title: Active Acoustic Monitoring System (AAMS) for marine life and hazard detection through integration of the Subsurface-threat Detection Sonar Network bro
research_keywords: and maritime obstacle detection.,Digital Signal Processing for Sonar target tracking and classification,autonomous detection of marine mammals,Acoustic Transducer for Active Sonar,Marine Mammal Detection and Tracking,
abstract: Scientific Solutions, Inc. (SSI), teamed with BAE Systems and Southall Environmental Associates, Inc. (SEA), proposes to investigate the feasibility of using commercially available active sonar to autonomously identify and track marine mammals from transiting SURTASS-LFA surface ships at ranges out to and beyond 2,000 yards. Active sonar has been proven effective to detect and track marine animals under various conditions and system configurations. The logical next step is to establish the capability, conditions and configuration that would overlap with the marine mammal detection requirement provided by the current system. Then establish a route for the evolution of the HFM3 software to provide mechanisms to track, classify, and provide the ability to deliver actionable high fidelity information for the watch stander. This will be done by integrating the commercially available sonar head with the broadband track-before-alert algorithms and software SSI and BAE Systems have developed for the identification and tracking of divers and unmanned underwater vehicles in a harbor environment. These algorithms and software provide processes to improve the capability to rank and modify the classifying information. By training the classification engine database we continually evolve the classification process.

award_title: Computerized Psychological Techniques to Teach Knowledge and Increase Skill Levels Quickly
research_keywords: Brain State,accelerated learning,Neuro Linguistic Programming,mindfulness,flow,Psychological state,Adaptive training,Physiological Measurement
abstract: Optimized training for advanced Navy systems requires a notable change in the learning paradigma training paradigm in which the training system assists the learner in an effort to enter and maintain an optimal brain learning state. The Curriculum for Accelerated Learning through Mindfulness (CALM) solution provides a pre-training mindfulness module that prepares the sailor for learning and a methodology to assess the flow state of learner throughout a contextually relevant naval learning experience using psychophysiological measures. The CALM solution includes the BaseCamp in which a trainees physiological state baseline is established, a Mindfulness Module that prepares the sailors brain for optimized and accelerated learning, the Testbed for Intelligent Tracking and Real-time Assessment of Trainee Engagement (TITRATE) physiological measurement suite and the Adaptive Driver to Augment Performance and Training (ADAPT) API. CALM addresses the Navys identified need for a computerized innovative interactive visual, audio, and kinesthetic training program that increases the speed of learning, comprehension, and performance aboard ships to better cross-train sailors quickly.

award_title: Computerized Psychological Techniques to Teach Knowledge and Increase Skill Levels Quickly
research_keywords: Performance,Enhanced training techniques,Human brain,neuro-linguistic programming,anchoring,subconscious,retained comprehension,learning speed
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Result in immediate mental/physical state of a sailor to attend to readiness to engage arms from any other state of un-readiness. In essence, to increase sailor learning speed, comprehension, and performance. This is done through human behavior/development techniques.DESCRIPTION: While resting or engaging in recreational activities, etc. there is always the chance of having to be in the ready-to-engage state, whereby the individual would then be at their station and be in the ultimate state to both access and apply their training with the weapon of choice. Their ability to switch those decisions from that point forward are highly dependent upon their neurological and physical state.

award_title: Biologic SONAR and Processing Network Improvement for Situational Awareness
research_keywords: High Frequency Sonar,machine learning,mammalian sonar,echolocation of bats and dolphin,Littorals
abstract: The ASSETT Team, comprised of ASSETT, Inc., Texas A&Ms Dr. Smotherman and MNW Associates, intends to develop a machine learning process to improve performance of high frequency sonar. Our added learning process incorporating knowledge base, learning mode, and feedback from enhanced monitoring will enable the sonar to emulate the echolocation behavior of bats and dolphin. Dolphin have no problem in shallow littorals with complex bathymetry, non iso-velocity, and non-isotropic environments that challenge current high frequency sonar effectiveness. The ASSETT Team will apply mammalian adaptive behavior to improve operational dependability of high frequency sonars in these challenging environments.

award_title: Towed Array Capstan Cover
research_keywords: capstan surface,replaceable,coating,cover,High Friction
abstract: Many current submarine systems use the OA-9070B or E capstan towed array deployment and retrieval system. The OA-9070 is dependent on friction to generate marginally adequate deployment force to push the array through the friction inherent in the aft rollers. Repeated deployment and retraction cycles smooth the capstan surface, reducing the coefficient of friction to unacceptable levels.Physical Sciences, Inc. Materials Systems Division is teaming with Granite State Manufacturing to provide NAV-SEA with a high friction, high cycle life coating that will significantly increase the capstan-to-array friction and reduce the inspection and maintenance requirements of the OA-9070 system. The coating will be easily installed in-situ without removing the capstan hub and will function in the demanding military maritime environment. The coating can be removed and replaced as necessary during standard refits of the overall system.During the Phase I effort, PSI and GSM will demonstrate the array-capstan friction achievable with the approach under a range of temperature and contamination conditions. In future work, the approach will be rapidly transitioned to full functional testing, optimizing both the coating friction and the installation method.

award_title: Improved Coating Material for SSN Capstan Rim
research_keywords: In situ repair,Lower total ownership cost,Towed array handling,Reduced deployment failure,Increased friction,Urethane,Longer life,Capstan coating
abstract: ZKxKZ proposes to identify and demonstrate several new material solutions that will upgrade the performance of the surface coating of capstans used in the towed array handling systems of SSNs. Candidate surfacing materials will be selected with the objective of demonstrating a 40% increase in friction coefficient between the coating and towed array, compared to the current baseline of shot peened metal. Material samples of each candidate will be prepared, then tested to measure friction coefficient, wear behavior, adhesion to the CuNi substrate, long term stability after exposure to Isopar and saltwater, and other measurements identified by the Navy during PI. In parallel we will compare several alternative methods for installing the coating on the capstan, either while the capstan remains inside the SSNs ballast tank, or after the capstan has been removed from the SSN. Each application approach will be evaluated for the methods ability to be applied uniformly with a coating thickness of between 0.0005 and 0.02-inch, and, when being applied with the capstan inside the tank, to complete the application of the coating replacement procedure within the timeframe of a single dive by repair technicians.

award_title: Communication Plug for Submarine Hull (ComPlug4SH) System
research_keywords: CDT,Networking,Data acquisition,fiber optics,Interfaces,communication systems,Ultrasound communication,through hull communication
abstract: To provide the U.S. Navy an innovative undersea interface for hull penetration systems that will support long duration communication with external sensors, American GNC Corporation (AGNC) and the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (RPI) are proposing the Communication Plug for Submarine Hull (ComPlug4SH) System. The ComPlug4SH systems ultimate goal is to increase safety when launching probes to collect sea data (Conductivity, Temperature, and Depth) by providing a bridge between the submarines external environment and hull interior. The ComPlug4SH will allow to close the mechanical launcher structure (such as SUBSAFE systems and Non-Seawater Piping) while keeping a data communication channel through a hulls metallic plug, which will also be used to isolate the submarine exterior from the interior. The ComPlug4SH compiles State-of-the-Art (SOTA) technologies which include: (a) size, weight, power, and cost (SWaP-C) optimized processing board and internal communication interfaces; (b) robust data (and power if needed) transferal through barrier; (c) external interfaces to SOTA networking systems; and (d) local processing that enables optional complementary operations such as self-diagnostics, control, and monitoring.

award_title: Adaptive, Multi-Energy Computed Tomography for Large Additively Manufactured Parts
research_keywords: X-ray computed tomography (CT),NON-DESTRUCTIVE EVALUATION (NDE),additive manufacturing
abstract: Additive manufacturing (AM) technology, through its unique layer-by-layer, freeform fabrication capability, has the potential to reduce supply chain issues and enable new components with superior performance at reduced cost for the Navy. Although the development of metal AM techniques has made significant advances in recent years, unique processing and material development issues will require the use non-destructive evaluation (NDE) for critical AM fabricated parts. X-ray Computed Tomography (CT) has been demonstrated as a valuable tool in identifying porosity, cracks, and delamination in metal AM fabricated parts. While commercial off-the-shelf X-ray CT systems have been found suitable for NDE of small (10s of mm) AM parts, for larger AM parts (100s  1000s mm) no such X-ray CT systems exist. This proposal addresses NDE requirements for powder-bed fusion (PBF) and direct energy deposition (DED) AM fabricated parts ranging in size from 100s mm to 1000s mm scale and for materials ranging (in density) from aluminum to tungsten. In Phase I we will develop a conceptual design for the Adaptive, Multi-Energy Computed Tomography system for Large Additively Manufactured Parts (AMECT-LAMP), and demonstrate feasibility with analytical modeling and testing. In Phase II we will develop a prototype AMECT-LAMP, and experimentally verify its performance.

award_title: Plug-and-play Analytical Framework for Distributed Structured and Unstructured Data Sets for Condition Based Maintenance Plus (CBM+)
research_keywords: Hadoop Cluster,elastic,PHM,CBM+,Big Data framework
abstract: Prior to the advent of Big Data and the availability of affordable digital data storage, organizations would typically gather only the data from system logs that could be immediately identified as useful. With modern Big Data Collection, the focus has shifted to collecting and storing as much data as possible; even if that data is not immediately identified as useful to the human eye. The intention is to allow predictive algorithms determine which data is useful and to have a massive stash of data in its native format in digital storage forever, ultimately producing end product reports or notifications to the end user. Our true innovation for this effort will be introducing the hadoop cluster framework as the main data center application vice traditional data center approaches that are human-deterministic. The development approach is to oversimplify Plug and Play functionality through: reuse of native interfaces, cost effective scalability, and preservation of stored data via replicated nodes of the hadoop cluster. The resulting automated data repository will enable new non-traditional predictive algorithms to be developed and its results presented to shipboard users while underway and shore site users for specific analysis as required.

award_title: Removable and Maintainable Future Hull Arrays
research_keywords: arrays,,Composites,Sonar
abstract: PEI is proposing to design and develop a composite frame structure which will serve as the foundation and means for easy assembly and removal of either array sections, modules or individual vertical block staves (VBS). PEI will develop structural technologies for building and installing these large conformal arrays to the exterior hull. PEI technology will be expanded to allow conformal sonar arrays on other parts of the ship that will create new opportunities for use of bow and sail structure volumes while improving sonar sensor performance. PEI design will allow easy installation and removal of array sections during the Extended Dry-dock Selected Refit Availability (EDSRA) of a submarine. PEI design of this framework would facilitate the attachment and removal of array sections (modules and VBS) using interlocking features and fasteners. In addition, would also be modular so that the array size could be increased if required. Composite materials are inherently corrosion resistant and can also offer acoustic transparency so as to have minimal impact on sonar performance. Also, since framework and VBS back panels will be designed using composites, the contours/shapes can be complex and features can be integrated, reducing assembly costs.

award_title: Submarine Shipboard Power Unbalance Correction
research_keywords: submarine,Phase Unbalance Corrector
abstract: Commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS) electrical equipment is much less expensive than equipment specifically designed for military use, and provides faster integration of advanced capabilities. Since COTS equipment is typically single-phase, it is distributed between the three power lines to balance the current loading. However, it can be difficult to dynamically balance the currents to the 3% required by MIL-STD-1399/300B, since this depends on the current draws of the individual pieces of equipment at different times.A Power Unbalance Corrector (PUC) can compensate for these dynamic changes, and balance the currents between each phase. One way to design the PUC would be to take in the full power, balanced between the three phases, and deliver it to match each of the phase loads. This PUC would operate at 200 A per line, and would be large, expensive, and inefficient.Instead, there is a better approach. Diversified Technologies, Inc. (DTI) proposes an innovative approach to develop a PUC that will be a fraction of the size, cost, and weight of such a system.

award_title: Submarine Shipboard Power Unbalance Correction
research_keywords: Delta Power Phase Balance,Current Unbalance,Power Phase Balancing,power conditioning,Submarine Power Distribution,Power Unbalance Correction,Voltage Unbalance
abstract: The Navys submarine fleet uses 3 phase delta power per MIL-STD-1399/300B. The power distribution system operates most effectively when loading per phase is balanced within 3%. COTS data processing equipment used by the fleet typically needs single phase power, so balancing is achieved by manually assigning COTS items to power phases in a manner that equalizes phase loading. Assigning COTS items to power phases is imperfect and cannot provide load balancing in dynamic shipboard environments where loads on COTS change as the mission changes. A Power Unbalance Corrector (PUC) that automatically corrects unbalance would provide superior operational results. The proposed rack mounted 40 kW PUC accepts power from the submarines power distribution system and uses it to power multiple racks. The PUC automatically compensates up to 12% unbalance presenting a balanced load to the submarines power distribution system. PDAs proposed PUC implementation introduces a novel Bidirectional Inverter circuit that passes the balanced part of the power directly from the source to the load; only the unbalanced power needs to be converted. This approach is more than 95% efficient and provides size, weight, reliability, and cost advantages and meets the SBIR requirements.

award_title: Power Electronic Based Active Current Balancing System
research_keywords: power electronics,phase balancing,High power density,High efficiency,GaN,Navy power system
abstract: Unbalanced loading of electrical generators can increase system losses, reduce generator lifetime, and increase the frequency of spurious circuit breaker tripping. Current technology to balance loads include EVRs and UPSs, which are must too large and heavy for application in navy submarines. Therefore, the Navy is in need of more flexible and power dense solutions such that timely equipment changes and upgrades are possible. Mainstream Engineering proposes an active power filter (APF) based solution that is 19 inch rack mountable, can balance >12% current (power) unbalance on a 40 kW load, and occupies

award_title: Tunable, Rapid, Electronically Controlled X-band Filter
research_keywords: Interference Suppression,bandstop filters,Affordable filters,X-Band notch filters,Tunable Filters,Agile filters,Fast tuning
abstract: To address the Navy need for fast, affordable, and reliable tunable notch filters at X-band frequencies, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a new Tunable, Rapid, Electronically Controlled X-band (T-REX) notch filter, based on a resonating RF structure utilizing ferroelectric-based capacitors for ultrafast-frequency tuning. The innovation in the resonating RF structure provides a large tunable range by using voltage-variable barium strontium titanate (BST) capacitors to quickly (40dB location within the 8 GHz to 12 GHz range, minimal passband insertion loss (

award_title: Affordable, Fast-Tunable, Notch Filters at X-Band and Higher Frequencies
research_keywords: Low Cost,High Speed,Reconfigurable Microwave Filter,tunable microwave filter,Interference Mitigation,Anit-Jam,X-band filter
abstract: Indiana Microelectronics is proposing to conduct a feasibility study to two types of affordable, high speed, tunable notch filters in the X-Band and above. The first technology is based upon substrate integrated resonators tuned with solid state varactors. This type of filter technology is anticipated to produce a moderate quality factor while maintaining sub-microsecond tuning speeds. The second filter technology leverages High-Q MEMS RF tuner based filters. This filter technology will produce very High-Q performance at the sacrifice of tuning speeds. The results of the feasibility study will provide the Navy with well-defined tradeoffs for tunable microwave filters in the X-Band and above. A cost analysis of both filter technologies will also provide the Navy a means of determining affordability for use in next generation microwave systems. Furthermore, Indiana Microelectronics will work with Lockheed Martin, our transition partner, to define filter interface specifications and performance specifications to enable in-system testing of the Phase II filter prototypes.

award_title: Submarine Shipboard Power Supply Bridge
research_keywords: power bridge,Hold up converter,submarine,Bridge converter
abstract: Submarines have two independent electrical generators to provide continuous power to critical loads. These generators are not coordinated nor synchronized, so switching between them can cause a brief power interruption to the loads. Conventional uninterruptible power supplies can maintain power to critical loads during this switching, but they are much larger and heavier than required, since they are designed to operate for minutes at a time. A small, short-duration supply tailored to this switch-over requirement could replace these conventional supplies, freeing up substantial amounts of space and weight for other capability improvements.Diversified Technologies, Inc. (DTI) proposes to design, build, qualify, and field a short-duration Power Bridge Converter (PBC) meeting the size, power, power-quality, and reliability required for submarine deployment. The system will provide 40 kW of power during a 100 millisecond interruption. It will also limit the inrush current upon reapplication of power, as required by MIL-STD-1399/300B. Our proposed PBC design uses commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS) components, and can be built from parts that are available today. Keys to the PCBs performance are the high-reliability electrolytic capacitors for energy storage, the circuit architecture, silicon carbide switching transistors, the EMI filter design, and switches that limit inrush current.

award_title: Submarine Shipboard Power Supply Bridge
research_keywords: Power Supply Bridge,Capacitor Based UPS,Submarine Power Distribution,Power Interrupt,power conditioner,uninterruptable power supply,BUS Transfer Switch,BUS Transfer Ride Through
abstract: The Navys submarine fleet uses 3 phase delta power per MIL-STD-1399/300B. The power distribution system is driven from two power busses and automatically transfer loads between the busses when one loses power. During bus transfer, a 70  100 msec power interrupt may occur which can create upset in the loads. PDAs proposed rack mounted 40 kW Power Supply Bridge (PSB) is installed between the power distribution system and the loads to provide power to the loads during the interrupt period hence preventing upset in the loads. The PSB uses a novel Bidirectional Inverter circuit to convert DC energy stored in a capacitor bank to AC to power to the load when power is interrupted, and to efficiently charge the capacitors when power is normal. Precise Sensing & Control is included to direct the operation of the Bidirectional Inverter and the remainder of the PSB circuits in a manner that blocks backflow of current to the power distribution system during interrupt, or excessive inrush currents from the power distribution system at any time. The Bidirectional Inverter approach meets SBIR requirements and provides size, weight, efficiency, reliability, and cost characteristics superior to other alternatives.

company: P C KRAUSE AND ASSOCIATES INC
award_title: Submarine Shipboard Power Supply Bridge
research_keywords: dc/ac power conversion,UPS,High-Power Density,Wide-Bandgap,Energy Storage,Converter
abstract: The objective of this effort is to demonstrate the feasibility of a 40 kW UPS with at least 100ms of holdup time, integrated into a standard 19 inch rack mount enclosure with 4U (7 inch) height, and designed to meet electrical and mechanical/shock specifications required for naval shipboard application. Traditional UPS applications are typically not optimized for weight and volume, and utilize bulky lead-acid batteries that provide significantly more energy storage than is needed for naval bus-transfer holdup applications. The proposed converter utilizes wide-bandgap semiconductors and high power density energy storage to enable a significant reduction in weight and volume compared to existing shipboard UPS solutions. The proposed UPS will provide continuous power to critical loads during bus transfers and will reduce load inrush on the generation system following a bus-transfer event.

award_title: Light-field Processing Unit for Extreme Multi-View Displays
research_keywords: light-field displays,ar/vr,SWAP-C,Graphics Processing Unit,radiance image,Multi-view rendering,Parallel Hogel Rendering Optimization
abstract: The ability to resolve depth within a scene whether natural or artificial improves our spatial understanding of the scene and as a result reduces the cognitive load accompanying the analysis and collaboration on complex tasks.A light-field display projects 3D aerial imagery that is visible to the unaided eye (without glasses or head tracking) and allows for perspective correct visualization within the displays projection volume. Binocular disparity, occlusion, specular highlights and gradient shading, and other expected depth cues are correct from the viewers perspective as in the natural real-world light-field.Light-field radiance image rendering is the process of rendering all the perspective views present in the light-field from a 3D model regardless of viewer position. To implement multi-view rendering with a GPU requires that the host application dispatch a render pass for each viewpoint (micro-lens) required for the projection system; a light-field projection system may contain thousands of micro-lenses. Ultimately, the size, weight and power requirements (SWaP) requirements of a light-field display are largely a factor of radiance image computation. By removing the OS, CPUs and other PC system components, and refactoring the GPUs to render hogels in parallel, a more SWaP efficient light-field/multi-view rendering engine can be developed.

award_title: A Holographic and Light-field Processor for Extreme Multi-View Displays
research_keywords: Holographic Display,Holographic Optical Element,Hologram,diffractive optical element,Hogel,3D display,plenoptic display,Light Field Display
abstract: Under this SBIR effort, Holochip will develop its Rainfall Engine holographic processor, an advanced light-field processing unit (LfPU) for real-time synthetic light-field generation and parallel multi-view rendering in AEGIS Display Systems. The Rainfall Engine is capable of creating 3D visuals in real-time for use in plenoptic projectors, holographic and other light-field displays. It is a host application based on the graphics processor unit (GPU) and has significant advantages over conventional serial and cluster rendering approaches, including improvement in the display update rate while providing reduction in render latency, lag, and SWaP-C (size, weight, power and cost). Additionally, the Rainfall Engine will reduce the size, weight, power and cooling of the required computation cluster, as well as the number of computation components and requirements for long-term maintenance and support. Holochip will refine the LfPU architecture and describe the rendering benefits, paradigms and the associated SWaP-C reductions of the Rainfall Engine compared to off-the-shelf computation. Holochip will define the acceptable display list, draw operations, and describe rendering restrictions or limitations. Feasibility will be established by modeling of the 3D real-time visualization refresh rates as compared with current 2D real-time visualization refresh rates.

award_title: Food Service Integrated Barcode and Inventory Management System
research_keywords: Food Service Management System (FSM),inventory management,Food Service,Database,Logistics,barcode,Scanner
abstract: The Navy has the requirement for managing the inventory and safety of its food service products. Cybernet participated in Trident Warrior in 2009 to perform experimentation's with its ruggedized tablet platform. During this effort, we interviewed galley personnel to understand their requirements related to afloat operations. For them, the areas of paperless operation, recipe management, and food monitoring were of greatest importance. At the time, one of the barriers to implementation was a lack of supporting software that could operate on the hardware. Today, the Food Service Management (FSM) System 3 is available that unifies the logistics and operations of aboard and ashore galley operations, and portable hardware capabilities have increased substantially. Cybernet proposes to leverage past experiences unique to hardware deployment aboard ship, development of rugged platforms, and expertise in process integration to provide the Navy with a hardware/software solution that supports galley operation and logistics. The proposed system includes a complete logistic solution (hardware, software), accreditation, and integration with FSM.

award_title: Food Service Integrated Barcode and Inventory Management System
research_keywords: barcode,FSM 3.0,Galleys,Financial Integrity and Audit Compliance (FIAR),Fleet Supply,FACET,food service management
abstract: The automated identification and processing of goods and documents using machine-readable barcode identifiers is one of the key enabling technologies underlying most modern logistics system. However, the Navys efforts to utilize barcode technology with the Fleet Food Service Management (FSM) system has been often challenged by unique requirements for food service aboard operational vessels, the complexities of procurement, and the need for technologies and processes to comply with policies and regulations such as information assurance instructions and the 2010 Navy Financial Integrity and Audit Readiness mandate. Leveraging its experience in FIAR compliance and information assurance as the prime contractor for the Navys Fleet Audit Compliance Enhancement Tool (FACET), small business Premier Solutions Hi LLC proposes to develop a portable system for barcode identification, automated ordering and inventory, and FIAR compliant document retention that can interface with the Navy FSM 3.0 and other systems to streamline the operation of Navy galleys, stockrooms and messes both afloat and ashore.

award_title: CSSUP: A Mobile Food Service Support Platform for Culinary Specialists
research_keywords: food service management,Armed Force Recipe Services,Culinary Specialist,Training,food preparation,Food safety,1090 form,Menu Development
abstract: Navy Food Service Management (FSM) systems have enabled 21-day cycle menu planning, receipt control, and inventory management in an efficient and streamlined process. Integral to the FSMs menu development with highly acceptable menu items, is the data collected from a Food Preparation Worksheet, NAVSUP Form 1090, which includes an Armed Force Recipe Services (AFRS) index card for each menu item of the meals. The use of 1090 is, however, a manual and hard copy documentation process that reduces work performance and productivity because of the time required for manual paperwork. This in turn reduces the level and quality of training that can be provided to the CS. CSSUP is a user-centered design-driven mobile application that runs on a ruggedized 12 touch screen device. It is connected to the FSM system to help the CS to prepare food as per menu and recipe, log data and take notes similar to the 1090 form, and learn the food preparation process from step-by-step interactive training aids. CSSUP will encourage a collaborative environment for individual CSs in tracking and learning processes to improve meal acceptability, enabling the team to deliver effective and efficient food preparation services by improving menu acceptability and reducing wastage.

award_title: Human Performance Self-Service Kiosk and Application
research_keywords: Education,OPTIMIZATION,Kiosk,wellness,Fitness,Monitoring,Nutrition,Performance
abstract: This solicitation represents a tremendous opportunity to bring state-of-the-art human performance and nutrition technology to the US Navy in a format that meets very specific Navy requirements. As the nations leading provider of human performance assessment technology, CoachMePlus is ideally suited to develop a best-of-breed solution for the Navy. We currently work with over 220 professional and college teams to provide thousands of elite athletes real time interactive assessments of their fitness, wellness and human performance while leveraging an array of portable electronic devices, wearable, and wireless technologies. We propose to apply these same skills and experiences to provide the Navy an interactive touch screen Human Performance Self-Serve Kiosk (HPSSK) solution that both displays human performance information and serves as an individualized educational platform for users ashore and at sea.

award_title: Human Performance Self-Service Kiosk and Application
research_keywords: Mobile,streamlines current fitness efforts,Training,Kiosk
abstract: Develop a platform with interactive touch screen, such as a self-service Kiosk, that displays human performance information, serving as an educational tool for the user of afloat and shore based galleys. Application shall interface with Naval Operational Fuel & Fitness System (NOFFS), MyPlate and the Go for Green programs. Shall display 3-Dimensional human anatomy.

award_title: High Fidelity Acoustic Scattering Models for Large Objects
research_keywords: target scattering supervised learning acoustics underwater Virtual sources
abstract: The dimensionality of the underwater target scattering problem has always been an issue in trading the fidelity versus computational complexity and the trade off is not a trivial issue. The advances made in hardware and the drop in their cost combined with efficient algorithms provided an opportunity to extend the application of high fidelity models to realistic targets and thus improve the detection and classification of underwater targets with an impact on ASW operations and training. In this study, we propose a high fidelity model based on Virtual Source Concept (VSC) and a fast algorithm based on machine/supervised learning that is several orders of magnitude faster than deterministic calculations and more relevant to real world problems

award_title: Ultra-High Thermally Conductive, Dielectric, Conformable Thermal Interface Materials for Energy Storage &amp; Power Systems Thermal Management
research_keywords: Thermal Management,Thermal pads and gap-filler materials,thermal runaway,Conformable thermal interface material (TIM),large format lithium (Li)-ion batteries,dielectric thermal pads
abstract: To prevent the well-known potentially hazardous nature of lithium ion (Li-ion) batteries operated at high rates and high duty cycles for current and future Navy shipboard and ground applications, ADA Technologies proposes to develop a highly thermally conductive and simultaneously highly dielectric conformable thermal interface material (TIM) to enable novel thermal management design for cell-to-pack level heat removal in large-format Li-ion batteries. The TIM pad/film will be designed and tested to ensure no pump-out will occur under vibration, thermal and power/duty cycling, when utilized in energy storage and power electronics platforms for Navy and other DoD applications. ADAs proposed TIM will be designed to provide effective thermal interface between cells and a battery cooling module developed by our partner for Navy ship and terrestrial applications, including but not limited to next-generation weapons systems. Our TIMs and integration protocols will be designed to integrate with external active cooling loops already utilized by Navy (shipboard and other) battery platforms, ensuring a drop-in replacement requiring minimum assembly complications. We plan to leverage our decade-long expertise in the design, manufacturing and fabrication of TIMs to solve this unique need.

award_title: High Performance Thermal Interface Material for Energy Storage Devices and Other Electronic Components
research_keywords: Thermal Interface Material,Thermal Management,materials science,Energy Storage,Heat Transfer,Lightweight
abstract: The objective will be to develop and evaluate a thermal interface material with resistance to vibration and abrasion for use in militarized battery modules. Nanofillers will be used to improve thermal conductivity and reduce the thermal expansion coefficient. The developed TIM formulations will be tested for thermal conductance, electrical insulation, resistance to vibration/abrasion, conformance to irregular gaps, and manufacturing cost. Reworkability and repairability of the proposed TIM will also be demonstrated. At the end of Phase I, based on limited benchtop testing and cost, a small family of materials will be selected for further investigation in Phase II. A comprehensive report with results and conclusions will be submitted.

award_title: Novel Composite for High Performance Thermal Interface Material
research_keywords: Composite,Thermal Management,material hybrid,Thermal Interface Material,engineered anisotropy,anisotropic
abstract: Navy operational needs dictate that thermal interface materials (TIMs) have high thermal conductance, high dielectric strength, form non-permanent bonds, and be resilient to vibration and abrasion. Available TIMs each satisfy a portion of these requirements, but not all of them.Glacigen Materials will develop a new class of TIM by creating a novel composite material. This material will be embodied as a sheet of tailorable thickness with very high through thickness thermal conductivity (exceeding 5000 W/m2-K), but limited thermal conductivity in-plane. Glacigen will subsequently demonstrate the capacity to engineer in-plane anisotropy where the thermal conductivity along a single direction is favored over other directions. Phase I work will demonstrate the process which enables the unique matrix microstructure with relevant materials and then impregnating the composite matrix with the functional phase. Phase I work will conclude with thermal and mechanical characterization. Phase I option work will demonstrate scaling and engineered anisotropy.

award_title: Low SWAP, High Accuracy Integrated Meteorological Sensor Package for UAS&#039;s
research_keywords: meteorology,water vapor,Unmanned Aerial System,boundary layer,laser hygrometer
abstract: This program will develop and demonstrate a secondary payload for meteorological profiling of the marine atmospheric boundary layer from small and medium Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS), such as ScanEagle. This new capability will provide increased data for assimilation into Electromagnetic Maneuver Warfare and Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance sensor performance prediction models, as well as weather forecasting. Our payload concept builds on our experience gathered in developing an airborne laser hygrometer payload for the ScanEagle under a DoE project and features in situ measurement of water vapor using a tunable diode laser-based laser hygrometer that provides the required high measurement speed of water vapor and freedom from extractive sampling issues. High speed, highly compact pressure and temperature sensors are also integrated into the payload. The Phase I base program will focus on downsizing the size weight and power of our previous designs, including estimating size reduction in the system electronics to be had using high density interconnect architecture. The base program will create a CAD mechanical model subjected to thermal, structural, and computation flow dynamics modeling. The Phase I option program will validate the base program CFD modeling via testing the payload and spar in a local wind tunnel facility.

award_title: UAV-Compatible Secondary Payload for Meteorological Profiling
research_keywords: Diode Laser Absorprtion Spectroscopy,VCSEL,Temperature Sensor,pressure sensor,hygrometer,WMS
abstract: Southwest Sciences proposes a meteorological sensor for high sensitivity, compact and low power measurements of temperature, moisture, and pressure for UAS deployment. The targeted performance capabilities of Southwest Sciences meteorological sensor package will measure fine scale gradients of water vapor, temperature and pressure that will allow more accurate assessment of conditions that result in anomalous propagation of electromagnetic radiation in the radar and communication bands. Our proposed project builds on the extensive experience Southwest Sciences has in providing and supporting vertical cavity surface emitting laser (VCSEL) hygrometer instruments.

award_title: High Accuracy, Fast Response Meteorological Profiling Payload with CICADA Compatibility
research_keywords: pressure,Meteorological profiling,humidity,EMV,UAS,UAV,temperature,Fast Response Measurement
abstract: A High Accuracy, Fast Response Meteorological Profiling Payload with CICADA Compatibility is proposed. All sensor subsystems (humidity, temperature, pressure) have already been successfully tested onboard a UAV and/or a weather balloon. The innovative solution is solid state-based and leverages the latest advancements in the field of multi-sensor dynamic signal restauration techniques. Examples of flight measurements show how the method on prototype level can already be used to correct vertical profiles and resolve turbulence spectra up to about 3Hz (humidity) and 4Hz (temperature). At an airspeed of 25m/s this corresponds to a spatial resolution of less than 10m.

award_title: JArtus: A Late-Stage Software Feature Reduction Tool for Security and Performance
research_keywords: Performance,Security,java,JavaScript,Programming,Feature Reduction,Cyber,Software
abstract: An object-oriented programming language such as Java is often the developers choice for implementing such applications, primarily due to its quick development cycle, mature ecosystem, and rich community resources. With the feature-rich Java libraries, third party code, and open-source tools that are leveraged to speed up time to market, performance degradation and security can be one of the tradeoffs. Applications include code and libraries that are only partially used, and the exploitable attack surface is much larger than it needs to be. PJR is proposing JArtus, an automated software refactoring tool that allows the user to selectively remove unwanted features and/or functionality from a Java software product.
