JArtus will be a desktop software tool that leverages research and novel approaches to using code slicing, and soot frameworks to identify features, unused code, and libraries that can be removed from Java applications. Users will be able to select, or simply press an easy button to refactor the software, and produce a new, smaller, more efficient, more secure version of the original application. JArtus will provide feature and functionality testing, security scanning, and performance metrics for the app before and after the code reduction and refactoring process.

award_title: AndroCutter: Seamless Pruning of Android Application Functionality
research_keywords: forced-path execution,Application code pruning,Static and dynamic code analysis,Mobile Applications
abstract: We plan to employ a holistic analysis approach that will extend existing static and dynamic analysis techniques augmenting them with our own forced path execution technology. Thus, we aim to combine static, dynamic, and forced-path analysis in order to maximize code coverage. The proposed approach enables the framework to address the program analysis shortcomings of each approach when they are used in isolation. We plan to leverage code pruning techniques to selectively remove application func- tionalities to restrict access without causing the program to terminate and in a manner that is not disruptive, whenever possible. The selective removal of application code enables a system operator or a user to make the applications conform to a customizable security policy. We plan to address novel and recurrent evasion techniques employed by applications to hide and subdue their behavior when under analysis.

award_title: DeepAgent
research_keywords: Autonomous Agents,machine learning,Artificial Intelligence (AI),Human-Robot Interaction (HRI),Virtual Humans,SIMULATION TRAINING,constructive agents
abstract: SoarTech proposes DeepAgent, a system for automatically learning and improving multiple, realistic behaviors in diverse, complex environments using observations of human gameplay. DeepAgent instruments a training simulation to record a compact representation of the simulation state, player actions, and reward at every time step. Deep reinforcement learning is used to learn deep neural networks which are specially designed to approximate value and policy functions in complex environments. At this point DeepAgent can begin to control agents in the simulation by following the learned policy function. This entire process can be repeated using additional observations or by having DeepAgent play against itself, leading to continuous improvement in the behavior.

award_title: Simulated Teachable Agents for Training Environments (STATE)
research_keywords: Cognitive Modeling,Small Unit Decision-Making (SUDM) Training,Computer Generated Forces,Interactive Learning,Intelligent Agent
abstract: Training simulations that currently support Small Unit Decision-Making (SUDM) training are laborious to configure and expensive to manage with live personnel, which results in training that is limited in scope. Current simulations require numerous pucksters to control simulated entities, driving up the manpower costs of conducting simulation-based training. To fulfill the roles of pucksters in simulation-based training environments, Charles River Analytics proposes to design and demonstrate Simulated Teachable Agents for Training Environments (STATE). We will base STATE on two existing capabilities: (1) SAMPLE, our in-house cognitive modeling architecture that implements Kleins model of Recognition-Primed Decision-making (RPD); and (2) AgentWorks, our in-house, intelligent agent development and run-time platform. STATE augments these capabilities with a Graphical Agent Teaching Interface and a suite of Behavior Learning Algorithms to develop and adapt SUDM-related behavior models. The result of the STATE effort will be a suite of tools that empowers a Trainer user base (as opposed to an engineering user base) to rapidly specify, train, and implement new agent behaviors for simulation-based training.

award_title: A Robust Compact Portable Instrument Package for the Complete Spatiotemporal Measurement of a Single Ultrashort Laser Pulse
research_keywords: FROG,femtosecond pulse measurement,and laser pulse measurement.,compact and portable pulse measurement device,measuring spatiotemporal,ultrafast pulse measurement,ultrashort pulse measurement,GRENOUILLE
abstract: We will develop a simple, lightweight, compact, robust, and inexpensive instrument package that will report essentially all ultrashort-laser-pulse characteristics. It will yield, on a single shot, the pedestal power and complete pulse spatiotemporal field, E(x,y,z,t)i.e. all possible pulse information, including pulse-shape stability, even if multi-shot operation is required. It will include user-friendly software yielding a highly intuitive color movie of each pulse, allowing monitoring by an essentially untrained operator. It will also provide outputs to control laser and pulse parameters, as desired. It will require minimal electrical power: a single laptop, which powers devices currently sold by Swamp Optics. Specifically, the package will contain a simple, robust, and compact device, called STRIPED FISH, to measure each pulses E(x,y,z,t). It uses a spatially filtered reference pulse, extracted from the test pulse and measured by a well-established, simple, robust, and compact device, called GRENOUILLE. Finally, a novel device will measure the presence of any pedestal present.

award_title: Development of LUCS, a Live, Ultra-Compact, Multispectral USPL Characterization System
research_keywords: Ultra-Short Pulse,Transportable,Integrated Diagnostics,phase extraction,Laser,comprehensive pulse characterization,spectrum measurement,Ultra-Compact
abstract: Researchers developing Ultra-Short-Pulse-Lasers (USPLs) need real-time measurements of key parameters, on both single-shot and statistically assessed basis. We propose to design and build a fully integrated, intuitive and user friendly, Live USPL Characterization System, termed LUCS, using novel methods of data capture, data reduction, and distributed processing. Phase I work will evaluate, select, and develop compact, portable individual diagnostics to reliably measure spatial, spectral, temporal, and pulse energy parameters under field conditions. Advanced data reduction algorithms and system architectures will be defined and prototyped. We will also design and optimize a much-needed USPL measurement capability presently unavailable: a single shot phase characterization technique insensitive to both alignment and beam profile, simultaneously providing detailed temporal and phase profiles. A single graphical user interface (GUI) will display user selectable, processed, laser parameters including live tracking of statistical variations in beam figures-of-merit. Additionally, the GUI will allow full control of all diagnostic system components. The GUI will initially run on a laptop and will ultimately be available as a tablet or smartphone app. In Phase II, these prototype components will be fully realized, with diagnostic subsystems seamlessly integrated within hardware and software architectures to provide rapid data processing, enabling 10-Hz live display updates.

award_title: Advanced Compact Inductor for Sonar Applications
research_keywords: uuv sonar,power inductors,advanced magnetic core materials,Single Crystal Transducer
abstract: The Navy requires compact high-power inductors to match single crystal transducers to their power amplifier drives for efficient, compact sonar operations in Unmanned Underwater Vehicle (UUV) applications, where volume and power are at a premium. Enabling more efficient UUV sonar operation will increase vehicle operational availability. Creare proposes to develop advanced, compact power inductors by commercializing a bulk nanocrystalline advanced core material whose cost-efficient fabrication has recently been demonstrated in an innovative process by our development partner. This core material provides saturation flux capability comparable to silicon steel while maintaining much higher electrical resistivity to reduce eddy current losses. Creare will use this advanced core material to develop compact inductor designs for UUV sonar applications. During Phase I we will demonstrate the feasibility of this approach through numerical analysis and laboratory testing. During Phase II we will refine the advanced core materials magnetic properties through incremental process improvements and fabricate inductors for testing. Creare will leverage our magnetic circuits and power electronics experience, along with the advanced materials capabilities of our development partner, to develop the compact inductor for sonar applications. We anticipate that the inductor development will be at TRL 5 at the conclusion of Phase II.

award_title: Development of a novel heat transfer component for toroid inductor applications
research_keywords: matching power inductor,flux density,core,low distortion,silicon-crystal-oscillator,toroid,winding,Broadband
abstract: Matching circuit power inductor(s) (PI) applied between sonar senders and silicon-crystal-oscillator (SCO) reduce the sonar senders required output power by matching the senders output impedance to the input impedance of the SCO. Mainstream has developed a unique method of increasing the heat transfer rate from the PIs core and reducing its size, weight, and power. In addition, a novel winding technique is applied to the new PI design that allows more windings per layer, further decreasing PI size and reducing the PIs stray capacitance. Lowering the PIs stray capacitance extends the PIs bandwidth and minimizes its distortion level.

award_title: Automated Robotic Cargo Handling (ARCH) System
research_keywords: Autonomous cargo handling,Robotics,robotic manipulation,JMIC,Unmanned aircraft,Computer Vision,AACUS
abstract: RE2 proposes the development of the Automated Robotic Cargo Handling (ARCH) system that will allow for autonomous loading and unloading of cargo in an austere landing zone for helicopter system. The ARCH system is a modular robotic system which can be rapidly installed into the cargo bar of an aircraft without modification of the aircraft. This system will allow faster autonomous loading and unloading of cargo to reduce the overall exposure of personnel and equipment in tactical landing zones

award_title: Nickel Aluminum Bronze for Additive Manufacturing Alloy Development
research_keywords: density functional theory,nickel aluminum bronze,Phase Field Modeling,Selective Laser Melting
abstract: Nickel aluminum bronze alloys (NAB) have been used extensively in sea-water applications where high strength, high toughness and high corrosion resistance are required. To date, there have been very few attempts to extend AM to NAB. The traditional composition of NAB, UNS C95800 containing 9.5% aluminum, 5% nickel, 4.5% iron and remaining copper, is slow cooled and precipitation strengthened and may pose difficulties while processing using techniques that involve rapid heating and cooling. Using computational approaches, it is possible to optimize the NAB composition that is amenable to AM without the loss of the mechanical and corrosion properties due to the formation of unwelcomed phases such as 2. The aim of this project proposed by Universal Technology Corporation (UTC) is to develop modelling tool based on the finite element and phase field approach to optimize the NAB composition. The input data for developing the computational tool will be generated by producing test coupons via SLM of NAB alloyThe Phase I option will demonstrate the feasibility of using the NAB composition optimized using the computational tool as the feedstock to build the test coupons and study them for their mechanical and corrosion behavior.

award_title: ICME Optimization of Nickel Aluminum Bronze Feedstock for Directed Energy
research_keywords: nickel aluminum bronze,Propellers,Integrated computational materials engineering (ICME),additive manufacturing,Materials by Design,directed energy deposition
abstract: Nickel Aluminum Bronze (NAB) alloys are widely used in maritime applications for their unique combination of high strength and resistance to the effects of exposure to Naval/maritime environments. However, the supply chain for the large, complex castings needed for the many Navy platforms is severely limited. Additive Manufacturing (AM) promises to be an innovative technology that can enable rapid manufacturing of complex parts at greatly reduced cycle time and with greatly enhanced production flexibility. The market currently lacks NAB feedstocks for AM processing with established best practices and known material performance, which limits the adoption of AM for the manufacturing of Naval seawater components. In this Phase I SBIR program, QuesTek Innovations LLC, a leader in the field of integrated computational materials engineering, is partnering with Pennsylvania State University to develop a new NAB feedstock optimized for the unique processing conditions of AM. QuesTek is uniquely suited to rapidly designing new feedstocks optimized for AM using its advanced Materials by Design stage-gate alloy development process, which is based upon mechanistic models to predict key process-structure and structure-property relationships. Technical feasibility of the developed feedstock will be demonstrated in Phase I with directed energy deposition build trials and coupon-scale property validation.

award_title: Multi-Beam, Free-Space Optical Terminal for Tactical Operations
research_keywords: Laser Communications,RF denied,Optical communication,Lasercomm,free-space optical,FSO
abstract: Point-to-point Free-Space Optical (FSO) communication systems have been demonstrated and are commercially available. FSO systems have many desirable attributes for Navy vessels and aircraft, especially their ability to operate without RF emissions and their immunity to RF interference and jamming. However, to achieve widespread use in naval applications, a more advanced communication network is required, with the ability to simultaneously communicate between multiple ships and aircraft.To address this need, SA Photonics proposes the development of our MultiEye FSO communication system. The MultiEye system utilizes technology and systems developed or being developed on multiple Navy and Air Force programs to provide simultaneous high data rate communication between multiple Navy ships and Aircraft. MultiEye will utilize SA Photonics field proven technology for atmospheric on-the-move FSO systems. MultiEye consists of a multi-beam shipboard FSO terminal as well as individual terminals for aircraft and rotorcraft.

award_title: Multi-Beam Optical Terminal for Tactical Operations (MOTTO)
research_keywords: risley,Tactical Communications,"free space optical communications","non-mechanical beamsteering"
abstract: The focus of this topic is the development of an FSO terminal capable of simultaneously communicating with multiple platforms over a full 360 degrees in azimuth. Single beam free space optical communication allows high-speed point-to-point data links. However, an optical terminal with two or more beams can act as a communications relay allowing the construction of optical communications networks. With this in mind, the Navy is funding the development of a multi-beam transmit/receive capability that can be deployed on USN/USMC platforms. The Navy has requested a terminal with at least two independently directed links which would allow the formation of a ring network, with up to as many as four independent terminals, to allow the construction of self-forming mesh networks.

award_title: Origination of Defects in Powder Bed Fusion Additive Manufacturing (17-RD-923)
research_keywords: Qualification,additive manufacturing,in-situ,ePBF,defects,Rapid Characterization
abstract: While the technologies involved in additive manufacturing of metallic components continue to mature, there are still many barriers to surpass before the promise of the manufacturing method is fully realized. At the front of the list of barriers is developing a better understanding of the origination of defects and how microstructures evolve throughout the process. To that end, UES, Inc. has assembled a team consisting of North Carolina State University and CalRAM, Inc. to investigate the role of process parameters and part orientation on part quality through coupling experimental characterization and process simulation. We propose to design a component with complex features which resemble a heat exchanger, manufacture multiple parts using electron-beam powder bed fusion additive manufacturing, characterize and quantify the microstructure and defects, and couple the experimental results to a thermomechanical model. By integrating a parametric study on process parameters, rapid characterization, and simulation we aim develop a toolset for designers and manufacturers that will increase first part yield and help streamline the qualification process.

award_title: Understanding AM Solidification Profile Effects on Material Inhomogenieties, Defects, and Qualification
research_keywords: melt pool physics,Thermodynamic and kinetic models,phase selection,cellular automata,ICME,Phase stability,allotropes,Selective Laser Melting
abstract: The research objective of this proposal is to demonstrate feasibility of a solidification science based Integrated Computational Materials Engineering (ICME) that combines computational heat, mass transfer, fluid flow and mechanics simulations with thermodynamic and kinetic models to enable cellular automata (CA) framework. Its purpose is to link the AM laser power bed process parameters with as-built microstructure including phase selection, material inhomogeneities, and the potential for the occurrence of porosity and lack-of-fusion defects. The ICME prediction of 3-D distributions of the thermal gradient (G), interface velocity (R) and the melt pool fluid flow would be utilized as input to the calculation of constitutional supercooling and the columnar-to-equiaxed transition. The dynamics of solidification interface velocity will be modeled using interface response function theories to compute the inhomogeneities caused by phase selection phenomena in metals and alloys. The evolution of the solidification front will be traced within the CA grid to predict the overall solidification grain morphology and texture. ICME will be utilized to detect and/or mitigate the presence of material inhomogeneities. Deposition trials will be performed for two stainless steel alloys to demonstrate the applicability of the solidification based calculation of site-specific microstructure.

award_title: Synthetic Vision System for Ground Forces
address1: 1201 W. 5th Street, Suite T-800, Los Angeles, CA 9
research_keywords: Synthetic Vision System,Situational awareness,Call-for-Fire Training,Head-Mounted Display,Call-for-Fire Operations,Decision-making,AUGMENTED REALITY,Small Unit Forces
abstract: Delivering contextual data via an Augmented Reality (AR) wearable shows promise in accelerating tactical decision making while enhancing situational awareness for dismounted soldiers in call-for-fire scenarios. The military can leverage commercialized industrial solutions like the DAQRI Smart Helmet (DSH), an AR platform that provides a transparent optical display with state-of-the-art performance specifications in a comfortable, durable, user-friendly form factor operational in full daylight. The DSH can be cost-effectively upgraded to provide USMC Ground Forces with an advanced tool for enhancing decision making and situational awareness. Our proposed DAQRI Augmented Reality Situational Awareness and Decision Support Synthetic Vision System (DARSADS SVS) combines the existing DAQRI AR platform (DSH) with Lockheeds current Wide Area Augmented Reality (WAAR) project which integrates with target designation system KILSWITCH, enabling a seamless transition from training to battlefield operations.DARSADS SVS provides a foundation for prototyping information visualizations informed by experimentally validated cognitive models such as Salience, Effort (inhibition), Expectancy, Value (SEEV) capable of predicting attention tunneling. Our tactical, real-time AR decision support will incorporate the lessons learned from decades of aviation HUD design research to mitigate attention and perception limitations thanks to our collaboration with the premier expert in the field, Dr. Chris Wickens.

award_title: Synthetic Vision System for Ground Forces
research_keywords: Decision Making,Heads-up display (HUD),attention,Synthetic Vision System (SVS),Helmet-mounted Display (HMD),Augmented Reality (AR)
abstract: Our Fused Augmented RealtiesUser Interface (FAR-UI) already provides Synthetic Vision Augmentation of head-mounted displays (HMDs) for enhanced situational awareness (SA) visualizations for dismounted warfighters. Key innovations include wider field of view (especially useful used with narrow field of view high magnification tasks); intuitive low cognitive workload augmented reality graphics (eyes stay on target areas); and perfect viewing conditions 24/7/365 augmenting real-world viewing with Unity3D synthetic vision terrains. Our OSD/Army and Air Force sponsored FAR-UI versions are focused upon intuitive situational awareness enhancements for small unit leaders decision making via information fusion from small tactical UAS/UGV and larger UAS respectively. Our current OSD/Army and Air Force efforts do NOT include fire and close air support use cases. Given our advanced science and technical foundations of similar dismounted use cases (and prior separate successful call for fire and close air support S&T efforts) we envision this Navy/USMC project as a high-payoff, low-risk effort. We will deliver functional prototypes for what-you-see-and-hear-is-what-you-get assessments and subject-matter-expert feedback within the Phase-I base. Further our university partner independently testing with our Navy sponsored Fused Realities Augmented Modules product will scientifically quantify the task/workload benefits and tradeoffs of the candidate innovations we tailor to USN/USMC requirements.

award_title: Pedagogy Models for Training in Mixed Reality Learning Environments
research_keywords: machine learning,mixed reality,Maintenance Training,intelligent scoring,AUGMENTED REALITY,Intelligent Tutoring Systems,guided experiential learning
abstract: This effort will develop, demonstrate, and validate pedagogical models for training maintenance and troubleshooting in mixed reality (MR) environments., providing the concept and design for a for a software tool to design and assess MR training solutions: the Mixed Realty Training Tool (MRTT). The approach will develop an elaborated version of Guided Experiential Learning principles for pedagogical models focused on learning maintenance and troubleshooting of complex systems, utilizing machine learning algorithms. Simulation-based assessments will inform student models utilized by an intelligent tutoring system..

award_title: ADDMIRE: Automating Design Decisions for Mixed Reality Learning Environments
research_keywords: User Experience Design,Capturing Expert Knowledge,Pedagogy Models,mixed reality,Training Effectiveness,Virtual Maintenance Training,AUGMENTED REALITY,Design Guidelines
abstract: Mixed Reality (MR) technologies can create realistic and engaging learning environments by merging real and computer-generated elements into a single space. However, the use of such technologies does not guarantee effective learning. In fact, the inappropriate selection or implementation of technologies can hinder learning (Appleman, 2005; Bransford, 2000). Unfortunately, there are no design support tools to assist military Instructional Systems Designers (ISDs) in choosing learning strategies that fully leverage the affordances  and offset the limitations  associated with different types of MR learning technologies. To address this critical gap, Aptima will develop the Automating Design Decisions for MIxed Reality Learning Environments (ADDMIRE) system, which will provide ISDs with practical design and implementation guidance that will (1) maximize their pedagogical value, (2) minimize the amount of extraneous cognitive load, and (3) suggest the most appropriate measures for assessing proficiency, learning, and transfer. As part of the ADDMIRE system, Subject Matter Expert (SME) experiential knowledge and insights will be collected and linked to best practices from the published literature. The result will be a robust and extensible framework for designing MR learning environments across a wide range of Naval jobs and job families.

award_title: Pedagogy Models for Training in Mixed Reality Learning Environments
research_keywords: instructional design,Virtual reality,pedagogy,mixed reality,knowledge elicitation,Tacit knowledge,AUGMENTED REALITY,Engineering Maintenance
abstract: An area in dire need of training innovation is that of ship maintenance, which represents one of the Navys most acute readiness concerns. Reduced crew ships such as the LCS/Frigate and the CVN-78 provide inherently fewer opportunities for On the Job Training (OJT) due to the limited number of maintainers aboard each ship and limited time available for existing maintainers to dedicate to training on ship. Additionally, naval ship maintenance subject matter experts are retiring, with no mechanisms in place to transfer their tacit knowledge to future sailors.Design Interactive (DI) proposes to develop and validate 1) a Mixed reality Adaptive Scaffolding Tool for Enhancing Readiness (MASTER) to support engineering maintenance training, namely troubleshooting skills, and 2) an EXpertise TRansfer, Analytics, and Content Tagging (EXTRACT) tool to embed instructional strategies from SMEs within training environments. This will provide a scientifically grounded methodology for developing 2 testbed systems: a classroom-based VR system and an Augmented Reality tool for OJT and job support. The combined MASTER and EXTRACT capabilities will integrate with existing and emergent mixed reality platforms to provide military training organizations with a pedagogically grounded approach to improving warfighter readiness and performance throughout the training continuum, from desks to decks.

award_title: Theater Anti-Submarine Warfare Contextual Reasoning
research_keywords: constraints,Contextual reasoning,Anti-Submarine Warfare,Bayesian tracking
abstract: The Theater ASW Contextual Reasoning system (TASW-CR) will present a set of mission objectives for a threat submarine to analysts on the watch floor and allow them to use available information to evaluate and weight likely mission objectives. Using these mission objectives and contextual information such as weather, geographic features, state of hostilities, and location of blue forces, combined with sparse contact information on the submarine and other hostile forces, TASW-CR will produce constrained estimates in terms of probability distributions on the present and future state of the threat submarine. The probability distributions will be produced by a non-linear Bayesian tracker that is capable of using probabilistic motion models representing the mission objectives identified by the analysts and incorporating the contextual information to reduce the AOA size for the present and future state of the threat submarine compared to using only the sparse contact information.

award_title: Theater Anti-Submarine Warfare Contextual Reasoning
research_keywords: knowledge acquisition,KNOWLEDGE CAPTURE,Decision Support Systems,Cognitive Modeling,Theater anti-submarine warfare,intelligent agents,Expert systems
abstract: Planning for anti-submarine missions requires the TASW Battle Watch Captain to understand the intentions of the enemy based on a vast context of information. There are many factors that these watch standers use to draw their conclusions. Everything from weather to recent hostilities can affect their decision making. An opportunity exists to create an automatic tool for assessing theater-wide ASW situations by leveraging state of the art expert systems technology to assist the TASW Battle Watch Captain. Discovery Machine, Inc. (DMI) in partnership with Arorae Corporation (together the DMI team) proposes to leverage the DM Knowledge Service Modeler (KSM) to create a TASW console. The DM Knowledge Service Modeler is an open and extensible architecture based on artificial intelligence and knowledge capture software. Our research has resulted in technology that enables subject matter experts (SMEs) to capture and deploy their own expertise into decision support systems resulting in better automation and increased performance of personnel. DMI's technology does not require the experts to write code. It builds on how SMEs currently assess a situation, and applies expertise to automate and assist.

award_title: Theater Anti-Submarine Warfare Contextual Reasoning
research_keywords: Prediction,adaptive filter,submarine,location,heat map,Ontology
abstract: Our proposed solution will develop a derivative adaptive filter drawn from Control Theory to continuously evaluate threat submarine contact data and negative search data to generate the best fit estimated contact location derived by weighting each member of a set of estimated threat submarine tracks. These estimated threat submarine track inputs to the adaptive filter will be generated from two types of data. Hard data, such as threat submarine historical tracks and operating characteristics including transit and maximum speed, can be easily converted to locational information. Soft data requires consolidation and conversion using ontologically-based rule sets and fuzzy logic/machine learning to transform data, such as the tension level, with the threat country to create a set of plausible target tracks based on this information. The adaptive filter will output a heat map to indicate the likelihood of future locations for the threat submarine.

award_title: Interferometric ISAR Imaging of Maritime Targets for Improved Classification
research_keywords: Triton,feature extraction,3D model,maritime ATR,ISAR,P-8 Poseidon,Interferometry
abstract: STR will develop a novel approach to 3D imaging and classification of maritime targets using interferometric inverse synthetic aperture radar (InISAR) in order to improve timeliness, accuracy, and sustainability of target recognition in congested littoral environments. In contrast to 2D ISAR imaging or other published InISAR work, our approach provides true 3D metric measurements and true cross-range scale, independently of the knowledge of the motion profile of the target. This enables a host of novel features to be extracted from InISAR imagery and used to improve target classification performance and eliminate the template explosion issue of conventional multi-view radar ATR. In Phase I we will (1) demonstrate feasibility of InISAR using realistic simulated data, flight trajectories, and maritime target motions and show the accuracy with which true 3D target measurements and pose can be determined, (2) quantify improvement in ATR performance due to inclusion of 3D target measurements, and (3) develop the CONOPS for this new imaging modality in the operational context. In Phase II we will implement the algorithms in a real-time processor and demonstrate operation in a field test. We have identified Raytheon SAS as a transition partner and are including their letter of support.

award_title: Interferometric ISAR Imaging of Maritime Targets for Improved Classification
research_keywords: interferometer,ISAR,Radar
abstract: Per the topic description, the performance of ISAR image based classification suffers when vessels are similar with very few distinguishing features, and while this problem exists for vessels of all sizes, the situation worsens as the vessel size becomes smaller. An approach to obtaining additional features from ISAR imaging to further enhance classification performance is to exploit multiple transmit (Tx) and receive (Rx) phase centers. Interferometric ISAR operation is the most basic Tx-Rx architecture comprised of a single Tx phase center and two displaced Rx phase centers. This architecture allows for ISAR images to be formed from the individual Tx-Rx pairs, and subsequently combine them to form a phase interferogram. Our proposed effort satisfies the objectives and is synergistic with related transition activities.

award_title: Shipboard Flywheel Energy Storage Parasitic Reduction
research_keywords: High Temperature Superconducting Magnetic Bearing Controlled Damper
abstract: Our team proposes to build on our previous high temperature superconducting magnetic bearing (HTSMB) design experience to enable multi-MW class flywheel energy storage systems (FESS) to exhibit low standby leak-down rates, comparable to Li-ion batteries. Comparing the current state of the art for FESS to chemical energy storage generally leads to the conclusion that FESS offers major advantages for high power and high cycle life applications and for load-leveling power demand transients to shield electrical grids from high power demand spikes. BT-CEMs previous efforts studying low loss bearings for flywheels concluded that an HTSMB can provide the lowest system level losses but will require a reliable damping solution. Our teams proprietary controlled damping approach, which achieves full rotordynamic stability with very low (strategically placed) forces and very low losses, only incurs losses when damping is required. ONRs Combat Hybrid Power System (CHPS) is a primary example of leading edge technology for shipboard MW-class flywheel load-leveling systems. The CHPS machine will serve as the focus application for our teams HTSMB-CD development efforts. Our team proposes to fully develop this design for a CHPS type application as the result of this Phase I effort.

award_title: Novel, Low Parasitic, Next Generation Flywheel Energy Storage System
research_keywords: Power,High Energy Density,ship,Energy Storage,Composites,energy,flywheel,RIM
abstract: KaZaK Technologies team members are proposing several concepts to meet Navy requirements for development of innovative approaches to meet the solicitations primary objective for a low parasitic flywheel energy system (FES). Our team will work to design a FES to minimize purchase and operating costs. KaZaK efforts to design, fabricate and test a shipboard FES will meet Navy requirements. To accomplish these goals our team will draw on currently funded and previously funded Navy experiences in the design/ analysis/ fabrication of structures, composite/ metallic shipboard systems and shipboard integration to Navy performance and ship schedule requirements. Following design and manufacture, Phase II testing is required to verify that the FES meets dynamic performance requirements. In addition, there are thermal, shipboard geometric, design specific variables and other mechanical/environmental challenges to be met before completion of a shipboard FES is realized. To meet these design goals, KaZaK is proposing several low cost, lightweight designs. If awarded a Phase II, our team will work to apply Phase I designs and analyses to the fabrication of a prototype for testing.

award_title: Embedded Model Processing for In-Mission Reconnaissance Exploitation (EMPIRE)
research_keywords: Video processing,3D Modeling,Structure from Motion,urban modeling,Embedded Computing,wide area aerial surveillance,embedded exploitation
abstract: DZYNE Technologies proposes the research and development of EMPIRE, a capability that will provide Embedded Model Processing for In-Mission Reconnaissance Exploitation. Our objective is to deliver continuous 3D model generation of urban environments in an ultra-low SWaP form factor to help improve the Navys ability to model and understand urban environments through both direct manipulation of the models themselves and through correlated processing with other intelligence layers within a data fusion framework. Our capabilities for 3D modeling-based from aerial video processing will be advanced using recent developments in the field of computer vision and subsequently optimized and physically characterized within an embedded computing environment. We believe in the benefits of a phased approach for SWaP minimization. EMPIRE Phase I will pursue optimization, porting, and evaluation in a set of low-power COTS GPU embedded systems. Further work will see refinement of the 3D urban modeling pipeline, adding support for multiple sensors while further trimming / focusing computation.

award_title: Real Time Computation of Precision 3D Models Using Low Size, Weight, and Power (SWAP) Architectures
research_keywords: Weight,Efficient real time terrain rendering,terrain modeling for airborne low Size,and power (SWAP),efficient generation of high fidelity 3D terrain models,Efficient Digital Elevation Model (DEM) generation techniques
abstract: Toyon Research Corp. proposes innovative algorithm and embedded software development for efficient and accurate 3D terrain reconstruction using passive EO/IR sensors on small UAVs. The Phase I effort will include algorithm development, algorithm performance evaluation and demonstration, low-SWaP implementation and benchmarking, and system design activities. This will result in a documented feasibility determination and an initial system design. Subsequently, in Phase II a complete prototype will be developed and demonstrated, laying the groundwork for Phase III transition via integration with a Navy program of record small UAV system.

award_title: Real Time Computation of Precision 3D Models Using Low Size, Weight, and Power (SWAP) Architectures
research_keywords: Intelligence Surveillance and Reconnaissance (ISR),Structure from Motion,On-Board UAV Processing,Wide Area Motion Imaging (WAMI),bundle adjustment,Green Computing,RANSAC,3D Terrain Reconstruction
abstract: Transparent Sky LLC (TSky) and UltraHiNet LLC propose algorithms and hardware designs for precision computation in real-time of 3D (RT3D) models using low size, weight, and power (SWaP) architectures. will achieve the following:Examine existing data sets and collect new ones to properly simulate the final product.Determine if the candidate CPU/GPU can perform the task or if changes are desired.Determine what improvements should be made to the University of Missouri Bundle Adjustment for Sequential imagery (BA4S) algorithm for speed and SWaP constraints.Integrate UltraHiNets multiresolution techniques to further improve speed/reduce SWaP.Generate surface models from resulting point clouds.Provide a demonstration to the Navy/USMC showing energy efficient computation of high-fidelity terrain models from imagery similar to the desired UAV. This includes models and compressed models.Produce focused report on proposed methodology and algorithms, expected performance metrics, external data required, and development/execution constraints perceived.Plan commercialization efforts for Phase II, beyond those already begun by Transparent Sky. will build prototype hardware, develop production-quality algorithms and supporting software to implement Phase I results. These will be demonstrated in realistic environments with performance metrics relevant to DoD and commercial use cases.

award_title: Sustainable Autonomous Target Recognition of Maritime Targets from Passive ISAR Imagery
research_keywords: ,Bistatic,Passive ISAR,Maritime Classification Aids,Sensor Resource Manager,Multistatic
abstract: The RDRTec team proposes to study the feasibility of innovative approaches for bistatic Inverse Synthetic Aperture Radar (ISAR) imaging to provide robust, efficient, sustainable, and high performance target recognition capabilities to operators using multistatic ISAR images. This includes techniques for optimally combining the information and features from monostatic ISAR with multi-static ISAR images and incorporating them into Maritime Classification Aids (MCA) and radar Resource Manager (RM) that are currently transitioning to naval surveillance radars. Multi-static imaging has both challenges and opportunities. Besides the advantage of covert receiver platforms , additional opportunities include diverse illumination and viewing geometries expanding the information degrees of freedom that can provide richer information for target identification. Unique differences in scattering as a function of bistatic angle may be used as discriminating features and target pose angles can be estimated.

award_title: Sustainable Autonomous Target Recognition of Maritime Targets from Passive ISAR Imagery
research_keywords: Maritime,sustainable,ATR,classification,ISAR
abstract: The increasing proliferation of anti-access/area denial (A2AD) environments is driving intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance (ISR) platforms to operate in bistatic or multistatic configurations. While this reduces the threat to those platforms in A2AD environments, it also greatly expands the degrees of freedom a template-based classification database must encompass. The overhead and logistics burdens in maintaining such a database are immense, particularly since ISAR templates should also encompass the variety of typical vessel motions. EMSI proposes to extend its monostatic 3D ISAR technology to bistatic and multistatic systems, thereby extracting vessel features that allow classification with existing Navy monostatic databases, while requiring only short dwells on target.

award_title: Cellular Base Station for Low Earth Orbit Space Missions
research_keywords: Space Communications,MUOS,low SWAP,RADIATION TOLERANCE,Cellular Base Station,Cubesat
abstract: The Aeronix SpaceCellBase will provide a MUOS base-station in a low SWaP payload design that makes use of LEO proven radio components, existing waveform functionality available in the JTRS waveform repository, proven space cryptographic assets, and Aeronixs unique knowledge in all these areas. This technology can be delivered in the 3u CubeSat payload specification for a limited number of users and transmission time, the transition to a 6u CubeSat would enable expansion of user quantity and transmission time on a per orbit basis. Aeronix is a proven provider of satellite hardware, Type 1 Information Assurance technology, and fielded operational Cell technology based tactical radios to the DoD.

award_title: Cellular Call Processing Payload for Low Earth Orbit Space Missions
research_keywords: Cubesat,WCDMA,UHF,Payload,,communication,Nanosat,MUOS
abstract: MUOS call processing payloads on Nanosats will provide enhanced UHF SATCOM coverage at the poles of the earth and in areas where direct line of sight to the geosynchronous satellites are obstructed by geographical features such as mountainous terrain and slot canyons. This project will assess the feasibility of miniaturizing W5's standalone portable MUOS emulator, the Mighty MUOOS, into a MUOS call processing payloads for use on Nanosats. Once we have determined this is possible, this payload will provide a cost effective and persistent MUOS extension which will provide UHF SATCOM coverage not possible with previous geosynchronous satellite systems.

award_title: Cellular Base Station for Low Earth Orbit Space Missions
research_keywords: Gateway,small cell base station,SATCOM Beyond 65 lattitude,SATCOM,Cubesat,MUOS,WCDMA,Nanosat
abstract: This offer proposes a set of activities to develop concepts and architectures to explore the potential deployment of a cellular radio base station as a CubeSat payload to support MUOS communication beyond 65 latitude. Following a traditional systems engineering approach, the Phase 1 objective is to work through the full array of needs, requirements and constraints for the mission and then provide the exploration, analysis and trades necessary to arrive at an architecture and concept that best satisfies the mission objective - MUOS satellite communication services in the Polar Regions.

award_title: Next Generation Ultra High Frequency (UHF) Unified Satellite Communication Control System
research_keywords: SDR,Software Defined Radio,SATCOM
abstract: The current JMINI and IW UHF SATCOM Control Segment is split into three separate control systems, each with their own dedicated radio communications equipment. Both the control systems as well as the radio equipment contain proprietary components, which make maintenance difficult and expensive due to lack of vendor competition. We are proposing a modular and non-proprietary hardware and software architecture that will consolidate the three control systems into one, as well as simplify the radio communication equipment. The proposed system is centered around integration of Software Defined Radio (SDR) functionality into the control system and leveraging a plugin-based software architecture that allows decoupling of specific hardware from the rest of the control system. This approach will enable the government to utilize commodity COTS hardware not only for the control system, but potentially for the radio equipment as well, offering a path to long-term affordable sustainment for this critical communication system.

award_title: Next Generation Ultra High Frequency (UHF) Unified Satellite Communication Control System
research_keywords: DSM,UHF-SATCOM,IW,WDE,SDR
abstract: Legacy UHF-SATCOM has an enduring presence including coalition missions that cannot be replaced by the newer MUOS system. The solution presented enables the government to evolve management and control of current UHF-SATCOM system assets thru the adoption of an Open System Architecture designed to simplify the introduction of technology advances while supporting transition of existing equipment and software systems.This architecture provides government purpose rights for technical data and provide key features including a Domain Specific Modeling (DSM) engine to allow system engineers to enter MIL-Standard specification updates to generate system revisions for application controller systems with minimal coding impact. The solution leverages our Integrated Waveform (IW) controller to provide full IW support. Powerful reporting capabilities and Test/Training Modes allows experimentation and validation with accelerated timing and without actual RF transmission.We will provide a cross-domain solution to the problem of controller and planning terminals operating at a higher security classification. Our experience with the Risk Management Framework (RMF) allows a new cyber-hardened security architecture that exceeds accreditation requirements.Working with industry our teams extensive experience in Software Defined Radios (SDR) enables us to provide an Open Reference Model supporting the best-of-breed capabilities into Control Terminal (CT) elements.

award_title: Optimize Additive Manufacturing (AM) Post-Build Heat Treatment (HT) and Hot Iso-static Pressing (HIP) Processes for Fatigue Performance using an Integ
research_keywords: Phase Field Method,heat treatment,Computational Fluid Dynamics,Finite Element Analysis,Hot Iso-static Pressing,response surface method,sensitivity analysis
abstract: Additive manufacturing (AM) technology is becoming more popular for the fabrication of 3D metal products as it offers rapid prototyping and large design freedom. However, part quality and fatigue performance of components fabricated by current AM technology are not comparable to that produced by traditional methods. Post-build processing techniques, such as heat treatment (HT) and Hot Iso-static Pressing (HIP), have been developed to improve microstructure and remove internal flaws that are detrimental to fatigue resistance. In order to simulate the HT and HIP process and optimize the post-build process, an Integrated Computational Materials Engineering approach is utilized to link the process parameters with materials structures, properties and fatigue performance. We propose a unified computational package to (1) simulate the HT/HIP process including the physics of fluid flow, heat transfer, microstructure evolution and residual stress formation, and (2) predict the probabilistic distribution of fatigue life of AM components. Furthermore, a state-of-the-art hybrid optimization approach, combining sensitivity analysis, response surface method and genetic algorithm, is proposed to optimize post-build process parameters to minimize porosity and defects. Ultimately, the software developed will optimize the HT/HIP process for an AM part CAD/CAE model provided by the user.

award_title: Optimize Additive Manufacturing (AM) Post-Build Heat Treatment (HT) and Hot Iso-static Pressing Processes for Fatigue Performance using an Integrated
research_keywords: heat treatment,Porosity,Integrated computational materials engineering (ICME),hot isostatic pressing,Additive Manufacturing (AM),residual stress,Part Distortion,fatigue performance
abstract: Additive manufacturing (AM) is a novel process of fabricating components in a layer-by-layer method under the control of computer-aided design (CAD) information, rather than by the traditional use of specially-made casting molds and forming dies. AM produced materials are highly susceptible to fatigue due to presence of large number of pores and defect, limiting its use in fatigue critical applications. Without a proper understanding of how HT/HIP affects the microstructural features that cause fatigue failure, optimization of fatigue performance and hence the use of AM built parts in fatigue critical application will be limited.Under this SBIR program, QuesTek Innovations LLC will utilize its knowledge and expertise in Integrated Computational Materials Engineering (ICME) to assemble a suite of modeling tools capable of optimizing Additive Manufacturing (AM) post-build processes of metal parts for fatigue performance, without deteriorating other mechanical properties. As a leader in ICME and a pioneer in development of processing-structure-property models and ICME databases, QuesTek is uniquely qualified to extend its modeling capabilities to simulate porosity reduction, microstructural evolution and its effect on mechanical properties, residual stress and distortion as a function of heat treatment parameters.

award_title: Microstructure-Informed ICME for Pptimizing Post-Build Heat Treatment (HT) and Hot Isostatic Pressing (HIP) Processes for Enhanced Fatigue Performance
research_keywords: hot isostatic pressing,Microstructure informatics,OPTIMIZATION,heat treatment,Fatigue,additive manufacturing,ICME
abstract: The widespread adoption of AM for production of structural components is often stymied by the variability in static and dynamic properties caused by application of non-optimized post-processing schemes. MRL is proposing to demonstrate a microstructure-informed, ICME simulation tool for optimization of hot isostatic pressing and heat treatment to enhance static and dynamic performance of metal AM components. This tool will help empower designers to simulate the location-specific microstructure and specify the optimal HIP/heat treatment cycle to achieve maximum fatigue life for their geometry, material, and AM system.

award_title: Advanced Body Force Cueing for Dynamic Interface Simulation
research_keywords: Piloted Simulation,Rotorcraft Dynamic Interface,TILTROTOR,Pilot Body Force Cueing
abstract: One of the most challenging tasks for a naval aviator is to land a rotorcraft on a ship, the dynamic interface task. The pilot experiences variable wind environments, often degraded visual conditions, and a landing area that is moving in response to sea state. Creating a representative simulator-based testing and training environment for dynamic interface has also proven challenging. While existing technologies can provide motion cueing, the limitations of these devices can negatively impact effectiveness. To achieve a more effective body force cueing environment, the nature of the forces experienced by pilots in the critical dynamic interface flight regime must first be better understood. Then and only then can the cueing mechanisms be properly created new or reimagined from existing designs to produce the desired results in the simulator. A team led by Systems Technology, Inc. proposes to fully characterize the dynamic environment at the pilot station. A validated pilot biodynamic model will then be used to evaluate the impact of flight generated body forces versus simulated force cueing on the dynamic interface task. The critical body force cueing elements identified in this approach will be used to define candidate hardware solutions to be developed and tested in Phase II.

award_title: Pilot Centric Motion Cueing Framework for Rotorcraft Shipboard Simulation
research_keywords: Human perception model,Dynamic Interface,motion cueing,Rotorcraft,Flight Simulation
abstract: The effectiveness of rotorcraft flight simulation in handling qualities assessment and pilot training is enhanced by the presence of high-fidelity motion and body force cues, which can be particularly important for simulation of shipboard launch/recovery operations. Continuum Dynamics, Inc. (CDI) proposes to develop a model-based pilot-centric framework for the development and analysis of rotorcraft motion/force cueing systems with emphasis on shipboard operations. This model-based approach will combine high-fidelity aerodynamic models to characterize the rotorcraft operating environment and human perception models to develop and implement optimal cueing strategies. The approach can be used to evaluate an existing motion system quantitatively to assess motion cue fidelity and to integrate additional cueing hardware (e.g., dynamic motion seat) to enhance realism and improve effectiveness of the virtual environment. In Phase I, the pilot-centric motion/body force cueing framework will be developed, and framework sub-models will be evaluated and benchmarked. The methodology will be tested and evaluated using a representative tiltrotor simulation with G-seat to provide body force cues. Results from Phase I will provide a foundation for further development and evaluation within the NAVAIR V-22 simulator as part of follow-on activities.

award_title: Ultra-High Frequency Clutter Model for Airborne Surveillance Radar
research_keywords: CUDA,UHF Clutter,STAP,E2-D,MTI
abstract: The RDRTec team proposes in Phase 1 to develop a conceptual design for a standalone UHF Clutter model that supports Phase 2 efforts to demonstrate real-time generation of geo-spatial clutter signals for direct injection at radio frequency (RF) into the multi-channel E-2D Next Generation Advanced Hawkeye Radar. The variable fidelity Radar Analysis / Simulation Tool (RAST) is available for immediate use for determining the required level of fidelity. RAST has been used on many programs and is the predecessor to: AFRLs Strategic Radar Simulation RLSTAP; Knowledge-Based STAP (KBSTAP); and other Air Force and DARPA tools.This Phase 1 effort will: determine the level of fidelity (number of scatterers, scattering coefficients, scattering geometries, Internal Clutter Motion (ICM), clutter density) required to fully represent clutter environments as well as decorrelation and mismatch induced by the radar hardware and motion of the platform and the antenna rotation that impacts the STAP performance; develop the Phase 2 prototype architecture to support real-time T&E environments with RF clutter injection; and address increasing processing speeds by prototyping processing intensive algorithms in CUDA based Graphics Processing Units.

award_title: Ultra-High Frequency Clutter Model for Airborne Surveillance Radar
research_keywords: radar simulation,Modeling,Ground radar clutter,Airborne MTI radar,Space-Time Adaptive Processing
abstract: STR proposes the development of a high-fidelity UHF radar clutter data simulation environment, leveraging existing simulation code adapted to the UHF E-2D application for the purposes of direct injection into a radar simulator. Several prior programs at STR have developed radar signal processing algorithms for airborne MTI applications that have included A/D level clutter simulators. On this program, we will incorporate unique effects for UHF applications, to include parameterization of number of scatterers per range/Doppler cell, clutter reflectivity statistics and characteristics of broad range of clutter environments (e.g., maritime or land clutter). In addition, radar sensor attributes (motion, digitization, etc.) and platform effects will be included. An MTI processing chain model that includes space-time adaptive processing (STAP) will also be developed to validate details of the clutter model and to benchmark expected performance in the NAVAIR Architecture Management Integration Environment (AMIE). Along with the clutter modeling code to be developed in Phase I, STR will develop a plan to transition the code to real-time implementation prototyping. With extensive experience in radar clutter modeling, STAP algorithm development and direct development experience for the E-2D system, STR is uniquely qualified for the UHF clutter modeling for airborne surveillance radar project.

award_title: Ultra-High Frequency Clutter Model for Airborne Surveillance Radar
research_keywords: CLUTTER,site-specific simulations,RFView(TM),STAP,Radar modeling and simulation
abstract: In this proposal we introduce an overall solution for simulating high-fidelity, multi-channel, RF clutter signals to support advanced testing of the E2-D radar. Our approach leverages ISLs existing RFView(TM) radar simulation software which is built on decades of high-fidelity, site-specific radar clutter modeling and simulation experience. RFView(TM) models radar clutter in land, sea, and littoral environments and has been evaluated relative to experimental data from VHF to X-band frequencies. Recently, RFView(TM) was extended to support real-time radar hardware-in-the-loop (HWIL) testing via ISLs novel Real-time Electromagnetic Environment Simulator RTEMES(TM) technology.

award_title: Relevant Image Mosaic Image Management Algorithm Development
research_keywords: Mission Planning,image,algorithm,Imagery,Photogrammetric,Storage,image exploitation
abstract: Current Naval Air Systems imagery exploitation systems are fed new images from high speed data streams but have limited organic system file storage capability. With no built in logic to manage the storage volume, a first-in-first-out default overwrite situation often results, which hampers mission planning or results in planners having to expend time manually searching external libraries for needed imagery. Sonalysts proposed Mission-Focused Imagery Selection Tool (M-FIST) will provide a software technology solution to allow planners to use a user-friendly geographical interface to identify mission requirements based on locations, image type, image age, and multiple photogrammetric properties. These requirements are then compared with metadata extracted from both previously stored and incoming imagery feeds to determine in real-time the most relevant imagery to accept and/or delete from the exploitation systems storage volume. M-FIST will provide system operators with a dynamic intuitive interface that includes a representation of the user-defined requirements, existing imagery, and a depiction of how well existing imagery meets mission needs.

award_title: Management Engine for Mission Relevant Imagery (MEMRI)
research_keywords: image management software,GXP interoperatbility,relevancy metadata,Geographic Information System,NAVAIR mission operations,storage optimization,mission relevant imagery
abstract: and a limited capacity to store the data, the Navy must intelligently allocate available storage to preserve imagery that relates to current and future mission objectives. Current image management and exploitation software does not provide this capability, instead navely deleting the oldest imagery to make room for new data, which can easily discard critical intelligence. To solve this problem, the ATC-NY team will develop the Management Engine for Mission Relevant Imagery (MEMRI), an image management framework that utilizes a combination of established imagery metadata and new objective relevancy metadata to define automated and customizable retention policies for prioritizing data on monitored storage systems.

award_title: Smart Caching of Imagery for Carry On System (SCICOS)
research_keywords: imagery retrieval,Metadata and Content Extraction,Image Management Algorithm,Scalable Data Caching
abstract: The use of imagery is essential to the Navys maritime domain awareness. Ability to retrieve relevant imagery and retain these data sets for exploitation drastically improves the Navys ability to conduct Intelligence Surveillance Reconnaissance operations. Current imagery management systems do not account for users query and metadata filtering priorities, which can lead to loss of valuable imagery data as onboard storage capacity becomes limited. DZYNE Technologies proposes to develop the Smart Caching of Imagery for Carry On System (SCICOS) that leverages our experience in data management and image and metadata content extraction to provide a scalable imagery management system. We propose a data retention strategy (imagery caching) that leverages the users query and persistence rules to rank imagery priority. The SCICOS system handles imagery retention automatically based on users interaction and configuration of the persistence rule set, which allows the user to focus on their mission operations. The proposed effort will develop an end-to-end solution that supports (a) intuitive query and filter selection of imagery by metadata; (b) an automated imagery retention based on users usage and persistence rule definition; (c) a scalable framework for imagery management that automatically extracts metadata and imagery content to increase rapid search and retrieval.

award_title: Rapidly Actuated Mirror Steerer
research_keywords: Mechatronics,actuators,Beam Control,fast steering mirror
abstract: To address the Navys need for a high bandwidth fast steering mirror (FSM) for future high energy laser (HEL) missions, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a Rapidly Actuated Mirror Steerer (RAMS) system. The RAMS technology is based on novel actuation structures and reflector designs for operational bandwidths faster than 5 kHz. Specifically, the innovation in high bandwidth mechanical actuators and lightweight mirror design will allow for the correction of atmospheric and aero-optic effects, as well as support the internal weapon optical train alignment maintenance for future fast-mover airborne missions. This integrated system offers significantly enhanced operating bandwidth and accelerations in a small footprint. In Phase I, POC will demonstrate the feasibility of the RAMS technology through design, fabrication, and demonstration of the system prototype. In Phase II, POC plans to advance, optimize, and ruggedize the RAMS assembly to meet the Navys operational requirements.

award_title: High Bandwidth Fast Steering Mirror
research_keywords: Tilt Compensation,fast steering mirror,Aero-optics,Aero-Mechanics
abstract: Air flowing over the fuselage of aircraft can induce both mechanical vibrations in the platform. Furthermore, the turbulent air flow induced by the aircraft can cause light propagating through it to become aberrated due to the aero-optical disturbances. These aero-optical and aero-mechanical disturbances have a strong effect on the pointing of the light propagated through them. The speed of these effects is much higher than normal atmospheric aberrations. Current fast steering mirror (FSM) technology cannot achieve the high bandwidths required for adequate compensation. In this effort we propose to develop a high speed FSM capable of improved compensation based on our successful work developing other aero-optical compensation systems over the last 10 years.

award_title: Pyrotechnic Hybridized Layouts via Advanced Manufacturing of Energetics
research_keywords: additive manufacturing,Energetics,flare,Decoy,pyrotechnics,Infrared
abstract: Military aircraft uses decoy flares to counter incoming threat missiles. Improvement in sensors and guiding mechanisms of missiles requires countermeasures to become more sophisticated to mislead them. One approach to enhance flare performance is through the introduction of multiple spectral characteristics in one device. Such functionally graded flare grains would have the ability to generate specific electromagnetic signatures in time and space. Lynntech proposes to use Additive Manufacturing (commonly known as 3D printing) for fabrication of hybridized flare grains. Our approach involves modification of currently used pyrotechnic compositions to allow their processing via additive manufacturing as well as the design of smart nozzle geometries to allow fabrication of core-shell flare grains. The developed material/printer combination will allow for fabrication of selectively tuned spectral signatures and inside-out burning characteristics that are not attainable by traditional pyrotechnic pellet production methods such as melt cast, melt cure, and powder pressing. We will evaluate the performance of the fabricated flare grains as a function of composition and energetic payload. The developed technology will allow for precise control of material layering and electromagnetic signature as a function of time. Ultimately, Lynntechs deposition method formulation will result in transformational changes in the performance of decoy flares.

award_title: Selective Emission of Light Utilizing Functionally-Graded Energetic Materials
research_keywords: 3D printing functionally-graded flare grains,energetics additive manufacturing
abstract: Flares are commonly used in the defense industry as light utilizing functionally-graded energetic materials for airborne expendable countermeasure applications. However, current flare production processes are rudimentary because they limit design flexibility and incur significant start up and maintenance costs due to low annual production volume. Additive Manufacturing (AM) is a superior alternative to traditional flare casting methods because it is production-volume independent and allows control over mesoscale geometry with multiple energetic materials. SAS has been internally conducting State-of-the-Art advanced energetics AM research since 2015 and has used energetic feedstock to successfully 3D print ammonium perchlorate composite propellant solid rocket motors. During Phase I SAS will expand its energetics AM capabilities to allow 3D printing of 25g flare pellets using at least three different energetic materials with unique electromagnetic signatures. The Phase I Option program incorporates flare modeling software development and hot-fire testing and results analysis of 3D printed flares. Johns Hopkins University Energetics Research Group has been enlisted to provide energetic material research support and structural characterization of the 3D printed flare grains.

award_title: Miniature Oriented Tri-Axial Fluxgate Magnetometer Sensor
research_keywords: Oriented,UAV,MAD,magnetometer,Magnetic,Fluxgate
abstract: Oceanit proposes to develop a miniature oriented fluxgate magnetometer similar to the AN/ASQ-10 for use across multiple operational platforms with focus on unmanned vehicles in a maritime environment.

award_title: Optically-pumped atomic mag with full vector capability
research_keywords: atomic magnetometer,Rubidium,Vector Magnetometer,ASQ-10,ASQ-81
abstract: To support the Navy's AWS efforts we propose a new type of vector magnetometer based on an optically pumped rubidium vapor that provides an oriented vector output. The device will be small, low power and rugged.

award_title: Miniature Oriented Tri-Axial Fluxgate Magnetometer Sensor
research_keywords: magnetometer,Yttrium Iron Garnet,Magnetic Sensor,Fluxgate,magnetic field,Sensitivity,Noise
abstract: Recent development of unmanned vehicles (UVs) demands for new technologies on tri-axial fluxgate magnetometers with ultra-low noise level, reduced size and weight. The sensitivity and noise level of traditional tri-axial fluxgate magnetometers are limited by the intrinsic noise of magnetic materials. And their size and weight are limited by their bulky magnetic cores. The objective of this proposal is to develop tri-axial fluxgate magnetometers using single-crystal Yttrium Iron Garnet (YIG) films to reach an ultra-low magnetic noise of ~10fT/Hz1/2 , which is ~3 orders of magnitude better than the state of the art tri-axial fluxgate products. This outstanding performance of our proposed fluxgate magnetometers will be achieved by several innovations in this project: (a) development of low-noise magnetic material YIG, (b) design and fabrication of the YIG film with quasi-elliptic edge profile, and (c) rotational excitation mode. The electronic circuits integrated on one board will drive the rotating magnetic field at the frequency of 1650-1700 Hz, detect the single with digitization bit depth of 24 bits, control the measurement, and communicate with UVs. The weight and dimension of the package will be much better than the specifications in the project topic of 2.0lbs. and 8.0in respectively. The compact fluxgate magnetometer.

award_title: Miniature Oriented Tri-Axial Fluxgate Magnetometer Sensor
research_keywords: Fluxgate,MAD,UAV,Oriented,Magnetic,magnetometer,UV
abstract: Technology advances have produced a class of unmanned vehicles (UVs) that operate in air, on the ground, and underwater. These platforms are ideal for remote sensing because they are small, lightweight, fast, and covert. There is ongoing interest in integrating SIGINT sensor packages onto these platforms.One disadvantage to these small platforms is that they are easily buffeted about by environmental conditions (waves, wind, etc.), and this presents a challenge to low frequency electromagnetic (EM) sensors. This motion-induced signal becomes clutter, or noise, in the data, which overwhelms signals of interest.There is a need for high sensitivity, low frequency magnetic sensors for long range SIGINT on UVs. These sensors must have motion isolation and large dynamic range to sense small long-range signals atop large motion-induced signals. QUASAR Federal Systems (QFS) is a world leader in advanced electromagnetic sensing. That expertise includes a patent for an integrated, 3-axis, fluxgate/induction sensor. QFS also has extensive experience integrating sensors on both airborne and underwater platforms, and we have implemented multiple motion cancellation techniques into sensor systems we have developed. Here, QFS proposes a lightweight, low power, low magnetic signature, 3-axis fluxgate for UV platforms with active (and possibly passive) motion cancellation.

award_title: Training Wing Mishap Awareness Narratives (WingMAN)
research_keywords: Rotor-Wing,Situational awareness,Aviation,Training,Fixed-Wing,vestibular,spatial disorientation,Mishap
abstract: Spatial Disorientation (SD) is cited as a contributing factor in five to ten percent of all aviation incidents; and has a 90% fatality rate (Heinle & Ercoline, 2002). SD impacts both fixed- and rotor-wing aviators, and SD impacts pilots at every skill level. To combat SD, aviation training provides exposure to SD materials at multiple points in the training process, including classroom-based instruction and full-motion flight simulators. Availability for hardware systems, however, limit the SD exposure an aviator can have (Ercoline, 1997). Enhancing classroom-based SD instruction into more engaging visual formats is a potential solution to augment SD training. Soar Technology, Inc. proposes a playback-generation tool for Training Wing Mishap Awareness Narratives (WingMAN). WingMAN will allow an instructor to gather data from multiple sources to create a visual playback of any mishap for which data is available, including editing existing playbacks. At the end of Phase II, WingMAN will also support automating the integration of aircraft state data, incident audio recordings, and text-based information. WingMAN will support playback via a first-person 3D out-the-window visualizer, will support exporting narrative playbacks to a variety of formats suitable for delivery on desktops, mobile devices, and in Virtual Reality headsets.

award_title: MASTER: Mishap Awareness Scenario Training for Ensuring Readiness
research_keywords: virtual scenario authoring,Aviation mishaps,Situational Awareness (SA),spatial disorientation (SD),Virtual reality,AUGMENTED REALITY,Aviation Training,mishap recreation
abstract: While relatively infrequent, aviation mishaps can be devastating due to the high probability of loss of life and financial ramifications of such events. Factors such as spatial disorientation and lack of situational awareness are known root causes to aviation mishaps and, unfortunately, training for coping with such factors is generally lacking. To work towards a solution of this significant challenge, the Aptima team proposes to develop a Mishap Awareness Scenario Training for Ensuring Readiness (MASTER). The result will be a tool that allows Naval aviation instructors to create mishap scenarios from realistic data or through intuitive creation tools and will provide multiple methods for media export. The MASTER system will enhance training efficacy by providing multiples methods of immersive mishap replay along with a dedicated plan for evaluating the effectiveness of various training media. An Analysis of Alternatives (AoA) will also be performed to examine the best possible methods for training delivery. In summary, the anticipated components of the proposed system will work to streamline scenarios authoring and provide revised training for typical aviation mishap factors through immersive and realistic training scenarios.

award_title: System for Analyzing Flight-data to Enrich Mishap Awareness Training Tools and Enhance Readiness (SAFE-MATTERS)
research_keywords: spatial disorientation,Aviation,training enhancement,Mishap awareness,Virtual reality,Situation awareness,decision support
abstract: Spatial disorientation (SD) and loss of situational awareness (SA) contribute to nearly a third of military aviation mishaps, posing a serious threat to military aircrews worldwide. Current approaches to mitigate mishaps due to SD and loss of SA traditionally focus on instructor-led classroom teaching that introduces aviation and sensory physiology. However, to more effectively explain human contributions and system failures in mishap events, Naval Aviation Survival Training Center (NASTC) personnel require dedicated support to rapidly and intuitively recreate past mishap events, and then distribute training materials based on these recreations into classrooms, exposing students to actual SA/SD mishap events in a controlled, simulated environment. To address these needs, we propose to design and demonstrate a System for Analyzing Flight-data to Enrich Mishap Awareness Training Tools and Enhance Readiness (SAFE-MATTERS). SAFE-MATTERS will provide mishap awareness training support via three key components: (1) a library of contributing environment, aircraft, mission, and pilot factors relevant to SA/SD mishaps; (2) an intuitive simulator engine user interface to enable rapid mishap scenario authoring and customization; and (3) an application that supports both the creation and distribution of a range of training media to classrooms.

award_title: Laser Target and Analysis Board Development
research_keywords: target board,photo detector,directed energy,laser beam measurement,tracker,anti-aircraft missile countermeasure,Jitter,Laser
abstract: Laser-based anti-aircraft missile countermeasure systems use precisely aimed lasers to thwart the attack of these deadly missiles. In a matter of seconds, these systems must detect and characterize the threat, acquire the target, achieve track lock on the target, and initiate engagement of the threat's seeker with an in-band laser. The survival of our Warfighters and their aircraft during this extremely short engagement time envelope depends upon the near instantaneous application of laser energy with the proper beam characteristics required to defeat the threat. Given this critical performance requirement, the laser's performance must be verified throughout its entire operational lifespan--from initial integration and checkout of the system in the aircraft, through aircrew training and proficiency, to periodic operational performance verification. Tau Technologies has developed a modular, adaptable laser target board design concept that can provide precision laser measurement and characterization for these critical systems. The target board can be reconfigured to provide detection of various laser wavelengths. Detector modules can be positioned in various geometries and quantities on a backplane, providing enhanced beam detection capabilities. The target board concept includes a tracker source to stimulate the laser system under test, and an integrated location and orientation determination system.

award_title: Laser Target and Analysis Board Development
research_keywords: Power on Dome,laser characterization,Direct Measurement,Countermeasures,Laser-based,RIOT
abstract: DHPC Technologies (DHPC) will develop the design, architecture and composition of a portable Laser Target and Analysis Board, (LTAB) and all associated support equipment (data collection, remote power, communications, system enclosure, etc.). The LTAB, along with the support equipment, will comprise the Portable Integrated Laser Optical Test System, PILOTS. DHPCs approach is to combine and significantly enhance the Navys two legacy measurement subsystems, into a single, safe, and easily deployable trailered system. PILOTS will provide an innovated method for laser measurement, while providing operator comfort, advanced processing and advanced communications for remote operation. Initial focus will be on measuring IRCMs ability to achieve Power on Dome and collecting a Direct Measurement of its laser beam at relevant ranges (1-10 km). PILOTS will be designed to measure the laser parameters (irradiance, beam shape, pointing accuracy, etc.) at any remote outdoor real world range environment (semi rugged). Additionally, PILOTS will include a Laser Characterization Cart (LCC), whose purpose is to quantify the laser radiation characteristics as it exits the systems pointer/tracker assembly, PILOTS will be designed in an open, modular fashion to address growth paths to allow testing of other types of laser-based systems across the spectra in the future.

award_title: Spatial Link Analysis for Airborne Platforms (SLAAP)
research_keywords: 3-D Analysis,Antenna patterns,link analysis,Airborne Platforms,RF Link Budget,link availability,RF communications,Propagation
abstract: PMA-265 seeks a comprehensive RF propagation modeling tool that exploits three-dimensional antenna patterns, complete platform location and orientation specification, and terrain data to model air-to-ground, air-to-air, and air-to-satellite links over a wide range of RF frequencies.
