The solicitation authors want a robust tool that completely defines the 3-D RF environment and performs multiple types of spatial availability analysis, while facilitating use by individuals that do not possess a deep knowledge of RF propagation theory. Barron Associates, Inc., proposes development of the Spatial Link Analysis for Airborne Platforms (SLAAP) software tool, which will address the myriad facets of a complex electromagnetic modeling problem. A key innovation will be the ability to incorporate 3-D antenna patterns and dynamic aircraft orientation to produce a complete spatial analysis of RF coverage. The result of the proposed work will be a user-friendly GUI that incorporates the various aspects of the modeling problem, permitting easy study setup and generating, as output, 3-D visualizations that are easy to manipulate and consume. Phase I deliverables include use case demonstration, documentation of propagation models and algorithms utilized in Phase I and under consideration for Phase II, preliminary GUI layouts, and the roadmap to product transition to the fleet.

award_title: Advanced Radio Frequency Link Analysis Tool
research_keywords: Terrain,connectivity,communications link,Propagation Channel,atmospheric effects,Radio Frequency
abstract: The objective of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to develop a comprehensive RF link analysis tool for modeling air-to-air, air-to-ground, air-to-surface and air-to-satellite tactical communications in a multi-node, physical network environment. The proposed tool will interface with commercially available antenna modeling software and will provide comprehensive electromagnetic propagation effects as well as a three-dimensional availability analysis necessary for evaluating the RF system performance.

award_title: Communication and RF analysis tool
research_keywords: GUI,DTED,ray tracing,link availability,Radio Frequency,modulation scheme,WIPL,Antenna pattern
abstract: For a successful mission, the planning of the route based on communication link availability is important. The communication links are used to support functions of command and control, communication, intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance (ISR). The RF link performance depends on distance between transmitter and receiver, frequency, antenna, propagation channel and also the communication scheme. In this effort, IAI proposes the development of a Communication and RF Analysis Tool (CaRAT) to predict RF link availability based on antenna patterns, aircraft orientation and other factors that impact link availability. This software will include a graphical user interface that will enable the user to configure parameters and visualize the results.

award_title: Advanced Radio Frequency Link Analysis Tool
research_keywords: RF,radiofrequency,link budget,interference,dynamic scenario,communication,MODELING AND SIMULATION,SATCOM
abstract: In this proposal, we present a novel solution for RF link analysis that combines mature propagation models, innovative enhancements relevant to emerging technologies, and a custom graphical interface tailored to handle dynamic scenarios potentially including airborne platforms over land, sea, or littoral environments. The solution includes the ability to analyze communications systems, including noise and interference and their effect on the performance. A strong emphasis is placed on dynamic scenarios with moving vehicles, and analysis to determine link availability over large regions. The full modeling suite allows for tradeoffs between fidelity and run time, supporting all relevant parts of the problem, including support for built-in antennas or detailed 2D or 3D antenna gain patterns from external computation electromagnetic codes. The basic methodology is presented for the graphical user interface, with a task outlined to evaluate alternatives and determine specific tools and approaches for the final product. The resulting product will draw on years of experience and investment in commercial and government-off-the-shelf capabilities, while incorporating several key features needed to support military applications as well as multiple emerging technologies in wireless and automotive industries.

award_title: Mitigation of Helmet Vibration
research_keywords: Computational model,resonance,multidisciplinary design optimization,E-2D,Finite Element Analysis,structural-acoustic,3D scanning,HGU-68/P helmet
abstract: During operation of E-2D aircraft, excessive cockpit noise and helmet vibration have resulted in documented cases of aircrew fatigue, hearing loss, and missed radio communications. Preliminary studies have identified that poor vibro-acoustic performance of the HGU-68/P helmet in the frequency range of E-2D operation may be the root cause. Skyward proposes a solution leveraging high-fidelity computational simulation to predict the HGU-68/P vibro-acoustic performance and physics-based multidisciplinary optimization to explore design alternatives and potential solutions to reduce sound pressure levels and dynamic excitations experienced by the wearer. Efforts will include 3D scanning to capture helmet geometry, creation of high fidelity structural-acoustic finite element (FE) model of the helmet in the E-2D environment, validation of the model against experimental testing to reduce uncertainty in the computational models, and design optimization to explore solutions. The Phase I effort will produce a high-fidelity, experimentally validated computational model of the helmet, as well as multiple options for design modifications to reduce noise intensity and helmet accelerations, which can be explored in Phase II.

award_title: Mitigation of Noise and Vibration in Helmets
research_keywords: OPTIMIZATION,Finite Element Analysis,Vibration,modal testing,resonance,helmet,Noise Attenuation
abstract: Cornerstone Research Group Inc. (CRG) proposes to provide the Navy with experimentally validated solutions for reducing noise and vibration transmitted through the helmet in the E-2D aircraft, ultimately relieving pilots of harmful vibration and noise. This will be achieved through the development of a finite element model of the HGU-68/P helmet with appropriate loading and boundary conditions to simulate its actual use in the aircraft, experimental modal and acoustic testing to validate the model, the development of helmet modifications for reducing noise and vibration, and experimental testing to validate the modifications effectiveness for helmet noise and vibration mitigation. CRGs demonstrated expertise in human factors engineering, finite element analysis, and acoustic and vibration testing presents the Navy with the opportunity to obtain reduced pilot fatigue and increased operational performance through the introduction of experimentally validated solutions for helmet vibration mitigation.

award_title: Mitigation of Helmet Vibration
research_keywords: aircrew,resonant amplification,helmet vibration,propeller blade frequency,resonance,Modal Analysis,Finite Element Analysis,helmet noise
abstract: Acentech will leverage its expertise and considerable experience in solving vibration and noise problems to develop and provide finite element models and modal and transfer function analyses of the E-2D flight helmet to address the problem of pilot exposure to excessive vibration/noise related primarily to propeller blade passage tones. High-fidelity ANSYS FE models of the helmet composite shell including foamed liner components will be developed and used to predict structural resonance frequencies and mode shapes as well as shell vibration and ear noise levels for point and distributed pressure loads on the shell. Helmet testing on an artificial head utilizing modal and transfer function analyses will be used to characterize the helmet dynamic response to point force and distributed pressure loads, to provide validation of the FE models and to identify, along with the FE models, whether shell resonance amplifies tonal cockpit noise/vibration components. The FE models will be used in Phase II to optimize mitigation approaches that reduce pilot exposure, including structural modification of the shell and enhanced helmet and liner sound attenuation. Other approaches such as tuned vibration absorbers on the shell and active control strategies will also be evaluated for potential effectiveness and feasibility.

award_title: Flight Head and Hearing Protection System
research_keywords: resonant modes,Vibration Analysis,Vibration Mitigation,E-2D,hearing protection,helmets
abstract: Upgrades to the E-2D Advanced Hawkeye inadvertently resulted in higher acoustic loading at its propellers blade pass frequency (BPF). This frequency overlaps with vibrational modes of the standard fixed-wing aircrew helmet, the HGU-68/P. As a combined result, E-2D pilots are experiencing exceptionally large vibrational and acoustic (noise) loading, potentially compromising aircrew performance and mission success. Targeted improvements to the helmet system are needed to mitigate this issue. Creare proposes to apply our validated approach to solving vibro-acoustic problems and modify the HGU-68/P to reduce its vibrational and acoustic response around the E-2D BPF. This improved Flight Head and Hearing Protection System (FHHPS) will result is less pilot fatigue and noise exposure, enabling longer missions with greater chance of success.

award_title: Magnetorheological Active Damper with Linear Resonating Actuator (MAD-LRA) and Magnetorheological Impact Foams (MIF) for Mitigation of Helmet Vibratio
research_keywords: Vibration Control,Passive smart damper,vibration monitoring,MR damper,Active control
abstract: Noisy cockpits lead to higher workload during flight, compromised radio communications and excessive fatigue in pilots post flight. Excessive noise in cockpit also results in a temporary shift of the auditory threshold known as a Temporary Threshold Shift(TTS). At low frequencies, the helmet itself starts resonating at the characteristic frequency of the helmet close to the excitation source frequency such as BPF. This causes the ear cups to break seal with the pilots head and subject the pilot to excessive noise. The existing Communications earplug and active noise reduction technology cannot eliminate the helmet vibration. Therefore there is a need for new a technology reduce resonating helmet noise. We propose to develop a Magnetorheological Active Damper with Linear Resonating Actuator(MAD-LRA) and Magnetorheological Impact Foams(MIF) for mitigation of helmet vibration. There are two key innovations; one, is to integrate magnetorheological damping along with existing Linear Resonance Actuator(LRA) to develop an active damper with tunable damping force and frequency; two, to use state-of-the-art Magnetorheological Impact Foam(MIF) pads for passive damping using magnetic sheets creating light weight MIF damping pads for effective passive damping at selected locations. Combination of these active and passive damping will provide effective mitigation of helmet vibration during flight.

award_title: Epoxyless Connectors for Optical Fiber
research_keywords: Epoxyless ferrule,fiber optics,DIRCM,MWIR laser
abstract: The Navy has identified the need for an epoxyless fiber optic ferrule and associated connector housing, and mating adapter, for optical fibers designed for transmission from 2-10 microns in wavelength. The primary application for epoxyless mid-infrared (MWIR) fiber connector technology is the PMA-272 Directed Infrared Countermeasures (DIRCM) program and a secondary application is at-a-distance chemical and biological agent sensors. Other Navy applications of epoxyless low loss fiber optic connector technology, when used with other types of optical fiber, include high energy fiber laser weapons, platform interconnects, and tethers for towed arrays and undersea weapons. nPP proposes to offer epoxyless metallic ferrules optimized for laser sources in the MWIR, capable of running at the required powers and power densities (100 W, 10 GW/cm2) that are MIL-STD810G and AS6021 compliant. Aiding the ability to withstand these powers is that the ferrule will be metallic, and so will act as a combined radiative and thermally conductive heat sink reducing the temperature rise of the fiber, something the ceramic ferrules cannot do effectively. The need for and design of a custom heat-sinking connector housing and adaptor with optimized thermal properties that mate the two ferrules ends together will be investigated, and designed if required.

award_title: High Power Optical Connector
research_keywords: optical fiber termination,CONNECTOR,MWIR,Fiber Optic,epoxyless,Laser,Termini,optical fiber cable assembly
abstract: Triton Systems, Inc. proposes to develop an innovative method for terminating optical fiber with an epoxyless connector. Tritons design offers a robust solution that does not require adhesives which could be damaged by the high power throughput.

award_title: Free Space Optical Connector for High Power MWIR Applications
research_keywords: epoxyless,MWIR,fiber optics,chalcogenide,Mode Stripper,ZBLAN,Fiber connector
abstract: Q-Peak will leverage its extensive free space optical connector design experience to develop a novel high power optical connector for common Mid-Wave Infrared fibers which is mechanically robust. Q-Peak will demonstrate an integrated fiber collimator/mode stripper formed using a collapsed index-matched capillary tube. By leveraging a teaming agreement with NRL, Q-Peak will then demonstrate epoxy-free mounting of the fiber collimator assembly within a CTE-matched ferrule using a proprietary ultra-low Tg frit glass solder. In Phase II, Q-Peak will also work with NRL to concurrently develop a process for applying nanostructured (Motheye) AR coatings to the fiber collimator assembly. Finally, Q-Peak will leverage its extensive mechanical design talent to design a connector housing and mating interface which is robust against MIL-STD-810G environmental testing criteria through many mate-demate cycles.

award_title: Reliable Target Area of Uncertainty from an Underwater Acoustic Source(s)
research_keywords: GPS-denied navigation,Ocean Acoustics,Sonar,area of uncertainty
abstract: We will decrease the Areas of Uncertainties (AOU) of targets for the MAC sonar system by 1) modifying the pattern of buoys and 2) using traditional and novel types of acoustic data to self-locate the buoys and targets. The novel acoustic data will make it easier to identify and remove clutter. The proposed technology will improve the MAC systems performance even when the Global Positioning System is unavailable.

award_title: Reliable Target Area of Uncertainty from an Underwater Acoustic Source(s)
research_keywords: Acoustic Array Configuration Sensing,Direct Path Analysis
abstract: The Navys Multi-Static Active Coherent (MAC) system is a multi-static sonar system deployed in the ocean from an aircraft used for wide area search. Surface-drifting buoys are dropped at pre-determined locations and then drift with the currents in somewhat unpredictable ways. Acoustic source buoys are commanded to ping from an aircraft individually or simultaneously using different frequencies. The drifting receivers relay acoustic and auxiliary data to the aircraft for analysis of possible target detections followed by localization, classification and prosecution. In a GPS denied area of the globe, or without the use of any aircraft ability to localize the buoys, innovative acoustic approaches which leverage acoustic processing of the transmitted pings and incorporate innovative statistical methods are an excellent means of determining the relative position of each buoy and the overall shape of the buoy field. Understanding buoy positions and the overall position of the array will provide better localization of the target and the overall time to prosecute that target can be reduced.

award_title: Reliable Target Area of Uncertainty from an Underwater Acoustic Source(s)
research_keywords: AOU,Water,buoy,Acoustic,Multi-static,Active sonar
abstract: The overall and principal objective in the Phase I effort will be determining the feasibility of an algorithmic approach to yield reliable and reduced target AOUs in an air deployed multi-static active sonar field. The feasibility will be based on the realized accuracy gains; achieving real-time data turn-around; and the computer information processing (IP) resources needed for estimating AOUs in real time. Achieving these capabilities and demonstrating the overall feasibility requires a clear understanding of each aspect of the resultant multi-element processing information exchange. As identified in the SBIR topic discussion, the principal data input elements to be addressed in the algorithm development are: estimates of the initial buoy locations; estimates of the speed of sound in water; estimates of current velocities; and the acoustic signals [generated by the VLA source and received by the directional array sonobuoys in the deployed field].

award_title: Reliable Target Area of Uncertainty from an Underwater Acoustic Source(s)
research_keywords: Multistatic localization,buoy localization,multistatic active coherent,area of uncertainty,Sonobuoy,target location,Multistatic Sonar
abstract: Signal Systems Corporation will develop Buoy Localization and Uncertainty Estimation (BLUE) which will accurately estimate areas of uncertainty for selected target echoes. The area of uncertainty will be significantly reduced by incorporating advanced buoy localization methods and by retrospective multiple hypothesis tracking on selected receivers with lower detection thresholds. The buoy localization techniques will reduce buoy location errors, sound speed uncertainty, and compass bias errors. The multiple hypothesis tracker will reduce target azimuth errors by repeated measurements of the targets angle of arrival. We seek to reduce the circular error probability radius by a factor of two (2), resulting in a four times reduction in AOU. Accurate and reliable AOUs will be computed from the position probability density function of the target, using in-situ estimates of the relevant target localization parameters. The buoy localization algorithms and retrospective tracker will be used to assess the effects different buoy patterns have on the resulting target AOU.

award_title: Inflatable Multi-Platform Recovery System
research_keywords: inflatable structure,drop-stitch inflatable hull panels,Shallow Water Combat Submersible,Seal Delivery Vehicle,submersible sled
abstract: The SEAL Delivery Vehicle (SDV) and the Shallow Water Combat Submersible (SWCS) are swimmer delivery vehicles used by Naval Special Warfare. When a malfunction disables one of these submersibles, under certain scenarios it can be recovered by towing, using a rigid sled for support. The current sled is large and heavy: too large to be carried aboard a small craft like a Navy RHIB, and too large to be carried aboard a larger ship as standard equipment. A lightweight, inflatable sled that could facilitate high-speed surface towing of a disabled SDV or SWCS would improve the Navys ability to effect recovery over a broader range of circumstances. We propose to use lightweight drop-stitch inflatable panels, combined with an inflatable RHIB-style collar tube, to develop such a sled that would provide the stability and hydrodynamic shape required to safely support a disabled submersible while towing at speeds up to 20 knots.

award_title: Inflatable Multi-Platform Recovery System
research_keywords: inflatable,SWCS,Naval Special Warfare,SDV
abstract: Naval Special Warfare operations depend on mobility. A man-portable, rapidly deployable, inflatable surface system to facilitate the high-speed surface tow of a disabled undersea vehicle such as the SEAL Delivery Vehicle (SDV) and Shallow Water Combat Submersible (SWCS) is needed. Triton Systems proposes a packable inflatable system that deploys and installs rapidly and simply. During Phase I, the team will study the hydrodynamic requirements for safe and stable towing, analyze materials and manufacturing methods, develop deployment, installation, recovery, and stowage options, provide risk/payoff trade analysis for various options, and recommend a system design and associated cost estimate.

award_title: High Quality Composite Fabrication without Autoclaves or Ovens
research_keywords: repair,Out of autoclave,Composite Fabrication,curing,Nano-heaters
abstract: To fabricate high-quality composite components with acceptable thermal properties and low void volume, autoclaves are typically essential to provide elevated temperature processing cycles and external pressure required for adequate compaction. However, autoclaves represent large capital and energy investments while limiting the size of fabricated parts and production flexibility. Out-of-autoclave (OOA) fabrication technologies have not matured enough to consistently produce low-void content, high-quality parts. Advanced OOA methods are required to effectively apply heat and compact the resulting composites to meet the stringent mechanical specifications of structural aerospace components. Because large ovens have many of the same fabrication constraints as autoclaves, heating films/blankets have been employed for OOA applications. A potential improvement would be to use heating elements based on carbon nanotubes, such as those being developed by our partner at NC State University (NSCU). These systems will provide excellent temperature distribution across the composite while using less energy than conventional ovens/autoclaves. Engineers at Luna Innovations recently developed a simple composite fabrication technology which has demonstrated low-porosity composite fabrication using a single vacuum bag for compaction. Luna will combine our expertise along with novel nano-heating systems at NCSU to develop efficient, OOA technology for the fabrication and repair of aerospace-quality composites.

award_title: Out-of-Autoclave Composite Curing Utilizing Nanostructured Heaters and Integrated Temperature Monitoring
research_keywords: Fiber Optic,Quality Assurance,Out of autoclave,repair,nanostructured heaters,Nanomaterials
abstract: San Diego Composites, Inc. (SDC) has developed a conceptual out of autoclave (OOA) composite curing patch system based on integrated nanomaterial heaters that can be applied in repair applications to support the Navys need for an energy efficient, autoclave-quality repair method to support the EQ-4C Triton Program and other composite aircraft. Current repair methods utilized in composite repair do not produce bonded repairs that are virgin-laminate quality or acceptable by the FAA for structural components. The two major flaws in the current method are the heat application and lack of quality assurance of the joint. SDCs Laminate Integrated Nanostructure Based Autoclave-less Cure (LINBAC) repair technology will provide the Navy with a method for producing autoclave-quality composite repairs in-situ without the need for the high costs and stringent facility requirements of an autoclave. The technology uses nanostructured heaters integrated into the laminate and laid out in a gridding pattern and integrated sensors for quality assurance purposes. SDC has estimated that a 50% reduction in aircraft downtime could be realized for critical assets through the use of the LINBAC system over a traditional repair method. SDC plans to develop the heater technology and quality assurance method, then realize the repair technology.

award_title: Out-of-Autoclave Composite Curing Utilizing Nanostructured Heaters
research_keywords: flexible,Continuous Production and Product Form,Uniform Heating,Fast Heating and Cooling,Lightweight
abstract: General Nano and supply chain and OEM partners have developed VeeloHEAT, a lightweight, flexible, uniform heater that the aerospace composites industry is currently evaluating to improve throughput, quality and efficiency for out of autoclave composite processing, composite tooling with embedded heating elements, specialty heaters bonded to metallic tooling, and composite repair. Contained within the proposal, General Nano will summarize a suite of nanostructured heat materials that are manufactured using high-throughput assets and continuous manufacturing operations. The uniqueness of General Nano's products, form factors, manufacturing processes, and customer-centic product development focus earned The Boeing Company's "2016 Supplier of the Year for Technology" accolade. General Nano is committed to executing with the same level of focus in this Navy SBIR program.

award_title: Engineering Strain-Free Epitaxial Ternary Lead Salt Films for Ambient Temperature Infrared Detectors
research_keywords: photoconductive,epitaxial,Lead salts,Lattice-Matched,chemical detection,detector,Infrared
abstract: Physical Sciences Inc. (PSI) and the PARADIM Center at Cornell University will develop photoconductive infrared detectors capable of achieving a detectivity of 2 x 10^11 cm*Hz^1/2/W and a noise-equivalent power (NEP) of less than 0.5 pW/Hz^1/2 at ambient temperature. These gains will be realized by creating fully encapsulated epitaxial films of ternary lead salts. Using vapor-phase deposition techniques, PSI and team members will grow strain-free epitaxial heterostructures consisting of a ternary lead salt photoconductive layer, custom-grown single-crystal substrates engineered to match the lattice constant of the absorber, and an epitaxial capping layer. This approach/architecture will enable quantum efficiencies of greater than 30% by eliminating structural defects such as misfit dislocations and unpassivated surface states that compromise carrier extraction. During Phase I, PSI will demonstrate growth of single-crystal substrates and strain-free ternary lead salt epilayers. PSI will also submit a complete design for a photoconductive detector. In a Phase I option, PSI and partners will demonstrate growth of epitaxial passivation layers lattice-matched to the growth substrate and measure the photoresponse of test devices. During Phase II, PSI will create and test complete detectors meeting the above specifications for detectivity, NEP, and quantum efficiency.

award_title: Hot Wall Epitaxy of Mixed Lead Chalcogenides in Resonant Cavity Structures
research_keywords: ternary lead salt,mixed chalcogenides,thin film,resonant cavity,MWIR detector,Focal plane array
abstract: The US Navys Combined Electro-Optical/Infrared Surveillance and Response System (CESARS) is seeking medium wavelength infrared detectors (MWIR) that can use spectral signatures in 2-5 m range to remotely detect and characterize explosive chemicals or chemical warfare species. Group III-V and II-VI compound semiconductors-based focal plane arrays (FPAs) have the desired properties in the MWIR for remote detection of chemical species, however they require cryogenic cooling to minimize dark current noise, which adds significantly to the size, weight, power and cost of the detector. On the other hand, narrow bandgap lead salts can operate at >200 K, and are also more chemically stable. Binary lead salts have been well-studied for MWIR applications. However, mixed chalcogenides that offer wavelength tunability, are not commercially available mainly due to challenges in manufacturing device-grade material. We propose to develop a high-quality ternary lead salt detector which can operate at room temperature with high detectivity, and with cutoff wavelength spanning the range of 3.5 to 4.6 m. A novel cost-effective method for fabricating high-quality films will be demonstrated. Such films will then by integrated into Resonant Cavity-Enhanced FPA architecture to improve detectivity, QE and tunability of the MWIR detectors.

award_title: Lead-Salt Infrared Detectors
research_keywords: Room Temperature MWIR Detector,Threat Warning Sensor,Lead Salt Infrared Detector,physical vapor deposition
abstract: St Johns Optical Systems (SJOS) has already made a committed to a technology transition for lead salt focal plane arrays in collaboration with BAE Systems. This SBIR will allow us to develop new detectors that are well suited for threat-warning applications and for commercial use with industrial inspection. We will incorporate and expand upon advances in PbSe detectors made under our participation in the DARPA WIRED program along with BAE Systems. In addition, ternary alloy lead salts are within the capability of the existing SJOS lead salt film growth facility, and will offer new possibilities for detector performance. Research by our team to date has already begun to incorporate these techniques, and shows promise to boost signal-to-noise by more than a factor of 10. This would be sufficient to realize the goals of this program based on our existing measurements. Here we propose research and development in ternary alloy lead salts in order to achieve a range of cutoff wavelengths from 3.5 to 4.6 m with a D* on the order of 1E11 Jones based on standard lead salt detector characterization practices.

award_title: Numerical Methods Combat Power and Energy Systems (CPES)
research_keywords: early stage ship design,all-electric ship,decision support,Surrogate math models
abstract: The US Navy has been moving towards Integrated Power Systems (IPS) for Naval ships because they separate the prime movers from the propulsion train, maximize the efficiency, reduce acoustic signatures, improve redundancy, improve survivability, and provide compatibility with the increasing power requirements from advanced weapons, sensors, and radar systems. In electric warship design the ability to rapidly test many architectural concepts by simulating operational activities is critical for successfully completing early stage design activities. Further, integration of IPS design with LEAPS is essential for compatibility with the Navys overall ship design process. Available power system simulation tools require fidelity of information and computational resources that are too high for early stage design activities. The proposed research will address this need and create an Emulator Toolkit for LEAPS. Emulators (i.e. surrogate models) will represent the time varying behavior of components and/or subsystems of an IPS. A mathematical synthesis method will be integrating the emulators for creating a surrogate model for the entire IPS. During Phase I alternative mathematical methods for generating and integrating the emulators will be investigated and documented. A down selection of the most appropriate methods will be completed and an implementation plan compatible with LEAPS will be made.

award_title: Numerical Methods Combat Power and Energy Systems (CPES)
research_keywords: S3D,statistical emulator,mission analytics,surrogate modeling,time-integration scheme,pulse loads,adaptable numerical modeling strategy
abstract: New CPES concepts are pushing the electrical power demands of U.S. Navy ships continually higher. What makes these technologies fundamentally different are their very high pulse loads and highly distributed, interconnected architectures. Ships cannot support these new technologies without considerable modifications. The ONR-funded Electric Ship Research and Design Consortium produced the Smart Ship Systems Design (S3D) tool to address shortcomings in existing tools, but S3D is still very limited. In its current state, S3D can only perform quasi-static analysis of thermal, mechanical, and electrical loads, which can miss key elements of simulating high pulse loads. S3D also lacks a statistical method for understanding variability in operational mission loads. Finally, system component definitions in S3D do not support set-based design (SBD) philosophies being adopted by other Navy tools, such as RSDE. In this effort, we propose to research and document methods to improve S3D with statistical mission emulators, fully-dynamic time-domain analysis, and surrogate modeling techniques to support early-stage ship design and SBD. Perhaps most importantly, we propose to deliver adaptable modeling strategies so that S3D can evolve and continue to offer valuable analysis as the CPES landscape is still rapidly changing.

award_title: Abrasive Blasting Nozzle Noise Control
research_keywords: Turbulent Mixing Noise,Abrasive Blasting Nozzle,Paint and Surface Coatings Removal,jet impingement,Productivity of Blasting Nozzle,Supersonic Shock Noise
abstract: Oceanit proposes to develop technologies to improve the acoustics performance of abrasive blasting nozzles for paint and surface coatings removal.

award_title: High Productivity Low Noise Abrasive Blast Nozzle
research_keywords: abrasive blasting,Nozzle,noise induced hearing loss,noise reduction
abstract: Navy vessels, along with other military, civil, and commercial equipment and structures, are routinely stripped by abrasive blasting in preparation for re-coating. Using existing nozzles, blasting generates continuous noise levels up to 145 dBA, and even with correctly worn double hearing protection, blasting operators are at risk of hearing damage. Noise induced hearing loss has become the most costly Department of Defense disability, and in FY15, 2.5M veterans received $1B in compensation benefits for tinnitus and hearing loss. Creare will develop an improved blast nozzle design that offers improved coating removal productivity and energy efficiency while reducing noise emissions by up to 30 dB relative to existing nozzles. This design will generate significant savings in labor, energy, and costs associated with hearing damage, making this nozzle a disruptive technology evolution that will be attractive in essentially all military and commercial blasting operations.

award_title: Abrasive Blasting Nozzle Noise Control
research_keywords: Nozzle,abrasive blasting,Noise control,Jet noise
abstract: An abrasive blasting nozzle is a complex aero-acoustic noise source, characterized by super-sonic, two-phase flow. Noise from an abrasive blasting nozzle is comprised of three sources: (i) turbulent mixing noise (ii) shock-associated noise and (iii) jet impingement noise. It is not uncommon for abrasive nozzles to generate noise levels greater than 120 dB(A); far exceeding typical occupational noise limits. The work proposed herein will apply sophisticated aero-acoustics principals to the design of an abrasive blasting nozzle; reducing noise from the nozzle while simultaneously improving the devices productivity. The nozzle developed through this effort will provide industry with a device that represents an evolutionary step forward in safety and efficiency.

award_title: Fast Rise-time High Power Radio Frequency (HPRF) Pulse Shaping
research_keywords: waveguide triggered plasma switches,pulse shaping,solid state,High-Power Microwave
abstract: Eagle Harbor Technologies, Inc. (EHT) is collaborating with researchers at the Pulsed Power and Power Electronics Center at Texas Tech University (TTU) to develop a high-power microwave switch that is capable of very fast rise times, adjustable pulse width, and high pulse repetition frequency (PRF). EHT has developed solid-state pulsed power systems that has the potential to improve the performance of the TTU microwave switch and demonstrate high PRF operation. The goal of this SBIR program is to develop a low-cost, compact, microwave switch that can significantly increase the U.S. Navy directed energy capabilities.

award_title: Fast Rise Time High Power Radio Frequency Pulse Shaping
research_keywords: pulse shaping,edge and tail clipping,High Power,Plasma switch,Fast rise time,HPRF,megawatt switching
abstract: The Navy has a need for a fast rise time High Power Radio Frequency (HPRF) pulse shaping tool to augment its capabilities for lethality and counter-electronics testing. Verus Research (VR) team members have designed, built and tested similar capabilities for HPRF systems and have extensive expertise and experience in the field of effects testing and will leverage that expertise to develop a cost effective, compact solution. The concept of switching RF output to generate various pulses with a few nanosecond rise times and pulse durations ranging from 10s to 1000 nanoseconds has broad potential to the HPRF testing community. VR proposes designing and modeling a plasma switch assembly to determine the optimum physical and electrical characteristics required to create an efficient and reliable switch for multi-megawatt sources. The pulse shaping assembly consists of a pair of switches (front and tail clipping), a high-power circulator and a dual output pulser to drive. Verus Research will model and design the system with the broadest versatility and integrate its operational parameters into the design and the appropriate models.

award_title: Perfusion Technology for Vascular Composite Tissue Conservation and Maintenance
research_keywords: Combat injury,machine perfusion,Preservation,Regeneration,Transplant,trauma,Vascular Composite
abstract: Advancements in body armor combined with better combat casualty care have greatly increased the survival rate of soldiers suffering battlefield trauma injuries. The increased survivability, however, has resulted in an increase of wounded warriors being sent home with severe injuries that ultimately reduce their quality of life post-treatment, especially amputations and damage to vascularized composite tissues. Recent research and advances in regenerative medicine offers never-before seen possibilities for new therapies and treatment of trauma injuries to vascularized composite tissues; however, many surgical and treatment outcomes are still affected by the limited amount of time avaible for organ or tissue preservation following a trauma induced injury. Surgical outcomes could be greatly improved if tissue salvage and conservation could be achieved over longer time periods. Towards these ends, TDA Research, Inc. proposes to develop a novel perfusion system for the salvage and repair of trauma injured vascularized composite tissue. This system will increase the preservation time for vascularized composite tissue, enabling advanced treatments or transplant capabilities.

award_title: Production and maintenance of tissue-engineered human osteochondral grafts
research_keywords: Osteochondral Tissue Engineering,bioreactor,Preservation,Autologous
abstract: EpiBone is a company engineering living, anatomically precise and functionally mature skeletal grafts from autologous stem cells. Cartilage injuries affect approximately 900K Americans with >400K procedures performed every year. Cartilage lesions are frequently associated with other articular injuries and can progress to joint degeneration and osteoarthritis (OA). OA affects20% Americans with costs surpassing $130B per year. Compared to civilian population, active military service members are affected with OA diseases with higher rates and younger ages. OA is among the most common causes of disability in service members who are medically retired or separated from the military. 71% of extremityinjuries suffered by soldiers in recent conflicts have been associated with intra-articular injury.  Current therapeutic practices suffer from several drawbacks, thus creating the need for novel, cell-based therapies for regenerating functional cartilage tissue.  We here propose to develop a unique class of bioreactor-cultured, stratified, mechanically functional osteochondral grafts for articular cartilage repair that are customized to the patient and defect being treated. The success of our product could have a tremendous impact in ameliorating current standards of treatment for osteochondral defects, representing a definitive solution avoiding morbidity, and leading to faster recovery and return to duty for the injured soldiers.

award_title: High Sub-zero Storage Technology for Countermeasure Stockpiling of Bone Marrow, Skin &amp; Blood Vessels
research_keywords: Bone marrow banking,cryopreservation of stem cells,tissue cryopreservation,isochoric cryopreservation,Vitrification,biobanking,organ preservation,banking of hematopoietic stem cells
abstract: While millions of patients are affected by the inability to bank many types of cells, tissues and vital organs, the demands on optimal preservation modalities for  mass casualty contexts are  higher and not well met.  In this context, solutions need to be transport-friendly and field ready. Our innovations allow indefinite storage of living biological matter at high subzero temperatures that enable transportation and storage without the need for cumbersome use of liquid nitrogen. The approach is universal and will enable stockpiling of (i) bone marrow (and cord blood/peripheral blood-HSCs), natural and bioengineered (ii) skin, (iii) veins and arteries, and eventually also (iv) VCA and (v) vital organs.     Importantly our approach does not suffer the CPA toxicity, osmotic injury or ice damage inherent in all current preservation modalities. We propose a novel approach to biopreservation that combines recent advances in nature inspired, non-toxic cryoprotective and stress tolerance enhancement strategies with a novel isochoric  (constant volume) thermodynamically-advantaged storage system that enables indefinite storage at high subzero temperatures.  The commercial potential for this approach, embodying both novel techniques of biobanking and enabling devices, targets a large addressable market currently of the order of $50 billion for cell, tissue and organ units worldwide.

award_title: Secure Wireless Disposable Pulse Oximeter Patch that Generates a PPG Waveform
research_keywords: Pulse oximetry,Photoplethysmograph,Respiration Rate,WIRELESS,wearable devices,noninvasive monitoring,triage,Combat Casualty Care
abstract: Wearable devices have grown to meet the demand for continuous, noninvasive vital signs monitoring in the military and civilian health care markets.  These devices have largely excluded pulse oximetry because non-traditional sites, such as the chest, arm and legs, pose a challenge.  We have previously demonstrated the ability to accurately monitor pulse oximetry on the chest, arms and calf.  This project proposes to develop a wearable, secure wireless adhesive patch system to monitor pulse oximetry, respiration rate and other core vital signs from non-traditional sites.  The system will provide real-time, continuous monitoring, and be able to withstand the physical environmental challenges of shock, dust, sand, and water. The battery-powered, wireless oximeter will transmit computed parameters and pulse oximeter photoplethysmograph (PPG) waveform to military-selected medic end user device (EUD).  Data transmission to the EUD enables two features: simultaneous monitoring of multiple casualties; and development of predictive models and indices independent of the monitoring device. The wireless oximeter will include technological advancements such as miniaturization, reduced power consumption, high bandwidth wireless communication and enhanced measurement algorithms. These advances will lay the foundation for further development and testing in this rugged environment and integration beyond the medics EUD into larger medical record systems.

award_title: Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS) for Image Stabilization in Small Missiles
address1: 53 Old Solomons Island Rd Suite H
research_keywords: Micro-Electro-Mechanical Sensors,MEMS,Optical Image Stabilization,small low cost misssiles
abstract: MEMS inertial sensor technology holds the promise of reducing the size, weight, power and cost (SWPaC) requirements for performing existing functions in Army missile systems. New MEMS inertial sensors will enable the Army's next generation of smaller and lighter missiles. Tanenhaus and Associates, Inc. miniature IMU (M350) meets SWPaC requirements using its patented innovative approach of combining arrays of COTS MEMS sensors to achieve far superior performance than MEMS used alone. The MEMS arrays provide redundancy and robustness and achieve sensor low drift errors. In this Phase I SBIR will expand the use of COTS MEMS technology that has exceptionally wide angular rate range for use low cost missile stabilization systems.  A reduced size version of the M350 is proposed that will meet the 1.5 cu.in low power low weight goals of this program. When TAIs low drift error solution is applied to MEMS gyro capable of 100,000 deg./sec angular rates, the jitter performance is dramatically lower. The TAI IMU/INS technology is flexible; software upgrades allow for its adaptability for a variety of uses with the same internal hardware. Both the inner electronic module and the outside case can be changed easily to meet small missile requirements.

award_title: Reprogrammable Software Radio
research_keywords: Missile,Data Link,Radio,RaSoR,MML,IFPC
abstract: The RaSoR supports various current and future missiles with a single, re-programmable software radio unit.

award_title: Repurposed Software Programmable Radio Technology to Support Flexible Missile Uplink/Downlink Implementations
research_keywords: SDR,Missile,Communications,uplink,downlink,waveforms,reprogrammable,DSP
abstract: Supporting multiple missile types, and frequency bands, is the inherent functionality of the Space Micro's Dual channel Software Defined Radio. As a repurposed SDR, this hardware radio supports firmware reprogramming to multiple waveform configurations (DoD specified), and accepts IF block down-conversions from L, S, C, X, and Ku bands. Size and power usage are only a small fraction of the legacy systems currently deployed (according to non-classified data comparisons); however, full legacy compatibility and interoperability are inherent and guaranteed by design. Further, support for future missile waveforms is supported due to the generous digital signal processing logic resources made available by the Xilinx Kintex-7 series FPGA used in the Space Micro tri-band SDR. Figure 1 illustrates the functional blocks of our dual-channel SDR.

award_title: Flexible Missile Uplink Downlink Software Ground Radio
research_keywords: Missile,uplink,downlink,Software Programmable,SDR,IAMD,IBCS,IFPC Inc 2-I
abstract: The Army Integrated Air and Missile Defense (IAMD) integrates sensors and weapon and a common mission command (MC) across a single, integrated fire control network.  As one of its program pillars it intends to reduce the MC footprint and replace obsolete architecture.  As an integral part of the IAMD architecture the Indirect Fire Protection Capability (IFPC) Increment 2 - Intercept mission will provide a robust platoon-level protection capability against all projected rocket, artillery and mortar (RAM), cruise missile, and unmanned aircraft systems (UAS) threats, and subsequently is interested in expanding its complement of Multi-Mission Launcher (MML) interceptors, including, but not limited to, the AIM-9X, the AIM-120, the AI3 and the Miniature Hit-To-Kill (MHTK).    This proposal addresses the potential problem of unique/stovepipe missile uplink/downlink (UL/DL) equipment, which from a size, weight and power (SWaP) perspective impacts the mobility and transportability of the MML.  The opportunity is to leverage Innoflights expertise developing and fielding compact, rugged software defined radios to design a flexible multi-channel, multi-user radio supporting missile UL/DL implementations for multiple missiles.  The target SWaP will match the IAMDs Small Footprint Radio (SFR) supporting the IFPC platoon network communications requirements.

award_title: High Bandwidth Ka/X-Band Software-defined Compact Radio
research_keywords: SmallSat and CubeSat transceiver radio,Software-defined radio,AES-256 NSA Encryption,S / X / Ka Bands,Army RGT and AFSCN interoperability,Solid State Data Recorder,Spectrum Efficient Waveforms
abstract: Innoflight will develop a high performance software-defined compact radio (SCR) with Ka and X dual band downlink capability and S Band uplink capability. The Ka / X SCR will support 300 Mbps downlink and 5 Mbps uplinks rates using spectrally efficient waveforms.  It will offer interoperability with standard government and commercial ground stations such as the Army RGT (Remote Ground Terminal), AFSCN (Air Force Satellite Control Network), NASA Near Earth Network (NEN), and multiple commercial service networks.      It will support advanced waveform processing include various spectrally efficient modulation techniques, forward error correction methods and simple bus interfaces.  Link confidentiality and authentication will be supported by internal AES-256 encryption suite or and external certified unit such as the Innoflight Gnome or the KI-55.  A built-in Solid State Data Recorder (SSDR) will host up to 1 Tbyte of mission data and support the full downlink throughput of 300 Mbps.      Innoflight will leverage its on-orbit heritage and market leading SCR technology as the point of departure in order to reduce the overall design risk and focus on the high risk elements of this effort.

award_title: High Bandwidth Redundant Communication Links for Small Satellites
address1: 11711 N. Creek Pkwy S., Suite D113
research_keywords: Software Defined Radio,Satellite communications,Ka-band,X-band,SATCOM
abstract: Small satellites have never lacked the capability to collect large quantities of operationally relevant data. The real limitation in fielding large constellations has been the inability to downlink the large quantities of data. Neither the ground station assets nor the high throughput communications subsystems have existed to close many point-to-point tight-beam links to low-Earth orbit. To satisfy the demand for these increased data volumes, TUI proposes to both leverage and extend its existing modular SWIFT software-defined radio (SDR) platform to create a multi-band S-, X-, and Ka-band transceiver capable of closing SATCOM links in excess of 300 Mbps to smaller, tactically placed ground stations. Key enabling technologies include the integration TUIs existing three degree-of-freedom (3DOF) COBRA gimbal for steering high-gain apertures, existing and in-development X- and Ka-band RF frontends with greater than 500 MHz of instantaneous bandwidth, and the proposed next generation SWIFT baseband processor with greater than 500 MHz of modulation bandwidth and the ability to stream significant quantities of data to and from external high-density storage subsystems. The proposed transceiver will guarantee the operational relevance of the next generation of tactical US Army small satellites.

award_title: High Bandwidth Redundant Communication Links for Small Satellites
research_keywords: Cubesat,Nanosatellite,Ka-band,X-band,high bandwidth downlink,
abstract: The choke point for small satellites is the mission downlink.  It is possible to deploy sensors on small satellites capable of capturing gigabytes of data per orbit, but there are no small, low-cost broadband transmitters capable of getting this enormous amount of data to the ground in a timely manner.  This project will prove the feasibility of achieving downlink rates of 120 Mbps in the X-band (7.25-7.75 GHz) and 300 Mbps in the Ka-band (30-31 GHz).   Innovations include adaptive coding and modulation to match the instantaneous bit rate to the time-varying signal-to-noise ratio as the satellite passes overhead.

award_title: Laser diode array with diffraction limited divergence
research_keywords: Volume Bragg grating,laser diode,diffraction limited divergence,coherent beam combining,spectral beam combining
abstract: The development of laser weapons has a profound impact on military missions throughout the services. An ideal laser system must be capable of delivering hundreds of kilowatts of average power to a target at multi-kilometer ranges through adverse atmospheric conditions. The highest power within diffraction limited divergence was demonstrated with solid state and fiber lasers. However, development of multi-gain media systems where gain media (crystal or fiber) pumped by laser diodes reduces the overall efficiency of the laser system and therefore increases the total power requirements. On the other hand, high power laser diode (LD) arrays that demonstrate highest efficiency and compactness suffer from high divergence resulted from inevitable multimode regime.   The new approach we propose levels of LD control and integration. It includes a new design of a semiconductor waveguide and an external cavity geometry with volume Bragg gratings (VBGs) providing spectral narrowing and angular divergence down to diffraction limit for high pumping currents; coherent combining by means of multiplexed VBGs that enable efficient radiation exchange between individual LDs and phase locking to provide a coherent LD array; spectral combining of coherent LD arrays by a sequence of multiplexed VBGs.

award_title: High Power Direct Diode Laser
research_keywords: High power laser,direct diode laser,high brightness,directed energy
abstract: We propose to build the highest brightness direct diode laser ever constructed, a nearly diffraction limited laser subsystem at a power level of > 50 kW CW using wavelength beam combining (WBC). WBC is a technique which allows for the combination of many distinct diode elements in which the common output beam has nearly the same beam characteristics as that of a single element. Since wavelength beam combining is a truly scalable approach this will lead to scaling direct diode lasers to hundreds of kW with a nearly diffraction limited output beam.

award_title: BLACK Diodes
research_keywords: high-power semiconductor lasers,Diode lasers,coherent array,beam combination,beam combining,laser array,diffraction-limited beam,Directed Energy Weapons
abstract: From 1985 to 1998, nearly $175M was invested in developing coherent semiconductor laser arrays in the Air Force PILOT program. However, the laser systems that were ultimately deployed from this program were either single-element lasers or incoherent laser arrays  no viable coherent arrays were produced.  The key remaining challenges to producing coherent semiconductor laser arrays are:  (A) Both individual emitters and coherently combined arrays fall pray to spatial and dynamic instabilities due to inherent nonlinearities in the semiconductor medium.  (B) The large number of laser elements required to reach Directed Energy Weapon (DEW) power levels dictate that active phase control of the diodes is required, impairing the overall system with a large and cumbersome overhead.  We propose a qualitatively new approach to semiconductor laser beam combination that overcomes these obstacles.  Specifically, we propose to develop a coherent semiconductor laser system that provides:  (1) Mitigation of spatial and dynamic nonlinear instabilities  (2) Strict diffraction-limited single-lobe emission  (3) Inherent scalability with no complex controls, active feedback, or phase stabilization  The new methodology is scalable both in parallel and concatenated serial application, and enables for the first time the use of broad-area semiconductor lasers with diffraction-limited beam quality.

award_title: Flexible Integrated Intelligent Network (FIIN) for Prognostics Health Management (PHM) Systems
research_keywords: Maintenance,Intelligent Agent,Distributed Problem Solving,DIAGNOSTICS,Prognostics,Information Sharing,HEALTH MANAGEMENT,flight management system
abstract: Operational availability, reliability, and performance of Army aircraft are key factors in achieving mission success. The aircraft depend on health of their systems to perform reliably over extended periods of time. Monitoring of aircraft usage trends and time spent in stressful flight regimes produces the information needed to apply prognostic health management (PHM) knowledge to operational/maintenance decision-making at individual aircraft and fleet levels. Achieving the information architecture for maintainers and flight crews to apply new PHM technologies effectively requires an advanced, intelligent network. AVNIK Defense Solutions, Inc. proposes, with our subcontract team member Instrumental Sciences, Inc. (ISI), a flexible integrated intelligent network (FIIN) concept based on the new technologies of distributed work environments and cooperative intelligent agent architectures. This AVNIK concept will lead to a robust network to meet Future Vertical Lift (FVL) systems needs for automated handling and sharing of distributed information from aircraft operation and maintenance histories. The primary objectives of the Phase I research are to (1) determine the feasibility of the AVNIK FIIN concept and (2) characterize the potential of the FIIN implementation to improve aircraft/system availability.

award_title: Intelligent Flexible Open Architecture Network
research_keywords: Prognostics Health Management,NETWORK,DIAGNOSTICS,Rotorcraft,Joint common architecture (JCA),Prognostics,Aviation
abstract: To address the need for a flexible integrated intelligent network (FIIN) for prognostics health management (PHM) for Army aviation applications, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a new Intelligent Flexible Open Architecture Network (IFOAN). It is based on an open architecture network and Joint Common Architecture (JCA)-compliant software. Specifically, the innovation in design of a hierarchical fiber optic network and design of PHM software incorporating grid-based data mining, advanced statistical classification, and a high-performance net-centric rule engine will enable the IFOAN to provide PHM capabilities to aircraft maintainers and crew members over a FIIN. As a result, IFOAN offers such advantages as a flexible, integrated, robust, reliable, resilient, low size/weight/power, broad bandwidth, reconfigurable and self-healable device, compatible with both legacy and future aircraft. It provides accurate and automated damage inspection and near-real-time trend analyses and prediction of remaining useful life of aircraft. In Phase I, POC will conduct a feasibility and trade-off assessment of FIIN options and design the IFOAN architecture, addressing Army requirements and technical challenges. In Phase II, POC will develop a working prototype and assess its performance in a Systems Integration Laboratory (SIL) environment. The Phase II IFOAN will reach technology readiness level (TRL)-5.

award_title: Flexible Integrated Intelligent Network (FIIN) for Prognostics Health Management (PHM) Systems
research_keywords: prognostic,Rotorcraft,Aircraft,network,WIRELESS,AUTONOMOUS,CBM+,HEALTH MANAGEMENT
abstract: Significant strides towards sensors and prognostic algorithms needed for an integrated rotorcraft Prognostic Health Management (PHM) system have been made in recent years. Future rotorcraft such as those in the Future Vertical Lift family can benefit from a Flexible Integrated Intelligent Network (FIIN). Sporian proposes to develop a FIIN for rotorcraft PHM that will be highly autonomous, self-organizing, and self-aware. The network will be designed to be highly fault- and damage-tolerant. The FIIN will self-re-organize and continue to perform in the case of failure or damage to elements of the system. The overall concept for the proposed system is based on multiple FIIN coordinators operating in a masterless peer configuration that interface with existing non-PHM sensors as well as a suite of PHM-specific sensors or sensor systems. The FIIN will perform prognostics on sensor data and when actionable maintenance information is generated, will deliver that data to maintenance personnel on the ground. Phase I efforts will focus on defining the overall system requirements, evaluating competing FIIN options, and developing an initial design for the on-aircraft and ground portions of the FIIN system. Phase I Option will involve prototyping and demonstration of critical aspects of the network in a laboratory environment.

award_title: Flexible Integrated Intelligent Network (FIIN) for Prognostics Health Management (PHM) Systems
research_keywords: PHM,HEALTH MANAGEMENT,IoT,networks,Future Vertical Lift
abstract: GSS will develop the Flexible Integrated Intelligent Network (FIIN) architecture for Prognostics and Health Management (PHM) Systems using Modular Open Systems Approach (MOSA) design principles. By following the MOSA design principles, the FIIN architecture will leverage investments made throughout the defense industrial base to produce new commercial products, practices, and technologies that will integrate advanced capabilities more easily into future Army aircraft and field superior PHM capabilities more quickly and affordably into legacy Army rotorcraft. We will look to adopt into the FIIN architecture open standards-based technologies from the automotive industry (e.g., Controlled Area Network) or IP based technologies to provide a common interface for a message-based communication protocol and integration of multiple PHM control modules from health-enabled aircraft systems. Leveraging the Future Airborne Capability Environment (FACE) work being done by the Open Group FACE Consortium, we will consider the possibilities of integrating a communication protocol that introduces a standard interface for run-time PHM data exchange with FACE compliant and systems. This includes researching the Joint Common Architecture (JCA) to ensure that the two developing frameworks are considered in defining the FIIN architecture. We will also consider integration of actual diagnostic logic and corrosion sensors into the PHM modules.

award_title: LOW COST PROCESS FOR FABRICATING AERODYNAMIC CERAMIC/GLASS COMPOSITE IR DOMES
research_keywords: glass ceramic,Spinel,IR dome,missile dome,missile seeker,precision munitions
abstract: Missile seekers for precision guided munitions are key elements of modern defense systems. Seekers using laser guidance or imaging require IR- transparent protective domes. Depending on the application, these domes may plastic, glass, ceramic, polycrystal, or single crystal. Plastic and glass are relatively inexpensive and easily formed into non-spherical shapes. They are, however relatively soft and fragile. Ceramic and crystalline domes are much more rugged and suitable for higher temperatures, but using present technology are expensive and generally only spherical sections because of the difficulty and high cost of producing non-spherical, aerodynamic shapes. This effort will investigate new technology that combines the low cost and formability of strengthened glass with the ruggedness of ceramics. Chemically strengthened ceramic-glass composites can be produced at much lower cost and require little or no post processing. The costs of manufacturing and processing are comparable to that of glass, but the strength is improved through inclusion of ceramic particulates and ion-exchange in the glass phase. In this proposed effort, Radiation Monitoring Devices, Inc., in collaboration with researchers at Naval Research Laboratory (NRL) will investigate the fabrication of glass ceramic domes in aerodynamic shapes using low cost processes using technologies developed by the DOD at NRL.

award_title: Low Cost Aerodynamic Spinel Domes via 3D Printing
research_keywords: visible -MWIR,Spinel,3D Printing,aerodynamic dome,Low Cost,transparent
abstract: TA&T proposes to show how 3D printing of spinel domes and ogives with high optical transparency can meet the Army's requirements for low cost, aerodynamic missile domes by providing a lower cost alternative to the conventional processing techniques of dome production. 3D printing enables a significant decrease in labor, tooling, and capital equipment costs, with the added benefit of creating a more dimensionally accurate and repeatable blank. This increase in process reliability would help further decrease overall cost by reducing the cost of fixturing for grinding and polishing. Such a "digital" manufacturing process that has virtually unlimited geometric dome design flexibilty would be a great benefit.

award_title: An affordable elastomeric insulation material for solid rocket motors with improved ablation resistance
research_keywords: Thermostructural composites,polymer nanocomposites,Ablatives,ablation,Erosion,solid rocket motor insulation,filled elastomers.
abstract: The KAI team proposes to develop a comprehensive experimental and numerical research program to characterize the ablation, thermal, and mechanical response of new solid rocket motor (SRM) internal insulation material to facilitate ARMY's new advanced missiles. The principal aim of the project is to introduce an innovative elastomeric ablative material with superior ablation resistance and lower density than the state-of-the-art (SOTA) ethylene propylene diene monomer (EPDM)/Aramid currently used as internal insulation for SRMs. The objective is to develop and demonstrate an innovative and mature solution for SRM internal insulation. The proposed SRM internal insulation material system is based on a combination of a low density elastomeric polymer, density reducer fillers, advanced organic fibers, adhesion and char promoter fillers. The combination of these components enables the design of an elastomeric insulating material with improved char retention, ablation resistance, insulation capability, superior adhesion performance with modern SRM propellants based on hydroxyl terminated polybutadiene (HTPB) binders, and at the same time, lower density compared to the SOTA formulations such as EPDM/Aramid. Success of the project will lead to a scalable thermal insulation material to improve the operating lifespan of structures that undergo extreme environments for ARMY missile systems.

award_title: Affordable, High Performance, Elastomeric, Solid Rocket Motor Case Insulation
research_keywords: Thermostructural composites,ablation,Erosion,solid rocket motor insulation,filled elastomers
abstract: Cornerstone Research Group, Inc. proposes new elastomeric materials for use in solid rocket motor case insulation that are low cost, easy to produce, and can integrate with existing manufacturing. CRG already has a cyanate ester elastomer (CEE) material that has been tested in a sub-scale motor and performed well, particularly in low mass flux conditions, but if properly reinforced it offers improvement across a broad performance range. Now, a new elastomeric material is in development that is based on CRGs family of high temperature organic resins, MG Resins, and it is anticipated to perform even better than the CEE materials tested previously. In this program, CRG will evaluate the suitability of MG Elastomer for rocket motor insulation. CRG will then compare its MG Elastomers with its CEE. The material that shows the best promise to displace the current EPDM material will then be carried into Phase II for processing scale up, supply chain maturation, cost optimization and sub-scale motor testing. The full, three-phase program offers multiple routes to achieving disruptive innovation in solid rocket motor insulation technology, replacing the EPDM incumbent while maintaining cost, availability, and manufacturing advantages that have made that material a dependable solution for thirty years.

award_title: Multisensing Target Discriminator
research_keywords: Multisensing Target Discriminator,MTD,83mm,SLM,Orbital Research
abstract: Orbital Research Inc. (Cleveland, OH) will develop a Multisensing Target Discriminator (MTD) for integration with existing and future shoulder launched munitions, with the initial target being 83mm platforms. The Orbital Team, including Nammo Talley (Mesa AZ), will leverage their expertise in shock hardened electronics and analog sensor conditioning and amplification. Having Nammo Talley on the team with their position as the integrator of the relevant target platforms will enable solutions to be designed in a focused fashion, specifically as to what can be fielded fastest. Key to Orbitals approach is to focus on starting to discriminate the target before impact, in order to allocate more time for a more comprehensive decision tree for discrimination. The MTD is a ruggedized sensor module that can be integrated into the nose of the 83mm round that will provide this discriminatory information to the fuze in order to best inform a multi-mode warhead. It contains three main sensor components that enable the Multisensing Target Discriminator to perform its analysis rapidly and with better results than a single sensor can. Test capabilities on-site at Orbital Research will ensure rapid and low cost experimentation to validate design concepts, including Orbitals 100,000 g Shock table.

award_title: Multisensing Target Discrimination System
research_keywords: autonomous target detection,Discrimination,Sensor Systems,seeker,Missile,Optical,magnetometer
abstract: The development of precision shoulder launched munitions and other lightweight, soldier borne weapons systems requires a new class of sensors and sensor systems that can autonomously detect and discriminate between various target classes in real time. This is especially true for fire and forget munitions where the weapon has an on-board seeker system that can autonomously hone in on a desired target. Recent research shows that a wide variety of sensor systems including stand-off sensors for collision avoidance, advanced infrared and low light detectors, RF detectors, magnetometers, direct impact sensors as well as others can be used to detect various targets in and around unmanned air and ground vehicles as well as missile systems. The goal of this research is to develop and integrate several of these sensors to form a unique miniaturized sensor system that can be used not only to detect various targets but also discriminate between target classes. Specifically, the system of sensor systems will be developed to integrate with soldier borne weapons systems and will be designed to perform the detection and discrimination functions autonomously within 100 microseconds and with better than 95% accuracy.

award_title: Longwave Infrared Electrically Tunable Laser Line Rejection Filter
research_keywords: longwave infrared,LWIR,Tunable,transmission filter,Notch Filter,laser line rejection filter,Electro-optical,cholesteric liquid crystal
abstract: To address the Armys need for tunable laser line rejection transmission (notch) filters in the longwave infrared (LWIR) region, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a new polarization insensitive Longwave Infrared Electrically Tunable Laser Line Rejection Filter (ETIRE) based on fast (>60 Hz) electrical tuning of the reflection peak of cholesteric liquid crystal (CHLC) to reject the undesired laser line wavelengths without any mechanical movement. The proposed design allows ETIRE to efficiently block laser radiation (>90% rejection at the notch), while transmitting ambient light (>90%). The innovative ETIRE design enables filter linewidth of

award_title: Tunable LWIR Notch Filter Metasurfaces
research_keywords: tunable filter,IR,metasurface,counter-directed energy,Graphene,Fano resonance,plasmonics,Photonics
abstract: For dynamic protection of LWIR sensors from laser dazzler threats, Nanohmics, Inc., proposes to develop a thin, light-weight, high-transmittance, electrically tunable notch filter based on microfabricated metasurfaces. One or more 200 nm filter notches can be electrically activated and tuned to reject >90% of incident threats. The metasurfaces comprise an engineered array of resonant microstructures that leverage standard materials and microfabrication techniques to reduce cost and provide a rapid route to commercialization. The high-rejection filter prototype is thermally engineered to operate properly for optical power up to 80mW/sq.cm. The thin (

award_title: Development of Longwave Infrared Tunable Laserline Rejection Filters
research_keywords: longwave infrared,tunable notch filter,laserline rejection filter,Phase Change Materials,frequency selective surfaces,active matrix addressing
abstract: Boulder Nonlinear Systems and our teaming partner, The Ohio State University, will investigate tunable notch filter technology based on frequency selective surfaces and phase change materials. Modelling and trade studies will be used to select the most promising frequency selective surface geometry and phase change material. A design will be completed for active matrix addressing to tune the phase change material. Demonstration of wavelength tuning using a phase change material will constitute the Phase I proof of principle. A design for a prototype longwave infrared (LWIR) tunable notch filter will be completed. The prototype tunable filter will be fabricated and tested in Phase II.

award_title: Quantum Nonlinear Photonic Switch
research_keywords: Quantum cryptography,High-speed switch,Quantum switch,optical fiber
abstract: To address the Armys need for a high-speed, low-loss optical switch enabling high-capacity quantum entanglement photon routing in fiber-based quantum networks, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a new Quantum Nonlinear Photonic Switch (QUANOPIS). The proposed device is based on a novel design of a nonlinear fiber loop mirror, with electrical control of its operation. These innovations will enable the QUANOPIS to operate much faster than traditional microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) and mechanical switches, and with much lower insertion loss than high-speed electro-optic modulators. As a result, the QUANOPIS offers a 10-GHz photon switching rate, with an insertion loss of

award_title: All-fiber Ultrafast Quantum Optical Switches
research_keywords: Quantum Key Distribution,QKD,Telecommunications,Quantum Networking,Single Photons,fiber optics,Lasers
abstract: Q-Peak will design and develop a novel ultrafast, extremely low loss, all-fiber switching architecture that promises near Raman-free operation. By utilizing a novel interferometric all-fiber switch with nonlinear enhancement, it is possible to provide both ultrafast switching speeds and reduce laser power requirements.

award_title: High Speed Low Loss Quantum Optical Switch for 1550nm band
research_keywords: quantum information,photon detection,Optical Switch,fiber-optics,quantum networks,entanglement,Switching,Routing
abstract: Optical switches that are simultaneously fast (sub-nanosecond), low loss (< 2 dB), and add low noise (< 10-4 added noise photons per mode) are not available commercially, but would be an important tool for manipulating quantum signals. It is important for such a switch to operate near 1550 nm, as this is the lowest loss wavelength in standard optical fibers and as such is desirable for distributing quantum information over long distances. Switches based on cross-phase modulation in optical fiber are capable of meeting the requirements, but have thus far for technological reasons operated near 1310 nm. We will develop new optical switches suitable for quantum signals in the 1550 nm band. Various components of the switch will be characterized to optimize the design, and the switching function will be demonstrated. Since the proposed switch geometry is essentially a long interferometer, an active phase locking scheme will be developed to enable stable and reliable operation. The locking scheme will be extended to allow for multiple cascaded interferometers which enables more complex optical processing. We will demonstrate the ability of the switch to maintain signal fidelity when operating on a quantum entangled signal, thereby showing the feasibility of the technology.

award_title: Digital RF Expendable Active Countermeasure
research_keywords: DRFM,Countermeasure,Expendable,Aerodynamics,Power Supply,transceiver,SWaP
abstract: To address the Armys need for innovative RF countermeasures compatible with the limited size, weight, and power (SWaP) of rotary-wing aircraft to counter advances in radar threat systems, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes a new Digital RF Expendable Active counterMeasure (DREAM), to replace traditional passive radar countermeasures. The DREAM comprises a low-SWaP, 2-18 GHz RF transceiver with commercial off-the-shelf RF components and a field-programmable gate array to form the digital RF memory (DRFM); a novel wideband conformal antenna; a lightweight power supply; and an aerodynamic enclosure. This innovative integration will enable a low-SWaP, DRFM countermeasure that fits within the size constraints of conventional passive countermeasures and weighs

award_title: Compact Active-RF Countermeasure for Helicopter Protection (1000-381)
research_keywords: Digital RF Memory (DRFM),active RF countermeasure,compact form-factor,economical approach,helicopter platform,wideband antenna
abstract: SI2 Technologies (SI2) will design a DRFM-based, compact active-RF countermeasure for helicopter protection. The design will cover 2 through 18 GHz signals, and will be specifically adapted to be form and fit compatible with the ALE-47 launcher already on the helicopters. This countermeasure will provide a minimum of 30 seconds of operation, giving the helicopter time to maneuver or otherwise address the threat. This approach is based on SI2s proven expertise in wideband antenna design, design of electronics for compact volumes, and design of power supplies for munitions and related constrained areas. In Phase I, SI2 will simulate and optimize the antenna, electronics, power supply, and aerobraking concepts for performance, size, and cost. We will fabricate and test proof-of-concept hardware demonstrators to demonstrate TRL4 at the conclusion of the Phase I program. We will also generate design packages suitable to proceed with prototype manufacturing in Phase II. In Phase II, we will build and test an expendable prototype to demonstrate TRL6 at the conclusion of the program. We will also perform additional analyses on the aerodynamics of the expendable and on options for long-shelf-life power supply solutions to assist in preparing the countermeasure to transition to a Program of Record.

award_title: Expendable Active RF Technology for Helicopters (EARTH)
research_keywords: Countermeasures,DRFM,AN/ALE-47,active expendable,heterogeneous on chip integration,mixed signal RF,aircraft survivability equipment (ASE),false target generation
abstract: Passive expendable threat countermeasures have been the primary mechanism for defeating radar-guided threats to rotary wing aircraft. These dispenser systems interface directly with the Radar Warning Receiver (RWR) to select the best response to a detected threat. The modern generation of RF threats has become smarter and added agile emissions in order to see through passive countermeasures. DRFMs are active countermeasure systems that use memory to delay or store threat pulses and then digitally re-modulate the signals to produce realistic coherent false targets. SPEC is proposing a fast moving program to develop and field the worlds most advanced expendable active RF countermeasures for the protection of Rotary Wing Aircraft and ultimately for the protection of all airframes. A DRFM typically consists of RF up/down-converter sections, ADC and DAC sections, and a high speed digital signal processor with memory. Recent advances in materials and technology offer unprecedented levels of heterogeneous on-chip integration of RF, mixed-signal, and digital signal processing circuits.
