SPEC proposes to develop an expendable active countermeasure system design for modern threats, using integrated, substrate level, heterogeneous technologies and packaging necessary to satisfy SWaP requirements, and extremely demanding aerodynamic performance specifications that account for rotor wash of the aircraft.

award_title: Expendable Active RF Technology for Helicopters (EARTH)
research_keywords: Countermeasure,RF Transmitter,MAV
abstract: Countermeasures for hostiles in the aerospace environment are commonly passive devices. As the sophistication of threats grow, there is interest in active countermeasures. An active countermeasure consists of an RF transmitter that may be deployed in the same manner as passive countermeasures using similar equipment. In order to be considered a drop-in replacement, size and weight constraints are placed on these active countermeasures and introduce challenges in development of such devices. The proposed effort will develop a small form factor RF transmitter integrated with a rotor with autorotation capabilities. The vehicle is designed to reach stable descent after deployment without any extra power and minimal number of moving parts. Tests will be conducted to verify stable descent of the vehicle from arbitrary drop orientations and RF transmitter performance at 2-18 GHz.

award_title: SEASHORE: Software Assurance for Heterogeneous Runtime Envionments
research_keywords: Cyber Security,Malware,source code analysis,software development lifecycle,graphics processing unit (GPU),Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC),API hooking
abstract: Automated software assurance tools are critical for finding vulnerabilities or malicious code in Commercial Off The Shelf (COTS) software and systems, but current tools do not address the threats posed by modern, heterogeneous runtime systems such as distributed/cloud computing or Graphics Processing Unit (GPU) accelerated code. Many tools require source code access, which may not be available. Existing tools also focus on specific software modules (akin to unit testing) or attack methods (e.g., fuzz testing) and do not provide the context needed to evaluate alerts. The result is that many alerts are false alarms or go unheeded, while critical problems are not appropriately emphasized. To address this need, ATC-NY will design and build SEASHORE, a software assurance tool for heterogeneous runtime environments. SEASHORE uses function call and API hooking to detect misuse or unexpected call sequences, via rules and machine learning techniques, then unifies the results of this analysis with external probes, configuration tests, and third-party tools in a hierarchical risk model. In doing so, SEASHORE helps the security analyst discover vulnerabilities and potentially malicious code in GPU-accelerated COTS software, then determine the risks those vulnerabilities pose to mission success.

award_title: Developing A Robust Software Assurance Tools for Cyber Security
research_keywords: Cyber Security,Software assurance,malicious code injection,software vulnerabilities,graphics processing unit (GPU),binary level
abstract: BlueRISC proposes a fundamental software assurance model upon which an automated tool will be built for inferring as to exploitability as well as malicious nature of the software under investigation. The proposed model enables a passive characterization of software that is able to drive an active testing framework complemented with machine learning. This reduces false positive and false negative of vulnerable codes as well as packed, malicious codes in heterogeneous computing architectures. The proposed tool is able to operate at the binary-level, increasingly breadth of coverage as well as scope, and removes the reliance on the availability of source-code.

award_title: Security Assurance of Heterogeneous Software Systems
research_keywords: Heterogeneous Software,Cyber Security,Vulnerability Detection,Hardware Accelerators,program analysis,Automatic Deobfuscation,Trace-based Disassembly,Machine Code Analysis
abstract: Modern software systems increasingly use specialized hardware such as Graphics Processing Units (GPUs) and other types of hardware accelerators to run more efficiently. The use of this specialized hardware opens up new cyber-attack vectors and creates opportunities for hiding malware from existing tools for malware analysis and detection. We propose to design and build an automated analysis tool that detects both unintentional vulnerabilities and explicitly introduced malicious code in software written for such heterogeneous hardware systems. The tool will combine both static and dynamic analysis components, which will work together to enable effective security analysis of heterogeneous software. The tool will operate at the machine-code level and will leverage and improve the extensive existing GrammaTech infrastructure for machine-code analysis.

award_title: High Power MWIR Laser with Coherently Combined Emitters
research_keywords: MWIR laser,laser diode,Self-Fourier Cavity,Phase Locked Array,Coherent Combination,Monolithic Laser Array
abstract: The goal of this project is to develop a power-scalable laser source in the Mid-Wave InfraRed (MWIR) range based on semiconductor laser technology. The main thrust will focus on power scaling using a simple passive coherent beam combination technique. Scaling the output power of a single laser diode element beyond a few Watts presents a daunting challenge as phenomena such as catastrophic optical damage or heat dissipation typically limit the maximum power that a laser diode can generate. Use of passive coherent beam combination allows circumventing such limitations and scale the output power by simply adding more single elements, while maintaining a diffraction-limited beam quality and the simplicity of laser diodes.

award_title: Self-Rerouting and Curative Interconnect Technology (SERCUIT)
research_keywords: Self-routing,Self-healing,wiring,Aircraft,Damage
abstract: Concepts to Systems, Inc. (C2Si), cooperating with Professor Sundaresan of Ohio State University (OSU), proposes the development of an innovative self-healing and self-routing wiring system for use in aircraft internal wiring system. C2Si innovation is in use of polymer composite with the conductive core made from a mixture of elastomer/ionomer matrix and conductive self-aligning nanoparticle additives. The wire architecture is placement of healing/rerouting layer between center conductor and outer insulator and protection polymer sheath with minimal modification of manufacturing process and possibility of reducing wire weight. C2Si team will perform Multiphysics modeling and design in Phase I. The preliminary design experimentation and reliability testing will be performed. C2Si team will demonstrate proposed design and produce testing results at proof-of- concept level. The proposed self-rerouting and curative interconnect technology (SERCUIT) is based on the prior research and development experience of C2Si PI and OSU PI who have worked together before on self-healing technologies for wire insulation. Successful completion of Phase I work will result in establishing feasibility of the proposed SERCUIT concepts and down selection of the technology meeting topic criteria.

company: Blue Ridge Research And Consulting, LLC
award_title: Optimized Geospatial Tool for Ambient Soundscapes
research_keywords: Mission Planning,Ambient Acoustic,Background Noise,Soundscapes,machine learning,Geospatial Model,Geospatial Data,Detection and Audibility
abstract: This proposal addresses the need to develop a robust model for biological, geophysical, and anthropogenic ambient sounds in different environments. The spatial and temporal resolution of the sound level mapping tool will improve mission planning for both rural and urban environments. During Phase-I, a geospatial data-based ambient sound model will be developed and exercised for at least three benchmark CONUS locations, one of which contains significant anthropogenic noise. As part of this effort, geospatial database requirements will be established and new geospatial/acoustic datasets incorporated into existing databases. The soundscape modeling framework will incorporate multiple unsupervised machine-learning approaches, with the novel goal of treating geospatial modeling inputs and different acoustic outputs as part of the same optimization problem. To downselect to Phase-II modeling approaches, the modeling tradespace will be studied for multi-metric predictive capability, efficiency, and robustness. The Phase-I effort will also develop strategies to eventually extend the ambient soundscape modeling to OCONUS locations, including identifying which geospatial data are available and exploring means for acquiring additional geospatial/acoustic data. Eventual transition of the modeling tool to the military and commercial sectors (e.g. the real estate industry) will be aided by Phase-I technology transition planning and business case analyses.

award_title: Geospatial Sound Modeling for Military and Community Noise Metrics
research_keywords: Ambient Noise,audibility,Noise,natural quiet,ambient environment,TRAFFIC,Aviation
abstract: In Phase I, Ambient Logic will create a Geospatial Sound Model (GSM) that estimates multiple indicators of the background noise across the contiguous United States (CONUS). Given either latitude/longitude coordinates or an address, the GSM will provide the daytime ambient noise spectrum in one-third octave bands, the DNL, and the A-weighted Leq for all 24 hours. Prediction accuracy of these metrics will be measured by rigorous cross validation. Ambient Logic will increase the efficiency of GSM formulation and mitigate the effects of wind noise in the current geospatial database to achieve greater speed and accuracy. They will also investigate the impact of data on model predictions, showing how many new measurements are necessary to reach the desired accuracy in a region. In anticipation of expanding to OCONUS regions, properties of globally available data sources will be assessed and a method will be developed to target locations for acoustic measurements that will provide the most benefit. In Phase II, the GSM will provide expanded noise estimates for both CONUS and OCONUS locations. Similar to how current weather models rapidly update as measured conditions change, the Phase II GSM will accept fresh data to improve estimates at locations with limited data.

award_title: Efficient Prediction of Thermal Stresses and Distortion in Complex Optimized Missile Structures
research_keywords: Powder Bed Metal Additive Manufacturing,Support structure,Thermo-mechanical Modeling and Simulation,residual stress,topology optimization,Adaptive Surrogate Modeling
abstract: TDA has teamed up with Naval Research Laboratory (NRL) as its subcontractor to address the target SBIR topic objectives of (a) increasing computational efficiency of AM calculations, (b) modeling strategies for complex geometries with support structures, (c) optimizing support structures for these geometries, and (d) integrating the tools with existing metal AM machines interface software.TDA plans to improve the in-house fully automated thermo-mechanical AM finite element numerical simulation tool, especially to rapidly calculate distortions and residual stresses. Our model follows an ICME framework for multi-scale AM simulation module consisting of a coarse-grain module for component level processing and a high fidelity module capturing material local behavior.Based on our experience, two surrogate models are selected for the proposed work and will be used to meet the requirements of computational efficiency; the main advantage of these techniques is their proven computational efficiency when properly trained. We also propose a novel topology optimization approach for the support structure which will help minimizing the overhang distortions; the simplicity of its computation guarantees a fast and robust solution. The target is to achieve high computational efficiency to meet the desired objective of calculating distortions of a small bracket (4x2.5x2 in3) within 5 minutes.

award_title: Efficient Prediction of Thermal Stresses and Distortion in Complex Optimized Missile Structures
research_keywords: Metal powder AM,DMLS,support generation,AM process simulation,OPTIMIZATION,residual stress,distortion
abstract: Additive manufacturing (AM) technology offers the potential to fabricate complex geometries that cannot be realized using conventional subtractive methods.In current industrial AM processes, support structure is typically needed for complex geometries that contain overhangs.Determination of the type and distribution of support structure is often based solely on technician experience.This process is far from optimal and does not take into account thermally-induced residual stress buildup and subsequent part distortion that can occur when the support material is removed.Hence significant non-recurring engineering costs are incurred to develop a repeatable AM fabrication process for production.Currently, a computational tool that is capable of optimizing the support structure design to minimize thermally-induced residual stress or distortion does not exist.The key challenge to the development of an efficient topology optimization tool for support structures is the lack of an ultra-fast method for predicting residual stress and distortion in an AM part.Materials Sciences Corporation with team with the University of Pittsburgh to develop a computational tool cable of simulating the residual stress and distortion of a realistic AM part in minutes for use in developing optimal support structure by employing a numerically efficient finite element (FE) based process simulation model.

award_title: Innovative Rendering for Simulation
research_keywords: ray tracing,Rendering,High Performance Computing,Massively Parallel Computing
abstract: SURVICE Engineering is proposing to design and develop an interactive physics-based rendering pipeline using modern ray tracing techniques, leveraging best-of-breed in acceleration structures, vector processing, and massively parallel computing architectures.  Existing ray tracing engines are currently optimized for computer graphics applications and do not provide the level of fidelity required for advanced sensor and weapon system simulation.  The proposed approach leverages, extends, and optimizes existing industry-developed ray tracing engines for physically accurate global illumination rendering while maintaining performance across the full complement of current and next-generation computing architectures.

award_title: Innovative Rendering for Simulation
research_keywords: Rendering,Scene generation,MODELING AND SIMULATION,weapon system,image fidelity,benchmarking
abstract: Scene generation fidelity requirements are reaching the limits of traditional raster-based rendering methods. Thus, a need has arisen to perform a thorough investigation and design for innovative approaches that include methods like ray tracing which can scale as a rendering solution.Signature Research, Inc. details a solution which relies on the development of a benchmarking data set and benchmarking framework. This new capability allows one to quantitatively evaluate rendering system designs, gauge implementation decisions, and navigate advances in hardware and software technology. Our resulting proof-of-concept real-time rendering system design is based upon the foundation of the collection of empirical data across three aspects of the problem.1. Evaluation of a representative sample set of rendering frameworks covering open- and closed-source software, raster- and ray trace-based rendering methods, and various hardware and software optimization approaches.2. Benchmarking hardware changes such as networking architectures, processor designs, and cache layouts.3. Benchmarking software configuration changes at the operating system and rendering algorithm levels.These empirical results will then feed into our rendering system design to produce a rendering solution that can meet the performance and fidelity requirements for existing and future use cases.

award_title: High Fidelity Accelerated Vector Wave Propagation Model with Data Verification and Enhancement in Urban Environments
research_keywords: vector wave propagation,PHYSICS-BASED MODELING,machine learning,3-D ray tracing,depolarization,acceleration method,geometrics optics,multipath effects
abstract: In this proposal, a high fidelity accelerated vector wave propagation model with data verification and enhancement is developed for mmW propagation prediction and rapid generation of complex multipath effects within urban environments. For each propagation mechanism: specular reflection, diffraction, and diffuse scattering, we properly model the polarization behaviors and study their impacts on the multipath effects. Ray tracing is implemented as a deterministic method to model the ray interaction with the urban environments. In order to reduce the computational load of tray tracing process, a sighted object search algorithm, ray path discovery method and sectorized ray path validity check approach are developed to achieve time efficiency. Furthermore, we explore machine learning techniques to exploit the measured data for the purpose of accelerating physic based propagation model while maintaining high accuracy. Spatial and temporal statistics generated from the developed model are used to evaluate the prediction accuracy and runtime is estimated for assessing the potential of the proposed model. The software is designed with cross-platform functionality so that it can operate on different host platforms, and make it easier to be compatible with existing Army simulation and scene generation software and tool suites in the future.

award_title: Modeling mmW Multipath Effects in Urban Environments
research_keywords: Ray-tracing,Multipath,urban propagation,GPU acceleration,dynamic scenario modeling,MODELING AND SIMULATION,Millimeter Wave
abstract: In this proposal, we present a novel solution for simulating wave propagation in urban areas with a key emphasis on dynamic scenarios with moving transmitters and receivers/sensors, and potential for moving vehicles.Based on full three-dimensional ray-tracing, our approach encompasses established techniques that are accurate and handle all aspects of multipath, including reflections, diffractions, shadowing and scattering.This is further enhanced to extend from traditional ray-tracing frequencies, usually designed for UHF up to X-Band, to handle critical atmospheric and environmental effects at millimeter wave bands.The key innovations focus on techniques to calculate results rapidly, using a combination of unique preprocessing, optimized path generation, and parallelization and hardware acceleration, deriving from many years of experience in hardware-accelerated solutions for electromagnetic simulation.This provides accurate predictions of multipath, but does so in a way that can handle dynamic, quickly changing conditions, and offers tradeoffs between fidelity and speed.Results are accurate enough to support complex radar and antenna array applications for modern technologies in defense and industry, emphasizing urban scenarios with multipath between points that are in motion.This will provide a valuable new tool for applications in radar, military and commercial communications, and mobility solutions for telecommunications and automotive industries.

award_title: Novel Materials for Kinetic Energy Penetrators
research_keywords: Amorphous metals,Kinetic Energy Penetrators,depleted uranium,nanostructured materials,alloy nanopowders,advanced materials,Tungsten
abstract: MATSYS proposes to develop and demonstrate novel tungsten-based alloys with nanocrystalline microstructure and a scalable manufacturing process for cost-effective fabrication of kinetic energy (KE) penetrators.  Depleted Uranium (DU) alloys demonstrate superior ballistic performance over conventional tungsten heavy alloys (WHA).  However, residue from DU munitions presents issues, such as the cleanup of a persistent health and environmental hazard.  The increased performance of DU is attributed to a localized flow-softening behavior, more commonly referred to as adiabatic shear.  WHA alloys are a natural candidate for KE penetrator applications because of their high density.  However, they do not generally show any strain localization desires for self-sharpening behavior.  Recent work has shown that tungsten-based alloys with nanocrystalline microstructure exhibit strain localization and extraordinary promise as a penetrator material.  Our approach is to use thermodynamic modeling to design new stable nanocrystalline tungsten-based alloys, and then use high energy milling to refine the microstructure of the powder for the selected compositions and consolidate these powders into bulk, fully dense, nanostructured material.  This effort will use thermodynamic modeling to identify potential alloy compositions, and combine our unique expertise in high energy milling and instrumented-Hot Isostatic Pressing to develop bulk nanostructured tungsten-based alloys for next generation KE munitions.

award_title: Materials Design of a High-Density Self-Sharpening Kinetic Energy Penetrator Using Integrated Computational Materials Engineering
research_keywords: Materials Design,Integrated computational materials engineering (ICME),CALPHAD,Ductile tungsten,Hafnium,Phase transformation,Constitutive instability,FINITE ELEMENT MODELING
abstract: QuesTek will utilize an integrated computational materials engineering (ICME)-based approach in combination with our with our Materials by Design methodology to develop an optimized W/Hf-alloy composite consisting of a transforming Hf alloy designed for enhanced self-sharpening behavior and QuesTeks patented ductile W alloy to produce a high-density, self-sharpening composite. In Phase I, QuesTek will utilize our proprietary thermodynamic modeling capabilities to design a novel Hf alloy with a transformation temperature optimized to harness the thermally-assisted constitutive instabilities that arise during adiabatic heating and promote shear banding. Design validation will be performed via thermal analysis of laboratory-scale buttons. A scaled up prototype will undergo quasi-static and high strain rate testing along with microstructural characterization to validate shear band formation. These tests will serve to demonstrate the feasibility of effective self-sharpening behavior of the Hf-alloy phase to be ultimately combined with a high-density ductile W phase in a sintered composite. Finite Element Modeling will be employed in the Phase I Option to predict shear banding behavior in composite systems. The final design will optimize the tradeoff between self-sharpening behavior and high density while maintaining the desired properties of high strength, ductility, and fracture toughness to ensure penetrator integrity during launch and impact.

award_title: An RF and EO/IR Mixed Sensor System for Human Target Detection and Geolocation
research_keywords: GPS denied geolocation,cooperative human target,non-cooperative human target,TOA fusion,DOA fusion,LFMCW ranging,multi-target tracking,indoor and outdoor
abstract: In this proposal, IFT presents an RF and EO/IR mixed sensor system for human target detection and geolocation. It is low SWaP and low cost. Thus, sensors can be easily integrated on small UXV (UAV or UGV). Due to the application of a novel ranging technique, a high ranging accuracy is obtained with a low complexity transceiver and transponder system. In a small region, very high localization accuracy can be obtained. IFTs rich experience in cooperative and non-cooperative target localization greatly reduce the rick in the project implementation. The system can be applied in indoor and outdoor environment as long as three or more platforms have their location determined. Its deployment is convenient. Its application possibility including various DOD missions, such as terrorist searching, small scale street combat, and civil applications, such as disaster rescue, search and recovery, and agricultural augmentation of automatic target/vehicle surveillance.

award_title: Embedded IR (embIR) Thermal Imaging Camera for Nano-UAVs
research_keywords: microbolometer,thermal imaging,embIR,Embedded Systems,microcontroller,NV-IPM,
abstract: This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I Project proposes a breakthrough development in embedded infrared (embIR) thermal imaging with a camera system that utilizes an embedded microcontroller for command, control, digital data processing, and output signal generation while optimizing for image rate, image quality, system size, system weight, thermal management, and power consumption. By combining the latest generation of miniaturized uncooled infrared (IR) imagers with RPX Technologies proprietary embedded microcontroller technology, a completely integrated unified-package camera capable of analog and digital video output can be constructed to meet the requirements outlined in the MCoE Soldier Borne Sensor (SBS) Request for Information (RFI).  Initial component evaluation using the Night Vision Integrated Performance Model (NV-IPM) shows that the integrated system, along with reasonable optical component modifications, can meet or exceed the requirements outlined for probabilities of detection and recognition.

award_title: Miniaturized small-pixel Uncooled Infrared Imager for Nano Unmanned Air Vehicles
research_keywords: uncooled infrared camera,large format,small pixel pitch,Miniaturized,ULTRA-LIGHTWEIGHT,nano-UAVs
abstract: Micro-infrared (IR) camera packages are now possible as a result of uncooled sensor performance improvements (sensitivity and time constant) in small pixel pitch (12 m). Leveraging prior investment in miniaturized uncooled infrared camera cores, digital readout circuitry and electronics design, there is an opportunity to demonstrate a digital output micro-IR camera package with direct application to nano-unmanned air vehicles (UAVs) and other very compact soldier-borne situational-awareness sensor applications. Black Forest Engineering has developed micro uncooled cameras on prior SBIR efforts using 17 m pixel pitch uncooled FPA and custom ASIC camera electronics for micro-UAV applications. The proposed Phase I effort will show proof of concept of micro-IR cameras for nano-UAVs. The design will support camera core weight < 2 grams, and a packaged camera weight of 5 to 18 grams depending on optics selection. The camera will support rapid turn-on and rapid in-flight non-uniformity correction. DoD performance models will confirm the design meets the Armys system performance requirements, target detection and activity recognition as specified for the MCoE Soldier Borne Sensor. A validated sensor package design will detail sensor components and performance modeling (including size, weight and power) to asses risk and maturity of the prototype design.

award_title: Radar Waveform Diversity
research_keywords: RF node,Modality,Radar,Electronic Attack,Electronic support,Weaponized IO,Counter UAS,waveform diversity
abstract: Current radar systems are driven by sensing requirements in the field. Today, and even more so in the future, the operation of these systems will be plagued by heterogeneous threats, each seeking to counter the sensing capability with different types of countermeasures. The traditional approach to solving this problem would be to introduce multiple individual systems (sensors and effectors) into the solution space. We view this as an inefficient and ineffective approach to solving asymmetric threats. As a game changing approach to the future battlespace, we envision a more flexible system configuration which increases the modality of future radar architectures through an RF Node architecture. Spear Research defines radar waveform diversity as the ability to transmit and receive specialized waveforms that enhance existing radar capabilities and execute alternate missions beyond standard radar functions.

award_title: Advanced Microgrid Power Distribution Unit
research_keywords: Power distribution,Microgrid,Generator,electrical switch,electricity breaker,intelligent load management,Forward Operating Base
abstract: Bennett Advanced Research proposes to use advances in intelligent power control and management to balance loads and manage assets on a forward operating base or other tactical environment to ensure that the power provided is stable and consistent.

award_title: Next Generation Intelligent Power Distribution Unit (IPDU) for Tactical Microgrids
research_keywords: Microgrid,Energy Efficiency,generators,Circuit Breaker,controls,Power Management,PDISE,Fuel
abstract: Hyperion Technology Group Inc. (Hyperion) in an effort to address the needs laid out in the solicitation A16-112 titled Next Generation Intelligent Power Distribution Unit (IPDU) for Tactical Microgrids plans to develop an intelligent power distribution system that will make tactical microgrids more robust, while reducing fuel consumption. The key advantage of the Hyperion proposed approach to an IPDU is the ability to shed loads based on mission priorities to match the available output of the microgrid to prevent total power failure. To accomplish this, the lowest priority loads will be temporarily switched off so the prime power source is not overloaded or prevent the circuit breakers from tripping. The current approach that power managers and tactical microgrid design engineers must use is to size generators for worse case loading, which typically results in generator capacity several times larger than the average power levels. The ability to shed loads based on priority will facilitate the use of smaller generators which in turn can operate closer to ratings resulting in increased efficiency (smaller generators equal less fuel) with less maintenance (due to less wet stacking).

award_title: Software Based All Digital Wireless Modem
research_keywords: COTS server,FPGA-based hardware acceleration,OpenCL/C/C++,Software Defined Radio,Cloud Computing,wireless telecommunications,Distributed Processing,Digital IF.
abstract: Fast Fit Technologies, LLC. proposes to research and show that a software based "all Digital-IF (Intermediate Frequency) wireless communications modem" using Commercial Off-The-Shelf (COTS) server technology with built-in hardware acceleration card can be produced. The resulting research will show that given the state of technology, both currently available today and in the next calendar year, a multi-hundred mega-symbol (Msps) "all Digital IF" modem can be produced without the need for any custom hardware. The resulting modem will build on the work done for the ANSI/TIA-5041, FAST Digital IF Architecture and Open Standard Digital IF Interfaces standard, where input and output data will be a digitized modulated waveform encapsulated in VITA-49 frames over a digital fabric, such as 10G Ethernet. Fast Fit Technologies, LLC. proposes to use the European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI) standard 302 307 Digital Video Broadcasting (DVB); Second generation framing structure, channel coding and modulation systems for Broadcasting, Interactive Services, News Gathering and other broadband satellite applications (DVB-S2) as the waveform of choice, since this waveform is a standard and many COTS devices could be tested with the resulting work to prove the viability of the research; however, the resulting work may support any waveform standard to include

award_title: Software Based All Digital Wireless Modem
research_keywords: all digital modem,distributed digital IF,spacial diversity,ANSI/TIA 5041,OpenCL,transionospheric scintillation,MIMO,FAST OSDI
abstract: The fundamental technical objectives are to determine the feasibility of a software defined modem or all-digital modem (ADM) with streaming Digital-IF interface that may be ported to various hardware platforms meeting a set of basic  standards.  The effort will also focus on applications where Distributed Digital-IF can be used to combat the effects of transionopheric scintillation, occurring in either the natural ionosphere or a nuclear disturbed ionosphere.

award_title: Waterproofing Cargo Airdrop Equipment
research_keywords: Cargo,air drop,waterproof,superyhydrophobic,Wear resistant,Solid lubricant,Abrasion resistant,Low Cost
abstract: To address the Armys need for reusable and low maintenance airdrop-related hardware when dropped into wet environments, San Diego Composites, Inc. (SDC) is developing a superhydrophobic, durable coating with rapid ambient heating for efficient moisture dissociation and self-cleaning. SDCs superhydrophobic abrasion-resistant coating (SHARC) can be applied retroactively to existing equipment or integrated within the production line of air drop components. SDC will utilize a homogeneously layered compacted powder suspended in a superhydrophobic polymer binder to create an abrasion resistant coating that provides the necessary durability for airdrop applications. Abrasion and disruption of the surface geometry will simply reveal another layer below with identical superhydrophobic properties to the previous surface. The coating will also have a high emissivity to aid in evaporation of any remnant moisture on the surfaces of all airdrop hardware, and act as a solid lubricant for contact features in mechanical hardware, such as the parachute release.  This SHARC coating will give extensive protection over extended periods of time, drastically reducing maintenance and being applied at a low cost.

award_title: Ultra-Durable Polyolefin Based Waterproofing Coating
research_keywords: Thermoplastic,Polymer,moisture-impermeable,thermal-spray,VOC-FREE,field-repairable
abstract: The U.S. Army is interested in the development of innovative materials, films, coatings and technologies or manufacturing techniques which allow current U.S. Army airdrop related hardware and equipment to survive fresh and salt water operations with increased reliability and without damage and significant maintenance impact. Resodyn Corporation proposes for development a durable, moisture-impermeable, super-hydrophobic thermoplastic coating (SHTC) material to address the U.S. Armys need under consideration. The SHTC will be in essence a low-melting temperature powder coating material capable to strongly adhere to steel, aluminum and textile (nylon) surfaces without causing any degradation to any of the abovementioned substrates. For metallic substrates the material may be deposited either through traditional electrostatic deposition methods or through the novel polymer thermal spray (PTS) deposition method invented by Resodyn Corporation. The proposed SHTC material will be suitable for both retrofitting existent airdrop hardware at the U.S. Army depot-level and coating brand new hardware at the OEM level. Initial pre-proposal results from an un-optimized SHTC material indicate that the proposed material technology has great potential for waterproofing of U.S. Armys airdrop related hardware and equipment. The PTS technology will allow for field repair of SHTC-coated articles.

award_title: Development of an Improved General Purpose Tent Fabric
research_keywords: non woven tent fabric,low cost tent fabric,polyurethane tent fabric,cold crack resistant tent fabric,environmental resistant tent fabric
abstract: Low cost polyurethane laminate tent materials are designed to solve the cold crack issue with PVC tent fabrics. The use of novel construction of urethane/textile laminates offers a breakthrough in environmental durability over current offerings. This new laminate configuration provides for a new class of economical lightweight shelters with extended operating capability.Using a composite textile reinforcement system reduces coating cost and complexity at the same time optimizes for both tear and tensile properties. This composite textile is matched with advanced coating designs to yield excellent spectral and flame performance at reduced mass, while remaining low cost.

award_title: Lightweight, Durable Fabrics for Military Shelters
research_keywords: Cold durable,tent,fabric. Shelters,textile,Omniphobic
abstract: General purpose shelter fabric construction has not changed in decades since historical polyvinylchloride (PVC) laminated polyester scrim fabric system meets basic tent specifications (MIL-PRF-44103).  Despite its performance under normal conditions, the Army requires new materials with improved durability for extreme environmental conditions.  The currently used material has seen significant damage in fielded systems due to i) high speed wind whip to fabric, ii) cold cracking at temperatures below -30F, and iii) high stiffness at low temperatures.  Luna proposes to develop a highly durable toughened polymer fabric coating system that will overcome the durability issues associated with traditional PVC laminates in extreme environmental conditions.  Luna will utilize our extensive experience with polymer modification and fabric construction to develop novel multifunctional textile that will achieve these stringent structural properties.  These goals will be achieved to reduce the overall ownership cost of shelter systems by improving functional durability and reducing packing weight and volume.

award_title: Real Time On Board Video for Gun Launched Munitions
research_keywords: On board video system,GPS Denied Environments,real time,target tracking,Guidance,Navigation,touch screen,Camera
abstract: The army is seeking a new and novel generation of precision munitions that do not rely solely on GPS for targeting and guidance. The weapons systems proposed herein will utilize GPS, however, they will also be capable of operating in GPS denied environments. These munitions will function using both visual feedback derived from real time telemetry, manual selection of target using touch screen technology, and novel algorithms designed to use the real time telemetry and other sensor input (i.e. IR sensors) to identify and lock onto a given target.     The systems developed will be lightweight, inexpensive, and easily transportable by the contemporary warfighter. Launching the munitions will be accomplished using either a mortar or a rifle, such as M16A1 equipped with a specially designed launcher (M203).     Small accurate munitions that can be launched by a lone warfighter will give the army significant tactical advantage, the ability to remain stealth, and capable of inflicting damage in any arena. The development of these technologies has many potential commercial applications, especially in the burgeoning UAV markets. These novel video systems will eventually be incorporated with other SBIR work to utilize conformal lithium ion battery technologies and miniaturized conformal electronics packages.

award_title: Virtual Model-Based Systems Engineering Platform to Enable Agile Development of Secure FACE Software
research_keywords: Security,Future Airborne Capability Environment (FACE),Model-Based System Engineering (MBSE),agile software development,ARINC 653,Partitioned operating environment,separation kernel,Hypervisor
abstract: Rapid deployment and agile development are very difficult to achieve on large, complex software projects that require security and safety design assurance. We tackle this challenge by mapping an Agile development methodology into a design assurance process where safety, security, and performance all play a role. We create a Virtual Model-Based System Engineering (VMBSE) platform, leveraging FACE concepts of standardized interfaces and partitioning. The result will be a secure, cloud-based infrastructure (connected to both emulated and real test systems) that allows developers at multiple organizations to collaborate on iterative design, system exploration, and continuous integration, enabling rapid deployment while simultaneously achieving performance, safety, and security.

award_title: Innovative Approaches to Agile Software Development for Secure Modular Avionics Architectures
research_keywords: Face,JCA,Host,OMS,SOSA,MBSE,Joint Common Architecture,Integrated Modular  Avionics
abstract: Avilution is performing pioneering work to further the development of the eXtensible Flight System(XFS), a suite of portable avionics software applications with a common framework, which allows streamlined integration of new sensors, safety, and technology for private and commercial aviation. Avilution uses rapid software development practices with new ideas and technologies to create an innovative avionics architecture. XFS is developing network technologies to provide safer avionics more quickly and at lower cost than traditional avionics. The current capabilities of XFS include basic Flight Management System (FMS), moving map, Primary Flight Display (PFD)/Multi-Function Display (MFD), COMM Radio/Transponder, Electronic Circuit Breakers (ECBs), mode control panel, environment control, flap and trim control, audio panel integration, and Global Positioning System (GPS)/VHF Omni Directional Radio Range (VOR)/Instrument Landing System (ILS) navigation.     The overall technical objective of this proposal is to investigate approaches to align the XFS architecture to the FACE architecture and research how the software implementations of the XFS modules can be adapted to be FACE conformant UoPs. The goal is to find the approach that takes advantage of the enhanced openness provided by the XFS software licensing to further speed the addition of new software capabilities and new hardware devices.

award_title: Active fan/blower noise reduction
research_keywords: Active Noise Control,fan noise,audible detection range,auxiliary power unit,Fuel cell,APU,NVH
abstract: The proposed effort will result in a "universal" fan noise cancellation system for use with high performance fans used extensively in defense applications including auxiliary power unit (APU) applications.Fans are a critical noise source that impact the audible detection range of the platform.The importance of the fan noise for detection continues to increase as other technology improvements such as fuel cells and signature reduction technologies impacting APU noise levels.Successful development of a prototype active noise cancellation system for fans has the potential to make a significant improvement in audible detection range reduction, further enabling mission execution.The concept system includes both sensors and cancellation sources that are integrated into the fan and fan shroud.This yields an active fan noise cancellation system that is self contained and can be integrated into a fan design with minimal effort and with negligible impact on flow performance.The estimated cost and weight burden are comparable with less effective passive noise reduction solutions.

award_title: Metallic coatings for structural enhancement (METCOAT)
research_keywords: Structural metallic coating,cold spray deposition,Process Modeling,Structural analysis
abstract: Concepts to Systems, Inc. (C2Si), cooperating with Professor Steve Nutt of University of Southern California (USC), proposes to develop a low-cost, versatile, durable and structural properties enhancing metallic coating process for near net-shape plastic structural parts. C2Sis innovation is in the use of a cold spray technique to deposit optimum thickness of metal coating that enables minimum weight structural near net-shape parts. C2Si is proposing to utilize high-pressure cold spraying to deposit a metallic layer on plastics or short-fiber reinforced plastics to improve stiffness and strength of structural parts with minimal added weight. Cold spray deposited metals exhibit exceptional mechanical properties, and grain size and structure can generally be maintained from the powdered state to the as-deposited condition. The C2Si team possesses in-depth knowledge and direct experience of improving the cold spray deposition process (USC) coupled with modeling of advanced composite structures and low-cost environmentally suitable manufacturing process development for advanced composite structures (C2Si). Note that the thickness needed to enhance specific stiffness and strength cannot be processed cost effectively and by environmentally friendly process steps by competing deposition techniques. The C2Si team will demonstrate metal coating process and produce testing results at proof-of- performance level.

award_title: Metallic Coatings for Structural Enhancement of Polymers and Composites for Reduced Weight Missile Structure
research_keywords: electroplating,additive manufacturing,topology optimization,structural metallic coatings,engineering polymers
abstract: Missile modernization and future missile systems are for calling highly intricate designs in order to improve agility, adaptability, mobility and efficiency for the warfighter. These designs often utilize a series of geometrical-complex brackets, bulkheads, and housing designs in order to minimize packing space and optimize attachment schemes. This program presents an opportunity to develop lightweight, high performance (stiffness, strength, durable), geometrically complex missile components to serve as brackets, bulkheads, housings, or covers. The approach will combine three major technologies: (1) advanced material systems, such as fiber filled molding compounds for balanced properties and cost, (2) state-out-the art material fabrication techniques, such as additive manufacturing to create highly detailed components, and (3) priority plating techniques to promote durability and mutilifunctionality (damage tolerance, thermal and electrical property enhancements). While each technology is well-understood when used separately, a strategy for combining all three technologies is still need in order to deliver optimal mechanical performance. Thus, this program focuses on design optimization and tailoring of these technologies to missile application rather than pure scientific advancement of un-proven materials.

award_title: Miniaturization of high average power, high peak power, wide bandwidth antennas
research_keywords: Compact,High Power
abstract: Since 2010, ASR has been working with partners at the University of Arizona and now the University of New South Wales in Canberra, Australia, on strategies that allow us to leverage electrically small antenna concepts for HPEM applications.  Our past projects have been in conjunction with numerous agencies including the US Army, the US Navy, and large defense prime contractors.  In this proposal, we will leverage our recent experience to develop a low-profile antenna array system that can simultaneously handle high peak and average powers from HPEM sources in a nearly conformal configuration that is compact enough to integrate onto an MRAP or similar ground vehicle.

award_title: Miniaturization of high average power, high peak power, wide bandwidth antennas
research_keywords: Ultra wideband Antenna,High Power Microwave,non-linear transmission lines,counter-Improvised explosive devices,LENS,high strength dielectric,Pulsed Power,UWB dispersion compensation
abstract: XL Scientific is pleased to respond to the Armys SBIR solicitation A16-123 entitled Miniaturization of high average power, high peak power, wide bandwidth antennas. To meet the Army's requirement, XL Scientific proposes the use of its "Ferengi" antenna concept. This antenna incorporates several design features which XL Scientific will optimize as part of the research effort to offer the following benefits  antenna miniaturization; UWB impedance matching; UWB radiated pulse dispersion compensation; UWB directionality and front-to-back ratio enhancement; HPM power handling and UWB array synthesis.

award_title: Templated Synthesis of Boron Suboxide
research_keywords: Boron,boron suboxide,b6o,Armor,hard armor
abstract: The US Army desires the development of a synthetic procedure which will afford phase-pure boron suboxide (B6O). Lynntech proposed a template synthesis scheme which combines pre-formed chemical moieties to generate the desired extended lattice structure. Lynntechs approach avoids potential pitfalls with regards to the single-atom substitutional disorder within the produced lattice.Lynntech and its assembled team is uniquely qualified for this task, combining their institutional knowledge and individual experience in deltahedral boron cluster chemistry, wet chemistry, solid-state synthesis, scale-up technologies, and materials characterization. The diverse team includes inorganic and organometallic chemists, diffraction experts, materials scientists, and engineers.

award_title: Multi-Spectral Solution to Sniper Missed-Distance Corrective Offset
research_keywords: precision fire,sniper,Electro-optics,bullet,Tracking
abstract: Snipers gain a decisive tactical advantage and provide significant psychological effect by delivering precise fire from concealed positions. Under difficult and rapidly changing downrange conditions, successful engagement often hinges on rapid follow-up shots with an applied corrective hold. The limits of depth perception prevent spotters from adequately estimating the precise point at which the observed bullet trace corresponds to the vertical plane of the target. Herein lays the problem: there is no commercially available system which is specifically designed for tracking precision rifle fire.Lynntech will provide a multi-spectral computer vision based system for bullet tracking and determining the sniper missed-distance corrective offset. Lynntechs bullet tracking and correction tool minimizes the time between initial engagement and successful re-engagement while simultaneously increases the probability of a hit on target. Lynntech and its assembled team is uniquely qualified for this task, uniting institutional knowledge and individual experience in ballistics, electro-optical imaging, computer vision, and sniper TTPs. The diverse team includes Aerospace and Mechanical Engineers, world-renowned external ballistic experts, military-trained snipers, and a retired military precision weapons armorer.

award_title: Target/Impact-Point Offset Fast Feedback (TIPOFF)
research_keywords: bullet tracking,BULLET DETECTION,offset correction,probability of hit improvement,missed distance
abstract: The goal for a sniper is one shot, one kill. However, there are circumstances where a second shot is necessary. The goal is to take the second shot as quickly as possible, minimizing the changes in windage or target position. Accuracy of the second shot can be significantly improved if the miss distance of the first shot is known with high accuracy.   Intelligent Automation, Inc. (IAI) and AAI/Textron Systems (AAI) will develop TIPOFF, a spotter assist system that will track the sniper bullet in flight, determine where it crosses the target plane and convert this information to miss distance. Whether trade studies indicate that disturbed air or infrared tracking is optimal, this is the ideal team to study, develop and implement the solution. The disturbed air solution amounts to replacing a highly-trained human with a camera and complex algorithms and the IR tracking solution amounts to undersampling the track of a fast moving bullet and extracting a high-resolution trajectory from low SNR data and then projecting it to the target plane. Regardless of the technique, quick rapid calculation of the missed distance will allow a rapid second shot with a very high probability of hit.

award_title: Launderable Enhanced Electrotextile Snap-Connector Arrangement
research_keywords: CONNECTOR,WEARABLE,E-textile,Launderability,Power transport,Data transport,Low Cost
abstract: To address the Armys need for lightweight, low-bulk, rugged, and launderable connectors for transport of power and data with no negative impact on the flame-retardant character of the materials Army aircrews wear while on duty, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop the new Launderable Enhanced Electrotextile Snap-Connector Arrangement (LEESA). It is based on a robust approach to seamless integration of electronics and textiles found in POCs family of e-wearables. Specifically, the innovation in low-profile, washable, self-sealing electrical interconnection with high data rate and low bit error rate will enable the LEESA connector to advance the state of the art in e-textiles while simultaneously preserving warfighter safety, which directly addresses Air Soldier requirements such as ruggedization against degradation from detergent, water, and agitation without impacting flame retardancy of the underlying garment, e-textile, or narrow fabric. In Phase I, POC will demonstrate the feasibility of LEESA by reaching technology readiness level (TRL)-3/-4 in laboratory experiments and by modeling and simulation (M&S). In Phase II, POC plans to develop an advanced prototype and perform validation and performance testing in conjunction with the Army, reaching TRL-5/-6.

award_title: A Low-Profile PAN Connector Platform for Aviator Wearable Electronics
research_keywords: CONNECTOR,cable,personal area network,PAN,Aviator,wearable electronics,C4I,Flame retardant
abstract: Aviator modernization programs, such as Air Warrior and Air Soldier System, focus on improving Aircrew survivability and mission effectiveness and offers a major step forward for the US Army with the introduction of advanced electronic systems integrated with the individual aviator ensemble. A key to achieving these goals is the integrated power, data, and communications links that connect the body borne equipment that make up these critical SA systems.While these enhanced capabilities will, ultimately, make the Army Aviator more informed, capable and survivable, they present some significant challenges for system wearability, comfort and performance.Nowhere is this challenge more magnified than in the area of Personal Area Network (PAN) cables and connectors.To meet this critical need, Human Systems Integration, Inc. (HSI), a leading developer of Wearable Electronics products and solutions, will develop and implement a new PAN connector system to ergonomically, ruggedly and reliably interconnect the complex electronic functionality of the modern Aviator ensemble. This objective PAN connector will be extremely low-profile and conformal, provide the requisite electrical performance, and prove to be extremely rugged in the typical Aviator environment. It will also meet Aviator equipment flame retardant standards and withstand ensemble laundering procedures.

award_title: Soldier Borne Cross Domain Solution
research_keywords: Networking,classification,cross domain,UAS/UAV/UGV,Security,seL4,Mobile computing
abstract: Soldiers employ multiple digital assets on the battlefield for digital communications and surveillance.These sources do not support SECRET level classification and may not ever.The Nett Warrior system is an integrated system that allows soldiers to use Android devices for SECRET level tactical and front-line use (e.g., common operating picture, data feeds, real-time comms, etc.).These new non-SECRET systems would improve the effectiveness, lethality, and improve the ability to complete missions; but these systems cannot be connected to Nett Warrior because of the lack of a cross-domain solution to allow the data to flow from these non-SECRET devices and sources into the SECRET device while blocking and controlling data flowing the other way.A solution is needed to securely attach these non-SECRET data sources safely into the Nett Warrior and other SECRET systems (e.g., A-PASS, or KilSwitch).ATCorp has proposed a cross-domain guard solution that will add this capability with little to no change in the soldiers current CSWaP requirements of the currently carried Nett Warrior system.This new system also provides new capabilities to benefit the Nett Warrior program, and is agnostic to future upgrades to Net Warrior End User Devices, radios and accessories.

award_title: Soldier Borne Cross Domain Solution
research_keywords: ultra-low SWaP,secure hypervisor,Cyber Security,wearable CDS,System on Chip,boundary guard,UCDSMO certified,soldier borne
abstract: This effort will produce a design for an ultra-small size, ultra-low weight, ultra-low power (ultra-low SWaP) bi-directional tactical cross domain solution suitable for carriage by a dismounted soldier without increasing his physical load bearing burden. The CDS design will provide assured, filtered transfer of tactical command and control, situational awareness, and sensor data feeds between a classified wireless tactical network and unclassified sensors, data links and processing devices borne by the soldier. The CDS will prevent classified data spillage and cyber malware attacks through protocol and content aware deep content inspection of the data to be transferred governed by pre-programmed security policy rule sets. The approach will utilize proven, UCDSMO certified, COTS CDS software, a power efficient, high performance Xilinx Zynq Ultrascale+ multi-processor system on chip (MPSoC) Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA) with quad ARM processor cores and a secure, open source Xen hypervisor virtual machine environment to enforce domain separation. These proven COTS technologies will be combined with a small custom designed input/output power management module featuring multi-port USB/power distribution hubs on both the high and low sides of the CDS. The entire assembly will be designed to be packaged in a rugged, light weight enclosure.

award_title: Comprehensive Sky Compass
research_keywords: Jets,targeting system,GPS,azimuth,lunar orientation,planetary orientation,Polarimetry,algorithm
abstract: All DoD branches benefit from interoperable, robust, and accurate targeting systems for forward observers and terminal attack controllers. These systems allow personnel to report relative distance in terms of three measures:  observer current position (for example from reading a map or global navigation satellite systems, whose signal is subject to jamming), distance to target (by laser measurement, in general very reliable), and direction or angle towards the targetthe most critical being azimuth, or rotation from north. A magnetic compass is not sufficiently accurate or reliable; better are sky compasses which leverage astronomic observables, with reliable and consistent use scenarios. Sky compasses can function day or night when a celestial object is detectable.  Lynntech has assembled a team with exceptional insight for developing this desired upgrade, and we offer a particularly efficient route to a rigorously tested, reliable device. In addition we will develop custom algorithms, which help avoid IP and licensing issues. In Phase I we prove feasibility of our design by evaluating prototype components, and in Phase II we interface with stakeholders, build and test prototypes, and build an IP fence around our innovation.

award_title: Augmented-Reality Adaptive Live-Fire Training System
research_keywords: live-fire training,AUGMENTED REALITY,Head-Mounted Display,clip-on imager,wireless display
abstract: To address the Armys need for an augmented-reality (AR) live-fire training system, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a new Augmented-Reality Adaptive Live-Fire Training (AURALIT) system encompassing a head tracker and two visual subsystems: (1) a head-mounted display (HMD) for range scanning and (2) a weapon-mounted clip-on display for targeting. All subsystems communicate wirelessly with a central computer to generate the AR imagery. The monocular HMD supports a wide field of view without interfering with the shooters firing position. The compact clip-on display reproduces the scene as viewed through the weapon scope, regardless of scope type, thus preserving the original scopes eye relief. Finally, AURALITs AR fusion techniques require minimal image processing to add simulated target silhouettes and location of miss and hit (LOMAH) data to real-world scenery, thus ensuring an imperceptible latency. Thus, AURALIT will enable firearm training with real-time AR imagery. In Phase I, POC will demonstrate AURALITs feasibility as an integrated AR technology for training by generating real-time AR avatars and data, including simulated LOMAH positions. In Phase II, POC plans to develop a prototype capable of real-time AR scene generation, including LOMAH integration, at a live-fire range, to reach TRL-6.

award_title: Augmented/Mixed Reality for Live Fire Ranges
research_keywords: AUGMENTED REALITY,LOMAH,BRM,Training
abstract: Augmented Reality (AR) is a technology that has the potential to revolutionize soldier training by enabling realistic real-world training while taking advantage of the inherent programmability of computer controlled virtual entities. The US Army is seeking to modernize Basic Rifleman Marksmanship (BRM) familiarization and qualification training by replacing the current pop-up, paper, and silhouette targets with an AR solution, coupled with a Location of Miss and Hit (LOMAH) system. This would enable more efficient, varied, comprehensive, and cost effective BRM training. AR technology will enable targets to be varied, allowing anything from silhouettes to tactically correct enemy models. Additionally, the targets could be scripted to move, pop-out from correct cover and concealment, and other advanced techniques. Environmental effects can also be simulated with AR technology, allowing advanced soldier training under a variety of conditions. Potential commercial applications for this technologyproviding an effective and improved training approachinclude, but are not limited to: law enforcement, sports shooting, and commercial/private ranges (for pleasure and competitions). The technology could also be further expanded to be used without live fire, and thus be expanded to paintball, airsoft, etc.

award_title: A Compact II-VI Colloidal Quantum Dot Imaging System for High-Speed and High-Resolution Full Stokes Polarimetry
research_keywords: II-VI Colloidal Quantum Dot Infrared Focal Plane Array,Polarimetric Imaging,MWIR,Plasmonic micropolarizers
abstract: Infrared polarimetry has proven to enhance target detection and tracking in cluttered environments, and is of significant importance to high energy laser weapon targeting systems.  Modern state of the art infrared polarimeters possess numerous limitations that render them impractical for tracking at high slew-rates. Efforts have been made to implement micropolarization filters directly onto a focal plane array (FPA), however hybridized FPA technology limits performance through excessive polarization crosstalk and robustness issues caused by the need for back thinning.  HgTe colloidal quantum dot (CQD) FPAs, developed by Sivananthan Laboratories, are MWIR photon detectors, demonstrate high performance and fast response, have the potential for uncooled operation, and are monolithically integrated with readout integrated circuits. Monolithic integration enables the fabrication of micropolarizer array directly onto the absorber material, making high performance, compact, and robust polarimeters possible.  As experts in CQD FPA technology and computational modeling, we propose to develop plasmonic micropolarizer filter arrays, compatible with CQD technology, through computational modeling and fabrication process development as a part of the Phase I effort.  A compact and high performance polarimetric FPA will be developed with a resolution of 1344 x 784 and capable of operating at frame rates up to 4,380 fps (windowed).

award_title: Compact Infrared Polarimeter for Target Tracking in Clutter
research_keywords: infrared polarimeter,long wave infrared,mid wave infrared,imaging polarimeter,3D polarimeter,Stokes vector
abstract: QuantaSpec will modify its hyperspectral imager technology to develop a compact infrared polarimeter that has a SWAP footprint that is slightly greater than a thermal camera. Two approaches will be investigated.  One of the approaches measures the complete Stokes vector at full frame rate and full spatial resolution.   The prior art approach of using polarizers integrated on to a focal plane array (FPA) greatly degrades image resolution because a pixel is used for each polarization state. QuantaSpec's approach is superior to integrating filters on focal plane arrays (FPAs) because it does not use a pixel for each polarization state which preserves image resolution.   In addition, Quantaspec's approach is a Fourier approach which enables calibration to compensate for imperfect components or alignment.  Further, QuantaSpec's approach captures all elements of the Stokes vector simultaneously at full frame rate, unlike the prior art rotating polarizaer approach.  QuantaSpec's approach can work over much of the mid wave infrared and all of the long wave infrared.  Lastly QuantaSpec's approach uses no moving parts.

award_title: Fuel Efficiency for Tactical Wheel Vehicles and Convoys (FETCH)
research_keywords: Cruise Control,Fuel Economy,autonomous,Convoy,Terrain
abstract: The US military fields many types of vehicles for various types of tasks.   One area of improvement which has yet to be explored in depth for these platforms is fuel economy.  As fuel prices continue to increase and budgets are tightened, the military is concerned about reducing these costs.  In addition, the cost of a convoy with which to transport the fuel to remote locations takes a heavy tool in human life. This effort will be focused on ways to use novel engine modifications to improve fuel economy and power by examining the operating range currently used with this vehicle.  Diesel engines are designed primarily to produce maximum power while under load with the best fuel economy possible.  However, very often these vehicles are at rest, powering accessories, or are operating in a modality not requiring full power output.  These engines do not have a modality to produce only the required power at any given point.  Robotic Research, LLC intends to improve the fuel economy and power of military vehicles by exploring a range of improvements.  Specifically, we believe we can utilize our experience with Engine Control Management (ECM) improvements, as well as smart driving technology, to accomplish these goals.

award_title: Alane Solid Hydrogen Storage
research_keywords: Alane fuel,Aluminum hydride,fuel cell powered tactical vehicles,operate on battlefield without Hydrogen refueling station
abstract: Ardica Technologies, Inc. has identified aluminum hydride, AlH3 or Alane, as a hydrogen storage material for ground vehicle fuel cell systems. Alane has 10.1% hydrogen by weight, and a volumetric energy density of 147 g H2/L, significantly greater than compressed hydrogen. It operates at moderate temperature with minimal energy input, and does not require any pressure vessels. In this Phase I proposal Ardica will build a benchtop system to assess the feasibility of using Alane, and show its performance in comparison to compressed hydrogen. Ardica will then create an analytical model of a large Alane cartridge, and conduct experiments to establish material properties which will improve the model accuracy. The results of this will establish the performance and cost of a scaled-up prototype hydrogen storage system. As an option, Ardica will develop a system model to investigate different system architectures for a scaled-up Alane hydrogen fuel cell powered ground vehicle. The validation of Alanes feasibility, and the results of these models will enable Ardica to create a large-scale prototype during a Phase II proposal.

award_title: High Stability and High Density Solid Hydrogen Storage
research_keywords: Hydrogen Storage
abstract: Using the newly realized novel composite of magnesium nano-particles encapsulated with atomically thin reduce graphene oxide, Optowares in collaboration with Lawrence National Laboratory proposes to demonstrate and eventually produce solid-state hydrogen storage system under moderate condition (100 oC and pressure of 15 bar) for ground vehicle power application, having the desired attributes of high reliability, high stability, large capacity, compact size, long operation life,and light weight that have not been attainable before.A prototype unit will be built in Phase I to demonstrate the operation of the material and support system and its advantages in comparison with other hydrogen storage methods.As an engineering company with excellent commercialization track record, Optowares will also demonstrate the new approach's economical viability and compatibility for use in various ground vehicle applications.

award_title: Tunable Textured Composites for Lightweight Power Systems
research_keywords: power electronics,voltage tunable inductor,power converters,striction circuits,magneto-electric materials,textured composites
abstract: A new voltage tunable inductor (VTI) will be developed based on textured magnetoelectric composite and a corresponding electrical control circuit will be developed enabling its use in applications with high frequency enabled wide bandgap-based DC-DC (switchmode) conversion. Rapid electrical characterization of the new variable inductor devices will enable early design and simulation of a novel converter and control system platform during Phase I. These new VTIs will be integrated into an advanced WBG switchmode converter design for high frequency applications that leverage state-of-the-art developments in circuit design developed specifically for this novel striction material. The program exit goal is to demonstrate and document figures of merit for the new tunable inductors identifying the key relationships between the addition of control to power budget, size, weight, and overall performance of WBG-based switchmode converters.

award_title: Long-Range Multiple Ballistic Missile Optimized Engagement in a Multi-Target Environment
research_keywords: Cooperative Missile Guidance,Evolutionary Algorithms,Covariance Matrix Adaptation,Neural networks,ballistic missile defense,Intercept,Modeling,Simulation
abstract: Corvid Technologies proposes to develop a robust, fast running algorithm to calculate strategies for cooperative missile guidance of interceptors against multiple threats. These strategizes will determine the number of interceptors to be launched, their launch times, which threats they will engage, and will coordinate their flight paths to enhance lethality and lower cost. This algorithm will be developed using a two-tiered approach. First create a large database of optimized strategies spanning many different threat scenarios by using global optimization techniques such as evolutionary algorithms or covariance matrix adaptation. Second use this database to train a neural network to create optimized strategies in real time. This algorithm will be customized to the specific capabilities and limitations of a particular interceptor system through comprehensive simulation in order to cover the complete range of potential threat scenarios.

award_title: Long-Range Multiple Ballistic Missile Optimized Engagement in a Multi-Target Environment
research_keywords: Networked,missiles,Algorithms,cooperative intercept,Trajectory Shaping,temporal functions,trade-off,Analysis
abstract: Cintel will develop and evaluate architectures to optimize engagement and intercept of multiple threat assets by long-range ballistic missile interceptors with affordable, robust engagement algorithms.     Desired lethality levels are driving system designs that leverage increasingly complex subsystems.  This increase in complexity incurs an increase in cost (per-interceptor cost).  The innovation presented here will achieve the desired lethality levels by leveraging advanced system architectures rather than advanced systems.  By pursuing novel engagement capability, cost effective systems performing at or above desired standards can be utilized.    These alternative capability concepts include, but may not be limited to, leader-follower guided missiles, collaborative or cooperative guided missile engagements with multiple interceptors, learning algorithms for guidance of multiple missile interceptors, and optimization of multiple guided missiles for distributed lethality.  Therefore, the Cintel team will create a set of tools allowing the tradeoff analysis of different engagement architectures.  This will require the definition of new objective functions to enable the optimization of architectures.  The key deliverable for this Phase I effort will be the definition and evaluation of key defensive/offensive missile architecture concepts with performance valuation for each concept.  Additionally, preparation for Phase II will include a proposal on a concept down-selection and maturation plan.

award_title: Air Missile Defense Weather Management
research_keywords: weather,REQUIREMENTS,air missile defense (AMD),kill probability,PATRIOT,Training,combat readiness planning,engagement response
abstract: Weather requirements for air missile defense (AMD) are outdated, leaving launch decisions makers with little confidence in considering weather in the weapons assignment decision process. As such, the presence of weather reduces the probability of intercept, putting the Warfighter at risk. In this proposal, an integration effort is presented to leverage several years of DoD investment in weather requirements research to develop an in situ weather assessment capability for autonomous weather decision support in the PATRIOT missile system. When applied to several systems, this capability provides broader battlespace weather awareness and response. The proposed technology will support AMD users in training, combat readiness planning, and engagement response. Phase I will focus on developing an approach for integrating relevant DoD invested technologies into a seamless working process. In Phase II, a prototype system will be developed in preparation for operational testing. A part of the transition effort will also target user training, allowing the user to shape the future of the capability. The successful completion of this effort will provide the process for a game changing technology whereby contemporary weather information is effectively treated as an actor in the battlespace.

award_title: Ballistic Missile Defense Weather Management
research_keywords: Rain Erosion,Computational Fluid Dynamics,ballistic missile defense,missile aerodynamics
abstract: Corvid Technologies is pleased to offer this Phase I proposal in response to Army SBIR topic A17-010, Ballistic Missile Defense Weather Management.In the proposed effort, we will leverage Corvids established capabilities in computational aerodynamics and structural mechanics to develop a framework for assessing the influence of weather on Ballistic Missile Defense (BMD) interceptor aerodynamics.These effects, which arise because of shock layer distortion due to hydrometeor impact, will be modeled using a mix of first-principles computational tools and engineering methods based on high-fidelity results.The end result of the proposed framework will be a tool for determining whether a BMD interceptor possesses sufficient control authority to engage a target successfully in either a given flight-test or operational-intercept weather environment.

award_title: Eutectics and Nanomaterials-based Supercapacitors for Enhanced Low-temperature Performance
research_keywords: Electrolyte,Supercapacitor,Electrode,DES,deep eutectic solvent
abstract: Supercapacitors have emerged as energy storage devices exhibiting higher energy densities than traditional capacitors, as well as higher power densities than batteries or fuel cells. Current supercapacitor technology is limited by the operational temperature range of the electrolyte. This proposal will investigate deep eutectic solvents (DESs) as a novel class of electrolytes to enable high-performance supercapacitors with an operating temperature range between -45 C to 65 C. By contrast, aqueous electrolytes are limited to above-zero temperatures (freezing point of water) and have a low breakdown voltage (~ 1.2 V). Although organic electrolytes operate over a larger temperature range and exhibit higher breakdown voltages (~ 2.5 V), they also possess much lower conductivities, and correspondingly lower power densities for the supercapacitor, and can be highly flammable. DESs are expected to display wider operational temperature ranges and larger electrochemical stability windows (breakdown voltage in the range 3-7 V) as compared with conventional aqueous or organic electrolytes, resulting in supercapacitors exhibiting higher energy and power densities. The proposed approach utilizes a combination of experimental and supercomputing methods that will simultaneously maximize the probability of success and minimize the cost-per-eutectic investigated.

award_title: Textile Treatment for Targeted Antifungal Activity
research_keywords: antifungal,Targeted delivery,skin flora,Microbiome,textile treatment
abstract: In response to the defined need for improve conditions for warfighters to avoid problematic fungal skin infections, Luna Innovations is proposing the development of the Agastache antifungal textile treatment: a novel method to specifically target and kill pathogenic fungi.  Agastache is envisioned as a platform textile treatment, capable of being permanently applied to any common textile, and will have fast acting antifungal effects on pathogenic fungi in close proximity, however not on any other members of the normal healthy skin flora.  The Agastache platform technology has applications for specific targeting of other infectious microorganisms as well, both as a textile treatment, and potentially as an administered therapeutic.    The Agastache fabric treatment technology will be demonstrated in laboratory-scale microbial growth conditions and assays.  Successful discrimination of pathogenic fungi and commensal microbial species by the Agastache antifungal technology when attached to a solid support will enable the further development of a textile-based testing system.

award_title: Extremophile-Sourced Targeted Antifungals for Textile Applications to Promote a Healthy Skin Microbiome
research_keywords: Biosynthetic Gene Cluster,thermophilic,nonribosomal peptide,minimum inhibitory concentration,minimum lethal concentration,Commensal,dermatophyte,metagenomic
abstract: CFD Research Corporation (CFDRC) has a unique metagenomic platform for harnessing the potential of natural products (NPs) from understudied extremophilic microbiomes.  This project will exploit our extremophilic microbiome drug discovery (EMDD) platform by state-of-the-art (SOTA) synthetic biology methods to discover novel targeted antifungals in a high throughput manner.  Target/commensal specificity will be measured by minimum inhibitory and lethal concentration (MIC/MLC) assays against targets: Trichophyton rubrum, Trichophyton mentagrophytes, and Epidermophyton floccosum, and commensals: Malassezia furfur, Staphylococcus epidermidis, Micrococcus, and Propionibacteria. The specificity goal is a 2-fold lower MIC and/or MLC in targets compared to commensals over 24 hours.  Targeted antifungal(s) will undergo further purification and chemical analysis by mass spectrometry to characterize the compound(s).
