Finally, production will be optimized and scaled up, and best textile application methods determined for the targeted antifungal molecules.

award_title: Biologically-Derived Targeted Antifungals for Textile Applications
research_keywords: antifungal,Trichophyton,antimicrobial peptides,textiles,cotton,socks,
abstract: Fungal skin infections plague active duty servicemembers at elevated rates due to exposure to warm, humid climates, poor skin hygiene, and close-quarters living arrangements.We have developed a novel solution that incorporates a endophytic fungal extract with selective activity against Trichophyton species of pathogens.In addition, the selected compound has negligible impact on the organisms that natural inhabit skin.This approach offers the potential for effective control of fungal skin pathogens while preserving benefits of a healthy skin microbiome, and limiting the development of resistant organisms.In a secondary invention, the compound will be incorporated into common-use textiles for apparel applications and other uses.

award_title: All-ALD Hafnia and Ferrite-based Multiferroics for CMOS-Compatible Tunable Microwave Applications
research_keywords: ALD,multiferroic,CMOS compatible,Microwave,RF,magnetoelectric,ferroelectric
abstract: The next generation of Army communications and electronic warfare systems requires enhanced performance in concert with reduced size, weight, and cost. These goals require the availability of new materials, integration strategies, and process science solutions to realize novel frequency-agile and frequency-selective open architecture device components with enhanced performance and functionality.   We will develop composite multiferroic thin films for tunable microwave applications. These films will be deposited by atomic layer deposition and all processing temperatures will be kept below 450C, making our devices CMOS-compatible. We will carry out a full range of material and electrical tests on our films and devices to ensure they meet the Army's needs.

award_title: CMOS Compatible Deposition of Multi-Ferroic Films for Tunable Microwave Applications
research_keywords: CMOS compatible,multiferroic,magnetoelectric,Multiferroic filters,multiferroic inductors,tunable inductors,Tunable Filters,bandstop filters
abstract: Different tuning technologies have been used for tunable microwave devices, including semiconductor varactors, ferroelectric based varactors, magnetic field tunable ferromagnetic resonance, MEMS switches, voltage tunable multiferroic heterostructures with voltage tunable permeability or ferromagnetic resonance, etc. However, voltage-tunable inductance, permeability or FMR frequency has not been made possible until recently demonstrated by subcontractor PI Sun et al. In the Phase I of this project, we propose to develop and demonstrate CMOS-compatible low temperature sputtering and spin-coating deposition process for high quality multiferroic thin film heterostructures with large piezo-magnetic coefficient of >5ppm/Oe, low magnetic loss tangent  1 V/cm/Oe. In Phase II of this project, we will demonstrate CMOS compatible magnetic/piezoelectric heterostructures with large magnetoelectric coupling coefficient of > 2 V/cm/Oe, and integrated voltage multiferroic bandstop filters and integrated voltage tunable multiferroic inductors on the basis of the CMOS compatible magnetic/piezoelectric heterostructures developed in Phase I period. This project will enable direct integration of multiferroic devices onto CMOS integrated circuits (ICs), and significantly extend the functionality of CMOS ICs.

award_title: Advanced Electrode Manufacturing for High Energy and High Power Batteries
research_keywords: Electrode manufacturing,thick electrode,High Power,high energy,graded pore structure
abstract: This small business innovation research (SBIR) proposal addresses the solvent-related safety issue and limited energy and power densities of the current lithium ion battery (LIB) technology.  Storagenergy Technologies Inc. proposes to develop advanced electrode manufacturing process for a multi-layer electrode LIB cell having ordered graded pore structure.  The proposed process eliminates the use of toxic solvent used in the conventional process.  It also applies a novel technique to create unidirectional graded pore structure which will maximize the utilization of active materials in thicker electrodes.

award_title: Lithium Ion Battery Electrodes Manufacturing to Improve Power and Energy Performance
research_keywords: Lithium Ion Battery,electrodes,Solvent,electrode structure,charge transport,specific energy,specific power
abstract: Navitas proposes a novel approach to produce high energy, high power lithium batteries.Our innovative approach will implement multilayer electrodes with gradient pore structure throughout the thickness of the electrode. The graded electrode structure will enhance lithium ion transport by transitioning from a smaller, narrower pore size distribution at the separator interface to a larger, broader pore size distribution at the current collector interface. The innovative electrodes will be fabricated using water-based binder. In Phase I, Navitas will individually demonstrate the benefits of each of the following advances: dual slot-die coating, advanced drying technologies, and electrode additives in the fabrication of multilayer electrodes with gradient pore structure.Feasibility will be demonstrated at full-cell level using >200mAh pouch cells.In Phase II, Navitas integrate the three Phase I advances and scale up the integrated process for pilot production of multilayer electrodes. Phase II will develop 3.0Ah prototype cells and demonstrate the functionality over a wide-temperature range, under select environmental, storage, and cycling conditions. In addition, Navitas will initiate the scale-up and design processes and develop a preliminary cost structure for the production of battery systems >250 Wh/kg and >4kW/kg.

award_title: Low Cost, Compact, and High Power Terahertz Emitter Arrays with 1550-nm Telecommunications Laser Drivers
research_keywords: Terahertz source,1550nm laser
abstract: In this program, Freedom Photonics will develop a high-performance terahertz photoconductor source, pumped at 1550nm.

award_title: GaAs-Based, 1550-nm-Driven, THz Photoconductive Devices and Arrays with Optimal ErAs Quantum Dots
research_keywords: Er-doped GaAs,ultrafast photoconductivity,THz photoconductive devices,photomixers,Photoconductive switches,planar antennas,THz radiation and power.
abstract: This proposal concerns the utilization of recently developed erbium-doped GaAs (GaAs:Er) containing ErAs quantum dots at approximately 2% volumetric concentration.  Such GaAs:Er displays optimal THz performance because of excellent optical and electron-transport properties for driving at room temperature with 1550-nm lasers.  The absorption coefficient at 1550 nm is > 5000 cm-1, the electron mobility is > 2000 cm2/V-s, and the dark resistivity is > 105 ohm-cm.  The proposed Baseline Phase-I effort will commence with studying the uniformity and reliability of the electron and THz behavior in test devices at the (3.0-inch) wafer scale. It will then improve the performence even further using thicker epitaxial layers (2.0 compared to 1.0 um) and silicon nitride antireflection coating to improve the external quantum efficiency, and a better antenna (twin-slot) to improve the impedance matching to the THz device and therefore the available power for radiation into free space.  Finally, the Optional Phase-I effort  will focus on the 1550-nm optical-fiber coupling using industry-standard pigtailing techniques to allow arrays of such devices to be driven more efficiently and packaged more robustly, than what has been done in the past.

award_title: High-Speed Cryogenic Optical Connector for Focal Plane Array Read-out
research_keywords: Optical Link,cryogenic,VCSEL,micro-optical components
abstract: A cryogenic optical link is proposed for development that uses a VCSEL-based micro transmitter placed inside the cryostat, and transmitting through a dewar window to a detector-based micro receiver placed outside the dewar. Interconnection to focal plane readout circuit is proposed using an application specific integrated circuit to receive the read out data and electrically drive the VCSEL to transmit the data. The micro transmitter and micro receiver include integrated lens for collimation and high alignment tolerance. In order to overcome reliability  and detuning problems faced by commercial off the shelf oxide VCSELs, a lithographic oxide-free VCSEL is proposed for the cryogenic laser. Scaling to single data channel speed to > 50 Gbps is proposed due to compact packaging and short lead lengths of the micro optical components. Scaling to high channel count is also possible using single mode VCSEL arrays for wide alignment tolerances of VCSEL and detector arrays.

award_title: High-Speed Free-Space Optical Link for Cryogenic Focal Plane Array Read-Out
research_keywords: FSO,free-space optical,cryogenic sensor,FPA,Focal plane array,Interconnect,Optical Link,Imaging Sensor
abstract: Freedom Photonics and the University of California Santa Barbara (UCSB) have partnered to develop a novel free-space optical (FSO) link that will enable high-speed interconnects operating at multi-tens of Gbps, which are required for the newer, cryogenically cooled, large format, high definition (HD), fast frame rate, focal plane array (FPA) readout integrated circuits (ROIC). Cooled focal plane array technology is found in many Army missile guidance systems, such as the FGM-148 Javelin. By using free-space optics to collect data from the ROIC through a window in the dewar, it is possible not only to provide a large bandwidth interconnect but to also eliminate the thermal conduction losses through copper wires, which in turn will reduce the Size, Weight and Power (SWaP) of the system.

award_title: Monitoring, Diagnostics, and Prognostics System for Lead Acid Batteries
research_keywords: Batteries,lead acid,Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy,DIAGNOSTICS,Prognostics
abstract: Lead acid batteries, currently used in 95% of military ground vehicles, represent in excess of $100M per year in maintenance costs.  Furthermore, the failure modes of these batteries are such that they provide no indication of impending failure.  The batteries simply do not function, leaving the warfighter exposed and unequipped with no prior warning.  The ability to diagnose state of battery health and provide prognostics on remaining useful life ensures early detection of impending faults while simultaneously reducing burdens associated with battery maintenance.  To provide visibility into lead acid battery health conditions, Luna proposes to develop a multi-modal battery evaluation system using electrical impedance spectroscopy and dynamic electrical characteristic monitoring techniques to perform in-service diagnostics and prognostics.  This monitoring, diagnostics, and prognostics system for lead acid batteries (MDP LAB) will enable maintainers to identify impending faults, ascertain failure modes including loss of electrolyte, sulfation, and acid stratification, and respond with required maintenance actions prior to system failures. The system will leverage both static voltage and current characteristics along with dynamic load switching profiles and electrochemical characterizations of the battery to identify incipient faults, impending failures, and remaining service life.

award_title: Lead Acid Battery Monitoring, Diagnostics, and Prognostics
research_keywords: Lead acid battery,DIAGNOSTICS,capacity,cold cranking amps,Prognostics,Battery Monitoring,battery failure,6T format
abstract: Oceanit proposes to develop and demonstrate advanced techniques for lead acid battery monitoring, diagnosis, and prognosis in order to reduce lead acid battery failures and predict battery failure.

award_title: Lead Acid Battery Monitoring, Diagnostics, and Prognostics
research_keywords: Battery monitor,lead acid,AGM,flooded battery
abstract: EIC proposes to develop a lead acid battery monitor with an ability to report battery status accurately. The goal is to detect battery degradation and develop advanced techniques for monitoring, diagnosis, and prognosis to enable reduced battery maintenance and increased battery service life.

award_title: Predictive Models of Lead Acid Battery State of Charge and Health
research_keywords: Lead acid battery,Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy,Battery Monitoring
abstract: Lead acid batteries are the old commercially available rechargeable battery technology. They find application in a range of vehicle starting applications as well as a wide array of deep cycle uses such as grid storage, backup power and deep cycle power on a range of commercial, utility, first responder, and military vehicles. Despite being around for over 100 years, there remains no good way of determining the state of charge and diagnosing a range of potential recoverable and non-recoverable degradation faults. Mainstream proposes to develop a range of predictive models that are based on highly sensitive electrochemical impedance spectroscopy that couples battery state both at open circuit and under load. These models will estimate the real-time state of charge and capacity of the battery. Moreover, these models will be designed to identify several key conditions in the cells; which, if uncorrected, can lead to degradation and failure of the battery. These conditions include surface charge, sulfonation of the electrodes, electrode stratification and corrosion of the current collector grid in the positive electrode. In Phase II, Mainstream will incorporate these predictive models into battery monitoring module to provide feedback on early corrective strategies and provide real-time battery state of charge measurements.

award_title: HPC enabled FDTD Channel Modeling for Dense Urban Scenes in the HF/VHF Band
research_keywords: FDTD,DGTD,domain decomposition,Maxwells Equations,Multi-Scale,extreme-size,parallel computing,HF/VHF
abstract: In this SBIR solicitation, the Army has identified a need to develop a highly accurate and efficient finite-difference-time-domain (FDTD) electromagnetic wave propagation software that is portable onto high performance computers (HPCs). The software shall be able to simulate electromagnetic (EM) wave propagation at High Frequency (HF) and Very High Frequency (VHF) bands. Applications include modeling and simulation (M&S) of mobile radio network performance in a large dense urban environment. XL Scientific proposes to build a full-wave simulation software that solves Maxwells equations using a discontinuous Galerkin time domain (DGTD) domain decomposition (DD) method. Use of the DD technique will enable us to handle multi-scale, extreme-size computational domains. The DD method requires decomposition of the computational domain into smaller subdomains. Each subdomain is gridded independently with an unstructured mesh. Then the Maxwells equations are discretized to a system of semi-discrete ordinary differential equations (ODEs). Both explicit and implicit solvers will be developed for solving the ODEs. Theoretically, the explicit method will be equivalent to the FDTD method. But the DGTD method is more flexible and efficient than the FDTD in terms of dealing with complex geometries and time integration. The software will be parallelized and runs on distributed-memory HPC computers.

award_title: HPC enabled FDTD Channel Modeling for Dense Urban Scenes in the HF/VHF Band
research_keywords: radio wave propagation,ELECTROMAGNETIC MODELING,low-frequency analysis,hybrid techniques
abstract: The objective of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to develop a comprehensive modeling environment for the accurate study of propagation channels and consequent development of communication systems with particular emphasis on the HF/VHF frequency bands. The proposed software will provide accurate solutions based on full-wave modeling of the scene as well as a high degree of computational efficiency using a combination of hardware and software acceleration schemes including code parallelization, domain decomposition, multi-core threading as well as hybrid full-wave and asymptotic techniques under certain assumptions. A fully parametric CAD modeling environment will be provided capable of dynamically generating and reconfiguring mobile network scenarios.

award_title: All Solid-State Batteries Based on Ceramic Separators
research_keywords: All solid-state battery,Solid Electrolyte,High Energy Density,cycling performance,interface,LITHIUM,ceramic.
abstract: All Solid-State Battery, by replacing liquid electrolyte with solvent-free solid electrolyte (SE) which is anticipated to preclude dendrite formation, has the promise to ultimately resolve the safety issues of lithium ion batteries. Storagenergy Technologies Inc. propose a superior all solid-state battery based on lithium anode, ceramic membranes and advanced composite cathode. If successful, the all solid-state battery could offer tremendous benefits to many national needs.

award_title: Conformal Solid State Batteries Enabled By Flexible Solid Electrolyte
research_keywords: safety,Conformal Battery,Solid State Electrolyte,Solid State Battery,Dry Process,SOLDIER
abstract: The goal of this program is to develop a conformal solid-state Li cell enabled by a flexible solid state laminated stack.The solid state electrolyte will be a polymer composite which will balance charge transport and mechanical properties.This approach will support scalable production and benefit cycle life through managing interfacial strain and impedance.In Phase I, a full Li solid cell (>0.25 Ah) will be demonstrated with the unit stack specific energy > 250 Wh/kg.In Phase II, the materials and processes will be optimized and scaled up to build large format solid cells (>3 Ah) which will provide specific energy > 350 Wh/kg, energy density >800 Wh/l, and cycle life >250.Wide temperature range and safety advantage of the solid state cell will also be demonstrated.A conformal solid state battery of 12 V, 150 Wh will be delivered by the end of Phase II.

award_title: Conformal Stable Solid-State (CS3) High Energy, and High Power Lithium-Ion Batteries (LIBs)
research_keywords: Energy Storage,Solid-state battery,Conformal Battery,Lithium-ion battery,reducing logistical burden for soldiers,high energy,High Power,safety
abstract: Current military batteries are flammable and suffer from insufficient specific energy, which create safety and tactical burden for the soldiers. The use of solid-state batteries may offer enhanced safety and energy density; however, current solid-state technology typically relies on metallic lithium anode, which cannot be rapidly charged or discharged at low temperatures and is unsafe if exposed to air or water. Lynntech proposes to develop a conformal safe solid-state (CS3) high energy and high power lithium-ion battery (LIB) by using the combination of high-capacity flexible silicon anodes, lithium-rich layered oxide cathodes, as well as flexible and conductive solid electrolytes. This approach will offer a CS3 battery with a long cycle life over a wide operating temperature range, high rate capability, low inherent materials and systems safety risks that can conform to the desired shape. During Phase I, Lynntech will develop all solid-state Li-ion cells, and evaluate the capacity, rate capability, cycle life, specific energy, and specific power at the full cell level. Flexibility testing will also be performed. During Phase II, Lynntech will develop a prototype CS3 battery to meet the Armys performance requirements. Lynntech will also perform preliminary cell abuse tolerance testing and design of scalable cell manufacturing.

award_title: Safe Solid State High Power, High Energy Conformal Energy Storage
research_keywords: solid-state batteries,Conformal,specific energy,silicon,safety
abstract: The modern warfighter has access to a wide array of tactical, communication, navigation, and health sensors, monitors, and displays that require robust power sources to truly confer an advantage on the battlefield.  Conventional lithium-ion (Li-ion) batteries typically fall short of energy density requirements for these systems and also pose safety risks. To address this need, Solid Power, Inc. (Solid Power) proposes to advance its solid-state battery system to exceed the energy density, stability, and safety of conventional Li-ion cells while also allowing for mechanical flexibility. Solid Power will leverage its highly energy dense solid state material system while replacing the typical Li metal anode with a high capacity alloy anode. Phase I will culminate with the demonstration of 250 mAh conformal pouch cells with >250 Wh/kg along with a path to >350 Wh/kg during Phase II.

award_title: Autonomous Environmental Routing Onboard (AERO)
research_keywords: UAV,UAS,intelligent autonomous systems,atmospheric effects,automated impacts routing,weather,uncertainty,Decision Making
abstract: The Autonomous Environmental Routing Onboard (AERO) system is an innovative software-hardware solution that performs onboard processing of environmental information from multiple sources to execute autonomous route adjustments, minimizing negative environmental impacts as well as leveraging advantageous conditions, for multi-rotor autonomous systems (MRAS) executing missions as a swarm.AERO is an intelligent MRAS, which can ingest meteorological data to construct impact grids provided to the Automated Impacts Routing (AIR) system, resulting in optimal routes for the autopilot controller. The solution includes onboard sensor hosting and communication with an intelligent autonomous system (IAS) swarm and ground control. AERO can leverage favorable environmental conditions to expand flight time, improving the swarms mission capabilities. AEROs innovative architecture allows for integration of various environmental sensor type for route optimization and collective data sharing. With its dual-mode capabilities, AERO is designed to function by ingesting data grids and sharing onboard sensor data. When connectivity is not available, AERO becomes self-reliant, using internally-stored data and sensors to continue the mission.AERO can be further expanded to additional Defense and Government (e.g. FAA, NASA) needs as well as other emergent federal, civil, and commercial applications (e.g. Homeland Security and Customs, Border Patrol, UAS manufacturers, Amazon, Google, etc.).

award_title: Linear Efficient Broadband Transmitter Architecture at mm-wave frequencies
research_keywords: Power Amplifier,Gallium Nitride,efficiency,Radiation hardening,Global Positioning System,L band,satellite payload,envelope tracking
abstract: To meet the demands of the A17-027 SBIR solicitation, the MaXentric / UCSD / HRL team proposes the BEEMT (Back-off Efficiency Enhanced Transmitter), which uses high power and high frequency HRL 40 nm GaN technology for Army mm-wave handheld application.  During Phase I work, the team will study most appropriate power amplifier configuration to achieve 10 GHz bandwidth, over 1 W output power, and over 5 Gbps data rate with high back-off efficiency and linearity.  Besides the power amplifier design, baseband waveform generation, DC-to-mm-wave up-conversion, and wideband signal linearization scheme will be developed.

award_title: Linear Efficient Broadband Transmitter Architecture at mm-wave frequencies
research_keywords: Broadband transmitter,mm-Wave communication,dual-mode mixed-signal processing,Doherty power amplifier,reconfigurable SAR ADC,low noise PLL.
abstract: There is an ever-increasing demand on low-cost high-throughput wireless front-ends. Such high-throughput front-ends support broadband data transmission (multi-Gbit/s) for a wide variety of sensors and unmanned platforms in situational awareness, monitoring, and reconnaissance. Their wideband nature also supports the deployment of broadband communication/radar combo-systems, as well as numerous emerging commercial applications such as 5G networks, augmented reality (AR)/virtual reality (VR) devices, and hyperspectral imaging systems.The transmitter often governs the total output power, energy consumption, linearity, and bandwidth of the communication/radar front-end, which respectively determines the communication distance, energy efficiency, signal-fidelity/emission, and modulation rates. Although mm-Wave transmitters supports large signal bandwidth, existing designs exhibit limited output power and compromised efficiency, in particular at deep power-back-off (PBO) situation. Moreover, the linearity of such high-throughput transmitters cannot be enhanced using conventional techniques, such as feedback-based digital pre-distortion (DPD), which are unable to support multi-Gbit/s bandwidth and require impractical baseband computation complexity.In phase I of this SBIR project, Digital Analog Integration, Inc. and Georgia Tech team will work closely to investigate, design, and simulate watt-level broadband dual-mode mixed-signal mm-wave Doherty transmitter in all-silicon and silicon/GaN heterogeneous integration platforms with our novel Doherty PA based highly efficient transmitter architecture.

award_title: Multi-Fuel Burners for Soldier Power
research_keywords: burner,multi fuel,JP-8,Power,SOLDIER,TPV,TEG,Portable
abstract: Recent advances in thermophotovoltaic (TPV) and Thermoelectric (TEG) has created an opportunity to develop a 25 watts portable soldier power system that when hybridized with rechargeable batteries will substantially extend the solider mission durations. Under Army support the feasibility is demonstrated with a propane based TPV system. Under the proposed project a multi fuel burner will be developed that enables the technology to operate on JP-8, DF-2, JP-5 and other fuels that are available to the solider. Under Phase I, a burner will be fabricated and tested on logistic fuels, propane and other fuels listed in the topic. The burner parasitic power will be defined. The interface between the burner and the TPV/power module will be defined. With the test data and input from TPV and TEG manufactures, the power module will designed and used to performs a tradeoff analysis between the burner size, weight, efficiency, and the range of usable fuels and the mode of heat transfer, heat recuperation and other important thermal integration decisions. At the Phase I conclusion the burner has been demonstrated with its critical components to determine the feasibility to achieve the targets of the burner. Under the Option program the detailed power system design

award_title: Flameless, Fuel-Flexible Burner for a 1 kg, High Efficiency, Thermal-To-Electric Battery Charger
research_keywords: JP-8 burner,Thermoelectric,thermophotovoltaic,Lightweight,catalyst,battery-charger,Fuel-flexible,Generator
abstract: PCI will build on it successful track record of developing lightweight, durable, and efficient JP-8 burners for 40 and 80 W Stirling engines and develop a burner that meets and exceeds all the performance metrics of the solicitation. It uses a novel design to readily achieve temperatures at the high and low end of the application. It will be suitable for a variety of energy conversion devices. PCI is partnering with a thermal-to-electric conversion component provider and with a provider of control and power conditioning components. The deliverable at the end of Phase I will be a comprehensive 25 W generator design, supported with experimental and analytical data that will allow quantitative comparison with the solicitation metrics. It will include battery charging electronics and all balance of plant component selection. If successful, a high fidelity generator prototype will be fabricated and delivered to the Army at the end of Phase II.

award_title: Multi-Fuel Thermophotovoltaic Power Generator
research_keywords: thermophotovoltaic,Thermoelectric,catalytic combustion,JP-8,kerosene,Battery Charger
abstract: As the US Military continues to increase its focus on detached, portable and unmanned power systems, the need for compact, light weight and efficient electric generation has grown significantly.Currently many of the low power requirements of the battlefield are supplied by batteries and small portable engine generators.These sources are inherently heavy and inefficient, driving the need for logistic supply of material and fuel.A liquid-fueled power generator that weighs less than 1 kg and can output 30 W of power for battery recharging will be developed in the proposed program.

award_title: Multi-Fuel Burners for Soldier Power
research_keywords: Thermoelectric power conversion,thermophotovoltaic power conversion,Recuperator,burner,JP-8
abstract: The Army has an ever-growing need to provide electric power to soldiers on the battlefield.  Of particular need is an efficient, power dense, jet fuel-powered system for charging batteries.  The Army has invested heavily in thermal-to-electric power conversion, most notably in thermoelectric generators or TEGs.  Because the conversion efficiency of TEGs is relatively low, and because the hot side temperature of high efficiency TEGs is high, a high efficiency recuperated burner is needed to achieve high conversion efficiency for the overall system.  This topic calls for a high efficiency burner technology for thermal-to-electric battery changing in the 30 We power range.  We propose to develop a unique, recuperated burner for this application capable of operating on jet fuel or a range of other conventional fuels including gaseous fuels, biodiesel, and gasoline.  Our burner technology is general and could be applied to different thermal-to-electric conversion technology including TEGs and thermophotovoltaic systems (TPV).  In Phase I, we will complete a system-level design to define requirements for our burner, and then prototype and test an initial embodiment of the burner.  In Phase II, we will iterate the burner design and integrate and demonstrate the burner in a prototype battery charging system.

award_title: Colloidal Quantum Dots for Cost Reduction in EO/IR Detectors for Infrared Imaging
research_keywords: colloidal,quantum,dot,Infrared,low-cost,ROIC,IR
abstract: There is a strong and urgent need for developing low-cost high performance infrared detector technology that can operate at higher temperatures (> 250 K).  Over the years, many new and innovative technologies have emerged that have made some progress towards this goal, but the gap between high performance and low-cost has been difficult to bridge, until recently.  Since the development of colloidal quantum dots, which can be synthesized readily with simple low-cost equipment, there has been a significant push towards developing a CQD IR camera.  We propose innovative chemical reactions to make well-passivated air-stable MWIR absorbing CQDs that are n and p-type.  We also propose an innovative method to deposit p and n-type CQDs that will yield superior charge transport properties  yielding IR devices with a high quantum efficiency (>30 %).  The successful completion of our Phase I effort will ultimately lead to the development of a low-cost MWIR CQD IR camera.

award_title: Colloidal Quantum Dots for Cost Reduction in EO/IR Detectors for Infrared Imaging
research_keywords: II-VI Colloidal Quantum Dot Infrared Focal Plane Array,MWIR,Low-Cost infrared detection
abstract: While state-of-the-art microbolometers demonstrate impressive capabilities for low-cost uncooled longwave infrared (LWIR) imaging, there is currently a need for low-cost, midwave infrared (MWIR) imaging systems capable of high performance with fast frame rates at high operating temperatures.HgTe colloidal quantum dot (CQD) focal plane arrays (FPAs), developed by our team, are MWIR photon detectors that demonstrate high performance and fast response, have the potential for uncooled operation, and are monolithically integrated with readout integrated circuits.We propose to develop new fabrication techniques to overcome the current technological challenges prohibiting high photon detector performance at elevated operating temperatures, to develop a high resolution (1344 x 744) MWIR CQD FPA and integrate the FPA into a low-cost and high performance imaging system. The system will provide cost, size, weight and power advantages over all current MWIR technologies, providing solutions for numerous military applications.Our team is uniquely positioned to take on the challenges associated with the development of a compact and low-cost MWIR CQD-based imaging system, having been the first to demonstrate MWIR CQD FPAs and possessing a track record of developing innovative low-cost infrared camera systems.

award_title: Self Regenerative Coatings for Enhanced Protection of Silicon Based Ceramic Composites in Particle Laden Degraded Engine Environments (17-RD-938)
research_keywords: Si based ceramic matrix composites,High temperature combustion environment,surface recession,Environmental barrier coating (EBC),Particle laden environment,EBC damage,Protective Coating
abstract: Light weight Si based ceramic matrix composites are currently being considered as a replacement of the Ni based superalloy components of the future aero turbine engines for increased specific power and efficiency. However, such composites suffer from the surface recession under high temperature combustion environment of the turbine engine.  Environmental barrier coatings (EBCs) are necessary to protect the composites from surface recession.  State-of-the art EBCs themselves suffer from the particle laden engine environment.  In this SBIR Phase I proposal, UES Inc., in collaboration with the Penn State University and HAMR Indus, proposes to develop novel top protective coatings to mitigate the EBC damage from the particle laden engine environment

award_title: Self Regenerative Coatings for Enhanced Protection of Silicon Based Ceramic Composites in Particle Laden Degraded Engine Environments
research_keywords: Self Regenerative Environmental Barrier Coatings,gas turbine engine,Particle Laden Degraded Engine Environments,Ceramic Matrix Composites
abstract: Environmental barrier coatings (EBCs) are coating systems that are applied to the surface of Si-based ceramics resulting in protection against moisture-assisted oxidation-induced ceramic recession. These coatings require many attributes to be successful including: good stability in the presence of water vapor; a mechanism for limiting the transport of oxygen and water vapor to the ceramic substrate; good chemical compatibility at the interface; high temperature phase stability, to limit volume changes resulting from phase transformations in the coating materials; and the ability to provide thermal protection. These requirements also must be retained in the presence of particle laden environments. Particle interactions with the coating systems in service can result in both the gradual removal of material (i.e., erosion) and the cracking and immediate removal of significant amounts of material (i.e., impact or foreign object damage). At higher engine operating temperatures, particles ingested in the engine will melt and result in the formation of glassy deposits on engine components that reduce coating durability.  The work is this program is designed to utilize a baseline T/EBC system and, then, incorporate and test multiple protection concepts that are anticipated to result in improved durability in particle laden environments.

award_title: Protective CMAS Coatings for SiC CMCs
research_keywords: SiC Ceramic Composites,Sand Degradation,Environmental Barrier Coatings,High Temperature,Gas Turbines
abstract: TA&T proposes to develop and demonstrate a multi-layer based EBC that exhibits exceptional resistance to both the water vapor laded combustion environment of turbine engines and the external operational environments of molten sand ingestion at 1400oC.Several variants of experimental EBC compositions will be explored based on magnetron sputtered, multilayer hafnium oxide systems with excellent phase stability. Chemical resistance top coats will also be applied.A systematic approach includes the following: deposition on SiC CMC substrates, comprehensive characterization methods-XRD, SEM, EDS-to optimize deposition conditions, coating chemistry and microstructure; elevated isothermal and thermal cycling tests of EBC coated SiC CMC coupons in a 50/50 air/water vapor environment with sand; hot combustion tests of EBC coated SiC CMC bars with sand ingestion to determine and compare their potential for an accelerated Phase 2 program.

award_title: High-Fidelity Design Tools and Technologies for High-Pressure Heavy Fuel Injectors
research_keywords: Large Eddy Simulation,two-phase flow,liquid fuel atomization,breakup instability,volume-of-fluid method,High Performance Computing
abstract: The objective of the proposed SBIR project is to develop a computational tool capable of predicting the atomization of liquid injected through a practical I.C. Engine fuel injector under realistic operating conditions. The goal of the present study is to advance an existing state-of-the-art simulation methodology in several areas to substantially reduce the computational cost while still providing a predictive capability of the atomization process. To achieve this goal, a hybrid volume-of-fluid method (VoF) will be developed that enriches the interface reconstruction with Lagrangian marker particles to improve the ability to capture under-resolved interfacial structures. The breakup of under-resolved liquid structures will be modeled by theoretical instability theory to predict post-breakup droplet sizes. The resulting droplets are then represented in a Lagrangian particle/parcel description and undergo secondary atomization with evaporation. In this modeling approach, a significant reduction in computational cost will be achieved by relaxing the severe resolution requirements of thin ligaments and sheets/bags in high Weber number flows. During Phase I, efforts will be made to develop the subgrid breakup model based on the hybrid VoF method and to validate using the problem of turbulent atomization of liquid fuel with comparison to Direct Numerical Simulation data and experimental measurements.

award_title: High-Fidelity Design Tools and Technologies for High-Pressure Heavy Fuel Injectors
research_keywords: Sprays,Fuel Injectors,Liquid atomization,Large-eddy simulation
abstract: In propulsion systems, liquid fuel is atomized and burned in a way that maximizes engine efficiency and minimizes emissions. To accomplish this task, it is necessary to design injectors and nozzles that lead to adequate mixing of fuel and air. Unfortunately, mathematical models of liquid atomization for CFD are still far from adequate to design injectors and nozzles. This atomization has been divided into three stages (i) primary atomization in which the liquid jet breaks into blobs of fluid termed primary drops henceforth; (ii) secondary atomization in which these primary drops break further into smaller drops; and, (iii) the later evolution of the spray. It is evident that the primary-atomization stage sets the initial conditions for all subsequent processes. Thus, the accurate modeling of primary atomization is critical for the overall accurate modeling of atomization. Unfortunately, primary atomization is the least understood of these three processes. Classic models need a calibration process that is onerous because primary atomization involves many physical parameters disregard most of the physics. Combustion Science & Engineering, Inc. proposes a solution to the above dilemma by developing a novel subgrid-scale (sgs) model of primary atomization based on the so-called Linear-Eddy Model (LEM) / One-Dimensional-Turbulence (ODT) framework.

award_title: High-Fidelity Design Tools and Technologies for High-Pressure Heavy Fuel Injectors
research_keywords: fuel injection,free surface capture,high pressure fluid,Computational Fluid Dynamics,spray,primary atomization,secondary breakup
abstract: Fuel injection is a strongly multi-physical process, involving the effects of droplet breakup, deformation, atomization, evaporation, turbulence, and non-ideal thermodynamics, among others, not all of which are strictly deterministic at the present time. In the work proposed here, HyPerComp Inc. seeks to transition an advanced high-fidelity simulation software suite (being used extensively in aero-propulsion) to model heavy fuel injectors at high injection pressures. The solver will be built upon a Large Eddy Simulation code written for turbulent combustion. It will deploy a free surface capture method in the vicinity of the injector where the flowfield is dense (i.e., high liquid volume fraction), and couple it to a Lagrangian spray model in the far-field where the flow is dilute. We will augment this code with sub-models for spray properties, leading to a tool capable of modeling primary atomization and jet penetration, as well as dispersion, evaporation and mixing, with particular emphasis on high-pressure injection systems. The staff at HyPerComp Inc. has close to three decades of association with computational fluid dynamics modeling in aeronautical applications. HyPerComp will work jointly in this project with Prof. Suresh Menon of the Computational Combustion Laboratory (CCL) at the Georgia Institute of Technology.

award_title: Revolutionary Concepts for Multi-Mode Adaptive Advanced Cycle Gas Turbine Engine
research_keywords: Adaptive-Cycle,Multi-Mode Turbine Engine,Variable Flow Fan,turbo-alternator
abstract: Florida Turbine Technologies (FTT) is seeking technology combinations that improve the performance, agility, reliability, maintainability, sustainability, and affordability of small Vertical Take-off and Landing (VTOL) aircraft / UAVs. FTT proposes the development of advanced adaptive turbine engine cycle concepts, based upon the existing FTT320 core engine architecture, which utilize a variable flow fan to allocate power between the fan and output shaft or alternator. The resulting 100hp - 200hp adaptive cycle turbine engines would smoothly transition between efficient high-speed forward flight with the turbofan, and vertical flight in the turbo-shaft or turbo-alternator mode.

award_title: HIgh Efficiency, Advanced Cycle, Multi-ITB, Turbo Shaft Engine for Advanced Propulsion, Multi-Mode Operation with Power On Demand Capability
research_keywords: Inter Turbine Burner Gas Turbine Engine Power Generation
abstract: Tactical requirements of unmanned air, ground and maritime vehicles, operating in clandestine environments for long periods of time, have dictated the need for the DoD to develop hybrid type propulsion systems. Advanced cycle engines which generate large amounts of electrical power either for weapons or electric propulsion, while retaining the capability to directly propel the vehicle are necessary. Requirements exist for sustained high altitude operations of UAVs which would normally tax the system in terms of power generation capabilities. In the Phase I effort Spytek plans to leverage assets from its recent Phase II and current phase III SBIR efforts with AFRL. These assets include the dual ITB FI304 engine which was tested under a Phase II and has high interest for potential use from UAV builders. Using Spyteks innovative Inter Turbine Burner (ITB) technology, variable nozzle guide vanesand J304 engine core, Spytek proposes the advanced cycle TI304 engine, an ITB equipped turbo-shaft engine for high altitude UAV use, with capability for low altitude VTOL type hybrid operations in response to this solicitation.What is proposed is an advanced cycle, hybrid operation capable, turbo-shaft engine designed for high altitude operations while not compromising power generation capabilities at low altitude.

award_title: Additive Manufacturing of Long Rod Penetrator Sabots using Carbon Nanotube Metal Matrix Composites
research_keywords: additive manufacturing,Carbon nanotubes,metal matrix composites,long rod penetrator sabots
abstract: Additive Manufacturing has the potential to dramatically reduce the weight and cost of long rod penetrator sabots if the right material systems can be utilized in manufacturing. While short fiber polymer composites offer significant weight and cost savings, they are limited in their maximum mechanical performance and cannot meet the specific stiffness and specific strength objectives of this program. Recently,SHEPRA and its development partner the University of Dayton demonstrated a carbon nanotube metal matrix composites produced by Selective Laser Melting (SLM) that demonstrated a 16% increase in elastic modulus and 22% increase in yield strength at 2% carbon nanotube volume loading.These results are consistent with academic literature that shows a 50% increase in modulus and 100% increase in strength at 5% carbon nanotube volume loading in aluminum. These results will meet the requirements of this program.SHEPRA will leverage prior experience to deliver to the Army a carbon nanotubealuminum metal matrix composite for use in Additive Manufacturing of long rod penetrator sabots that utilizes commercial off the shelf materials and AM manufacturing systems. In addition a supply chain has been established that integrates a DOD prime OEM to ensure successful technology transition and commercialization.

award_title: Low-Cost, Lightweight, High-Strength Structural Materials for Small and Medium Caliber Sabots
research_keywords: additive manufacturing,topology optimization,structural design,Sabot,Lightweight
abstract: The use of kinetic energy projectiles relies on a sabot structure to trap and transfer the expanding propellant energy to the penetrator.  While the sabot is critical to projectile acceleration, it negatively affects the lethality performance of the penetrator.  Therefore, lighter sabots are needed to increase penetrator kinetic energy.  While traditional composite methods developed for large caliber projectiles have been successful, these approaches have not been scalable for small and medium caliber projectiles.  Corvid Technologies proposes to design a new sabot utilizing a light weight metallic support structure with a polymer overmold. This methodology differs from those previous by shifting the problem from material design to structural design. The sabot structure will be designed with topology optimization to yield an optimal lightweight metal structure. This structure will be fabricated using additive manufacturing which affords both rapid fabrication and the realization of optimal solutions unattainable through traditional manufacturing.  A polymer overmold is applied to structurally reinforce the sabot and maintain the current designs near-net external geometry. In this way, the metal structure and polymer overmold are designed in tandem to achieve optimal structural, aerodynamic, and kinetic energy performance.  Corvid will provide material testing to validate material properties and performance.

award_title: Lightweight and High-Strength Materials for Small and Medium Caliber Sabots Using Cost Effective Higher Pressure Powder Compaction Green Manufacturing
research_keywords: lightweight alloy composites,Advanced Composite Materials,Alumnium/Magnesium Alloys,Ceramic Strengtheners,Boron Carbides,Powders/Whiskers,prototype sabot,Cost Effective Manufacturing
abstract: The major objective is to design and develop advanced lightweight and stronger sabot materials with adequate elongation to failure and cost effective manufacturing for medium and small caliber sabot component applications based on ARMYs SBIR requirements using advanced lightweight alloy composites using various controlled compositions using Aluminum Alloys 5000 series, 7000 series, and Aluminum/Magnesium as matrix materials (~Al has density of 2.7 g/cc and Magnesium has density of 1.74g/cc) with varying% of Magnesium to reduce the densities further and with adiitionals varying compositions of strengthening composite reinforcing materials such as Boron Carbides (density of 2.52 g/cc), Silicon (density of 2.329g/cc) /Silicon Oxide (density of 2.65 g/cc) (strengtheners). In Phase I, UTRON Kinetics will develop various metal matrix composite compositions to optimize using powders/whiskers of varying sizes (coarse, fine, and sub-micron/nanosize levels) including commercially available powders and cryomilled Aluminum alloy matrix powders and morphologies in the form of test coupons using UTRON Kineticss patented high pressure (upto 150 tsi) powder compaction GREEN manufacturing to characterize the materials behavior and properties including the microstructures/microchemistry and then fabricate the prototype sabot using representative medium sabot part design geometry as a proof of concept for ARMY. Proposed collaborator  for transition is General Dynamics-OTS.

award_title: Lightweight Bullet and Fragment Impact Protection for Mobile Missile Launcher
research_keywords: Insensitive Munitions,IM,Armor,Protection,bullet,Fragment,Ballistic,Armor-Piercing
abstract: Missile launcher armor is needed to protect propellants from unintended ignition when struck by ballistic projectiles and fragments.  Allowing fragments to penetrate the armor at low speed limits the chance of ignition while lightening the armor.  The closely-spaced shot pattern and thickness and weight limits still make a significant design challenge.  Safe has selected materials suitable for the threat, which are the highest-performing ballistic materials that can be commercialized in the ground vehicle market.  The approach eschews simulation and moves directly to testing to demonstrate feasibility.  Tests are framed within a Design of Experiments approach that develops a design equation from test data on coupons built at potential design points, to assure that the lightest possible design is found that meets all requirements.  The project team includes engineers with extensive experience designing and producing armor.  The commercialization plan relies on the relatively low cost of the materials to foster widespread market penetration, and includes a potential strategic partner for high rate manufacturing or surge demand.  The combination of a statistically based design approach, thoughtful material selection, experienced team, and solid commercialization plan assure the best possible chance to solve this problem and commercialize the resulting product.

award_title: Lightweight Bullet and Fragment Impact Protection for Mobile Missile Launcher
research_keywords: Armor,Insensitive Munitions,STANAG 4241,STANAG 4496,missile protection,launcher armor,MIL-STD-2105
abstract: Currently Army missiles are vulnerable to bullet and fragment impact even when housed within their protective canisters. Missile canisters are generally made of lightweight metalsor composites offering little defense from ballistic impacts. Recent advances in Insensitive Munitions (IM) lightweight armor design indicate the feasibility of a solution for developing practical MIL-STD-2105D compliant canisters. Bullet and fragment impact test data has demonstrated effective impact resistant armor applicable to canister design, making them compatible with both space and weight constraints of typical mobile missile launchers and handling equipment weight limitations.American Technical Coatings, Inc. (DBA ATC Materials, Inc.) of Westlake, OH is a leader in IM armor technologies and is currently producing the NAVY/MDA qualified MIL-STD-2105D Type VI+ Transportation Protection System (TPS).ATCs lightweight armor for canisters is an offshoot of TPS technology and has demonstrated successful IM response reduction of energetic materials in several Army tests.This armor can be easily fitted to any canister or missile launcher, providing enhanced warfighter safety and preservation of scarce munitions so critical during combat operations. Lightweight armor technology can also be used for related applications such as ballistic shields for protection of personnel or hazardous and high-value cargo.

award_title: Inspection System for Body and Vehicle Ballistic Armor
research_keywords: nonlinear elastic wave spectroscopy,Non-linear Acoustic,Impact Resonance,Man-portable Non-destructive Inspection System,Ballistic Protection,Body armor,armored vehicles,
abstract: Personnel and vehicle ballistic armor can be damaged in handling and use, and by severe ballistic and shock impact.  Dropping a ceramic armor plate onto a hard surface, or diving for cover, could fracture the ceramic, cause fiber/matrix damage in the retention layer, or could de-laminate any of the adjacent layers.  Adhesive bonds can degrade slowly over time and their integrity is highly dependent on the surface preparation when applied.  A field portable unit is acute for the deployed testing of body armor and vehicle ballistic armor at the point of manufacture, field testing in active combat zones, and depot testing as deployed armor is recovered and stored for future use.  Novel non-linear acoustic and impact resonance NDI techniques are proposed to detect submillimeter delamination of ceramic-composite interfaces.  These techniques can identify micro-deformations and micro-cracking before they evolve into critical defects capable of weakening or threatening the structural integrity of the material, detect weaknesses in adhesive bonds before they disbond; and identify millimeter cracks in ceramics.  NLA Diagnostics is uniquely qualified to deliver a field portable unit based on its current RECON, a portable instrument designed to accurately detect and assess micro-cracks and fractures in structures using multiple NDI techniques.

award_title: Inspection System for Body and Vehicle Ballistic Armor
research_keywords: millimeter wave imaging,real time,Body armor,Vehicle Armor,layered structures,Nondestructive Testing,3D Imaging,thick structures
abstract: In Phase I we will model, analyze, and optimize our existing non-ionizng, low power imaging technology for armor.We will demonstrate a breadboard microwave/millimeter wave NDI system that behaves like a video camerabut which creates 3D images of the interior of multi-layer dielectric materials.We will use flat and curved vehicle and body armor samples up to 2 thickness and show ability to inspect areas of 2 square feet in less than 5 minutes.We will detect debonds, inclusions, and cracks in composites, Kevlar, rubber, and ceramicsand inspect interfaces between layers.Phase I will include a Phase II prototype design and a draft Commercialization Plan.The overall objective of this endeavor is to determine specific microwave imaging system design specifications for the development of a ruggedized, real-time, high-resolution, 3D and man-portable microwave camera, for rapid, on-site inspection of body and vehicle armors for unintended and ballistic damages.We will also demonstrate ability to build the proposed imaging system to be rugged, reliable and easy to use for use in highly-demanding and stressful environments.The proposed system is expected to provide scalability for individual body armor up to large vehicle are in a battery operated system.

award_title: Mega-City Analysis and Visualization Environment (M-CAVE)
research_keywords: human domain,mega-city,quantum probability,Common Operating Picture,judgment and decision making,Big Data
abstract: Knowledge-Based Systems Incorporated (KBSI) proposes Mega-City Analysis and Visualization Environment (M-CAVE) in response to the Army SBIR Civil Affairs Information and Military Sustainment in the Megacity Environment (topic number A17-036). We propose to conduct a feasibility study, including technical demonstrations, of a mega-city common operating picture (COP) focused on the unique features of the human domain. The mega-city COP will support successful mission planning and information exploitation by way of an innovative model of decision making in the human domain using the mathematics of quantum probability. Our models will be informed by a state-of-the-art natural language processing pipeline and associated geospatially and temporally based COP visualizations. We will assess our approach by selecting data from open sources that are representative of an existing mega-city and predicting known outcomes from the data.

award_title: SecureDBC
research_keywords: provenance,Database,multi-level security,SQL,pedigree,Accumulo,NoSQL,Unified Data
abstract: The Army uses software applications and databases throughout its tactical systems to provide mission critical services.  With mission software moving towards laptops and mobile devices in network disconnected environments, there is a need for a single-instance database solution which provides cell-level visibility with data provenance as information traverses the database.  This will allow the Army to enforce protection of database information through third-party applications.  Architecture Technology Corp (ATCorp) proposes SecureDBC, a software Application Provider Interface (API) product to provide database cell-level visibility to applications while tracking data provenance.  SecureDBC protects information stored in a database and only allows applications to view database query results (at the cell-level) if they are permitted access.  In addition, SecureDBC maintains pedigree and provenance information of data stored and accessed through the database.  SecureDBC will be designed similarly to the Open Database Connector (ODBC) API and architecture which enables it to be application and database agnostic.  This will reduce development costs of Army applications by mimicking standard database connectors familiar to programmers.

award_title: DECEITS- Database Enhancements for Computing Environments and Integrity protection in Tactical Systems
research_keywords: databases,Security,ENCRYPTION,provenance,tactical edge,edge computing
abstract: DECEITS provide multi level security and information flow control with cell level encryption for existing relational databases. At the tactical edge, access to advanced cloud based services such Apache Accumulo may not possible. DECEITS allows these types of services to deployed in any point of the network, but also to be integrated in already applications and services.

award_title: L-Band Interference Rejection Applique (LIRA)
research_keywords: Interference Mitigation,Cosite Interference,Filtering,GPS,Position Navigation and Timing
abstract: Intelligent Automation, Inc. proposes to develop an L-band interference rejection applique for mitigating cosite interference from nearby out-of-band transmissions. As spectrum congestion increases, through spectrum auctions such as AWS-3 for example, the impact of cosite and adjacent channel interference on radio operations will increase. For example, JTRS training sites operating in the 1755-1850 MHz band may experience more interference from cellular transmissions. Similarly, meteorological ground stations operating in the 1695-1710 MHz band may experience more interference from cellular uplink transmissions. Position, navigation and timing (PNT) signals such as Global Positioning System (GPS) are among the weakest signals received at a receiver. Therefore, these receivers will be impacted the most because of cosite interference due to tactical radio operations in for example 1750-1850 MHz.

award_title: Signal Processing at Radio Frequency (RF) for Position Navigation &amp; Timing Co-Site Interference
research_keywords: Co-Site Interference Mitigation,Jamming,GPS/PNT,Signal processing at RF,Frequency selective limiter,wideband radio,high dynamic range
abstract: Metamagnetics proposes a powerful new solution to the co-site interference mitigation problem based on its versatile Frequency Selective Limiter (FSL) technology. Operations in an increasingly congested electromagnetic spectrum, constantly intensifying demand for data at the tactical edge, and the diminishing extent of electromagnetic spectrum provisioned for the military has resulted in the need for advanced technologies to mitigate Global Positioning System (GPS) interference due to co-site interference with C4ISR . Metamagnetics FSL technology has the potential to provide the Army with a powerful innovative interference mitigation tool that is much needed on the battlefield. Unlike other common approaches such as tunable filter banks, antenna radiation pattern adjustment and signal diversity, the FSL is a completely passive high power RF signal processing tool. Current SOA methods fall short in that they require copious extra components to sense and tune the electronics to mitigate the interference, or they rely on geometry and position of antenna elements, which can be difficult to maintain while moving and is cumbersome. The FSL is a compact passive device that can be placed in the RF front end to protect sensitive downstream components without compromising or taking away from the overall system performance.

award_title: Low-Profile Multiband Antenna
research_keywords: antenna,UHF,L-band,Circular Polarization,Miniature,low-profile
abstract: To address the U.S. Army need for low-profile broadband antennas that can operate in the UHF (200-440 MHz) and L (950-2150 MHz) bands, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a new Low-profile, Multiband Antenna (LOMUA). This device is based on a design utilizing planar elements backed by an artificial magnetic conductor for size reduction. Specifically, the LOMUA system will radiate efficiently in the frequency bands of interest (gain = -3 dB at UHF, gain = 0 dB at L-band), and have a 360 deg operational azimuth, while supporting both right-hand and left-hand circular polarization. In Phase I POC will develop a proof-of-concept electrically small, multiband antenna through simulation and analysis, and will perform sufficient analysis to verify that the designed antenna can efficiently radiate frequencies in the UHF and L-band and meet the required antenna capabilities. In Phase II, POC plans to optimize the LOMUA design, quantifying performance metrics and enhancing the design through modification, and to fabricate and deliver a prototype. POC will also prepare a transition plan and evaluate LOMUA in a representative vehicular platform environment at technology readiness level (TRL)-5/-6.

award_title: UHF L-band Transmitter Receiver Antenna (ULTRA)
research_keywords: Blue Force Tracking (BFT),Situational awareness,UHF and L-Band satellite communication (SATCOM),broadband antennas,metamaterials,Position Location Information (PLI),multi-band antennas,electrically small antennas
abstract: The Department of Defense depends on multiple systems to establish and update position information of our forces on the battlefield. However, the current interfacing capability for position location information (PLI) systems is limited to a select few service providers. By adding flexibility to the RF media interface for these systems, new levels of connectedness and reliability can be achieved, providing greater situational awareness to every warfighter.Currently, new multi-band waveforms are in development to support transceiver function across multiple wireless systems and assist in enhancing PLI reliability. These new waveforms require significant bandwidth and efficiency from the corresponding RF sensors. However, limited real estate on tactical vehicular platforms precludes traditionally broadband and efficient antenna designs. The competing requirements for size, bandwidth, efficiency, and pattern coverage are especially challenging for systems operating at frequencies such as UHF and L-Band.FIRST RF proposes a variety of novel material and loading technologies thatwhen combined with FIRST RFs proven broadband radiatorsminimize the size of the antenna without compromising its bandwidth or efficiency.

award_title: Small High-Power Agile Colocated Electronically Tunable Bandpass Filter
research_keywords: agile,Tunable,Bandpass Filters,Multiradio interface,Fast tuning,Low-SWAP
abstract: To address the Army need for a low cost, Small, Agile Filter  Tunable (SAF-T) capable of being tuned via a variety of different control protocols, i.e., platform data bus, radio interfaces, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) is proposing a new Small High-Power Agile Colocated Electronically Tunable (SPACE) bandpass filter, based on a resonating RF structure with ferroelectric-based capacitors for tuning. The innovation in high-Q resonating RF structures provides a large tunable range by using high-power, voltage-tunable, barium strontium titanate (BST) capacitors to quickly (

award_title: Small Agile Filter-Tunable (SAF-T)
research_keywords: tunable filter,High Power,Reconfigurable,Agile RF
abstract: The use of multiple radios on a vehicle and dynamic, frequency-hopping communication methods increase the need for compact tunable filters. When operating high power radios in close proximity to one another, it is just as important to clean up the transmit spectrum as well as the receive spectrum to maintain good signal to noise ratio and link performance. Indiana Microelectronics is proposing a bank of reconfigurable filters using solid state switches and varactor diodes to cover a wide band of interest with fast tuning speeds, while still maintaining enough linearity to operate in the transmit path of a radio. The ability to control the center frequency, bandwidth, and number of poles of the filters will allow the system to optimize performance across a wide range of operational environments. The use of reconfigurable resonators consisting of lumped-element and substrate-integrated components where necessary allows for a compact, high performance, multi-pole design that can fit into applications where size and weight are critical.

award_title: Generation of MWIR Ultra-Short Pulses through Nonlinear Conversion in Optical Fibers
research_keywords: Ultra-Short Pulse,Nonlinear Conversion,Infrared,Higher order mode,Soliton self-frequency shifting
abstract: There is a growing interest in shifting the wavelength of ultra-short pulse (USP) lasers systems to new spectral regimes, in order to harness the unique properties of USP lasers for new applications. For many of these applications high peak powers, on the order of terawatts (TWs), are desired. Due to the lack of laser gain media that are able to produce emission directly at mid-IR frequencies, current laser technology relies on nonlinear processes to generate light in this region of the spectrum. Optical parametric chirped pulse amplification (OPCPA) has been shown as a viable method for generating TW peak powers; however, these systems often utilize complex geometries and several stages of nonlinear conversion to reach the mid-IR. In an effort to simplify these systems and provide a path from laboratory proof-of-principle to fieldable technology, Q-Peak is offering an enabling technology that replaces the complex optical setups required to generate broadband, ultra-short, seed pulses with a monolithic, alignment-free, optical fiber based approach. Q-Peak will develop and demonstrate nonlinear conversion of ultra-short pulses to mid-IR frequencies using Raman-assisted Soliton Self-Frequency Shifting (SSFS) in IR transmissive optical fibers which can be used as a seed for high peak power OPCPA laser systems.

award_title: TW Mid-Infrared Laser
research_keywords: MWIR laser,MWIR fiber laser,ultrafast fiber laser,High energy femtosecond fiber laser,OPA
abstract: Based on our success in developing several the worlds first commercial high energy femtosecond fiber laser system and OPA systems, PolarOnyx propose, for the first time, a compact fiber laser pumped high energy mid-wave infrared laser to meet with the requirement of the Army solicitation A17-042. The laser is a hybrid fiber/solid state laser based MOPA incorporating our proprietary technology of pulse shaping and spectral shaping in generation of ultrashort MW-IR pulses from an OPA. A tabletop experiment will be demonstrated in Phase I time frame. A hardware will be delivered in Phase II.

award_title: Automated Detection, Identification and Tracking of Unmanned Aerial Systems
research_keywords: unmanned aerial systems (UAS),unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV),counter-UAS (CUAS),Infrared Cameras,distributed aperture system (DAS),Detection and Tracking,convolutional neural networks (CNN),machine learning
abstract: To address the Army need to automatically detect and track small unmanned aerial systems (UAS) from ground vehicles equipped with distributed aperture systems (DAS) of infrared (IR) cameras, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop new software for Automated Detection, Identification and Tracking of Unmanned Aerial Systems (ADITUAS), based on an innovative combination of machine vision and machine learning algorithms. These algorithms will enable real-time extraction of data relevant to counter-UAS (CUAS) systems from raw DAS output. The algorithms will work on moving DAS platforms, being able to filter out platform movement before attempting UAS detection. Specifically, innovations in image registration, in using convolutional neural networks (CNN) to detect moving objects in cluttered environments, and in structure-from-motion (SFM) ranging will enable the software to detect, identify, and track UAS using DAS video output, and optionally translate UAS positions to 3D world coordinate systems. As a result, the software will provide actionable input to CUAS systems, which directly addresses the Army requirements. In Phase I, POC will demonstrate the feasibility of the ADITUAS approach by developing a Technology Readiness Level (TRL)-3 software implementation. In Phase II, POC will build a TRL 6 ADITUAS system based on COTS GPU hardware.

award_title: High-Speed Image Processing in Heavily Degraded Environments Using a Machine Learning Classifier
research_keywords: Infrared,machine learning,Image processing,Degraded Visual Environment
abstract: Driving ground vehicles in heavily degraded visual environments brings significant risk since course corrections cannot be made safely without visual cues. Infrared imagery can improve visibility in degraded visual environments, however when heavily degraded, this method alone is insufficient. Noise sources can be rapidly categorized and suppressed in near real-time by applying modern image processing techniques with machine-learning-based classification strategies. Noise sources will first be analyzed in degraded imagery including the temporal component of the noise. A supervised machine learning approach will categorize these noise sources, allowing for rapid identification of the optimal noise removal method. These noise signatures will be next replicated, and then transforms developed that can repair damage done by such noise sources. Finally, a limited scope implementation will be done to ensure high-speed application of these image enhancements is suitable while driving a vehicle. Phase II efforts will fully implement the method and target below 80 ms latency.  Phase III efforts will focus on widespread implementation.

award_title: Digital In-Pixel Uncooled LWIR Bolometer Camera
research_keywords: digital pixel,uncooled infrared camera,large format,small pixel pitch,high frame rate,high dynamic range
abstract: Current uncooled bolometer readout integrated circuits (ROICs) utilize in-pixel analog circuitry with analog-to-digital conversion (ADC) accomplished in the camera electronics or in the ROIC in the column circuitry. Locating ADC function in-pixel will provide much higher dynamic range and frame rate for uncooled longwave infrared (LWIR) imaging in large array formats. Benefits are also expected for production costs, signal-to-noise ratio, and CMOS foundry flexibility for commercial applications. The proposed Phase I effort will show, by design, proof of concept of digital in-pixel circuitry to achieve 1280x1024 format imaging in 12 m pixel pitch with 16-bits signal dynamic range and frame rate 240 Hz. The Black Forest Engineering (BFE) ADC approach utilizes an ADC circuit compatible with both scaled CMOS and 3D IC stacking. On Phase I, BFE will compare implementation methods addressing performance, cost, and risk. On Phase II the all-digital ROIC will be fabricated with bolometers and wafer level vacuum packaging. The ROIC will be integrated into a camera system prototype to demonstrate capability (performance and features) of digital in-pixel circuitry.

award_title: Multi-band Infrared Adjunct (MIRA)
research_keywords: aircraft survivability,Multi-Spectral Adjunct Sensor,Missile Warning Systems (MWS),Integrated Detector Suite,plume signature,Spectral Analysis,Temporal Analysis.
abstract: Aircraft Missile Warning Systems are used to detect threats, to alert aircrews, & provide Situational Awareness within sufficient time to perform countermeasures and maneuvers preventing the aircraft from being hit or possibly destroyed. The relatively coarse spectral resolution of legacy MWS sensors & the computational overhead associated with threat declaration & angle of arrival, limits the ability of current MWSs to classify & identify a threat.  In Phase I, DHPC will research spectral bands that may be utilized by an adjunct sensor, for threat classification and identification. DHPC will perform modeling and simulation of the scenarios & discrimination criteria and design a Multi-Spectral Adjunct Sensor (MSAS).  DHPC will develop the technical foundations of the MSAS, which may consist of either single element detectors, or a linear array, with a variety of spectral bands (UV/Visible/Infrared). Phase I will develop the threat discrimination criteria, and design a laboratory brass-board prototype based on these criteria. Phase II will be the fabrication, testing and delivery of the brass-board. Phase III will transition the MSAS onto the Armys fleet of legacy MWS systems, and leverage some of the prototypes capabilities into the next generation of MWS and future ASE systems.

award_title: Analytic for Federated Data
research_keywords: Analytic,recommender,Big Data,Cloud Computing,Multi-INT,Semantic,TCRI,BDP
abstract: Phoenix Operations Group will research open-source recommender engines for use in DoD and Intelligence missions.By injecting recommendations into streaming data frameworks (such as Apache Storm and Spark Streaming), recommendations can be made in a real-time context to supporting tipping and cueing functions.Phoenix will also leverage its innovative solutions from the Big Data and Cloud Computing domains so that the system will scale up to support enterprise level data volumes.The high-level architecture is composed of four subsystems: Capture, Analyze, Semantic Search and Display.The Capture subsystem is responsible for ingesting user actions, interaction and transactions.The Analyze subsystem is responsible for generating recommendations, persisting recommendations, and alerting based upon recommendations.The Semantic Search subsystem is responsible for executing user queries and inferring the users true intentions.The Display subsystem is responsible for user interfaces on multiple platforms.The four subsystems work in concert to provide a streaming multi-INT system that can be deployed to individual program platforms or as an enterprise solution.

award_title: Real-time Remotely Sensed Topography and Bathymetry using Visible and LWIR Imagery Acquired from Small UASs
research_keywords: visible imaging,TIR microbolometer imaging,multi-rotor sUAS,day-night bathymetry,topography,near real-time processing
abstract: Warfighters responsible for planning and conducting A2/AD entry operations require up-to-date, high-quality information within dynamic littoral zones. We plan to develop an easily deployable day-night measurement capability to accurately measure bathymetry, topography, currents and water surface temperature in near real-time from sensors and small computing capabilities housed within small multi-rotor vertical take-off and landing (VTOL) UASs. For decades it has been known that nearshore bathymetry can be estimated using gravity wave dispersion relationships derived from a sequential set of downward-looking images (time series), but the current implementation is insufficient to meet the needs of the warfighter. Our approach integrates the cBathy and three-dimensional Fourier based gravity wave dispersion algorithms using thermal and visible imagery to produce robust nearshore bathymetry with a well-understood uncertainty estimate. The sensitivity of the algorithms to direct georeferencing will be explored to reduce the need for ground control points and fiducials for nighttime operation. Structure from Motion techniques using both visible and thermal imagery will generate topographic subaerial dense point clouds with RGB and temperature overlays. Small low power computing components will enable on-board real-time processing so information can be transmitted to ground personnel in near real-time.

award_title: Open-Architecture Optical Array Payload for SUAS with Optional LIDAR
research_keywords: SUAS,onboard processing,Open-Architecture,camera array,EO,IR,Multispectral,Hyperspectral
abstract: The Army desires observations of an area over time in order to perform littoral terrain estimates, hydrodynamics estimation, and estimation of geological properties in turbid environments. Analysis options include 3-D terrain generation (structure-from-motion photogrammetry) and bathymetric processing (e.g. bathymetric inversion). The Army requires the data collection to be performed with a hand-launchable SUAS. SUAS-based photogrammetry and bathymetry processing require geo-registration of images from a moving platform. The current state-of-the-art for SUAS image collection and geo-registration is not suitable for near real-time tactical applications. Current registration algorithms degrade over water and cannot reliably quantify performance.  In Phase 1, Prioria will collect SUAS data of coastal environments using high-resolution camera array of COTS cameras and use the data to demonstrate the feasibility of robust geo-registration with error estimate for coastal land, surf zone, and littoral regions. In our proposal, we describe a novel data acquisition concept using the array camera which should mitigate traditional failure modes for registration over water. Finally, in the option, we will perform a preliminary design of an objective payload which will establish SWAP and performance tradeoffs of the passive array and optional LIDAR across the spectrum of hand-launchable SUAS.

award_title: Using a Novel Concentration Technology to Develop Products for Army Rations
research_keywords: bioseparations,Concentration,membrane technology,Food Science,evaporation,hybrid,Novel,Nutrition
abstract: This Phase I project seeks to establish the technical feasibility of developing a blended juice concentrate at a bench top level utilizing a novel hybrid membrane juice concentration technology.
