This issue of requiring additional time to arrive on station can be mitigated by increasing the power available for electric propulsion during the orbit-raising period.  If a spacecraft was able to deliver additional solar array power during this orbit raising period to the orbit-raising thruster, it could shorten this period by as much as 40%.  That improvement would enable in-service operation months ahead of time.  Cubic Aerospaces HPPT design enables the utilization of additional BOL solar power for electric propulsion, reducing the transfer orbit time required.

award_title: Scalable, High Performance, Pump-Fed Spacecraft Propulsion System
research_keywords: Nanosat and microsat propulsion,Pump-fed spacecraft propulsion,Green propellants propulsion,Low pressure feed systems,Printed spacecraft propulsion components,Low cost propulsion system
abstract: The project focuses on the development of a low cost, compact, low tank pressure, high performance nanosat propulsion system which could be scaled to larger spacecraft. The technology, based on micropumps developed for hydrazine, MMH, NTO, AF-M315E and LMP-103S, has been demonstrated in hot-fire tests with hydrazine, and hot fire tests are planned for a 100 lbf class MMH/MON-25 thruster. The proposed effort leverages developments made as part of several on-going programs and integrates them into a high performance system. The Phase I effort also includes hardware manufacturing and test to reduce development risks. With a micropump, the pressurization system is eliminated, the propellant storage and feed system can be designed for low pressures, and lighter, conformal tanks can be used for greater compactness. This reduces system overall size and mass thus providing increases in performance. Hardware costs are significantly less (fewer components). Furthermore, many of the components can be made affordably and quickly using additive manufacturing techniques.  The technology can be used for steady-state burns, in pulse-mode, and for throttling if needed for optimum mission operations, and is applicable to all propellant combinations and scales ranging from CubeSats and Nanosats to larger satellites such as GPS and AEHF.

award_title: Advanced Propellant Pressurization System
research_keywords: Spacecraft Propulsion,Chemical propulsion,Propellant Storage,propellant feed system,Pump,thruster
abstract: Spacecraft frequently use pressurized helium for propellant tank pressurization, which while safe and effective carries a weight penalty that becomes burdensome as tank size increases. In this project, Ultramet will investigate pressurization systems wherein the pressurant will come from either the thermal decomposition of a solid or from the decomposition of existing liquid propellant on the spacecraft. Both approaches eliminate the need for a helium reservoir. In one approach, a solid will fill the pores of an electrically heated monolith of ceramic foam, and gas will be generated on demand by passing electricity through the foam to thermally decompose the solid. An endothermic solid will be used so the system cannot undergo thermal runaway. In the other approach, small volumes of propellant will be fed into a small reaction vessel filled with electrically heated foam. In both approaches, the resulting gases will be fed into the pressurant side of the propellant tank to provide pressurization. Such systems will reduce the mass relative to a helium-based system. Because the hardware mass for this concept is independent of propellant throughput, the benefits become more pronounced with larger spacecraft. This approach also enables tank pressure to be regulated for reduced impulse variability.

award_title: Electrodeless Induction Thrust for Electric Propulsion
research_keywords: Electric propulsion,high specific impulse,High Thrust,Magnetic Induction Plasma Engine,Orbital Maneuver,Delta V
abstract: Despite much progress obtained in the pioneering MIPE research well documented in the literature of the 1960s, the available switching technology of the day was slow, heavy, expensive, and unreliable at high voltage and current. Switches needed to be switched at hundreds of kilohertz to achieve high exit velocity and high Isp. With modern Si, SiC, and GaN high voltage IGBTs or switching MOSFETs, many MW of power can now be switched reliably with losses of a percent or less. In this proposal, DTI proposes to leverage decades of expertise in state-of-the-art high power switching to study, design, and build a modernized version of the MIPE thruster. This lightweight, electrodeless thruster will exhibit high thrust and high specific impulse capabilities, with the added benefit of minimizing plasma-wall interactions through careful control of geometries and magnetic circuit design.

award_title: Targeted Electrospray Performance for High Efficiency and Scalability
research_keywords: electrospray,Electric propulsion,feedsystem,Ionic liquid,High Power
abstract: Electrospray thrusters are superior to plasma based electric propulsion with respect to thrust efficiency and thrust to power ratios (T/P), with difficulties predominantly being scaling to high power applications.  Specifically, Busek contends that such applications require more conventional propellant delivery mechanisms, which include latching and proportional flow control valves to manage the large amounts of propellant commensurate with kW-level electrospray propulsion.  As part of the Lisa Pathfinder mission, Busek has flight qualified and demonstrated on orbit such a feedsystem.  Busek proposes to develop a modularized electrospray emitter design suitable for production of arrays that are tailored for attachment to pressurized propellant sources.  Thruster performance shall be optimized for high efficiency and T/P, targeting emission of small ion clusters.  A four emitter array (~20W) shall be demonstrated in the Phase I, with scaling to 100W or greater performed during the Phase II effort, and larger systems produced from additional stacking and/or scaling.  Additionally, using novel power converter technology, Busek shall demonstrate increased high voltage generation efficiency, a key requirement for attaining system efficiencies approaching 70%.  Lessons learned will be implemented to develop scaling laws and designs necessary to approach the desired power levels in subsequent efforts.

award_title: Integrated Green Monopropellant Propellant Processing for High Power Electrospray Thrusters
research_keywords: electrospray,multi-mode propulsion,Ionic liquid,Green monopropellant,Electric propulsion
abstract: Green monopropellants have numerous performance and handling benefits over conventional propellants such as hydrazine. Many are derived from Ionic Liquids (IL) and are therefore well suited for use in electrospray electric propulsion systems. This affords the possibility of a multi-mode propulsion (MMP) capability, where both chemical and electric thrusters share a common propellant. Recently, Busek became the first to operate an electrospray thruster in space via the NASA ST7/ESA Pathfinder mission. Busek is also a leader in developing novel green monopropellant thrusters and is therefore poised to create and demonstrate MMP systems. Busek proposes to address presently gating challenges associated with electrospray-MMP systems. First, high thrust density emitters will be developed within the strict material compatibility constraints imposed by candidate propellants. Subsequently, an inline propellant processing unit will be developed to both appropriately distribute the liquid phase propellant and provide electrical isolation. In Phase I, the thruster head performance will be optimized towards high T/P and Isp >1000s, through targeting efficient nanodroplet beams, and demonstrated with propellant supplied via the inline processing unit. In Phase II the technology will be scaled towards a high power, 100s of W, system operated end-to-end with Buseks existing green monopropellant compatible tanks and valves.

award_title: Electric-based Combined Cycle Thruster for Multi-mode Propulsion
research_keywords: Monopropellant,multi-mode propulsion,FRC,Electric propulsion,Neutral Entrainment,Thrust-to-power
abstract: The Electric-Based Combined Cycle (EBCC) thruster is a new approach to spacecraft propulsion that combines the high thrust of a chemical combustion system and the high Isp of an electric propulsion thruster into a single thruster. In EBCC, a chemical propellant is burned in a sub-100 N rocket within a pulsed EP system. That decomposed, hot, neutral gas is then accelerated in a 5kWclass neutral entrainment thruster. Neutral entrainment uses molecular charge-exchange and dissociation processes in a pulsed electromagnetic accelerator to lower ionization losses and dramatically increase the total thrust-to-power. This coaxial geometry decreases overall system mass and complexity, while simultaneously increasing performance. By harnessing the momentum and chemical energy of the combustion propellant and entraining it in a plasma stream, a T/P can be increased to 110+ mN/kW at 1000 s on these lightweight propellants. This Phase I program will answer the challenges associated with combining a high flow chemical system with a low flow EP thruster. An experimental investigation will demonstrate the operation of a neutral entrainment thruster with a pulsed, high temperature gas injector. Additionally, this program will increase the fundamental understanding of the molecular species dynamics within a neutral entrainment process through analytical and experimental investigations.

company: COMBUSTION RESEARCH AND FLOW TECHNOLOGY INC
award_title: Variable Pressure/Flow Control Firefighting Nozzle
research_keywords: Firefighting nozzle,ultra-high pressure,Low Pressure Nozzle,Aircraft Rescue Fire Fighting (ARFF),Design Optimization
abstract: Combustion Research and Flow Technology (CRAFT Tech) and its partner, Vulcan Research & Controls (VRC) propose the development of a hybrid firefighting hand nozzle providing both Ultra-High Pressure (UHP) and Low Pressure (LP) operational modes for applic

award_title: Variable Pressure/Flow Control Firefighting Nozzle
research_keywords: ultra-high pressure (UHP),fire fighting equipment,nozzle design & development,dual-mode nozzle,P-34 RIV & P-19 ARFF,lightweight engineering,CFD simulation,proof-of-concept
abstract: Two fundamentally different firefighting systems are used by the Air Force.  The first is a Low Pressure (LP) system similar to those used by municipal fire departments, providing water/foam solution to a hand line nozzle at pressures typically between 50

award_title: Portable, Omnidirectional Retroreflector Testing System
research_keywords: retroreflectometer,in situ characterization,Non-destructive testing,Portable,wide-angle
abstract: To address the Air Forces need for a wide-angle retroreflectometer, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a new Portable, Omnidirectional Retroreflector Testing (PORT) system, based on a novel combination of omnidirectional beam steerin

award_title: Wide-angle Retroreflectometer
research_keywords: Reflectometer,retro-reflection,pavement markings,airfield safety
abstract: Good visibility of runway pavement markings is essential for pilots to land  and taxi safely.  While advances in lighting technologies such as centerline runway illumination have greatly improved nighttime visibility during landing,  retroreflective gl

award_title: Atmospheric Plasma Surface Activation of High Strength Steels for Electroplating
research_keywords: Atmospheric Plasma Surface Treatment APST,electroplating surface activation,landing gear part cleaning,Environmentally friendly surface energy enhancement,Media free surface activation process,blast media substitute,Plasmaflux or Plasmablast surface
abstract: The current surface activation process used to activate the surface of landing gear parts uses an aggressive grit blasting technique prior to electroplating. This technique is effective, but requires large amounts of blast media, requires a pre-cleaned surface and the process removes up to 0.1mils of substrate, much more than necessary. There is an urgent need for a process that can easily and effectively activate surfaces for electroplating without removing more than a few atoms of substrate. Atmospheric Plasma Solutions, Inc. (APS) has developed an Atmospheric Plasma Surface Treatment (APST) technology that can quickly and effectively surface activate a wide variety of substrates using only air and electricity by producing a cold, atmospheric pressure plasma beam which is directed at the surface to be activated.  Any organic surface contaminants and loose inorganic debris is etched away leaving a nearly atomically clean surface.  This proposed effort will focus on development of a conceptual design of this application, demonstrating the feasibility of the approach, and ensuring the ability of the APST process to meet stated DoD requirements. This effort will also lay the groundwork for subsequent scale-up of the process and further engineering development.

company: Engineering And Software System Solutions, Inc.
award_title: Alternative Method of Surface Activation of High Strength Steels for Electroplating
research_keywords: High Strength Steel,Surface Activation Technology,CHROMIUM,Cadmium,nickel,LHE Zinc-Nickel,Electroless Nickel,phosphate
abstract: During the overhaul process of aircraft and landing gear at Hill AFB, various high strength (HSS) aircraft components must have surface plated coatings periodically replaced.  Some of those coatings include chromium (Cr), nickel (Ni), electro-less nickel (E-Ni), cadmium (Cd), low hydrogen embrittlement (LHE ZnNi) and phosphate. To achieve acceptable adhesion properties from the plated coatings, the HSS surface must be activated and all corrosion/contamination must be removed by blasting the components with 120-grit aluminum oxide. After which, some plating process require that 300M HSS components, which has a high silica content, have additional activation in an ammonium bifluoride H2SO4/NH4HF2 bath. The ammonium bifluoride bath chemistry is intermediate rout to hydrofluoric acid, which is a very hazardous chemical, poses high risk to personnel, and is corrosive to the eyes, skin, and mucous membranes. Additionally, grit blasting, if not done properly, can be abusive to HSS landing gear/aircraft components and contaminated grit can cause galvanic corrosion. Consequently, during this SBIR Phase I project, ES3 proposes to complete the research necessary to demonstrate feasibility of replacing the current surface activation process with a alternative surface activation technology that is be safer for plating personnel and less abusive to landing gear/aircraft components.

company: Engineering And Software System Solutions, Inc.
award_title: Development of Additive Manufacturing for Landing Gear Components
research_keywords: additive manufacturing,Landing gear,3D Printing,Rapid Manufacturing,Material Science,Qualification,Laser melt,Testing
abstract: The USAF recognizes the potential of Additive Manufacturing (AM) to replace current forging and machining processes to produce landing gear parts of equal or improved strength, weight, and corrosion resistance. ES3 will demonstrate AM feasibility for landing gear, manufacture and qualify an AM landing gear part, and commercialize AM for landing gear. Phase I focuses on suitable AM processes and materials for landing gear with a feasibility evaluation for design, analysis, AM materials, AM processing, post processing, NDI, qualification, and facility requirements for AM landing gear parts. Based on our industry involvement, ES3 believes that the feasibility study will support pursuit of Phase II funding for rapid development and qualification of this emerging technology. Final commercialization is realized with an AM production specification and AM production parts.

award_title: Real-time, 3-D Model Deformation Measurement Capability for Perforated Wall Wind Tunnels
research_keywords: lidar,Ladar,Model Deformation Measurement,wind tunnel testing
abstract: All wind-tunnel models are subject to deformation and displacement as they are placed under increasing aerodynamic loading. Providing a capability for high fidelity, real-time 3D imaging of wind tunnel models while under test in transonic wind tunnels is

award_title: Distributed Position Sensing for 3D Surface Deformation in Wind Tunnels
research_keywords: wind tunnel,Fiber Optic Sensing,Coordinate Measurement Machine
abstract: High-definition fiber optic sensing will enable accurate, real-time 3D measurement of position, attitude, and surface deformation of test surfaces in the wind tunnel environment.  Lunas position sensing cable measures its 3D position and orientation, d

award_title: Reduction/Elimination of Unsteady Aerodynamic Loads on Model and Balance Support Systems in Large Scale Wind Tunnels
research_keywords: Model and balance  passive adaptive and active damping control and protection,Balance Damping,Balance Damage Prevention,Force and moment measurements accuracy improvement,wind tunnel testing,Testing Productivity Enhancement.
abstract: Wind tunnel testing of high performance aerodynamic systems, including force and moment measurements (of larger models), often involve unsteady oscillatory loads which may damage the expensive balance and would also normally impact the data accuracy and a

award_title: Development and Feasibility Demonstration of an Automated Active Damper Sting
research_keywords: active damping,wind tunnel,piezoceramic actuator,vibration reduction,Sting,automated control,wind tunnel balance,controls design
abstract: Unwanted vibration of heavy, sting-mounted, cantilevered models is an ongoing issue for wind tunnel facilities. Unsteady flow generated on models can result in vibration and oscillation of the model support system. Such vibration can result in compromised

award_title: Miniature Video Camera Technology for Embedded Probes
research_keywords: SWIR-band,Turbine engine,high dynamic range (HDR),augmentor performance,full-motion video,focalplane array,Compact,Dual-band
abstract: A compact Dual-Band SWIR focalplane imager to inspect and analyze turbine jet engine augments and exhaust is proposed. The system would be capable of seeing individual turbine fan blades and relaying surface temperatures in real-time. The Dual-Band Image

award_title: Miniature Video Camera Technology for Embedded Probes
research_keywords: Miniature camera,Viewing probes,turbine engines,DIAGNOSTICS,Augmentors,visible,LWIR,Thermoelectric Cooler (TEC)
abstract: Miniature cameras have long been used in the testing and monitoring of running turbine engines.  Advancements in general purpose sensor technology have allowed for smaller sensors with higher resolutions and frame rates while reducing cost.  Thus far thes

award_title: Time-Resolved Focusing Schlieren Deflectometer for Large Hypersonic Wind Tunnels
research_keywords: schlieren,focusing,deflectomer,time-resolved,Hypervelocity,wind tunnel,Aerodynamics,Optical
abstract: Non-intrusive methods for measuring turbulence in wind tunnels are necessary to provide a complete understanding of the hypersonic flow physics needed to improve modeling. In response to this need, we propose to design and construct a time-resolved focusi

award_title: Non-intrusive, Time Resolved Measurement of Density and Velocity Perturbations in Supersonic and Hypersonic Wind Tunnels
research_keywords: Wind tunnel diagnostics,Burst-mode laser,Hypersonics,FLDI,non-intrusive,Turbulence,seedless
abstract: The objective of this SBIR effort is to develop and validate two non-intrusive measurement techniques that measure localized density and velocity fluctuations in large-scale high-speed wind tunnels. We plan to work toward this end by: 1) using dual focuse

award_title: Advanced, Low-Erosion Electrode Technologies for Arcjet Testing
research_keywords: Hypersonics,are heater,electrodes,ampacity
abstract: Triton Systems proposes to develop and demonstrate the feasibility of a novel composite material to replace the current zirconium copper electrodes in arc heaters and allow hypersonic testing under more extreme conditions.  To demonstrate the feasibility

award_title: Advanced Composite Electrode for Arcjet Testing

abstract: We propose to investigate a number of high Tc SQUID magnetometer and gradiometer sensors designs based on helium ion direct-write Josephson junction technology normally operational at temperatures near 77 K.  Both planar washer type direct-inject and multilayer SQUID input coils will be considered and evaluated.

award_title: High Sensitivity Magnetometers and Gradiometers Based on Nano-Josephson Junction SQUIDs
research_keywords: squid,Nano-Josephson Junction,small magnetic field detection,helium ion-beam lithography,cryogenic packaging
abstract: In this SBIR Phase I, HYPRES and University of California Riverside will demonstrate the feasibility of low cost, high sensitivity magnetometers and gradiometers utilizing direct-write, high temperature superconducting (HTS) nano-Josephson junction SQUIDs. This fabrication technology is based on direct-write technique using helium focused ion beam (FIB). In this project, we will capitalize on the already achieved results showing SQUIDs with much lower flux noise than typical HTS SQUIDs. We will investigate the effects of non-uniformity and dimension on linearity, dynamic range and noise. We will simulate and design magnetometer and gradiometer circuits integrating a helium ion beam HTS SQUID and a flux concentrator to substantially increase sensitivity. Designs comprising both planar washer type direct-inject and multilayer SQUID input coils will be simulated, designed and evaluated. In Phase II, we plan to develop a compact, portable prototype magnetometers and gradiometers . These sensors will be characterized in a flux-locked loop to determine their sensitivity, bandwidth and dynamic range. Devices will be operated in a micro-dewar and/or on compact cryocoolers to determine practical size and weight requirements, noise properties and other capabilities. In Phase III, we will produce and market magnetometers and gradiometers for  biomedical and non-destructive evaluation instrumentation.

award_title: Development of Ga2O3 Epitaxial Layers and Heterostructures for Power Device Applications
research_keywords: -Ga2O3,high power electronics,MOCVD,oxide semiconductors,epitaxy
abstract: This Phase I program sets out to capitalize on recent advances in epitaxial growth of -Ga2O3 which have the potential to significantly improve upon the performance of currently available power electronics devices. Specifically, -Ga2O3, offers fundamental properties such as its ability to withstand very large electric fields that suggest its use as a power electronics material will lead to device performance beyond even that of SiC and GaN. We propose to determine the growth parameters that yield high quality, doped -Ga2O3 epitaxial layers and (AlxGa1-x)2O3/-Ga2O3 epitaxial heterostructures. That is, MOSFET and HEMT structures. For this program we have assembled a team of renowned scientists with expertise in the growth and characterization of semiconductor oxides.

award_title: Instrumentation for carbon-carbon structures in extreme environments
research_keywords: Carbon-Carbon,photolithography,inverse heat transfer,arc jet,recession,ablation,W-Re,thermocouple
abstract: An integrated measurement sensor for carbon-carbon (C-C) structures is needed for testing in arc jet facilities to meet testing needs for current and future hypersonic flight systems.   A commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS) high frequency response pressure sensor and a fabricated temperature, heat flux, and recession sensor built directly into a C-C substrate will be integrated into a test article for future arc jet testing. Utilizing a redundant sealing architecture, this work will also demonstrate that the as-designed sensor assembly and integration methodology enables rapid repair and/or replacement of the individual sensors on the assembly if a single sensing device fails in the field. The entire sensor assembly does not require active cooling and therefore this test assembly is suitable for incorporation into future flight test programs. The sensor assembly will utilize a super high temperature Kulite pressure transducer for pressure measurements, and one of two types of temperature / heat flux sensors. The first design uses a novel W-Re thin-film thermocouple (TFTC) array for surface temperature measurements, subsurface temperature measurements, and C-C recession rate. The other design, implemented for schedule risk reduction, uses a conventional temperature plug design based on individual thermocouples buried in the C-C substrate at known depths.

award_title: Computationally Optimized Metamaterial-Based Low-Power Integrated Photonics For Miniaturization And Ultra-Large-Scale Integration
research_keywords: maskless photolithography,nanofabrication,metamaterial photonics,CMOS compatibility,on-chip photonic-electronic integration
abstract: LumArray, Inc. is developing a low-cost maskless photolithography system that will meet the resolution, placement-accuracy, overlay, throughput and multilevel-alignment requirements of integrated photonic and electronic devices. The University of Utah has developed methods to design and characterize a new class of metamaterial-based photonic devices that, compared to existing photonic devices and proposed plasmonic devices, offer higher levels of integration, higher photon efficiency, novel functionalities and compatibility with CMOS.  The designs take into account the practical aspects of nanofabrication, thereby enabling efficient photonic-electronic integration on the same chip.  The highly compact metamaterial devices will provide: (1) efficient coupling of light from fiber to waveguides; (2) conversion from multi-mode to single-mode propagation; (3) efficient mode separation based on polarization; and (4) efficient mode separation based on wavelength.   In Phase 1, Univ. Utah will design exemplary photonic-metamaterial devices. These will then be patterned at LumArray using its maskless photolithography and etching capabilities, and returned to Utah for characterization and design iteration. In Phase 2 the team will demonstrate a system that integrates the novel photonic devices with simple electronic devices in a CMOS-compatible process. In Phase 3, we will pursue commercialization in conjunction with OpSis and similar foundries.

award_title: Toward Ultra-Dense Integrated Plasmonic Circuits
research_keywords: Plasmonic Waveguide,Hybridized,diffraction limit,ULTRAFAST,Photonics Integrated Circuits,EM Wave Sensor,Optical Router
abstract: Continuing demands for increased compute efficiency and communication bandwidth have led to the development of novel interconnect technologies with the potential to outperform conventional electrical interconnects. Nowadays, optical communication with passive photonic waveguides which supports GHz data rate and multiple communication channels (WDM) has been widely applied in large scale optical net-works in order to improve the energy efficiency. However, due to the intrinsic properties of light such as diffraction limit and adjacent crosstalk, the passive photonic waveguide is still hard to be densely integrated on-chip on the footprint aspect comparing with electronic wires. This also further limits the adaptation of high performance optical devices and still makes the conventional electronics communication network hard to beat in the on-chip level. For active devices such as modulators, this means fulfilling optical switching operations within light propagation distances of just a few wavelengths.  In this proposal Dr. Dalir from Omega Optics Inc. in collaboration with University of Texas at Austin propose a photonics integrated circuit for ultrafast- sensing and switching based on ultra-dense packaging.

research_keywords: battlefield airmen,Augmented Reality system,BAARS,digital night vision,day/night all-weather vision,Head-mounted display (HMD),Multispectral,EO/IR sensor
abstract: To address Air Force needs for a low-latency multispectral helmet-mountable near-to-eye augmented-reality system, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a new See-through All-weather Laser-projection Augmented-Reality Digital Multispectral Vision Goggles (STALAR-DMVG) with a wide field of view (FOV) and a high-resolution multispectral imagery overlay via common-aperture sensor blending, enabling low-latency performance with low size, weight, and power (SWaP) in a rugged structure. STALAR-DMVG is based on unique integration of key POC technologies: (1) a thin see through ellipsoidal off-axis collimator lens; (2) a scanning laser projector light engine providing high definition resolution, wide-FOV three-color imagery with near eye-limiting-resolution; (3) an integrated common-aperture multispectral imaging sensor based on an extremely compact wide FOV monocentric objective lens; and (4) a field programmable gate array-based low-power parallel-pipeline electronic processor providing low latency computing hardware and software. Innovated use of scanning laser display and narrowband coatings allows simple distortion correction and low light leakage enhancing situation awareness. In Phase I, POC plans to develop a low-SWaP, high-performance STALAR-DMVG design suitable for battlefield airman use, demonstrating the feasibility of meeting Air Force needs. In Phase II, POC will develop a working proof-of-concept prototype and demonstrate its capabilities for integration into Battlefield Airman Operation (BAO) kit.

abstract: Vlabs will define an architecture for a big data cybersecurity solution that will provide a real-time, intuitive and actionable analytics for enhanced situational awareness and rapid response. The system will facilitate automation of key security decisions with a goal to accelerate the attack detection time of highly resourceful adversaries. The system will ingest and analyze various data types and sources such as tickets, alerts, user accounts, performance monitoring, and a variety of document formats.  The solution will maximize the value extracted from every piece of evidence available in the scalable data lake. Vlabs is well positioned to perform this work from the extensive experience in big data analytics and the broad spectrum of cybersecurity technologies.

award_title: Data Driven Activity Based Intelligence with Probalistic Knowledge Graph
research_keywords: Knowledge Graph,pattern discovery,Abnormal Detection,Activity based Intelligence.
abstract: In this proposal, we propose Data Driven Activity Based Intelligence with Probabilistic Knowledge Graph. address the ABI bottlenecks of current approaches by developing comprehensive methodologies to leverage available multi-INT data to extract entities and correlations to enable pattern discovery and abnormal detection of activities. Because large amount of data via persistent sensors are available, advanced processing architectures with unified representation to accommodate big data are required. We propose to leverage existing state-of-the-art technologies to incorporate Multi-INTs using Knowledge Graph representation with the lambda framework to analyze data in both batching processing and streaming processing. We seek to develop a framework and technical underpinnings for Data Driven Activity Based Intelligence and apply the framework to address challenging problems in the current multipolar military threat environment. Specifically, the proposed technologies are grounded in the advanced georeference discovery algorithm, probabilistic Knowledge graph representation and inference, hypothesis management, and pattern discovery. The goal is to provide a solution for the case of unknown-unknowns for intelligence analysis where no models or signatures are given to discover activities. The resulting technology will enable advanced intelligence analysis by allowing a more complete understanding of the Activity Based Intelligence operational picture.

award_title: Ecosystem of Analytics via Massive Multi-analyst Multi-domain Analytics Laboratory (M3AL)
research_keywords: Situational awareness,mission awareness,Data Analytics,analytics ecosystem,common platform,cross-domain solution
abstract: Intelligent Automation, Inc. proposes to build an ecosystem of analytics via a common platform. The technological foundation is a massive multi-analyst multi-domain analytics laboratory (M3AL) that models analyst interactions as an ecosystem platform beyond just an aggregator tool. The ecosystem of analytics is a unified, cross-domain experimentation platform for multiple analytics that will be used to identify causalities among variables across domains, predict tool evolution and survival, analyze analyst behavior and reproduce results. We will develop the novel analytics ecosystem M3AL to discover and recommend the most relevant analytics (across domains) mapped to different missions tasks. M3AL will produce a real world network of analytics and apply advanced machine learning and graph analysis techniques to automatically select the most suitable tool or set of tools from this network for a mission within the given domain. We will first develop a stack of analytics categories. Then, we will build an analytics ecosystem platform tunable in terms of frequency of usage, description and controlled variables representative of these analytics. As output, it will generate a set of causalities among analytics and their variables, analytics performance, analytics description, analytics tags (explicit or hidden), and underlying mechanisms to assure effective mission tasking.

award_title: Airborne Unmanned Refueling Multi-aperture Optical Navigation
research_keywords: Automated Air to Air Refueling,multi-aperture,compound optics,Non-imaging,Relative Navigation,GPS-denied guidance and tracking.
abstract: To address the Air Force need for a GPS-denied relative navigation (RelNav) technology to be used by Remotely Piloted Aircraft (RPA) refueling, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a new Airborne Unmanned Refueling Multi-aperture Optical Navigation (AURUM-ON) system. The proposed navigation system is based on a novel compound-eye insect optic(s) and proven avionic components to achieve a low size, weight, and power (SWaP) mature system design. The innovation in wide field of view, multi-aperture configuration, customized beacons, high bandwidth, and custom embedded processing will enable the AURUM-ON system to detect, track and guide RPA during air-to-air refueling. As a result, AURUM-ON offers accuracy, availability, continuity, and wide-angle tracking without gimbals in a high-integrity solution directly addressing the Air Forces air platform requirements. In Phase I, POC will design a system and demonstrate the feasibility of AURUM-ON through analysis of expected required navigation performance (RNP) capabilities in terms of accuracy, integrity, availability, and continuity; discuss data and equipment requirements; and identify government-furnished equipment (GFI) required for Phase II. In Phase II, POC plans to build an AURUM-ON prototype for laboratory testing with hardware-in-the-loop simulation to evaluate RNP metrics and certification impacts.

award_title: Non-GPS Relative Navigation for Remotely Piloted Aircraft (RPA) Refueling
research_keywords: Multi-Sensor,multi-band,Relative Navigation,AUTONOMOUS,Refueling,RPA,UAV,Tanker
abstract: The ability to refuel piloted aircraft in flight is considered a strategic military asset and has been a critical element of success in nearly every US and NATO military engagement of the jet age. Equally important going forward will be the ability to refuel remotely piloted aircraft (RPA) in flight. Current USAF RPAs rely on cruise at low speeds and small payloads to extend endurance to accomplish their missions without refueling. But future RPAs will need speed and larger payloads, therefore decreasing endurance and creating greater operational need for these future RPAs to be equipped with automated aerial refueling (AAR) technology. Despite the many challenges of automating aerial refueling, AAR has been successfully demonstrated with the X-47B AAR program and previously with AFRL AAR flight test demonstrations. However, while successful, these AAR technologies depend largely on Global Positioning System (GPS) as the primary signal for relative navigation. GPS has proven to be extremely vulnerable to deliberate and inadvertent jamming, spoofing, and other effects. To break the dependence on GPS, CTSi proposes a multi-band, multi-sensor system capable of providing a robust, high reliability, safe positioning capability for AAR using independent sensors that are available at all times in all environments.

award_title: MAI NimbuSat EO-IR Terrestrial Weather Sensing
research_keywords: weather,small satellite,microsat,cloud imaging,multi-spectral sensor,global coverage,visible imaging,Infrared
abstract: Maryland Aerospace, Inc. (MAI), is pleased to present our NimbuSat Weather Satellite solution that we will develop in collaboration with the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory (APL) and Emergent Technologies (Emergent). Through MAI expertise in spacecraft design, APL expertise in weather sensors and weather data, and Emergent expertise in cluster flight, our solution will provide the Department of Defense (DOD) critical and timely global weather imagery. Our innovative commercial system will deliver weather data as a service to replace gaps that will eventually arise due to the retirement of the Defense Meteorological Satellite Program (DMSP). This system will utilize a constellation of small satellites hosting a sensor suite including low-light visible imagers (LLI), short-wavelength IR (SWIR), medium-wavelength IR (MWIR) and long-wavelength IR (LWIR) cameras. In Phase I, we will achieve a CDR level design (exceeding the required PDR level of maturity), enabling us to rapidly develop a fully qualified satellite in Phase II. Our Phase II/III baseline delivers a 6U CubeSat hosting APL LLI and LWIR cameras and Emergent flight software to demonstrate our concept with a NimbuSat pathfinder.

award_title: Gemini: Weather CubeSat using MODIS Bands
research_keywords: Theater Weather Imagery,Cloud Characterization,Operationally Responsive Space,Cubesat,weather,meteorology,Infrared,Multi-spectral
abstract: The upcoming gap in satellite weather data may be a significant crisis in the early 2020s, with the cancellation of the NPOESS satellite program, and the loss of the DMSP-19 Satellite. Weather sources resources are stretched thin, which may make the US reliant on foreign weather data. We propose a new Cubesat satellite called Gemini,  which would be a pathfinder satellite for an Operational Responsive Meteorology Constellation called MetNet. The Gemini-A instrument proposed here is a multi-spectral imager which uses 32 MODIS bands for fast and simple theater weather imaging, all within a 1.5U CalPoly CubeSat standard.  This is made possible through the innovative use of newer technologies, such as the High Operating Temperature MWIR FPA at 120K and a newly available Low-Light-Level CMOS Image Sensor. The most significant challenges will be the system, thermal, and electrical design involving integrating four cameras into a 1.5U form factor. Gemini-B would be a separate 3U Microwave Sounder, such as the Mirata CubeSat built by MIT-Lincoln Labs, and would be part of a later effort. As with AURA and JPSS, the combination of IR and Microwave Sounder would work synergistically to provide a total solution for Cloud Characterization.

award_title: Terrapin Agile Inspector Satellite
research_keywords: Solar Electric Propulsion,space situational awareness,SmallSat,Hall effect thruster,LLNL,iodine gas propellant,compact monolith telescope,ESPA
abstract: Millennium Space Systems will develop an Agile Inspector Satellite called Terrapin, which will produce a small Space Situational Awareness (SSA) system with over 6 Km/sec Delta-V providing significant orbital maneuverability.  We bring significant innovations into this spacecraft design including the Busek BHT-600 Hall Effect Thruster electric engine using iodine gas propellant sublimated from highly dense solid iodine in a compact tank, the high performance MMA R-HaWK Solar Arrays carrying 33% efficient IMM solar cells, and Lawrence Livermores 35 cm Aperture Compact Monolith SSA sensor for performing the mission. For this SBIR, Millennium will work with subcontractors Busek and MMA Design to do trade studies on the propulsion, power, and spacecraft options and develop preliminary design-level satellite.  In considering the Agile Inspector Satellite design, there is a significant trade to be done on spacecraft sizing. The smaller the spacecraft, the less expensive and easier to find a ride. However, the smaller the satellite, the smaller the payload carried. In addition, Solar-Electric Propulsion systems do not scale down effectively and lose efficiency affecting overall performance.

award_title: Geosynchronous Roaming Reconnaissance and Inspector Spacecraft
research_keywords: agile,Inspector,Satellite,Solar Electric Propulsion,Hall effect thruster,secondary payload
abstract: Busek proposes to develop an agile satellite capable of providing high resolution imagery of other satellites in Geostationary Orbit (GEO).  This solar electric satellite inspector could be launched as a low cost secondary payload.  For primary propulsion, the spacecraft will carry a high specific impulse Hall Effect thruster (HET).  The available change in velocity (V) will exceed 6 km/s, allowing unprecedented orbital maneuverability including transfers from Low Earth Orbit (LEO) to Geostationary orbit (GEO) coupled with additional maneuvers in GEO.   In Phase I, Busek will conduct system trades to identify an inspector satellite mission concept that will provide better than 0.1m resolution imagery of several GEO satellites. The work plan will include requirements definition, mission analysis, spacecraft design, and program planning.  Appropriate sensor/telescope options, orbital configuration, and downlinks will also be identified.  The spacecraft will be designed to survive a slow journey from LEO to GEO through the radiation belts.

award_title: 12U Agile Inspector CubeSat
research_keywords: GEO CubeSat,Iodine Propellant,Electric propulsion,radiation mitigation,space situational awareness,orbital debris tracking
abstract: ExoTerra's 12U Agile Inspector CubeSat uses technology developed for deep space NASA missions to enable transit from LEO to GEO by a 12U CubeSat.  This enables an affordable mission that can improve the ability to observe objects in GEO by over an order of magnitude. The system uses an iodine electric propulsion system and high specific power solar arrays to provide over 6 km/s of delta V at the highest thrust to weight ratio available in the industry.  This minimizes trip time through the Van Allen belts to reduce radiation levels and rapidly begin operations.

award_title: Scalable Coherent Photonic Array on a Silicon Platform
research_keywords: Silicon photonics,coherent optical transmitter array,frequency comb generation,wavelength diversity,high extinction ratio wavelength filter,low complexity,minimal chip footprint
abstract: Trex Enterprises in conjunction with Columbia University propose to develop and build a scalable coherent optical transmitter array in a silicon photonic chip.  The enabling technology at the heart of the coherent optical transmitter array is a state-of-the-art silicon photonic frequency comb generator and high extinction ratio wavelength demux.  The transmitter array will consist of 60 emitter channels, an inter-channel spacing of 100GHz and 200W of output power with 45dB sidemode suppression per channel.  The system architecture design will reduce chip complexity by minimizing the total number of unique SiP and CMOS components along with providing a chip layout that provides a reduced footprint of < 1mm2.  The total noise performance of the chip will be modeled, yielding an determination of the level of optical signal coherence within and across all emitters.  Lastly, the resulting complete SiP transmitter chip design will be shown to be compatible with commercial foundry procedures and will provide a viable path to achieve the scalability and the increased per channel output power required by the next phase target specifications.

award_title: Low-Noise Tunable Coherent Emitter Array Synthesis using Silicon Shock-Wave Mixers
research_keywords: coherent communications,electronic warfare,optoelectronic integration,channelization,LIDAR/LADAR,optical processing,Frequency combs,Photonics
abstract: Coherent communications and general optical sensing rely on highly coherent, low-noise optical carriers, by which information carried in phase quadratures and spectroscopic signatures can be decoded with high confidence. While the need for low-noise carriers is currently fulfilled by discrete single-wavelength emitters, the scaling of discrete emitter arrays for supporting typical sensing and communications needs easily violates the SWaP envelope of mobile and airborne platforms, rendering deployment infeasible. Besides these scalability limits, disjoint optical construction of individual emitters renders the frequency and phase of optical carriers uncorrelated and wandering in time, thereby forbidding joint detection of channels in which the relative phase of all channels must be known. Contrary to discrete arrays, a chip-scale emitter array can be constructed with optical performance comparable to discrete counterparts. This monolithic approach will allow orders of magnitude reduction of size and power consumption, brought by shared packaging and environmental (temperature) control. Furthermore, phase-coherent emitter arrays can be built with strict phase correlation among channels, rendering joint channel detection possible. RAM Photonics proposes a new class of emitters with  80 carriers, at  300 microWatts each and OSNR of  45dB, spaced on 100GHz or denser ITU grid.

award_title: Die Extraction and Reassembly of Integrated Circuit Modules on Low Temperature Co-Fired Ceramic Substrates
research_keywords: Integrated Circuit,Die Extraction and Reassembly,reliability,Diminishing Manufacturing Resources,manufacturing
abstract: This Phase I SBIR proposal addresses the Diminishing Manufacturing Sources (DMS) using the process of Die Extraction and Reassembly (DER). The DER process takes an IC die equivalent to the obsolete die from an undesirable and outdated package and reassembles that die into the needed package, hybrid or MCM. DER is an innovative and cost effective alternative solution to other higher cost solutions such as redesign of obsolete ICs.   The tools, techniques, and knowledge needed to certify DER parts for military use are still under development.  Innovations, as proposed in this project, would lead to tools and techniques that will eventually result in a certification process similar to those in place for MIL-STD-883 compliant parts.  Key aspects of Phase I of this program are as follows: 1. Die Extraction of a complex high pin-count plastic package. 2. Reassemble extracted die on LTCC Substrate along with passive components towards a self-contained Multi-Chip Module (MCM), with embedded passive components and thermal management structures. 3. Perform MIL-STD-883 compliant testing such that the new part created from DER process meets or exceeds all military standard specifications. 4. Develop transition plan/business case analysis, with industry partners.

award_title: Advanced Analog-to-Digital Converter for GPS Receivers
research_keywords: Analog to digital,ADC,CMOS,High Speed,ENOB
abstract: The USAF is interested in this development for use in a digitally-processed GPS receiver with strong anti-jam performance. The focus of this effort will seek to develop an ADC architecture that can be built in a commercial CMOS foundry and achieve 350 MSPS and 16ENOB with minimal power and cost.

award_title: Advanced Analog-to-Digital Converter for GPS Receivers
research_keywords: ADC,anti-jam,GPS,Conversion Frequency,resolution
abstract: It is required that GPS receivers operate efficiently in hostile jamming environments and in the presence of unintentional interference. A critical component for enabling anti-jam techniques for implementation in GPS receivers is a high performance Analog to Digital Converter (ADC).  The ADCs must have high conversion frequencies to support the modernized and future GPS receiver architectures while having a very high resolution to provide the dynamic range required to counter potential jamming and interference threats.  RBS Technologies, LLC has developed a technical approach which combines a unique asynchronous N bit ADC with pipelined and oversampling techniques to obtain the required performance objectives.  The asynchronous ADC completes an N-bit conversion is one clock cycle with N comparators.  The combination of energy efficiency and high conversion frequency makes the ADC an attractive building block for a high performance and high resolution ADC.  RBS Technologies will exploit the previous experience of key personnel with designing and fabrication of CMOS Nano-technology ADCs and Anti-jam GPS receivers.

award_title: Advanced Analog-to-Digital Converter for GPS Receivers
research_keywords: ADC,Digital Predistortion,digital calibration,pipelined ADC
abstract: Next generation satellite communication systems must be robust to hostile jammers which degrade link budget and desensitize reception. A proposed solution is to use frequency hopping techniques to communicate in a spectrum space free of hostile jammers and an all digital radio in which the agility and robustness is provided by high dynamic range and ENOB (16 bit) data-converters. To this end, broadband high dynamic range ADCs are needed to cover the broad-spectrum of interest allowing full coverage from GPS L1 to L2. To meet this demand, MaXentric proposes to take advantage of our previous program success in L-band ADC design Phase I and expertise in digital pre-distortion linearization correction. Our solution is comprised of classical pipelined ADC IC design married with advanced digital correction techniques to meet the solicitation of >100 MS/sec and ENOB of 16 bits.

award_title: Demonstration and Validation of Brush LHE Alkaline Zn-Ni as a Brush Cadmium (Cd) Alternative
research_keywords: Cadmium,Zinc-Nickel,IVD Al,hex-chrome,Brush plating
abstract: US Department of Defense (DOD) branches utilize aluminum and steel alloys for components throughout the different weapon systems. Traditionally brush cadmium (Cd) plating is used for local touch up after Cd plating operations and during repair and overhaul.  Both the Cd plating process and the hex-chromate conversion coating typically used have proven to be toxic (unlike other processes such as chromium plating, where a hazardous process yields a non-hazardous coating).  Consequently, ES3 successfully completed research via SBIR topics AF071-320 and AF081-101 for Cd replacement with LHE Alkaline Zinc Nickel Electroplating with non-hex chromate conversion coating for high and low strength steel aircraft general and threaded components and fasteners; and on aluminum and steel electrical connectors under SBIR topic AF161-007.  ES3 will leverage lessons learned during these previous efforts to develop, test and evaluate brush plating chemistries that can be utilized in lieu of existing brush Cd and Zn-Ni chemistries currently approved.  In Phase I, ES3 will investigate/develop brush Cd plating chemistry alternatives, including hex-chrome free conversion coatings, and conduct the feasibility study and testing necessary to demonstrate USAF preliminary evaluation criteria for steel and aluminum applications that were previously Cd or Zn-Ni plated or IVD Al coated.

research_keywords: Brush Cd,IVD Aluminum Coatings,Zn-Ni,Cd,plating,Aircraft Components

award_title: Remote Radio Antennas for Command Posts
research_keywords: command post,antenna remoting,free-space optical,RF over Fiber,RF on Fiber,survivability
abstract: The objective of Phase I is to define how best to remote antennas up to 500 meters with a feasible equipment solution. Moving antennas away from Brigade and Battalion command posts is critical to improving their survivability against an opponent that can find and attack our command and control (C2) assets. Correctly designed, the same antenna remoting equipment can also improve command post agility with reduced setup and teardown times, plus simplify command post configurations. To achieve the best feasible and operationally desirable approach to antenna remoting, Syntonics applies our systems engineering expertise to: Perform an all-encompassing trade study of alternative methods for remote combat net radio/antenna placement; Analyze approaches and opportunities for signal aggregation based on command post radio and platform distribution, and antenna aggregation for multiple transmitters and receivers; analyze the potential for aggregating transceivers by band; and Analyze packaging and power approaches for the remote systems. We develop a comprehensive white paper that substantiates findings, draws conclusions about how best to remote antennas and, during the Option period, develop a conceptual design for the Phase II prototype system.

award_title: Fiber Optic Antenna Remoting System for Command Posts
research_keywords: Fiber Optic Cable,Tactical Radios,RF-over-fiber Links,antenna remoting,Tactical Command Posts
abstract: Bringing battlefield information to a safe area and ensuring a continuous stable mission is critical for current and next generation Army command posts.By moving antennas away from the command post, its visibility is reduced and survivability increased.Pharad proposes to conduct a detailed trade-study assessing alternative command post antenna remoting technologies.We will then develop an optimal solution for a fiber optic based antenna remoting system that maintains radio communication link performance and enables LOS or NLOS placement of antennas, up to 500 meters away.We will investigate solutions that meet target performance metrics and reduce hardware volume, footprint, and power consumption.Opportunities for aggregating RF signals from the radios as well as aggregating remote antennas, will be explored.The antenna remoting solution will support all commonly used tactical radios with operating bandwidths extending from HF to C-band.It will provide a reliable and modular capability for interfacing the radios to the remote antennas and able to be deployed in less than 30 minutes.In the Phase I Option we will use the outcome of our feasibility studies to develop an optimal architecture for a prototype command post antenna remoting system that supports fielded VHF, HF and L-band radios.

award_title: Enhancing Performance via Innovative Coating of Additively Manufactured Parts
research_keywords: additive manufacturing,electroplating,Enhanced Performance,Plastic Parts
abstract: Additive Manufacturing (commonly known as 3D printing) is fast growing technology that reaches the point of increased adoption in various production environments. This unique technology allows fabrication of complex parts rapidly and cost effectively.Additive Manufacturing (AM) of plastic parts is well developed and several methods exist to fabricate components such as Filament Extrusion, Vat Photopolymerization, and Binder Jetting. While plastic AM is mature, the barriers for adoption of the technology, particularly, for military applications are significant.Parts created by plastic AM methods lack functionality due to limited selection of materials and poor performance.Lynntech proposes to develop an electroless plating approach for the deposition of tribological coatings on parts produced using Fused Deposition Modeling and Stereolithography. Electroless plating will allow uniform coating throughout the part regardless parts complexity. Lynntechs unique coating formulation will provide enhanced wear and friction resistance, hardness, high temperature protection, and improved mechanical performance. We will evaluate performance of printed parts as a function of coating conditions to develop process specifications and guidelines. The developed technology will be well defined, predictable, and reproducible. Ultimately, Lynntechs plating method and formulation will greatly enhance manufacturing of unique, high value, low volume components for military applications.

award_title: Single Element Achromatic Lens Technology
research_keywords: Achromatic metasurface,Flat lens,Multi-wavelength,dispersive phase compensation,metasurfaces,LENS
abstract: The Army is seeking the development of achromatic lens technologies to reduce the space and weight of optical systems. To address this Army need, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a novel Single Element Achromatic Lens (SEAL) technology based on metamaterials, dielectric nanoantennas, and form birefringence. The novel use and arrangement of the dielectric nanoantennas allows for achromatic focusing. The SEAL uses a monolayer metamaterial, which is thin and ultralight. Its achromatic behavior allows for focusing over a broad band of light without additional color correction features. Additionally, the SEAL is highly configurable to offer the desired lens properties. The simple SEAL design allows for cost-effective fabrication using advanced nanoimprint lithography. In Phase I, POC will demonstrate SEAL feasibility by designing, simulating, fabricating, and testing a prototype. In Phase II, POC plans to further develop a fully operational SEAL by refining and optimizing the design, developing the complete manufacturing process for mass production, and conducting thorough evaluation of optical performance in comparison to conventional lenses. By the completion of Phase II, we will have a mature working prototype that meets all Army requirements.

award_title: Real Time On Board Short Wave Infrared (SWIR) Video for Gun Launched Munitions
research_keywords: SWIR,Short wave infrared,INGAAS,IMAGER,imaging for targeting
abstract: A small size, weight, and power visible/Short Wave Infrared (SWIR) camera system will be developed for precision guided gun launched munitions. This 640x512 6um pitch InGaAs imaging system will be able to image light from 0.4 to 1.7um enabling the precision engagement of targets during the day and night as well as in fog and through smoke using the advantages of SWIR imaging. In addition this imager will enable the user to image and track laser designators and pointers deployed on the battlefield. The advantage of InGaAs SWIR imagers is their ability to conduct long range imaging through the atmosphere better than visible while being an uncooled infrared technology. We have shown that InGaAs SWIR imagers survive the 20,000g gun shock. We will be manufactured a small 300 frame per second needed to meet the imaging needs of the user to track targets while inside small gun launched projectile.

award_title: Land Navigation Aid
research_keywords: Navigation,robust navigation,multisensor navigation,Android,GPS-denied navigation,celestial navigation
abstract: The accuracy and integrity of positioning, navigation, and timing (PNT) sources are critical components of modern military operations. These requirements must be met in all operational environments, including situations where GPS signals are degraded or denied. While selective-availability anti-spoofing module (SAASM) enhanced GPS receivers provide greatly improved performance over civilian systems, they are not capable of providing accurate navigation solutions in all operational environments. This limits the mission effectiveness of existing systems and creates a need for improved performance. To address this need, we propose to develop a Portable Aided Navigation and Timing for Human Enabled Reckoning (PANTHER) system, designed to operate within the Nett Warrior common operating environment (COE). PANTHER is an innovative approach that seamlessly combines the full range of embedded sensors, an optimal robust nonlinear fusion engine, and a modular system architecture which enables us to greatly increase the PNT accuracy, availability, and integrity of the Nett Warrior system. PANTHER offers soldiers a system that is lightweight, intelligent, and mission effective.

award_title: Robotic Following using Deep Learning
research_keywords: Autonomy,Robotics,Leader Follower,unmanned,ground vehicle,Vehicle Control,Deep Learning,machine learning
abstract: JMP proposes to develop a system for robotic following using deep learning in a way that has not been done before by using 1) a novel hybrid CNN-RNN-encoder-decoder-based end-to-end deep learning approach to perform real-time scene analysis from passive video camera images, including lead vehicle identification, and to make time-series aware driving decisions, 2) a three-phase deep learning training protocol combining unsupervised, supervised, and reinforcement learning phases that supports lifelong incremental learning in a way that does not over-fit to specific training sets and is robust to environments and conditions that are different from the training, and 3) a proof-of-concept testbed for collecting large-scale real-world data sets and performing real-world tests using deep learning mobile robots.

award_title: Parallel Intermixing of Lithium-Ion 6T Batteries with Dissimilar Chemistries
research_keywords: Lithium-ion battery,parallel,LIFE,cycle,Performance,optimal
abstract: Galley Power is proposing to develop and evaluate an controller concept for paralleling lithium-ion 6T batteries with dissimilar chemistries. Galley Power's innovative concepts include 1)an integrated adaptive battery performance and life model; 2) a control framework so that batteries with different performance and life/cycle characteristics can be compared and controlled; 3) high efficiency bi-directional power train to balance the paralleled batteries without affecting the battery bank's transient and continuous power delivery performance. This controller will have small form-factor and low power consumption; in its ultimate implementation, this proposed controller will seamless fit into existing 6T lithium-ion battery's built-in battery management system. Galley Power is also proposing to develop battery model, baseline performance evaluation methodology and test protocol to evaluate the proposed solution in simulation in comparison with existing solutions. Galley Power will simulate and evaluate the performance improvement of proposed method based on baseline methodology. In Phase I option, Galley Power will procure lithium-ion 6T batteries and start testing; also, Galley Power will start develop the hardware and software in preparation for Phase II objectives.

award_title: Advanced Material for Electrical Power Cables
research_keywords: superwire,high-DC-current,ampacity,hybrid-copper,CNT,wires,cables,conductivity
abstract: Carbon nanotube (CNT)-based copper hybrid-conductors, density ~5 g/cc, at copper level conductivity potentially have an ampacity of two orders of magnitude above bulk copper. In this proposal, we posit that by improving CNT wire conductivity and coupling with copper infiltration we will achieve these goals. This extraordinary ampacity and conductivity come from suppressing electromigration coupled with the extreme charge-carrier mobility through the CNT pathways. Achievement of these goals encompass two processes: (1) Removing the fundamental structural/physical obstructions to charge carrier transport in CNT conductors by doping to a higher density of charge carriers, addressing alignment factors, atomically cleaning the surfaces, reducing the effect of Schottky barriers and minimizing growth defects through processing. Our goal is > 20 x 10^6 S/m for CNT yarn alone, and then (2) Infiltrating this CNT fiber with copper to take advantage of the very high CNT charge carrier mobility and high charge carrier density in copper. The demonstrated suppression of electromigration by CNTs within copper is key to ampacity increases. We will have a plied composite Cu/CNT cable fabricated commercially. A new manufacturing process to produce Cu/CNT hybrid wire by infiltrating molten copper inside the CNT fiber is described.

award_title: Automated Tuning and Calibration of By-Wire Vehicles for Automated Driving Functions
research_keywords: autonomous ground vehicle,Model Predictive Control,Self-Calibration,Auto-Tuning
abstract: The current process for setup and configuration of autonomous ground vehicles is a time consuming process which can often require a skilled engineer. This process includes measuring key sensor parameters and also tuning control parameters so the vehicle will operate properly. This proposed research will develop techniques for self-calibration of sensor parameters and automatic tuning of control system parameters for autonomous ground vehicles. The sensor parameters will include sensor locations, orientations and scale factors required for accurate measurement use. An Extended Kalman filter framework is proposed that allows key sensor states to be augmented into localization filter that exists on the vehicle. The automatic tuning will improve the control of the vehicle while driving in autonomous mode. A Model Predictive Control framework is proposed to make this possible. The MPC gains will be improved by monitoring the actual trajectory of the vehicle against a benchmark optimal trajectory. The difference between the paths is used as feedback into the controller gains calculation. The actual gains used in the MPC will converge to optimal values over time. This work will be implemented in simulation and also initial results will be obtained from actual vehicles.

award_title: Multi-stage Shaped-charge Warheads
research_keywords: Shaped-Charge liners,Reactive materials,nanostructured materials,bi-metallic materials,explosively formed penetrators,metal jet forming
abstract: MATSYS proposes to develop and demonstrate warheads capable of perforating light armored vehicles and unmanned aerial systems, coupled with a follow through mechanism that will defeat various targets. Shaped charge liners require explosives to drive the collapse of the liner and subsequent formation of the jet. This is an inherently inefficient process because only 10% of the liner mass is used to form the jet. In addition, the energy transfer from the detonation products into kinetic energy of the liner is woefully inefficient, primarily because of the shock impedance mismatch between the detonation products and the typical copper liner. Lower density materials, such as aluminum, have better impedance matching to the explosive, and therefore the transfer of energy is more efficient. Unfortunately, aluminum liners do not make good jets. This problem can be alleviated through the development of bi-metallic liners, with the liner material placed closest to the explosive couples well with the explosive (i.e., impedance matching) while the material on the other side forms a well-performing jet. The selection of reactive materials will further enhance performance. Our approach is to use modeling and simulation to identify novel material combinations, and develop designs for bi-metallic liners and associated prototyping technology.

award_title: Munition-Delivered Non-Kinetic Effects (NKE)
research_keywords: Non-Kinetic Munition,Cyber Munition,Cyber Attack Payload.
abstract: Proposed effort includes the development of a standard caliber Army munition (120mm to 155mm) containing a Non-Kinetic Cyber Attack payload. After the munition is activated, programmed, and fired, once over its desired target set this payload will be expelled and complete its mission. The payload programmingcan be set pre flight to deliver various effects depending on the mission set.

award_title: Deep Eutectic Solvent (DES)-based Electrolytes for Nanomaterials-based Supercapacitors
research_keywords: supercapacitors,high energy,High Power,Wide temperature range,Low temperature,deep eutectic solvent,conductivity,Viscosity
abstract: Current supercapacitors have a very long cycle life, high charge/discharge rates, high specific power, but relatively low specific energy compared to batteries. The theoretical energy and power of supercapacitors is determined by their capacitance, working voltage windows, and conductivities of electrode materials/electrolytes as a function of temperature. With recent advances in nanomaterials-based electrodes, the electrolyte primarily limits the performance of supercapacitors. Organic electrolyte-based supercapacitors are approaching their energy and power limits. Therefore, a safe cost-effective electrolyte with high conductivity and wide voltage windows over wide temperature ranges is needed for next-generation supercapacitors. Lynntech proposes to develop low-cost deep eutectic solvents (DESs) to widen the operational and storage temperature ranges while improving the electrode/electrolyte interface for high energy and high power supercapacitors. During Phase I, Lynntech will develop advanced electrolytes based on appropriate eutectic mixtures utilizing DESs. The ionic conductivity, viscosity, and electrochemical stability will be evaluated over a wide temperature range. A preliminary cell fabrication and testing will be performed. During Phase II, Lynntech will fabricate and evaluate the prototype supercapacitors based on the optimal electrolytes and graphene-based electrodes, and deliver prototypes to the Army for validation. The large scale synthesis of electrolytes and electrode materials will also be explored.

award_title: Spectrometer for night Sky Glow
research_keywords: Hadamard Transform,Encoder Mask,Sky Glow,Spectral radiometric,shortwave infrared,Visible to Near Infrared,Cooled detectors,Low Noise.
abstract: We provide a design supported by analysis and show the performance of an electro-optical system that can meet the requirements for the measurement of night sky glow.Key design aspects of the system will be evaluated under Phase-I via further design and performance analysis and fabrication of key components.

award_title: Airborne ISR Sensors Fusion Algorithms
research_keywords: AiTR,AiTD,EO/IR Fusion,PERSISTENT SURVEILLANCE,Deep Learning,convolutional neural networks
abstract: Intelligence products generated from sensors currently deployed on U.S. Army Airborne ISR platforms only utilize data from a single sensor modality. As such these products are limited in both current capability and the ability to extend to new intelligence missions. Toyon Research Corporation proposes to develop and implement advanced sensor fusion algorithms for EO/IR and 3D point cloud data. The algorithms leverage measurement data fused in the image and 3D space to perform Aided Target Recognition/Detection (AiTR/AiTD) as well as persistent target tracking. Toyon proposes to utilize convolutional neural networks (CNNs) trained to detect specific objects of interest, such as military vehicles, in the fused data.

award_title: Multi-Spectral Threat Warning Adjunct Sensor
research_keywords: HgCdTe,MCT,Acousto-Optic Tunable Filter,AOTF,Infrared,photo-detector,Spectrometer
abstract: EPIR Inc. and Brimrose Corp. propose to design and fabricate an adjunct sensor consisting of four spectrometers to cover the wavelength range from ultraviolet (UV) to long-wave infrared (LWIR). Each spectrometer is an integration of an acousto-optic tunable filter (AOTF) with either Si- or HgCdTe (MCT)- based photo-detector (PD). The sensor will be used to aid the existing Missile Warning/Hostile Fire Indication Systems. Due to our success on a recently finished NASA project, our efforts in this Phase I project will be concentrated on (1) the design and fabrication of MCT PDs in the infrared ranges, (2) the design of AOTFs for the correspondent PDs, and (3) the design of the sensor system accommodating all four PDs with low size, weight, and power consumption (SWaP). In Phase II we will fabricate and demonstrate the functionality of the prototype system based on the design finished in Phase I.MCT is the dominating choice of material for infrared applications. AOTF offers excellent waveband selection capability with no moving parts, and is insensitive to mechanical vibration. The combination of MCT PD with AOTF offers significant advantages to meet the requirements and to lower the SWaP of the system.

award_title: Versatile, Basalt Fiber-Reinforced Geopolymer Composites
research_keywords: Geopolymer composites,basalt fiber reinforcements,Auxetic fiber weaves,basalt weaves,alumino silicate polymers,construction materials,road and pavement repairs,barrack hut construction
abstract: Geopolymers are a class of inorganic polymers that that are made from calcined clays or industrial waste products such as fly ash and slag. Geopolymer composites are fire resistant and stable to high temperatures such as 950C. These composites are half the weight, can be 5 times stronger than high-strength concrete, and can set at ambient temperatures. The BASE project will develop geopolymer composites reinforced with basalt fiber reinforcements in the form of chopped fibers, randomly oriented fiber mats, weaves, dog bone-shaped Minibars or auxetic basalt fibers.The resulting composites will be especially suited to high-performance, lightweight, multi-use purposes including building construction, force protection, and force projection applications. The project will then optimize for two specific applications: 1) road repair as an alternative to asphalt and 2) deployable structures such as helicopter pads. The geopolymer composite for road repairs will be optimized for setting time and maximum mechanical strength. Preliminary work will be done on the unfolding geometry of deployable structures for flat helipads. This will illustrate the principles for other rapidly deployable, transportable structures.The OPTION will perform initial tests of the composites in environments simulating real-world applications.

award_title: Vascularized Tissue Construction Using Specialized 3D Bioprinting Techniques
research_keywords: vascularization,tissue engineering,Regenerative Medicine,trauma,tissue,3D bioprinting,tissue replacement
abstract: Tissue engineering technology is of particular import to the Army for the matter of producing tissue replacements for the repair and regeneration of various organ systems (liver, heart, muscle, lung, etc.) for wounded patients. Unfortunately, the production of masses of tissue with thicknesses greater than ~1 mm presents a challenge due to diffusion limits of nutrients into the tissue and waste out of the tissue. This is solved through proper vascularization. Providing vasculature for lab-grown tissues (in addition to providing the correct nutrients, growth factors, etc.) is essential to keeping them alive and functional for any relevant length of time. In order to meet these challenges, Lynntech is proposing the development of a hybrid bioreactor/3D-printing system in order to engineer vascularized tissue. We will demonstrate feasibility through the production of 1 cm thick, vascularized pieces of tissue. The Phase I development process will include fine-tuning the individual components of our system and evaluating the tissue for vascularization, health, and function over weeklong timescales. Testing will include metabolic assays, imaging of the vasculature, and mechanical testing. Methods and materials that meet the Armys objectives will be recommended for further development in Phase II and beyond.

award_title: Camouflage Netting for LADAR
research_keywords: ULCANS,camouflage,Ladar,concealment,textiles,Netting,Signature Management,Simulation
abstract: The next generation of Ultra-Lightweight Camouflage Net System (ULCANS) must conceal assets against detection and surveillance from a wide range of current and emerging threat systems. These threats include LADAR, radar, and multi-spectral and hyper-spectral imaging sensors. While current camouflage systems provide concealment against most of these threats, they fail to protect against LADAR. Through holes in the net, LADAR systems can sense assets concealed below the net. Additionally, the smooth catenary or bowl-shaped appearance of deployed nets can cue LADAR detection.ThermoAnalytics Inc., together with Saab Barracuda USA and Milliken & Company, will develop preliminary designs for strategies that deny or confuse LADAR detection of camouflage nets and assets. In the Phase I effort, the team will evaluate and estimate the performance of the strategies, create 3D models of net designs to identify strategies that can minimize catenary effects, and generate 3D point clouds using a LADAR simulation to investigate the effectiveness of the most promising strategies. Throughout the effort, the team will design in compatibility with the other requirements for ULCANS including concealment from other threat sensors, ventilation for thermal and wind loading, durability in field environments, lightweight, low cost, and short strike and erect cycles.

award_title: Development of a Military Hardened Expeditionary, Energy Efficient and Waterless/Low-Flow Laundry System
research_keywords: Low water use laundry,grey water recycling
abstract: Military deployable laundry systems consume large amounts of water cleaning soldier uniforms, under wear, and towels. The objective of this effort is to develop an innovative, low water consumption or waterless laundry system that exhibits military hardening, conforms to existing transport and logistics requirements, and ensures military personnel can service the equipment. A low flow or waterless laundry system will allow for laundry functions at more austere locations currently constrained by limited water and fuel resupply. This in turn will increase the morale, welfare and hygiene for soldiers deployed at remote basecamps, increasing overall mission readiness and effectiveness of our Army

award_title: Stochastic CFD Fire Modeling of Military Shelters
research_keywords: fire modeling,stochastic Monte Carlo simulations,CFD computational fluid dynamics,shelter fire safety,fire ignition propagation extinction,material flammability
abstract: Fire can act extremely quickly. In as little as 60 seconds a tent can be destroyed by fire, requiring very quick soldier reaction time to even survive. Improving fire safety begins with understanding the fire dynamics associated with each system. All current military shelters are evaluated for fire safety on a component basis only; there are no specifications for how the overall system design relates to generation of flame, heat, and smoke. As such, the Army needs a three-dimensional, reliable and validated fire model to simulate system-level shelter fire scenarios. The needed model will provide the Army with an effective, inexpensive method to perform iterative design, material, or configuration changes to any shelter design at low cost, avoiding the time and monetary investment in destructive live-fire testing.
