ADA Technologies proposes to leverage the extensive work done to develop FDS (Fire Dynamics Simulator) and modify its solver to a stochastic one, called MC-FDS. In Phase I, ADA will develop an initial version of MC-FDS, and use it to perform modeling of corresponding small-scale experiments similar to ASTM D6413 using cotton sateen and PVC-coated polyester. Side-by-side comparison of the model output and tests will demonstrate the capabilities and promise of MC-FDS.

award_title: AM for Entire Munitions
research_keywords: additive manufacturing,Munition,40mm,multimaterial,AM
abstract: Bennett Advanced Research proposes to create a system will that will allow a munition to be created at essentially any location that the US Army requires.

award_title: Biogenic Process for converting propellants and energetics into usable byproducts (such as biofuel)
research_keywords: BIOFUEL,algae,Propellant,Emissions Reduction,nutrient.
abstract: Algenol proposes to develop an innovative industrial scale biogenic process to convert propellants and/or energetics into valuable and environmentally friendly biofuel. The US Army has a large stockpile of unused propellants and energetics that have exceeded their useful life and must be disposed of. Algenol proposes to build off of previous contract work that demonstrated the use of hydrolyzed M6 propellant waste nitrogen as a nutrient source for the biological production of transportation fuel. This next phase of that research would leverage Algenols proprietary algae based technology platform to use nitrogen, in the form of nitrate and nitrite, generated from the alkaline hydrolysis of M6 propellant to produce algal biomass in semi-continuous cultivation as a precursor to the production of biocrude via hydrothermal liquefaction. Utilization of M6 propellant in this manner would circumvent the need to dispose of the material by open burn/open detonation and instead augment algal biomass growth and biofuel production thus reducing emissions and yielding a product that can be used as a transportation fuel by the general public or for military vehicles.

award_title: Advanced Pretreatment for Greywater Reuse
research_keywords: filtration,Waste water treatment,Sterile WaterProduction,
abstract: 1.1 The objective of this proposal is to improve the capability of the Army to sustain independence and self-sufficiency at expeditionary bases.Specifically, the current and future demands of highly mobile, resource limited, Forward Operating Bases (FOBs) require advancements in technologies for wastewater treatment.Potable water and greywater (wastewater that does not contain body or food wastes, i.e. from showers and laundries) account for a substantial percentage of the logistics support convoys in current (FOBs). Therefore, reducing water demand, by treating greywater and reclaiming potable water, is needed to reduce the number of convoys necessary to deliver potable water and remove greywater from the field. 1.2 Technological advances which can create a more consistent filtration, smaller footprint, lighter weight and longer life will support this need.

award_title: Variable Displacement Piston Energy Recovery Device for Seawater RO
research_keywords: reverse osmosis,Desalination,Energy recovery,Pump,seawater,Water
abstract: Seawater Reverse Osmosis (SWRO) for production of freshwater requires high pressures and flow rates of feed water, leading to high energy consumption.Energy recovery from the brine waste stream has potential to give SWRO an advantage as a source of drinking water, when compared to the logistical costs and increased risks for convoys trucking bottled water to small units where freshwater is not available.However, energy recovery at the scale of 10-15 GPH freshwater production from seawater is not capable of reaching the 15-20 watt-hr/gallon energy metric required.A combination high-pressure pump and energy recovery device is proposed that will recover the hydraulic energy from the brine stream and transmit it directly to the high pressure pump.The proposed method leverages the high-efficiency performance of piston pumps and hydraulic motors.Innovative design features are included for variable control of freshwater recovery rates while minimizing power transfer losses from the energy recovery device to the high pressure pump.Variable recovery control is essential to maximize SWRO efficiency as source water salinities and RO membrane performance varies.High efficiency pumping, energy recovery, and variable recovery control are all accomplished in one compact, lightweight, easily maintained unit powered by a single electric motor.

award_title: Magnetic Pulse Welder for In-Field Repair of Non-Weldable Aluminum Alloys
research_keywords: Solid State Welding,2000 series aluminum,7000 series aluminum,portable welder
abstract: Grid Logic proposes to develop a fieldable solid state welding process that can join and repair 2000 and 7000 series aluminum alloy components. This solution will be based on a new magnetic pulse welding technology from Grid Logic that permits the cold welding of these alloys without the material degradation problems common in arc fusion welding processes. The efforts primary objective will be to design and demonstrate the feasibility of this welding process on DOD approved target repair geometries. Grid Logic develops advanced manufacturing systems for production and repair of high-performance metallic components. It leverages its strong R&D capabilities to create turnkey manufacturing solutions for DOD and industrial manufacturers.

award_title: HIGH PERFORMANCE, FIRE RESISTANT HYBRIDSIL SEAT CUSHION PADDING FOR NEXT-GENERATION ARMY SEAT SYSTEMS
research_keywords: Vibration,Padding,seat,Cushion,Pressure Distribution,Fire Resistant,viscoelastic,foam
abstract: Through the proposed Army SBIR program, NanoSonic will empirically validate and rapidly transition next- generation vibration and pressuring reducing viscoelastic HybridSil seat cushions for improved soldier health, safety, and comfort. Working with Jankel, an industry leader in military seating that has sold more than 70,000 seats worldwide, NanoSonic will employ a rigorous design of experiments that will enable the correlation and combinatorial optimization of the molecular composition, physical properties, and bulk morphology of its viscoelastic HybridSil foams to produce game-changing seat cushion padding that provides a previously unavailable combination of vibration isolation, pressure distribution, and blast protection. Direct comparative analysis demonstrating the value proposition of HybridSil seat cushion padding over legacy systems will be completed by Jankel team members through pressure distribution mapping, MAST vibration transmission analysis, and drop tower testing. NanoSonics seat cushion padding will be tailored to meet the objective weight requirement and have immediate utility as a replacement cushion or component in a new seat design. This program will build from NanoSonics innovative energy absorbing, fire resistant HybridSil materials that have independently validated ballistic / blast durability in excess of polyureas, transition to flexible insulating silicate networks at elevated temperatures, and a health rating of zero.

award_title: Materials with Wideband Transmissivity
research_keywords: IRCM,Infrared countermeasures,dome,ceramic,
abstract: Current state-of-the-art infrared countermeasure (IRCM) systems require wider bandwidth lasers. As such, domes for these systems require high transmissivity in the region 300 nm8500 nm. Current IR dome materials, such as sapphire or Y2O3:La, exhibit sufficient transmission to 300 nm (as expected for these wide band gap materials), but do not meet the IR transparency requirements. By contrast, ZnS domes exhibit sufficient transmission to wavelengths longer than 8500 nm, but ZnS also absorbs in the near UV. To satisfy the wideband transmissivity requirement of next generation IRCM systems, new materials must be developed and novel methods to discover these materials must be employed. Lumenari proposes to use a combination of supercomputing and experimental methods to rapidly screen optical and mechanical properties of crystalline materials to elucidate UV and IR absorption cutoff wavelengths, as well as factors contributing to durability, coefficient of thermal expansion and water/air stability. This proposed approach will simultaneously maximize the probability of success and minimize the cost-per-material investigated. The work conducted in this Phase I project will yield a number of materials synthesizable in high purity at large quantities that are compatible with the IRCM transmission and durability requirements.

award_title: Cluster UAS Smart Munition for Missile Deployment
research_keywords: drone,unmanned,UAS,ducted-fan,swarm,EFP
abstract: AVID will perform conceptual design of a cluster of micro-air-vehicles (MAVs) that can be carried by a ground launched missile to the target site.A concept of operations will be developed to frame the requirements in each phase of the concept. Trade studies will be conducted using validated multidisciplinary MAV design tools with the objective of finding a design that maximizes the effectiveness of the cluster of MAVs at the minimum cost. Through analysis of rotor size, mission range, endurance and speed, fold configuration and motor sizing, an optimized aircraft will be chosen. Design of the carriage, separation and deployment will result in a full conceptual design.The conceptual design will be refined into a more complete model with design and off-design analysis.The final design will be the basis for a long range swarm that is capable of delivering multiple explosively formed projectiles to multiple targets.

award_title: Bridge Launch Technology for Ultra Lightweight Combat Vehicles
research_keywords: ULCV / GMV Bridge Launch and Recovery Technology,Lightweight,Stable,integrated,efficient,cost effective,Modular,vehicle
abstract: Lightweight combat vehicles will capable of traversing off road / trail and cross country mission profiles at a significantly higher speed than other vehicles in the arsenal.This places the burden of traversing obstacles such as blown out bridges, canals / dikes and rivers or tributaries on the lightweight vehicle systems themselves. Traditional systems such as the M-60 AVLB with its bridging element will not be able to maintain pace with these lightweight vehicles due to the severe mis-match of size, weight, speed, and transportability between the M-60 AVLB and an Ultralight Combat Vehicle.The GS Engineering system will both launch and recover the bridge, but also (optionally) transport the bridge system within the confines of the V-22 or CH-47 Air Transport window. The launch system will interface with the vehicle directly to the vehicles frame. The GS Engineering system will allow for the deployment of the self-contained bridge as well as give the same vehicle the ability to pick up and transport additional bridges. This design will also allow for a more efficient interface as far as transmitted loads into the bridge as well as into the vehicle through the use of multiple load paths.

award_title: High Efficiency Torque Multiplication for Military Ground Vehicle Transmissions
address1: 11777 S Sam Houston Pkwy W, Suite A
research_keywords: transmission,torque multiplication,CVT,Continuously Variable Transmission,infinitely-variable transmission,High efficiency,Advanced Propulsion,IVT
abstract: Orbital Traction proposes to demonstrate, through research and modeling, the fuel efficiency and performance gains achievable on military vehicles through optimization of the driveline using an innovative torque multiplication technology. This system replaces the existing torque converter, thereby addressing energy inefficiency within the driveline in ground vehicle transmissions. The reduction in fuel consumption would enable longer mission durations and/or increase operating ranges for the vehicles.Implementation of the new system, in conjunction with proper controls, is expected to yield a reduction in fuel usage, over standard mission profiles, by greater than 20%.Orbitals solution is a drop-in replacement for the torque converter and can be used to upgrade existing military transmissions.Leveraging prior DoD research, Orbital proposes research on a torque converter replacement with the novel application of an infinitely-variable speed transmission.Orbitals infinitely-variable transmissiontorque multiplier would eliminate many of the limitations of existing torque converters for heavy duty vehicles.The unit would provide a gear-neutral allowing input rotation with zero output rotation while maintaining output torque.At low speeds, substantially more torque can be produced.Packaging the system within the existing space claim minimizes the level of modification while maximizing performance improvements for optimum benefits.

award_title: Adaptive Armor Actuator Mechanisms
research_keywords: ADAPTIVE,actuator,Mechanism,pneumatic artificial muscle (PAM),linear,translation
abstract: Conventional vehicle armor has evolved considerably over the years, including homogeneous plates, composite materials, and reactive substrates.Variable orientations have also been implemented, including curved, sloped, angled, and spaced plates.A common characteristic among these conventional armor solutions is that they are static and incapable of changing in response to local threats.Adding a means by which the armor panels of a vehicle can adapt, or change under the direction of an occupant, would provide an improvement in protection capability. Many conventional actuation technologies exist that have the required performance capabilities for adaptive armor, but are limited in practical utility primarily due to their weight.As such, InnoVital Systems, Inc., in collaboration with the University of Maryland, proposes to develop an innovative adaptive armor actuation system using our patented, light weight, pneumatic artificial muscles. Building upon our extensive experience and related patent portfolio, we will perform analyses and detailed design work in Phase I of the project that will end with prototype bench-top demonstrations of an armor panel actuator.Phase II will be focused on further refinements, closed-loop control, and integration into functional hardware capable of realistic operations in a relevant environment.

award_title: OilEye FAFCI: Forward Area Fluid Contaminant Identification
research_keywords: contamination,particulates,Monitoring,Fuel,oil,Portable,imaging,Flow Microscopy
abstract: To support the Armys technological requirements for a fieldable fuel contamination sensor, FTL Labs Corporation (FTL) proposes a powerful new enabling technology for fuel monitoring using a miniaturized combination of sensing modes. FTL's OilEye design includes all fittings, sensors, electronics, and processing necessary to determine particle size distributions, unambiguous differentiation of water, solids, and bubbles, and provide output in standard units that correlate with traditional ASTM or ISO test methods.

award_title: High Capability Portable Foreign Object Debris (FOD) Removal System for Naval Aircraft
research_keywords: roboticized FOD technologies,Roomba type hanger FOD removal systems,automated FOD systems,self driving FOD systems,mobile robotic FOD systems
abstract: The basis of this proposal is to introduce robotic and automation techniques to better remediate foreign object debris (FOD) form hangers, taxiways and engine bays. This increases the effectiveness of existing FOD technologies by (1) eliminating or minimizing problems with the manual manipulation of these technologies and (2) enhancing FOD removal systems by adding multiple remediation technologies (i.e., more than one FOD technology). In both cases, RTT will use when possible, off the shelf and commercially available technologies modified for specific FOD applications. Current FOD remediation techniques are generally good at removing most FOD, as much as 95% or more. However, if the FOD technology cannot reach or simply misses the FOD, the FOD remains. RTT has brought automation and automatic control to a number of industrial environments to increase a variety of performance characteristics including productivity, quality and consistency. The focus is on the operational side of demonstrating that roboticized FOD systems can work in the field. Research is focused in motion control, navigation, operational control and monitoring. The net result is to address the hard to get FOD that creates billions of dollars of damages annually in the airline industry.

award_title: Medium Voltage Direct Current (MVDC) Casualty Power
research_keywords: Casualty Power System,Portable Power Cables,Temporary Power Systems,Power Terminals,Medium Voltage DC,,power cables,Medium Voltage DC Power Connectors
abstract: In Phase I the TCG Team will show the feasibility of their medium voltage direct current (MVDC) casualty power system.The system will include elements similar to shore power connector technology for safety and monitoring.A concept will be developed and analyzed to estimate its cost, weight, volume requirements, and the time required by the crew to deploy the system.A hazard analysis will be performed to ensure the concept is safe to deploy and operate.Technical risks associated with the concept will be identified.Based on the results of Phase I, and any modifications recommended by the Navy, during the Phase I Option the TCG Team will produce draft specifications and provide a capabilities description for the prototype components of the system to be manufactured and tested in Phase II.This may include basic drawing(s) for system components based on the characteristics of the system.It will include design modifications to optimize system design, minimize cost and weight, and meet the requirements of the Navy.Benefits of the new MVDC casualty power system will include an affordable, lightweight, and safe system to provide power to zones aboard ship isolated by damage.

award_title: Advanced PEM Electrocatalysts for Submarine Oxygen Generators
research_keywords: PEM,electrolysis,Electrocatalyst,Oxygen generator,submarine
abstract: Polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) electrolysis is used on-board submarines to generate breathing oxygen for the crew. Expensive noble metals are used as electrocatalysts and these precious metals contribute to approximately 25% of the cost of the electrolysis cell. Greatly reducing or eliminating the amount of noble metal electrocatalysts would significantly reduce the cost of the electrolysis cell stack. The Navy estimates that the cost savings would be ~$200,000 per electrolysis stack. Non-noble metal electrocatalysts are being developed, but so far no alternative has matched the performance of current Pt electrocatalystsThe objective of this Phase I project is to develop active electrocatalysts for PEM electrolyzers. We will prepare electrocatalysts using functionalized carbons as metal supports.We will optimize the metal content, as well as the physical properties (e.g., surface morphology and pore size distribution) of the new carbons and screen them based on their activity.We will prepare MEAs using the most promising materials and test their electrochemical performance under representative conditions.Based on the experimental results, we will carry out an engineering analysis to estimate cost of the new materials and compare them to current electrocatalysts.

award_title: Naval Special Warfare Ultra High Frequency (UHF) Satellite Communications (SATCOM) Low Elevation Angle Antenna
research_keywords: UHF,UFO,MUOS,low-profile,antenna
abstract: United States Special Operations Forces (SOF) are called upon to operate anywhere in the world at any time, in extremis.Often these SOF operators must deploy using undersea vehicles such as the Seal Delivery Vehicle (SDV) or, in the near future, the Shallow Water Combat Submersible (SWCS).UHF satellite communications are a major component of the SOFs ability to operate anywhere with impunity.However, the currently deployed SDV antenna system only support zenith to 45 degrees above horizon communications, limiting the effective locations of achievable UHF link to central and moderate latitudes.IERUS Technologies proposes to develop a next-generation SDV/SWCS-compatible UHF communications antenna supporting both UFO and MUOS frequency bands with full upper hemispherical coverage.IERUS will accomplish through our novel antenna and material design processes that have previously resulted in advanced low-profile antennas for commercial and defense applications.IERUS will further develop this antenna in a low-profile package, replacing the current antenna which protrudes up to five feet above the waterline and thereby making the SDV more vulnerable to visual identification.

award_title: Innovative Methods for Limited Dynamic Range Optical Detectors to More Effectively Operate in High Dynamic Range Environments
research_keywords: lidar,streak tube,ALMDS,Electro-optic,intensifier,STIL
abstract: Aret Associates proposes the use of innovative advancements in electro-optic components to extend the Airborne Laser Mine Detection System (ALMDS) dynamic range.ALMDS provides a fielded capability for detection and classification of surface and near surface mines.Since the program inception 15 years ago, many electro optic advancements have occurred.These advancements will increase dynamic range and system performance.Under this Phase 1 SBIR, Aret proposes a detailed characterization of a streak tube with integrated micro-channel plate (STIL-MCP) to replace the current electro-optic combination of streak tube and image intensifier.The STIL-MCP advancement will increase the dynamic range and system performance of ALMDS.

award_title: Culinary Specialist (CS) Food Service Support Platform
research_keywords: inventory management,food preparation,Mobile,FSM,food service management,hazardous analysis critical control point tracking,Culinary Specialist,Information Assurance
abstract: Progeny will provide an operational proof of concept that integrates with the current Food Service Management application as a service, identify viable hardware for the mobile platform to be used in the shipboard environment, prototype an operational proof-of-concept of the mobile platform. The prototype will demonstrate data interface and provide screen mock-ups. Progeny will also prepare any supporting documentation and define operational and technical evaluation metrics to support Phase II demonstration. Our true innovation for this effort will be to create an application that can natively deploy to multiple mobile platforms by leveraging the Xamarin framework. The applications will provide an initial layout and feasibility of the following: touch-capable navigation, work task assignment, recipe conversion, temperature and time logging, Hazardous Analysis Critical Control Point tracking, and food service documentation preparation. Additional efforts will demonstrate the feasibility of providing step-by-step interactive training, on-station video tutorials, and provide the ability to comment and take notes while training. Progeny has a proven track record of managing Certification and Accreditation packages from the creation of those packages, to guiding those packages through the approval process, and finally maintaining that packages security posture through the applications life cycle.

award_title: Development of Lightweight Heat Exchangers for Man-Portable Battery Recharging System
research_keywords: thermoelectric thermal management,oscillating heat pipes,electronics cooling,two-phase heat transfer,heat exchanger
abstract: This Phase I SBIR effort will demonstrate a compact, lightweight, and ultra-low thermal resistance air-cooled heat exchanger for man-portable thermoelectric battery recharging systems. The underlying heat transfer technology will be the Oscillating Heat Pipe (OHP). ThermAvant currently makes OHP-based heat sinks, heat spreaders and heat exchangers with ultra-high effective thermal conductivities (e.g., >30,000W/mK) and ultra-low thermal resistances (e.g.,

award_title: Cyber Battlefield Operating System Simulation Tools for LVC Simulations
research_keywords: Cyber Operations,cyber training,training system architectures,cyber tool suite
abstract: Dignitas Technologies Phase I approach will use our 20 years of Simulation & Training experience along with our architecture expertise to define a flexible service-oriented architecture (SOA) based tool set that will support training of Cyber Operations in Army training systems.Teamed with Metova Federal LLC for their cyber operations experience, Dignitas will provide a flexible and open approach to develop a tool suite of Cyber Operations training simulations. Our practical experience with major Army simulation systems will allow us to define an approach that has potential for immediate transition for training emerging cyber operations. Our approach will provide a system and architectural definition of a tool suite, a set of overarching requirements, and descriptions of relevant cyber training tasks addressed. Our efforts will be tailored to Army training capabilities in order to maximize transition, including government purpose rights development. Our reliance on open software and transparent approaches will help define a usable approach that facilitates technology injection and third party extension.

award_title: Carbon Monoxide Preservation of Vascularized Composite Grafts
research_keywords: Carbon Monoxide,vascularized composite tissues,autologous composite tissues,allogeneic composite tissues,metabolic suppression
abstract: The objective is development of a safe, effective delivery device for carbon monoxide (CO) for preservation of vascularized composite tissues for longer periods than currently possible. CO has previously demonstrated significant benefits for organ preservation in small animal models, however, there were safety issues that impeded translation to the clinic. The immediate objectives in this Phase I feasibility proposal are construction of a CO releasing device prototype in collaboration with Lorenz Meinel, University of Wurzburg, and demonstration of effectiveness in a rat hind limb model. Expert surgeons from Johns Hopkins University will supervise limb procurement methods. The CO releasing devices will be placed in bags of organ preservation solution and activated prior to flushing and preservation of rat hind limbs. Our objectives will be addressed in three tasks:In Task 1 construction and preliminary evaluation of a therapeutic device designed to deliver 40 M CO will be performed. In Task 2 we will evaluate the CO releasing therapeutic device by rat limb flushing and static storage on ice. In optional Task 3 we will compare the impact of different CO concentrations on limb preservation. Evaluations will consist of skeletal muscle and vascular tissue physiology, metabolism and histology studies.

award_title: A DMSO-Free Biomimetic Cryoprotective Matrix System For Bone Marrow Banking
research_keywords: Cryopreservation,hydrogel,Bioinspired,hematopoietic stem cells,chemistry,Bone Marrow Transplant,Peptidomimetics,
abstract: The biopreservation of hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) and bone marrow will allow for critical advances in healthcare, chemotherapy, and banking for mass casualty events. Cryopreservation is considered the answer, but remains a highly interdisciplinary problem that has yet to allow the successful full viability recovery of cells, tissues, and organs for on-demand applications. The use of cryoprotective agents (CPAs) like DMSO is hindered by their innate cytotoxicity and unfavorable effects in patients infused with DMSO containing HSCs. Opportunity lies in the development of a highly effective CPA or media system that significantly reduces or removes the use of harmful CPAs from cryoprotectant solutions. A cutting-edge preservation method and protocol is needed.Biomedical applications of hydrogels are ever growing with the advancement of antibiotic and traumatic wound care, time and location specific drug delivery, tissue engineering scaffolds, cell preservation, etc.X-Therma has engineered an advanced biomimetic cryoprotective matrix system for eventual use in bone marrow preservation. Phase I will focus on feasibility studies to assess the inherent cryoprotective effect of the matrix system. CD34+ cells will be encapsulated, subjected to a cryopreservation protocol and rewarming procedure. Simple cell assessment by live/dead and metabolic activity assays will be used to show feasibility.

award_title: SureTube: A Magnet-Assisted, Semi-Autonomous Approach to Blind Endotracheal Intubation
research_keywords: Endotracheal intubation,magnet-assisted,semi-autonomous,blind intubation,airway management,trauma,Battlefield,Combat Casualty Care
abstract: Current approaches to airway management in combat scenarios are limited. Surgical airways, the default procedure in many instances, are often unsuccessful and have high complication rates. Endotracheal intubation, the preferred approach to airway management, is often not possible because of environmental limitations, inadequate user skill or experience level, or patient limitations (e.g., airway trauma). Building on experience with device development for the combat medic, InnoVital will develop an unpowered, semi-autonomous system that leverages magnets to enable blind intubationimproving the success and ease of airway management in military and civilian pre-hospital settings. The approach also takes advantage of years of study of magnet-assisted intubation, refining and redirecting the solution for relevance to pre-hospital care. The SureTube system will be iteratively developed and prototyped to demonstrate feasibility in the Phase I effort. The envisioned solution will be familiar to medics in that the appearance and functioning of system components will be similar to commonly used airway tools. In addition to InnoVital Systems specific experience with the development of procedural aids for pre-hospital and acute care providers, existing relationships with relevant industry partners puts InnoVital in the best position for delivering a useful product.

award_title: Ensemble Prediction for Intelligent Combat Casualty Care (EPIC3)
research_keywords: Combat Casualty Care,Mobile application,machine learning,ensemble classifier,PROBABILISTIC REASONING,combat medic,injury prediction
abstract: Tactical Combat Casualty Care (TC3) is the difference between life or death following injury on the battlefield. First responders, combat medics, and casualty evacuation medics perform vital TC3 roles but are often overburdened by multiple casualties and overwhelmed by an increasing excess of sensor data that can be difficult to interpret in stressful and chaotic environments. Furthermore, injuries can be difficult to identify when symptoms are not obvious and treatment can be difficult to perform, depending on the skill of the performer. To address these challenges, we propose to design and evaluate Ensemble Prediction for Intelligent Combat Casualty Care (EPIC3), a mobile application that uses an ensemble of classifiers, frequently tuned via machine learning, to predict life-threatening and difficult-to-detect injuries. We will present the steps to treat those injuries through a simple, easy to use interface that tailors itself to the needs and skill level of the user.

award_title: Miniature, point-of-care device for establishing sterile connections in combat environments
research_keywords: Ultraviolet,LED,venous access,catheter sterilization,Portable,field-worthy,Miniaturized
abstract: Using catheters to achieve venous access is extremely important during combat casualty procedures, and they are only getting more important in the 21st Century. Hemorrhage is a major cause of battlefield death, and indeed caused more than 90% of preventable deaths between 2001 and 2011, and rapid replacement of blood volume is thus extremely important to saving the lives of our warfighters. Catheters also are used to deliver drugs, like pain medications. A major problem with catheters is their propensity to lead to infections, namely catheter-related blood stream infections (CRBSI). These infections can quickly become deadly, especially if they are caused by drug-resistant strains of bacteria or fungus. There is a clear need for new, effective methods to clean and sterilize catheters and their connections in combat environments. RemPhos Technologies LLC has developed a simple, hand-held, portable and reusable high intensity ultraviolet light source for automated simultaneous disinfection of hemodialysis catheter lumens and luer connectors. Under this project, the company will fabricate safe, operator-independent, high-intensity, miniaturized hardened device that is complete with miniaturized electronics; perfiorm UVA and UVC intensity measurements; and conduct definitive in vitro antimicrobial studies.

award_title: IV/Pilot: Simplifying the Expert Approach to Peripheral IV Placement to Increase First-Pass Success, Reduce Pain, and Decrease Complications
research_keywords: vascular access,IV,assist device,expert approach,Peripheral intravenous therapy,intravenous catheterization
abstract: Peripheral IV placement, a common and important first step in patient care, suffers from a low first-pass success rate. Repeated attempts are painful and lead to catheter failure due to other painful processes such as inflammation, infiltration and infection. Expert providers have higher first-pass success rates and lower incidence of IV failure, which translate to reduced pain for the patient. Through deconstruction of the most important and error-prone steps in IV placement, InnoVital Systems will design and build a device that allows novice users to perform like experts, increasing the ease and success rate of the procedure while reducing patient discomfort. The combined engineering and medical skillset and experience of the InnoVital team lowers the risk of the effort and enables its success. Furthermore, InnoVitals specific experience with the development of procedural aids for pre-hospital and acute care providers and existing relationships with relevant industry partners puts it in the best position for delivering a useful product.

award_title: Peripheral Nerve Targeting Liposome-Loaded TuneCoat Dressing for Treatment of Peripheral Neuropathy
research_keywords: Drug Delivery,transdermal,nanofiber,Combination Therapy,Peripheral neuropathy
abstract: Chronic neuropathic pain is a commonly occurring condition and a painful and debilitating problem for millions of Americans. The bulk of these neuropathic pains result from induced peripheral neuropathies, most commonly associated with diabetes, chemotherapy-treated cancers, and extremity injuries. Many drugs that have been shown effective in pain management when taken orally have extremely narrow therapeutic windows to prevent toxicity or undesirable side effects. In order to address the issues with drug-treatment of peripheral neuropathy, Luna Innovations proposes the development of a unique and highly-controllable nanofiber-based transdermal drug delivery system known as TuneCoat-2TM for the delivery of liposome-based nerve targeting drugs. The drug delivery nanofiber dressing will be used topically at the site of injury, will be applied by the patient, and will be designed to function with compression garments to permit use by patients who also suffer from secondary lymphedema. The fabrication protocol will allow for inclusion of multiple drugs in a single bandage with control over the delivery of each drug. Lunas TuneCoat-2TM dressing will significantly advance treatment of peripheral neuropathies and will be designed using only FDA-approved polymers and drugs, providing a relatively straight-forward approach towards clinical studies, FDA approval, and marketing.

award_title: Effectively controlled topical delivery of an innovative combination of targeted therapeutics to treat peripheral neuropathy
research_keywords: Peripheral neuropathy,epicutaneous delivery,topical gel formulation,combination targeted therapeutics for PN,neuropathic pain relief,nerve regeneration and repair,skin barrier penetration.
abstract: Peripheral Neuropathy (PN) is a painful debilitating condition caused by progressive subcutaneous nerve damage due to diabetes, chemotherapy or as a result of traumatic combat injuries. Current treatment options for PN are only moderately effective but have numerous drawbacks such as systemic effects, inefficient drug delivery and toxicity. Furthermore, long term use of some PN therapeutics can potentially lead to dependency. Lynntech, Inc. proposes to develop a biocompatible epicutaneous gel system for topical and controlled delivery of a unique combination of targeted therapeutics to effectively treat peripheral neuropathy. This novel combination therapeutic and delivery strategy will be designed to perform the dual action of mitigating pain and blocking/limiting nerve damage. The epicutaneous gel can be easily administered due to its familiar topical gel format. Phase I will provide proof-of-concept for efficacy of the combination PN therapeutic and delivery strategy using an appropriate in vitro 3D skin equivalent model. During Phase II development, an appropriate in vivo model of PN will be used to further develop the topical gel system for improved skin barrier penetration and optimal neuronal targeting ability. This innovative epicutaneous gel-based combination therapeutic system may significantly improve the quality of life of our soldiers with PN.

award_title: Solid State High Voltage Switching Device for Multi-Point Initiation
research_keywords: Electronic fuze,Pulsed Power,Transient Voltage Suppressor,Thyristor,Silicon Carbide,Transistor,Bipolar
abstract: This two-phase SBIR program will develop fully-qualified 1800 V/2500 A(peak)/

award_title: Dense Urban Environments Technology (DUET)
research_keywords: synthetic environments,Megacity,Urban,underground,multi-level terrain,Crowd modeling,Simulation
abstract: The current state of Modeling and Simulation (M&S) leaves the bulk of megacity concepts severely under-represented, spanning from lack of source data formats and source data content, to run-time representations and associated models.Dignitas Technologies and teammate Edgewise will leverage extensive expertise in synthetic natural environments to provide a detailed and comprehensive representation of dense urban environments, such as megacities, in modeling and simulation applications.Team Dignitas approach will address the complex geometries and topologies found in dense urban environments and associated human and object clutter and activities.Our approach will span streets, interiors, and underground along with associated physics and infrastructure effects, crowd/traffic and clutter models, as well as services required to support M&S functional needs.Our Phase I effort will leverage and build upon related research and commercial activities to provide a jump start to solution development.

award_title: Multi-resolution Modeling And Simulation Toolkit (MultiMAST)
research_keywords: LVC,Training,MODELING AND SIMULATION,megacities,expeditionary operations,MULTI-RESOLUTION MODELS,AnyLogic,DIS/HLA
abstract: The Army Operating Concept (AOC), published in 2014, describes the challenges faced by the Army when attempting to achieve victory in a complex world. In light of the concepts formalized in the AOC, it is clear that expeditionary Army operations are increasingly vital to maintain stability and security in a wide variety of complex, multi-faceted scenarios. Megacities, with populations over 10 million citizens, provide a unique challenge to expeditionary operations as they are deeply interconnected systems. As likely sources of future conflict, megacities are important in maintaining global stability and security. If the Army is to deploy expeditionary forces into megacity situations, it must be able to train its Soldiers to operate within them. Charles River Analytics, Inc. proposes to design and prototype a Multi-resolution Modeling and Simulation Toolkit (MultiMAST). MultiMAST will consist of a suite of component models for simulating megacity operations at both high and low resolutions, including a high-level model that integrates all component models and dynamically determines what resolution each section of the megacity will be modeled at, an interface that enables integration with other models such as OneSAF, and a trainer tool that allows intuitive authoring of training scenarios.

award_title: Sustained Maintenance Planning Software
research_keywords: Maintenance forecasting,fatigue monitoring,Degradation,Ontology,Predictive,inference
abstract: Total ownership costs and the life-cycle of mechanical components and systems can be vastly improved by increasing the reliability and overall operational readiness of the Navy fleet through the utilization of cost effective software techniques to utilize adaptive learning techniques to automatically understand component interdependencies and accurately predict component failure of equipment systems based on all available parametric data. Progeny believes integration of open-source software solutions with existing computer-controlled test and monitor systems that provide system status to predict failure will significantly decrease equipment maintenance costs by automatically recommending corrective hardware maintenance prior to failure occurring.Progenys proposed solution will leverage automated data acquisition, Natural Language Processing (NLP), big data storage techniques, and automatic calculation system-subsystem fatigue status and life remaining to recommend corrective maintenance.Our true innovation for this effort will be to provide a capability which automatically receives component fatigue damage assessment, calculates impacts to dependent hardware, and recommends condition-based maintenance. The resulting software will support unsupervised receipt and capturing of monitored damage assessment reports through integration of our solution with existing monitoring sensor hardware and reporting systems.

award_title: Predictive Maintenance Planning Software
research_keywords: winch,Prognostics,DIAGNOSTICS,Health monitoring,condition based maintenance,Sensors,Software
abstract: KCF Technologies understands that new CBM technology is required for realized Total Ownership Cost (TOC) reductions on many Navy platforms including winches. In particular, advanced solutions are needed to accurately predict component performance and maintenance from which overhauls can be reduced, work task times shortened, and maintenance logistics optimized. The lack of advanced monitoring technologies necessary to perform high fidelity diagnostics and prognosticswithin the constraints of most Navy platforms and logistics infrastructurerepresent a key technology gap that must be bridged to derive increased operational readiness and cost saving. In this project, advanced diagnostic and prognostic algorithms will be combined with KCFs mature commercial industrial machine monitoring solution. This marriage of technologies will be tailored and applied to the unique requirements of Navy winches.

award_title: Sustained Maintenance Planning Software
research_keywords: Support Equipment,condition based maintenance,DIAGNOSTICS,Sustainment,Fault Management,Predictive Analytics,Forecasters
abstract: Frontier Technology, Inc. (FTI) will develop and demonstrate an innovative, predictive condition-based maintenance forecaster that detects and diagnoses system performance degradation and forecasts time to failure as a means of reducing maintenance costs and increasing operational availability.The inability to anticipate corrective maintenance results in unscheduled outages that increase mean time to repair, decrease operational availability, and drive up costs.The forecaster will monitor system performance in real time, detect indicators of degradation and failure, diagnose the cause with a low probability of false alarm, determine time to failure and mission impact, and report to system stakeholders. The ability to predict the window for corrective action before an unscheduled system failure enables maintenance to be scheduled with the optimum use of time, people, tools and spares.The forecaster technical foundation consists of data-derived system performance analysis algorithms and processes using statistics, pattern recognition, machine learning and signal processing. At the completion of the project FTI will have demonstrated a forecaster that meets the requirements of the topic, can produce a report such as report such as, hardware A has a 90% probability of failure within the next 72-96 operating hours andcan meet the operational needs of the Navy.

award_title: Warden- Cyber Threat Anomaly Detection for Combat Systems
research_keywords: Anomaly Detection,combat systems,APT,Models
abstract: The DoD currently deploys combat systems that contain both known and unknown software vulnerabilities. These vulnerabilities make it possible for hackers to execute cyber attacks that result in system corruption or disruption and diminish confidence in Americas critical warfighting capabilities.While efforts have been made to enhance security through improved software development practices and the deployment of bolt-on signature-based intrusion detection capabilities, combat and weapon systems continue to be at risk of attack from well-resourced, sophisticated adversaries.Star Lab proposes to research and develop a cyber-protection system architecture that uses heuristic modeling and anomaly detection algorithms to detect imminent, undocumented cyber-attacks. Additionally, Star Lab has partnered with Lockheed Martin Mission Systems and Training to develop the models and algorithms used by its cyber-protection system architecture using system designs and representative data from the Aegis Combat System.Star Labs cyber-protection system architecture is designed to have wide applicability across a range of combat and weapon systems across the DoD.

award_title: Statistical Intrusion Detection System Generating Policy-based Responses to Cyber Threats
research_keywords: Cyber defense,intrusion detection,Intrusion Prevention,anomaly based detection,IDS
abstract: To address the Navy need for a real-time capability for anomaly-based detection of Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs) in Internet Protocol based Combat System networks, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a new Statistical Intrusion Detection System Generating Policy-based Responses to Cyber Threats (STINGER) based on Markov decision processes and intelligent action policy. This combination provides artificial intelligence needed to detect and mitigate the APTs and both known and new cyber-attacks. STINGER monitors network traffic, dynamically detects and classifies attacks using statistical analysis and an anomaly-based intrusion detection mechanism. STINGERs infrastructure-agnostic intrusion detection/response mechanism enables detection of currently undetectable new generation of cyber-attacks, such as highly distributed and coordinated attacks and low frequency attacks, as well as classification and mitigation of attacks. In Phase I, POC will develop STINGERs overall system architecture, framework and algorithms, and demonstrate feasibility by assembling and testing a prototype. In the Phase I Option we will refine the system design and prepare detailed technical specifications for the software to be developed in Phase II. In Phase II, POC will develop an advanced prototype to demonstrate real-time attack pattern detection and attack classification prediction model capabilities in representative enterprise networks and environments.

award_title: Modular Charge Delivery System (CDS) for Undersea Remotely Operated Vehicles (ROVs)
research_keywords: EOD,ROV,UUV,CDS,mine,MCM,Payload,delivery
abstract: US Navy EOD teams need to outfit currently procured small ROVs with a cost effective, aftermarket, multi-platform compatible, Charge Delivery System (CDS) that can use existing EOD explosive materials and processes. Boston Engineering has developed multiple underwater vehicle systems that deliver customer payloads, already overcoming common payload delivery issues such as changes to hydrodynamic loading and variances in system stability due to addition or removal of mass while providing high reliability attach/detach mechanisms. Our solution is inexpensive and easily assembled to a COTS ROV. The compatibility of this system with existing demolition charges avoids impacting the controlled explosive supply chain. Our system is passive, removing cost and complication related to electrical or software integration into the COTS ROV. Phase I focuses on verifying the robustness of our design and proving individual subsystem functionality, minimizing risk to Phase II. We propose to provide a functional, TRL6 prototype, capable of neutralizer placement on bottom, moored, and floating mines at the conclusion of PHII or sooner.

award_title: Modular Charge Delivery System (CDS) for Undersea Remotely Operated Vehicles (ROVs)
research_keywords: modular charge,Sea Mine countercharge,OP Charge,ROV charge,Remote explosive charge,Remote neutralization charge,UWIED neutralization charge,scalable neutralization charge.
abstract: The objective of this proposal is to demonstrate the feasibility of producing a Modular Charge Delivery System (CDS) that may integrate to a COTS or MOTS ROV to support the remote neutralization of naval sea mines and underwater improvised explosive devices (UWIEDs). The proposed opportunity utilizes standard demolition materials in an over-pressurization (OP charge) configuration, integrates to an ROV such that it provides optimum flight performance before and after charge separation, and has provisions to allow a diver to manually secure it to a target prior to detonation.

award_title: Hybrid Lidar/Radar Sensor for Improved Mine Detection
research_keywords: Avalanche photodiode,lidar,Ladar,Laser Radar,low light imaging,Flight,Readout integrated circuit,APD
abstract: A hybrid lidar/radar (HLR) sensor will be developed that enables hybrid lidar-radar underwater ranging to enhance target detection in underwater environments. The method is based on the use of an optically carried radio frequency (RF) signal in order to benefit from both the directivity of the optical beam (lidar), and the accuracy of RF signal processing (radar). To demonstrate the benefits of HLR, in Phase I, using a system-level approach and working with the contract technical representative, the U.S. Nave program office, and other stakeholders, an optimized HLR system will be developed. The HLR sensor will include a high-sampling-rate focal-plane array (FPA), laser, RF modulator, and scan optics. Using empirically derived performance parameters, performance will be modeled, and the system will be shown to benefit U.S. Navy mine-countermeasure (MCM) missions.Also in Phase I, a high-sample-rate monolithic avalanche photodiode (APD) photoreceiver array will be developed, an RF-modulated pulsed laser will be designed, and signal processing demonstrated. A breadboard prototype will be assembled to demonstrated proof-of-concept, and a system, to be fabricated and tested in Phase II, will be built.

award_title: Identify and Exploit Attributes of a Light Detection and Ranging (LIDAR) Signal to Improve Sea Mine Detection and Identification with a Low False Alarm Rate
research_keywords: lidar,ALMDS,Polarization,mine detection
abstract: The Airborne Laser Mine Detection System (ALMDS) provides a powerful capability for the detection and classification of surface and near-surface mines; however, there is room for considerable improvement by exploiting the polarization characteristics of ambient and target lidar returns.For example, the surface specular return and near-surface volumetric backscatter are nearly co-polarized with the incident radiation, whereas the target returns are effectively depolarized.Such differences can be effectively exploited to discriminate between target and ambient returns, increasing the probability of detection while reducing the false alarm rate.Aret proposes to develop and demonstrate a dual-polarization ALMDS receiver to capture the polarization characteristics of both ambient and target returns, and implement advanced algorithms to optimally exploit the various polarization properties.Performance advantages will be quantified by analysis in Phase 1, and demonstrated through flight test against representative mine targets in Phase 2.In parallel with quantifying these performance advantages, the effort will also address the optimal approach for implementation into the existing ALMDS architecture to allow a seamless transition to fleet operations.Aret Associates is the original developer and current production supplier of the ALMDS system, and is uniquely qualified to design, develop, and deliver such improvements for ALMDS.

award_title: Identify and Exploit Attributes of a Light Detection and Ranging (LIDAR) Signal to Improve Sea Mine Detection and Identification with a Low False Alarm Rate
research_keywords: ALMDS,mine,mine countermeasure systems,mine detection systems,AMCS,lidar,MH-60S,streak tube
abstract: Organic mines are serious threats to U.S. naval ships. As a result, the Navys Airborne Mine Countermeasure Systems are in place to negate these threats. One of the systems, the Airborne Laser Mine Detection System (ALMDS), is a mine countermeasure that is intended to detect, classify and localize sea mines. The system is mounted on the MH-60S helicopter.The heart of the ALMDS is the streak tube imaging LIDAR, which allows a high area search rate capability for reconnaissance and assessment of mine threats in littoral zones, confined straits, choke points and amphibious objective areas.One ALMDS objective is to detect mines as deep under the water surface as possible. This objective requires a detection system with a very large dynamic range when the ALMDS operates inside turbid harbors, where the laser light quickly losses its intensity in the water. Unfortunately, the streak tube has relatively low dynamic range. Therefore, there is a need to develop techniques to improve the dynamic range of the ALMDS.SA Photonics is pleased to propose the development of OPAL, which can improve the ALMDS dynamic range by more than 20 dB. OPAL is a complete add-on system; no ALMDS hardware alternation is needed.

award_title: Demonstration of High-dynamic-range Lidar Focal Plane Array
research_keywords: Avalanche photodiode,lidar,Ladar,Laser Radar,low light imaging,Flight,Readout integrated circuit,APD
abstract: A linear 256-element silicon-photodetector focal plane array (FPA) will be tested and characterized, before being integrated with camera electronics and tested. The FPA will be shown to have at least 6 bits of dynamic range beyond the existing lidar sensors used in airborne lidar systems for underwater mine detection. The ability to accommodate glint, while maintaining sensitivity will also be demonstrated. The results of these tests will be used to develop the design of a fine-pixel-pitch 1,024 element linear avalanche photodiode (APD) receiver, which will be fabricated and demonstrated in Phase II, and shown to provide enhanced probability of target detection, with lower false alarms, compared to existing lidar receivers.

award_title: Innovative Methods for Limited Dynamic Range Optical Detectors to More Effectively Operate in High Dynamic Range Environments
research_keywords: lidar,cmos camera,streak tube
abstract: To address the USN need for increased dynamic range in the ALMDS receiver, TSG proposes to use a trade study centered on the receiver back-end camera: a focal plane array (FPA) and its data processing architecture.The Phase 1 study will select the optimum FPA and design a camera with it. The trade study will use an innovative set of improvements that incrementally expand receiver subsystem performance in sensitivity, noise, resolution and fixed pattern noise. This validation leverages existing physical models of the receiver and the environment, and focuses on the existing camera-tube assembly as a base for high payoff, low risk incremental upgrades. The innovation in STIL-optimized CMOS imaging and streak tube integration will enable the program to significantly advance its detection performance without incurring excessive TRL risk. In Phase I, TSG will exercise models and conduct lab experiments with in house technology to produce a camera design and Phase 2 plan of action. In Phase II, TSG will build and test the new camera.In Phase 3, TSG will work with the program to displace the current production model using the Phase 2 camera design.

award_title: Naval Special Warfare Ultra High Frequency (UHF) Satellite Communications (SATCOM) Low Elevation Angle Antenna
research_keywords: UHF SATCOM antenna,UFO satellite,MUOS Satellite,Seal Delivery Vehicle,SATCOM,Low Elevation Angle UHF Mast Antenna,Quadrafiliar Helix,RHCP
abstract: Toyon proposes to design a UHF SATCOM antenna for the SEAL Delivery Vehicle (SDV) with the ability to switch between low-angle and high-angle gain patterns. As the mast tilts in rough seas, the antenna can be operated in a dynamic mode that selects either the low-angle or high-angle gain pattern to maintain optimal gain toward a UFO/MUOS satellite. This mitigates the gain rolloff that occurs with fixed-pattern mast antennas in real-world operational scenarios. Reflections off the sea that lead to scalloping of the gain pattern over the low elevation angles will be reduced by raising the antennas phase center to the top of the antenna when selecting the low-angle gain pattern and to the bottom of the antenna when selecting the high-angle gain pattern.

award_title: Submersible High-Gain Instrumentation Low-Elevation-Angle Antenna
research_keywords: Smart Antenna,Seal Delivery Vehicle,UHF SATCOM antenna,Satellite communications,UFO satellite,Low elevation angle,SATCOM
abstract: To address the Navy need for innovative, ultrahigh-frequency (UHF) SATCOM antennas with low-elevation-angle coverage to meet the operational needs of Naval Special Warfare such as SEAL Delivery Vehicles, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a new Submersible High-Gain Instrumentation Low-Elevation-Angle Antenna (Sub-GLEA). The innovation in electromagnetic field conditioning will enable reliable, high-gain, low-elevation-angle antennas for SDV in a small form factor. The Sub-GLEA is a monopole, wideband, high-gain, right hand circular polarization antenna, optimally designed for UHF SATCOM frequencies, that fits within an existing radome configuration. Therefore, this technology offers improved gain and elevation angle, which directly address the Navy requirements. Phase I focuses on conceptual design of the innovative low-elevation-angle UHF SATCOM antenna; POC will design the system, and will evaluate it against factors such as beam forming capability, gain, elevation angle, polarization, size, weight, power, cost, and radiation characteristics such as field of regard, instantaneous field of view, beam width, spectrum, and pattern tuning. In Phase II, POC will develop and demonstrate the feasibility with a prototype antenna and relevant drive electronics, through testing in an anechoic chamber or other suitable test facility.

award_title: Hermetically Sealed Absolute Vacuum Pressure Gauge
research_keywords: Vacuum gauge,Wide Dynamic Range,absolute pressure gauge,MEMS,Shipboard applications
abstract: Triton Systems proposes to develop a compact and hermetically sealed micro-fabricated vacuum sensor providing wide dynamic range (> 9 orders of magnitude), self-calibration capability, improved durability and reliability, and insensitivity to installation orientation for Navy shipboard applications. The proposed absolute pressure sensor is insensitive to gas species and environmental conditions, and immune to contamination from the vacuum system. Therefore, it is an ideal sensor for long period maintenance-free operation.In Phase I, we will design and optimize the vacuum sensor performance through modeling and simulation. We will build and test vacuum sensor cells to obtain key performance characteristics which will be used to design the Phase II prototype vacuum sensor.During Phase I Option, we will complete analyzing Phase I results and optimize the Phase II Prototype design. We will carefully consider a suitable method of hermetical sealing between the vacuum sensor compartment and control electronics compartment during the prototype vacuum gauge design.

award_title: Optically-Addressed, Hermetically Sealed, and Orientation-Independent Full-Scale Vacuum Gauge
research_keywords: full-scale vacuum measurement,ultra-high vacuum,UHV,MEMS,Pirani gauge,thermal conductivity,optical addressing,hermetic seal
abstract: Connectsix LLC proposes to research and develop a MEMS-based vacuum gauge which will enable safe and efficient operation of Navy high temperature superconductivity systems which require vacuum thermal insulation.The vacuum gauge uses novel, inexpensive, and robust MEMS structures, proprietary optical readout techniques, and low-cost commercially-available light sources and detectors to measure pressure-dependent heat loss and vacuum levels. The research and resultant vacuum gauge will have an extended working range, beyond that of standard- and Micro-Pirani thermal gauges, measuring from 2 ATM down to

award_title: Resonant Piezoelectric-Based, Wide-Range, High-Reliability Vacuum Sensor
research_keywords: High Vacuum Gauge,Hermetically Sealed,Orientation Independent,Wide Range,Long Lifespan,high reliability,Piezoelectric Resonator,Low Cost
abstract: SARA proposes an approach for developing a vacuum pressure sensor based on a piezoelectric resonator capable of monitoring pressures ranging from 1 microTorr to >2 atmospheres.Relatively small pressure-dependent shifts in the resonant frequency of such devices have been observed and reported in literature over the pressure range of interest. SARA intends to exploit this phenomenon using a proprietary control-circuit method that will enable significantly higher accuracy of the device relative to that of the published literature.This capability will enable pressure monitoring with acceptable accuracy over the full pressure range using a single low-cost sensing element. Development of this system will lead to a compact, fully-integrated, hermetically-sealed, and orientation-insensitive device capable of real-time vacuum pressure reporting. As the sensing element is built on the high reliability, long lifespan, and low cost of piezoelectric resonators, the device will allow for permanent integration into vacuum systems for system lifetime monitoring.

award_title: An Indoor GPS Satellite Constellation Emulation Antenna Array
research_keywords: Antenna array,Constellation,Emulation,GPS,movement control,phase calibration,pointing control,Propagation
abstract: This proposal present an indoor GPS satellite constellation emulation antenna array. GPS satellite signals are provided by a multi-channel GPS signal generator. The antenna array emulates GPS satellite constellation by moving on rails, which emulate GPS satellite orbits. Each antenna emulates one GPS satellite and has the same angular speed with the GPS satellite it is emulating. In the GPS satellite emulation process, all antennas point their main lobes to the emulated earth center (or the GPS receiver antenna under test). The same length cables are applied to connect the multi-channel GPS satellite signal generator and antennas, which maintain the same phase/time delay for all the antennas/channels, and the phase delay difference due to the emulated orbits are calibrated. At the GPS receiver antenna, the delay difference is only due to the GPS satellites movement, which is generated by the multi-channel GPS satellite signal generator.

award_title: Medium Voltage Direct Current (MVDC) Casualty Power System
research_keywords: MVDC,Casualty Power,power generation,automatic power routing,battlefield damage
abstract: In this SBIR, DTI proposes to design an MVDC Casualty Power System (CPS) which employs a combination of equipment permanently installed in each designated ship zone, and easily portable conductors that the crew can use jumper across damaged zones. This equipment will be designed to address the new challenges associated with highly integrated high power MVDC shipboard power systems, within the emerging architectures and standards for these systems. In Phase I, DTI will design and prototype this system for evaluation and testing in a shipboard environment. In Phase II, DTI will fully engineer, build and test a complete MVDC CPS prototype, incorporating all applicable manufacturing and installation standards. Throughout this effort DTI will work closely with the Navy and its Prime Contractors to transition the technology to the fleet in Phase III.

award_title: Unmanned Surface Vehicle (USV)-Mounted Acoustic Generator
research_keywords: Non-towed acoustic generator,low-drag,unmanned surface vehicle,acoustic frequency and amplitude,endurance,AUTONOMOUS
abstract: The US Navy is seeking an innovative acoustic source capable of generating a broad range of outputs that would be mounted either above the waterline or within the hull and structure of an existing Navy USV. However, if a solution were sub-surface, the acoustic generator would be stowed above the waterline or within the USV hull-form until performing operations. The system must be lightweight (less than 200lb); contained in a small-volume (less than 30cft); require minimal electrical or propulsion power (less than 10kw electrical power; Propulsive Power 90hp); have a high acoustical power radiation (between 175-185dB, each over frequency range of 10Hz to 5kHz); and mitigate the effects of craft speed and its variations (be speed independent). The acoustic generator will be autonomously activated by the USVs central command and control.

award_title: Unmanned Surface Vehicle (USV)-Mounted Acoustic Generator
research_keywords: CMC,hydrodynamic,Piezoelectric,Multi-way Array,LOW DRAG,High SPL
abstract: Wattre is proposing a transducer design study to trade-off the benefits of different types of transducer technologies and integrate the resulting array elements to create an optimal package to satisfy the sponsor requirements.To meet the wide bandwidth requirements, Wattre will investigate multiple acoustic generation methods and determine their suitability to be used in a multi element where each acoustic channel is responsible for a given operational frequency band..The design approach divides the acoustic source output signal into discrete frequency sections controlled by a crossover networkWithin this design a single device is not be required to operate across an overly wide bandwidth which results in higher input efficiencies and enhanced acoustic performance.This modular acoustic source design approachspreads the acoustic ouput requirement over multiple array elements where each individual array element is optimized for its discrete operational frequency band.The three candidate technologies described to be investigated within this proposal are PZT transducers for high frequency operation targeting 1kHz to 5kHz, Compounded Magnetics Circuitry (CMC) for mid/low frequency bandwidth targeting 40Hz to 1kHz bandwidth and a Hydrodynamic oscillator targeting low frequency 10Hz to 40Hz bandwidth.

award_title: Virginia Class PEM Electrolyzer Cost Reduction by Reduced PGM Loadings
research_keywords: Low PGM,catalyst,Anode,Electrolyzer,Cost Reduction
abstract: Giner Inc (Giner), having built over thirty operational PEM electrolysis cell stacks for the US Navys Seawolf, Ohio, and Los Angeles Class submarines is the worlds leading supplier of such equipment. Our proposal is to leverage the results of our earlier work on advanced PEM electrolyzer catalysts into a project aimed at productionizing and optimizing the best candidate material. Since anode catalyst loadings are approximately one order of magnitude higher than currently proven cathode catalyst loadings we expect to concentrate our development efforts on the anode materials. We propose to run optimization experiments on the low PGM anode catalyst to optimize the anode loading at or below 0.25 mg/cm2 which has been demonstrated to provide equivalent performance to our standard anode catalyst at 16 times that loading level. During the optional portion of the Phase I we propose to longevity test the down-selected catalyst loading at Navy submarine cell stack operating conditions. Our initial cost studies indicate that successful conclusion of this effort will definitively lead to a greater than 20% reduction in stack cost from the $1M figure stated in the solicitation to less than $800k.

award_title: Increased Utilization of Non-Strategic Metals for PEM Electrolyzers
research_keywords: electrolysis,ion exchange membrane,hydrogen catalyst,non-PGM materials,submarine,life support oxygen
abstract: Electrochemical generation of oxygen via proton exchange membrane (PEM) electrolysis is currently the source of oxygen for life support on board the Vanguard and other classes of submarines.While highly reliable, the cell stacks for the PEM electrolyzers contain high levels of expensive platinum group metals (PGMs).The proposed project seeks to leverage a combination of improved manufacturing processes for higher catalyst utilization and advanced catalysts with low or no PGM content in order to reduce stack cost for both the Navy and commercial applications.Proton OnSite will focus on advanced catalyst deposition methods, while leveraging catalyst synthesis and characterization capabilities at Stanford University to develop new catalyst compositions.Proton will also leverage the companys depth of knowledge in electrolysis cell stack design to look at the system holistically and ensure that the advanced membrane electrode assembly (MEA) can be effectively integrated into the cell stack to realize the performance gains while still meeting all the Navy application requirements.

award_title: Cobalt Oxide Nanocubane-based Oxygen Generator System
research_keywords: Non-noble metal based electrocatalysts,Proton Exchange Membrane,Oxygen generator,water splitting,water electrolysis,Nafion nanofibers,cobalt oxide nanocubanes,Submarines
abstract: To address the Navys need for a non-noble metal proton exchange membrane based electrocatalysts and engineered nanostructure for improved oxygen generator for submarines, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a new Cobalt Oxide (Co4O4) Nanocubane-based Oxygen Generator (CONOG) system. The proposed oxygen generator system is based on a novel design that utilizes electrospun Nafion nanofibers as the Proton Exchange Membrane (PEM). In CONOG system, Co4O4 nanocubanes are used as efficient oxygen evolution catalysts. As a result, the proposed approach offers high proton conductivity at the pores of the Nafion nanofibers. Particularly, utilization of cobalt oxide nanomaterials as oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalysts, enables the system to improve oxygen generation and significantly reduce costs. In Phase I, POC will demonstrate the feasibility of the CONOG system by fabricating a Membrane Electrode Assembly (MEA) structure incorporated with cobalt oxide nanocubanes as catalysts for the water oxidation process. In Phase II, POC plans to build a prototype 4-cell stack incorporating improved electrocatalysts and novel MEA structures capable of operating at equivalent current density of 1000 ASF and at an equivalent oxygen generation rate of 225 SCFH.

award_title: Anti-Reflective Surface Structures for Third Generation Infrared Sensors
research_keywords: Sub-wavelength surface structures,moth-eye coatings,high-transmittance,infrared optics,third-generation sensor,Anti-reflection
abstract: Third-generation focal plane arrays allow US Army soldiers to view high-resolution, high frame rate imagery across multiple infrared bands. To properly utilize the capabilities of these new sensors, including their high sensitivity across the SWIR, MWIR, and LWIR bands, third-generation imaging systems employ advanced optical systems with multiple refractive and reflective components. The number of surfaces, the large refractive indices of some of the infrared materials, and the large range of angular incidence associated with fast optics make it difficult to obtain multi-element infrared optical systems with high optical transmittance across a broad, multi-band spectral range. There is a need for new techniques and processes that can increase the spectral transmittance of the optical system components (infrared lenses, windows, and beamsplitters), and allow third-generation imaging systems to achieve their full potential. Nanohmics, Inc. and the Optical Structured Surfaces Laboratory at the University of North CarolinaCharlotte are working together to apply optimized random anti-reflective surface structure (rARSS) technology to address the spectral transmittance requirements associated with the optical components of third-generation imaging systems.

award_title: Self-Healing/Self Routing Wiring
research_keywords: Self-healing/Self-rerouting wiring,electrical components,Maintenance,autonomous control,eutectic metal,network sensing,FAULT DETECTION,reconfigurable antenna
abstract: The goal of this program is to develop and demonstrate a wiring system with the ability to detect faults and autonomously mitigate them through self-healing or self-rerouting. The wiring system must be ruggedized to survive the harsh operating conditions and environment that exist in the hull of military aircraft; this includes nearly constant vibrations, temperature extremes, and potential exposure to chemicals. To be implemented, the system needs to be as compact, versatile, and low weight as possible in addition to being comparable in cost to traditional wiring systems. The system also needs to be designed such that it can be retrofit in existing aircraft without the need for specialized equipment. Nano Terra will team with North Carolina State University (NCSU) to develop an integrated self-healing wiring system. This will build on the developments at NCSU for self-healing technologies, and the means to control their re-routing. Nano Terra will integrate these technologies in the wiring system and will lead the network sensing and control efforts as well as overall system design and integration.

award_title: Foreign Object Debris- Vacuum System (FOD-VAC)
research_keywords: Robust Construction,FOD Tracking,Borescope/Vacuum Capability,FOD Damage Mitigation,Versatile and Highly Capable,Domestic FOD Retrieval,Modular design,FOD Removal
abstract: To overcome the capability with FOD removal from both on flight line and in aircraft compartments, Hy-Tek Manufacturing Co. Inc. (HMC) herein proposes a novel approach to drastically reduce the instances of FOD damage to the U.S. Navy AV-8B Harrier. This system, coined the FOD-Vacuum Removal System (FOD-VAC), will satisfy the U.S. Navys requirements by providing a highly capable debris removal system. Development and implementation of this innovative system will result in a significant improvement over current mechanical and manual equipment. The proposed system will deploy a novel probe designed to remove domestic FOD from AV-8B Harrier from within engine bay and aircraft compartments. In addition, a tracking system is proposed to aid personnel in ensuring FOD removal of flight line surfaces. Successful deployment of the FOD-VAC will provide effective debris removal, both on the flight line and within confined aircraft compartments, in turn preventing FOD damage and the cost of engine removal, repair, replacement, and downtime. Hy-Tek Manufacturing (HMC) believes that the deployment of the proposed FOD-VAC system in conjunction with an FOD Prevention Plan will result in a significant reduction of FOD related incidents.

award_title: Digital Aberration Corrector for Aspheric Domes
research_keywords: Conformal domes,infrared missile domes,infrared missile seekers,aspheric optics,aberration correction,computational imaging,Algorithms,ENZ theory
abstract: To address the Army need for technology and methodology to cost-effectively image through non-spherical infrared missile domes, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a new Digital Aberration Corrector for Aspheric Domes (DACFADO), utilizing an innovative combination of computational imaging algorithms based on Extended Nijboer-Zernike (ENZ) theory of diffraction. These algorithms will work in a highly parallel manner on a modern graphics processing unit (GPU), enabling 30 fps real-time aberration correction. POCs innovation in computationally-assisted imaging will enable stationary and gimbaled infrared imaging missile seekers equipped with the DACFADO system to reliably image infrared radiation sources through a variety of aerodynamically optimized, non-spherical dome shapes. As a result, this technology offers a unique, highly adaptable infrared imaging capability, requiring only inexpensive, low size, weight, and power (SWaP) digital processing hardware, and enabling the use of low-drag domes in missiles, which directly addresses the Army requirements. In Phase I, POC will demonstrate the feasibility of the DACFADO system by developing a Technology Readiness Level (TRL)-3 prototype. In Phase II, POC plans to build a TRL-6 prototype implemented in a low SWaP processing hardware.

award_title: Next Generation Wind Measurement Technology
research_keywords: Wind measurement,Doppler,laser scanning,lidar
abstract: We propose a shipborne wind measurement system utilizing Doppler Lidar. The proposed system achieve superior SWAP and cost benefits through miniaturaization and leveraging of semiconductor wafer processing techniques. A fovial scan pattern with hemispheric coverage (2 pi ster radians) field of view and real-time frame refresh rate (30 Hz) is achievable.

award_title: Miniature Fiber Wind LADAR
research_keywords: Miniature Wind LADAR,Coherent Lidar,Doppler lidar,wind lidar,Wind LADAR,coherent ladar
abstract: Systems & Processes Engineering Corporation (SPEC) proposes a Wind Measurement LADAR System for measuring the wind field in the airspace around US Navy Air Capable Ships. The system uses a fiber optic based, eye-safe wind LADAR, initially designed for UAV systems, brought to bread board level on Army and NASA programs. The system leans on existing telecom fiber technology allowing low cost and miniature sizing. The sensor features a coherent fiber optic transceiver with a narrow band seed, AOM (Acousto Optical Modulator) for frequency shift and pulse forming, a three stage EDFA amplifier, all operating at eye-safe 1550nm. The LADAR uses phase encoded pulse trains allowing a 13/1 signal to noise improvement and 13x smaller range cells while preserving Doppler accuracy. This LADAR allows air current Doppler detection beyond 3km. The sensor output is Doppler shift in 3D pixels (voxels), 90 degree vertically 360 degrees horizontally, stabilized in global coordinates using a MEMs IMU/GPS input, giving full ship area wind profiles.
