The original UAV specifications meet the system requirements, with additional range capability. Electronics, laser and receiver are in PCIe 104 format, meeting the objective size requirement. Global stabilized scan allows voxel scan revisit to allow 1ft/sec velocity accuracy.

award_title: Next Generation Wind Measurement Technology
research_keywords: Next Generation Wind Measurement Technology,digital signal processing,Electromagnetics,THz transmissometer system,Absorption and Scattering Study - Advanced Modeling,Terahertz Atmospheric & Ionospheric Pro
abstract: Colorado Engineering Inc. (CEI), with its consultant Professor Albin J. Gasiewski (Consultant/UPI -Professor, University of Colorado, Boulder), propose to leverage its collective expertise in Terahertz Atmospheric & Ionospheric Propagation, Absorption and Scattering Study - Advanced Modeling (TAIPAS-AM), radar systems design, electromagnetics (EM) analysis and modeling, antenna design, RF design, advanced processing architectures, and Digital Signal Processing (DSP) algorithms to investigate the development of an advanced short range wind sensor that operates in the W band (40-110 GHz).to as high as 200 GHz The Phase I work will include architecting and modeling of the wind sensor performance trades from W band to the THz band, the entire system concept and a detailed block design of the advanced wind sensing system. CEI will combine its extensive expertise with embedded hardware and software, anti-tamper (AT), Information Assurance (IA) and Built-in Test (BIT) to develop an advanced high fidelity wind sensing system. The design will most likely require a combination of radio frequency (RF) and digital to meet tight Cost, Size, Weight and Power (CSWaP) requirements.

award_title: Compact Wind Radar
research_keywords: weather radar,electronically scanning antenna,Remote wind measurement,Millimeter Wave
abstract: To address the Navy need for an innovative and low-cost wind measurement system for air-capable ships and aircraft carriers, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a new Compact Wind Radar (CoWiR) with a new electronically scanning antenna allowing for wind measurements in any vertical plane up to an altitude of 200 ft. The CoWiR will be an all-weather system capable of providing precise information about the distribution of wind velocity vectors with accuracy of better than 1.5 kn, range resolution of 10 ft, and data update rate over 10 Hz. The CoWiR will be a weather-proof, rugged, easy to install device with dimensions of 6.25 in. x 6.25 in. x 5 in. Several CoWiRs will be sufficient for mapping wind speed and direction for the entire ship airspace in order to improve the safety of launch and recovery operations for manned and unmanned aircraft. In Phase I, POC will demonstrate the feasibility of the CoWiR approach through system design and simulations of its operation in various weather conditions, performing cost optimization and fabrication and testing of the experimental prototype (TRL-4). In Phase II, POC plans to develop a fully operational prototype and validate its compliance with Navy requirements (TRL-6).

award_title: Human Detection and Geolocation Technology
research_keywords: Autonomous navigation,Human detection,communication network
abstract: To address the Army need for an automatic robotic system for detection of humans in hard-to-reach locations in GPS-denied environments with improved accuracy when determining their locations, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a new Human Detection and Geolocation (HDGL) technology. The technology will use a robotic platform for the placement of multiple sets of sensors that will automatically establish a communication network to deliver their signals to a remote ground station. The utilization of POCs proprietary laser technology to improve platform position tracking in GPS-denied environments will guarantee precise determination of sensor positions and corresponding accuracy when determining human locations. The use of numerous sensors utilizing various signals associated with the presence of humans will facilitate achieving the probability of human detection of >50%. In Phase I, POC will demonstrate the feasibility of the HDGL technology by modeling and simulating its operation, and experimentally demonstrating the operation of sensors and the accuracy of the platforms navigation at TRL-3. In Phase II, POC plans to develop the fully operational system prototype and demonstrate its performance in realistic environments (TRL-6).

award_title: Integrated Hybrid Structural Health Monitoring (SHM) System
research_keywords: Fiber Bragg Grating Sensors,autonomous sensor,Lightweight,load environment,miniature fiber optic sensor,aircraft damage detection sensor,Ultra-low power wireless sensor,wireless SHM/NDE sensor system
abstract: Redondo Optics Inc. Proposes to develop and demonstrate to the Navy a miniature, light weight, and low power, fully integrated multi-channel hybrid PZT/FBG acousto-ultrasound (FAULSense) SHM system for the in-situ un-attended detection, identification, and localization of structural damage in advance Navy structures. The distributed FAULSense system uses a network of PZT actuators for the controlled excitation of acoustic waveform signals and a distributed array of FBG acoustic-ultrasound sensors for the global detection and measurement of the excitation structure response. In Phase I, ROI will design, assemble, and produce a working prototype of the hybrid FAULSense early warning damage detection SHM system and test it on a simulated aircraft structure to demonstrate its ability to detect and localized hidden structural damage. In Phase II, ROI with the support of Sikorsky team, it will produce a stand-alone FAULSense system and tested in a relevant aircraft platform environment under a variety of passive and dynamic aerodynamic test conditions. All of the Navy current and future aircraft will benefit significantly from this project, wherein the key technological challenge is to develop methodologies for high fidelity detection and characterization of flaws and degradation in complex aerodynamic structures.

award_title: Gradient Refractive Index Single Element Achromatic Lenses
research_keywords: Achromat,LENS,rifle scope,GRIN,polymers,SWaP
abstract: The program aims to design, manufacture, and characterize weight reduced single element achromatic lenses (SEAL) constructed of nanolayered polymer gradient refractive index (GRIN) materials for improved color correction in visible broadband (350 nm to 1544 nm) wavelength operating military relevant systems. Envisioned optical systems for integration of the GRIN SEAL optics include as riflescopes, spotting scopes, binoculars, and UAV cameras. Utilizing a patented optical design and manufacturing technology developed and verified under the recent DARPA MGRIN program, the Phase I SBIR program will design and fabricate a custom nanolayered polymer optic engineered, constructed, and characterized in Phase I program efforts in a riflescope relevant SEAL GRIN optic design that weighs less thanthat of existing product glass doublet optics with improved on-and off axis color correction as compared to the existing product.

award_title: Integrated Hybrid Structural Health Monitoring (SHM) System
research_keywords: 3) Integrated H/S,<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'></span>3) Integrated H/S,1) Hybrid sensor system,6)<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'></span>Event type and detection,5) Damage type and detection,<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'></span>2) DP
abstract: We propose SHM technology integrated with multi-scale, multi-physics analysis to demonstrate the technical feasibility of, an integrated hybrid SHM system that utilizes networks of fiber optic (FO) sensors and piezoelectric (PZT) actuators to monitor loads and detect damage state on both non-rotating and rotating structural components for the V-22 platform. In Phase I, a prototype of the hybrid SHM system will be demonstrated to monitor actual environment loading history and track damage states (and evolution of such damage) on a metallic and composite coupon. The hardware/software for data acquisition of the hybrid SHM system is proposed to be small/lightweight, packaged as a single unit and eventually integrated with the current V-22 Vibration/Structural Life and Engine Diagnostics (VSLED) system. An ultrasonic based wireless SHM system is proposed by ASC team to detect damages in structural components which can be easily integrated to current V-22s VSLED system. The proposed approach adds "local" damage discovery at the point and time of its inception by measuring changes in the character of ultrasonic waves; augments the "global" damage discovered from VSLED's vibration monitoring; is compatible with other software systems. Our plan for Phase II and commercialization of this approach will be further addressed.

award_title: Integrated Hybrid Structural Health Monitoring (SHM) System
research_keywords: Load Monitoring,structural health monitoring,sensor network,damage detection,onboard system,Fiber-Optic,Piezoelectric,diagnostic hardware
abstract: Structural health monitoring (SHM) is a new technology in the aerospace industrial environment and is increasingly being evaluated by the industry as a possible method to improve the safety and reliability of structures and thereby reduce their operational cost. Effective SHM systems must possess the ability to detect and track structural damage as well as monitor the actual environment and loading conditions the structure experiences. Current SHM systems utilize PZT actuators and fiber optic (FO) sensors separately to provide this information. In this program, Acellent Technologies Inc. in collaboration Intelligent Fiber Optic Systems Corporation (IFOS) proposes the development of an integrated system approach for a hybrid SHM system consisting of a hybrid PZTFO sensor network, monolithic connector for both sensor types, and data acquisition hardware/software integrated into a single unit that will take advantage of any commonality in electronic components. The proposed hybrid Genielight system will be easy-to-install and use onboard an aircraft and will have a single low-weight, small form factor hybrid diagnostic hardware and software system. Phase I will focus on developing the system architecture and establishing feasibility. The program is fully supported by partners including - The Boeing Company and Bell Helicopter.

award_title: Radar Waveform Diversity
research_keywords: Radar,Communications,electronic warfare,waveform diversity
abstract: SAZE Technologies will investigate multiple hardware and software techniques, both state of the art and new, to determine which combination will produce the most effective multi-mode radar, communications and electronic warfare system. The most promising combination of techniques will be molded into a preliminary system design and its performance for the different missions analyzed. The application of the techniques to existing radar systems will also analyzed. In the Phase 1 option SAZE will perform experiments to demonstrate critical function of the new techniques thereby attaining Technology Readiness Level 3, setting up for success in Phase 2. Working with the major DoD radar, communications and electronic warfare suppliers SAZE Technologies will have the techniques ready for insertion into the NG-FIRES program during its prototype design phase currently scheduled for 2019. SAZE has identified other transition opportunities as well.

award_title: Hybrid Integrated Structural Integrity Monitoring System
research_keywords: damage detection,structural health monitoring,VSLED,Fiber optic sensor,Load Monitoring,Piezoelectric
abstract: To address the Navys need for an integrated hybrid structural health monitoring (SHM) system, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a new Hybrid Integrated Structural Integrity Monitoring (HISIM) System. It is based on excitation of aircraft structures using piezoelectric (PZT) actuators and detection of the structural responses using novel fiber optic (FO) sensors. Specifically, the innovation in use of novel miniature PZT actuators, unique FO sensor designs, and a commercial modular signal-conditioner-based integrated data acquisition and control unit, will enable the HISIM to accurately detect structural damage. Therefore, this system offers high accuracy, broadband frequency response for detection of both static and dynamic structural response, no crosstalk between sensors, low signal attenuation for transmission across the entire platform, small size and weight, and no structural degradation after placement, which directly address the V-22 platform requirements for an integrated hybrid SHM system. In Phase I, POC will demonstrate the feasibility of HISIM by using a PZT/FO sensor network to monitor loads and detect damage on simulated structural components, reaching TRL-3. In Phase II, POC plans to develop a complete hybrid SHM system prototype and demonstrate the system's structural monitoring capabilities on representative V-22 structural components, reaching TRL-4 to -5.

award_title: Robotic Following using Deep Learning
research_keywords: machine learning,Neural networks,LSTM,reinforcement learning,driving simulators,autonomous control,robotic following
abstract: Toyon Research Corp. proposes to develop neural-network-based algorithms for the autonomous control of a vehicle, to follow a leader vehicle driven by a human. Traditional methods are rule-based, requiring responses to be explicitly programmed for each state encountered by the vehicle. However, such methods perform poorly when the vehicle encounters a new state, a disadvantage our approach will address. Taking a deep learning approach, by training the neural networks with a large corpus of data, the follower vehicle will be able to learn to respond a wide range of scenarios, even those it has never encountered before. A combination of Convolutional and Recurrent neural network architectures is proposed, to combine the spatial feature extraction capability of the former, and the ability to learn long-term temporal relationships of the latter. To allow further training of the neural network, state-of-the-art Reinforcement Learning algorithms will be investigated to allow unsupervised training of the networks. By allowing a limited degree of freedom to the follower vehicle, it can explore the environment and build further knowledge of the environment and the task, improving performance. Through the deployment of these algorithms on driving simulators, the neural networks can be trained for a large number of driving

award_title: All Solid-State Batteries for Navy Applications
research_keywords: All-solid-state battery,lithium metal anode,include high gravimetric and volumetric energy density,drop-in cathode replacement,lithium-ion batteries
abstract: There is growing interest in lithium ion aircraft batteries for military aircraft as a means to achieve substantial savings in weight and maintenance costs. However, the potential gains of lithium-ion battery technologies are largely limited due to safety hazards associated with the organic liquid electrolytes, which are flammable, volatile and corrosive. There is thus a significant need to develop lithium-ion capabilities without compromising safety for both military and civilian aircraft applications. Through the proposed research, Lionano will seek to develop a solid-state lithium ion battery to provide this capability. Lionano technology has the potential to greatly impact the military aviation sector, as well as the commercial aviation industry, through the development of a safe, light weight lithium-ion battery which increases operating ranges and decreases fuel costs.

award_title: All Solid-State Batteries for Navy Applications
research_keywords: Solid State Electrolyte,Solid State Battery,safety,electrodes,Liquid Electrolyte
abstract: All solid-state battery (ASSB) is one of the most promising next-generation battery technologies that is expected to offer significantly enhanced safety and energy density, and that however requires more advanced conductive solid electrolytes. In this SBIR project, by leveraging our recent investigations, Bioenno Tech proposes to develop a new ASSB based on a novel class of Li-S solid electrolyte with high ionic conductivity and the associated nanostructured electrodes with high specific capacities along with good ionic/electronic conductivities. Using this class of electrolyte along with the associated cathode and anode that can be processed with a cost-effective, scalable route, the issues of electrolyte/electrodes interfacial contact in the Li-S ASSB cell can be effectively addressed, leading to more desirable battery performance, including enhanced energy/power densities, improved cyclability, excellent safety, and potentially low costs. Phase I will focus on the feasibility demonstration of proposed technology, through material design, processing, prototyping and characterizations. A full scale Li-S ASSB cell will be prototyped and demonstrated. In the subsequent Phase II, further optimization, scaling up and characterizations will be carried out for both material design/processing, and the cell fabrication, which will pave the way to the successful development of a commercially viable Li-S ASSB product.

award_title: Multilayer Lithium-Ion All Solid State Battery (MLI-ASSB)
research_keywords: columnar-structure,electrical-testing,mechanical-testing,glass-ceramic electrolyte,functional layers,dense-structure,magnetron-sputtering,Solid-state battery
abstract: The U.S. Navy requires reliable all solid-state batteries (ASSB) that have solid state electrolytes to enhance the safety and performance of batteries used in its naval aircraft fleet. NanoCoatings, Inc. (NCI), along with South Dakota School of Mines (SDSMT) propose to use magnetron sputtering physical vapor deposition (MS PVD) to fabricate a novel multilayer ASSB architecture which will have tailored structures to accommodate lithiation/delithiation and enhance the contact resistance between the layers. By adjustment of MS-PVD parameters-tailored structures, such as dense for electrolyte and columnar for the intermediate functional layers fabricated with a novel glass-ceramic electrolyte, the mechanical integrity and required performance during ASSB cycling will be achieved. In the Phase I Base, separate anode and cathode structures with functional layers and solid-electrolyte layers will be fabricated for assembly into a battery cell. In the Phase I Option, a layer-by-layer complete battery cell will be fabricated by MS-PVD. SDSMT will fabricate the sputter targets for MS-PVD and perform detailed material and cell testing and evaluations which will include structural integrity (adhesion) and cell-performance evaluations, such as internal resistance, current-voltage behavior, discharge rate, and heat-generation. During the Phase I-Option NCI will develop a draft Materials and Process specification.

award_title: Practical All Solid-State (PASS) Li-Ion Batteries (LIB)
research_keywords: Solid-state battery,Battery,Solid Electrolyte,safety,Lithium-ion battery,Stability,Electrode,Interfacial Conductivity
abstract: All solid-state batteries can offer increased energy and improved safety for naval aircraft applications. Recently, the ionic conductivity of solid electrolytes has improved significantly. Current solid-state batteries however, still suffer from low power and short cycle life, especially at low temperatures, due to poor interfacial conductivity and stability between solid electrolytes and electrode materials. Lynntech proposes to develop a practical all solid-state (PASS) lithium-ion battery (LIB) based on the combination of core-shell electrode materials and high conductivity solid electrolytes to provide high energy and power, long cycle life, as well as functionality over a wide operating temperature range. During Phase I, Lynntech will develop advanced core-shell electrodes with highly conductive solid electrolytes, and evaluate the capacity, rate capability, cycle life, specific energy, and specific power of an all solid-state battery at the full cell level. A preliminary safety evaluation will also be performed. During Phase II, Lynntech will develop a prototype PASS LIB system to meet the Navys performance requirements. Lynntech will also perform a preliminary cost estimate for battery manufacturing and demonstrate the manufacturing feasibility.

award_title: A Superior All Solid State Battery Based on Highly Conductive Solid Polymer Electrolyte
research_keywords: safety,all solid state battery,Solid Polymer Electrolyte,High Energy Density
abstract: Conventional Li-ion batteries (LIBs) have significant safety problems due to the flammable organic solvent electrolytes. An all-solid-state lithium battery (ASSB) utilizing a solvent-free solid electrolyte (SE) can potentially address the above issues. Storagenergy Technologies Inc. (STI) proposes a superior ASSB based on a highly conductive solid polymer electrolyte (SPE). The goal of this Phase I project is to integrate the novel SPE with novel battery manufacture technique to demonstrate the feasibility of ASSB. During the Phase II, the electrodes, solid membrane, and fabrication process will be optimized further. The target of Phase II project is to develop an advanced ASSB, with the following features: high energy density (>250 Wh/kg), high power density (>1500 W/kg) with high chemical and electrochemical stability, low self-discharge rate and good thermal stability.

award_title: Ultrathin High Temperature Multifunctional Coaxial Wire Insulation
research_keywords: advanced materials,2D materials,nanocomposites,Wire Insulation
abstract: This SBIR project will develop a novel experimental protocol utilizing the fundamentals of materials science, chemistry, nano-engineering, and automation to create a first-of-its-kind two-dimensional (2D) thin-film coaxial wire construction with remarkable lightweight, strength, high-temperature, and anti-oxidation properties. Capitalizing on our preliminary results, the core fabrication leverages the unique exotic properties (e.g., unprecedented dielectrics, ultra-light stacks, exceptional mechanical properties) of the emerging 2D materials followed by strategic integrations with existing technologies, enabling merger of structures and materials in wire insulations. Key unique features of our product are 1) super-high temperature tolerance and anti-oxidation resistant, 2) superior properties of lightweight, strength and toughness, 3) nanofabrication precision over wire alignment and assembly, 4) natural integration to the existing manufacturing facilities, and 5) low-cost.The project outcomes will lead to a major proof-of-concept multifunctional wire insulation with great potential for massive scale-up in Phase II-III. Broadly, this project will open up an entirely new phase space for multiscale engineering of novel wire insulation materials with a wide range of applications in defense and commercial industry. C-Cretes experience in projects with similar complexity along with our collective state-of-the-art facilities/equipment as well as our key relationships with industry (Lockheed Martin, GE Aviation) will catalyze commercialization efforts.

award_title: Lightweight and ultra-conducting copper composite conductors
research_keywords: Composite,Lightweight,Graphene,Electrical Conductivity,interface,Wettability
abstract: The solicitation asks for lightweight wiring products as a replacement for traditional copper (Cu) based wiring for application in Next Generation Combat Vehicle Electrical Power Architecture (NGCVEPA). Carbon nanotube or graphene based materials and their composites with copper conductors are the most promising alternatives to achieve these objectives. While promising results have been shown with such materials in small lab scale samples, realizing this potential on practical scale wiring product has not been accomplished. The key roadblocks are the inefficient interface between the nanocarbon and the metal in the composite and practical bulk scale methods to address this problem. Lynntech proposes to develop graphene-copper composite conductor material with improved interface by addressing the fundamental limitations of the charge transfer process at the graphene-metal interface. In addition, Lynntech targets to develop scalable and economic approach for the composite fabrication process. The Phase I will provide feasibility to achieve >25% improvements in mass specific conductivity over the metal conductor in a wide temperature range up to 150C by demonstrating the concept in a lab scale process. The Phase II will focus on scale up of the process with a detail evaluation of mechanical and electrical properties for the military application.

award_title: Light Weight-High Strength Electrical Cables for Military Applications
research_keywords: wires,CNT,Carbon nanotubes,Copper composites
abstract: To develop, demonstrate, build and characterize several different gauge size cables which will be capable of increase current carrying capacity as compared to a standard copper electrical power cable of similar gauge size. These strands and cables will have the potential for significant weight and size reductions, as well as strength improvements for power cables across the military, industrial, and commercial markets. Electrical conductors are key components of just about every power device or system. However, increasing demands for power and data pushes the need for more capacity, and the total contribution of electrical conductor weight to the system has become significant in aircraft, ships, rail, automobiles and the warfighter. In this Phase I and eventual Phase II we propose the development for carbon nanotube (CNT) /Cu current carrying composite cables, in terms of improving their electrical properties, thermal properties, and tensile properties. We will focus on CNT yarns that are plated with Cu and insulated; on the properties of conductivity, ampacity (maximum current which can be carried); thermal conductivity; and mass normalized values. These strands and cables will be insulated and characterized. It will also be necessary to consider other aspects, including strength, scalability, affordability, and manufacturing processes.

award_title: High Temperature, Wet-Dielectric, and Flexible Wire Insulation
research_keywords: High Temperature,flexible,Wire Insulation,glass fiber,Abrasion resistant,Lightweight,Wet-dielectric,inexpensive
abstract: In this SBIR Phase I project, Advanced Cooling Technologies, Inc. (ACT) proposes to develop a flexible, lightweight, low cost, high electrical resistivity, abrasion resistant, erosion resistant, and wet-dielectric wire insulation for continuous operations at high temperatures exceeding 425C, for use in Navy aircraft applications. Continuous exposure of an engine wiring harness to harsh environmental conditions such as moisture, heat, vibration, and chemical contamination may result in insulation degradation and possible wire failure. Currently, glass fibers impregnated with polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) are widely used for wire insulation. However, the relatively low upper temperatures of PTFE (260 C) limits its applicability for use at high temperature. In this SBIR proposal, ACT proposes to develop high performance wire insulations with specific advantages as listed below:Ability to handle high temperatures exceeding 425CDurable wet-dielectricHighly flexibleResistance is much larger than 100 Mega-ohmsHighly abrasion resistant Excellent erosion protectiveLightweightInexpensive

award_title: High Temperature, High Performance Wire Insulation (16-RD-888)
research_keywords: electrical wiring,High Temperature,Engine bay,humidity,Insulation,Key performance parameters (KPP)
abstract: In this Phase I SBIR program, UES, Inc. in collaboration with the University of Dayton Research Institute plans to develop high temperature wire insulation. The relevant characteristics of the insulating materials with and without conductor will be evaluated under simulated atmosphere to demonstrate their feasibility as high temperature insulation meeting the required key performance parameters.

award_title: Automated Tuning and Calibration of By-Wire Vehicles for Automated Driving Functions
research_keywords: State estimation,UNMANNED GROUND VEHICLES,Mobility,off-road,Autonomy,Convoy,Leader-Follower
abstract: Actuation tuning and sensor calibration are essential procedures required to obtain expected and desired behavior from an optionally-manned platform. Unfortunately, these tasks often require custom and brittle procedures which are time consuming and difficult to conduct outside of a controlled environment with special-purpose test equipment. Furthermore, many of these procedures require routine re-tuning and re-calibration by dedicated personnel due to disturbances in sensor mounting locations, general wear on vehicle components, environmental variations, and replacement of parts due to failure or damage. To streamline the process of tuning and calibration, we propose a method of automatically determining actuation parameters, sensor calibration, and vehicle models. This effort will leverage our prior work on the ONR Code 30 Autonomy program, and in Phase I will focus on further developing the capability of automatic vehicle model parameter discovery, extending algorithms to support sensor self-calibration, and evaluating performance of the prototype in a benchtop environment with both simulated data and data from an unmanned ground vehicle. Upon demonstration of viability, in Phase II we plan to transition and optimize our process to run on-line, allowing for real-time adaptation of the models to changing vehicle and terrain conditions.

award_title: A Novel System for On-Site Structural Restoration Methods for Aircraft Components
research_keywords: Aircraft,titanium,repair,Structure,Helicopter
abstract: Navy aircraft components require constant repair of minor nicks, dings, and dents due to damage from field operations. Although the damage appears to be minor, these components may no longer meet design specifications and need to be scrapped, increasing downtime of the asset. Thus, there is a critical need to develop a repair technology that will restore both the dimensions and the pre-damage strength of the component, particularly for Ti-6Al-4V components on the H-1 and other Light/Attack Helicopters. Our novel solution is our handheld Compact Repair System (CRS). We have adapted a conventional solid state welding process currently used for large-scale manufacturing (conventional friction stir welding) and miniaturized the technology to facilitate the repair of minor damage. Our CRS is ideally suited to portable systems for the repair of minor damage. During the Phase I project, we will assemble the CRS, complete repair testing on relevant materials, design the prototype for aircraft repair, and demonstrate that the strength of the repaired parts (mechanical and fatigue) meet or exceed the baseline. During Phase II, we will complete the system design, fabrication, and testing and transition the technology to the Navy fleet.

award_title: Onsite Structural Restoration Methods for Aircraft Components
research_keywords: Directed energy blown powder process,Closed Loop Control,integrated modeling,dimensional tolerance,strength capability,adaptive dwell,mitigate defects,mitigate overbuild
abstract: The research objective of this proposal is to demonstrate feasibility of restoring the dimensional and structural capability of a notional damaged Ti-6Al-4V turbine blade using a combination of pulsed and continuous wave (CW) laser directed energy blown powder processes. The repair will be designed using physics-based, integrated process-structure-performance models instead of trial and error. The integrated models will be utilized in order to demonstrate feasibility of four metrics of repair design: (1) To maintain dimensional tolerance using the laser in a pulsed mode to attain rapid solidification of the melt pool for contour passes adjacent to the boundary; (2) To utilize location dependent application of the laser energy in order to mitigate overbuild and substrate melt-back around radii, curvature, edges, corners and overhang; (3) To mitigate build defects (porosity, lack of fusion, cracking) within interior tracks, contour tracks and at oblique intersections between interior tracks and contour tracks; (4) To utilize predictive models for material microstructure and yield strength in order to restore the strength capability for the damaged component.

award_title: Onsite Structural Restoration Methods for Aircraft Components (16-RD-887)
research_keywords: repair,Onsite Repair,Ti-6Al-4V Aircraft components,dimensional restoration,Damage
abstract: During the service life of an aircraft component it may get damaged due to a variety of events such as particle impact, wear, corrosion and thermal cycling induced fatigue. Besides service induced damage, the components may also get damaged during maintenance, and/or during component installation/removal/handling/inspection. Current repair process involves blending away the damages until the surface is smooth. However, this process has the drawback of leaving the repaired component with a lower thickness at the repair location which in turn reduces the ability for future repair as well as effect close tolerance component operation applications. In the Phase I SBIR program, UES, Inc. in collaboration with The Pennsylvania State University proposes to develop and demonstrate the feasibility of an innovative additive process to repair and restore damaged Ti-6Al-4V aircraft components. The proposed technique will also have the capability for onsite component repair and restoration.

award_title: Sealed High Power Density Electric Motors for Unmanned Aerial Systems
research_keywords: Electric motor,electrostatic,Capacitive,UAS,Dielectric,torque density,plastic
abstract: C-Motive is developing a new type of electrostatic motor for Unmanned Aerial Systems that is completely sealed against contamination, overcomes the limitations of both electromagnetic and classical vacuum-based electrostatic motors, and offers the same level of performance as rare earth permanent magnet motors without using any rare earth materials. This new electrostatic motor uses recently developed dielectric materials to produce high levels of torque at useful direct-drive speeds, with high energy efficiency. Furthermore, electrostatic motors are lightweight and inherently liquid cooled, yielding a propulsion system that is simultaneously robust against overheating and ideal for use in harsh environments including sand, humidity, and salt spray. The proposed project will determine the feasibility of this electrostatic motor for UAS applications.

award_title: Hardware Open Systems Technologies (HOST) Conformance Tool
research_keywords: Conformance,model,Face,VPX,AWESUM,Host,VITA,OpenVPX
abstract: Tucson Embedded Systems, Inc. (TES) proposes a novel approach to the Navy SBIR 2016.2Topic N162-086 Hardware Open Systems Technologies (HOST) Conformance Tool that reduces risk by building upon our existing proven toolset architecture and by using key personnel that have considerable experience in standards conformance, model based engineering, conformance verification tools, architecture development, and a professional stake in the advancement of the HOST Standard. HOST Conformance is defined as 100 percent compliance with all HOST requirements and identifies two products to be verified for conformance: Tier 3 Specifications and products developed to those specifications. TES understands and has been involved in the detailed conformance needs of conformance and has significant lessons learned that can be applied to HOST conformance process and tooling. As such, our response mitigates risk and increases feasibility and success by exposing, analyzing, documenting, and resolving the needs of the HOST component developers and military purchasers. Feasibility is further increased by leveraging the AWESUM Architecture. TES is committing to this project resources with significant and varying interest and experience in FACE Verification Authority conformance, hardware verification, National Instruments LabView, OpenVPX (VITA 65) standard, model-based engineering, real-time embedded systems and tool development, and the FACE Technical

award_title: Layerwise Laser Scanning for AM of Aluminum Alloys
research_keywords: additive manufacturing,Closed-loop feedback,layer wise laser scanning,in situ metrology
abstract: The next generation of additive manufacturing systems will incorporate feedback mechanisms for tightly controlling the process parameters during the build.The AIM(TM) in situ synchronization and metrology system developed by Grale Technologies is an ideal platform for exploring possible feedback paradigms, including sensor types and configurations, real-time software and firmware pipelines, advanced algorithms, and operational performance for various materials, including multi-material builds.We propose adding an AIM(TM) system with metrology and vision sensors to a 3DSystems ProX 320 machine and developing techniques to supply immediate feedback in order to maintain tight tolerances during the build process, detect possible defects, and provide correction information for recovering from such defects.Due to the inherent synergies between these two commercially available technologies, assembling a combination AIM + ProX320 test bed has low technical risk, low incremental cost, and provides a flexible platform that supports multiple options for in situ metrology and process monitoring/feedback for AM builds.

award_title: Hardware Open Systems Technologies (HOST) Conformance Tool
research_keywords: Host,Tier 1,Automated testing,Conformance,Tier 2
abstract: The HOST Automated Conformance Tool (HAC-T) is a tool that has the ability to verify the conformance of modules and chassis. The HOST standard is being formalized and the expectation is there will be an influx of HOST chassis and modules that are destined for the United States Navy (USN) Fleet. The HAC-T provides a means of verifying HOST conformance to the HOST Tier 1 and Tier 2 standards in an automated fashion. This allows the USN to build a catalog of known HOST conformant equipment that can be used within the fleet as necessary.

award_title: Hardware Open Systems Technologies (HOST) Conformance Tool
research_keywords: Hardware Open System Technologies (HOST),HOST automated test software,Interoperability,HOST conformance test automation,HOST conformance tool,OpenVPX Core Technology Standards
abstract: This project proposes the innovative development of HOST-based test modules, both physical and logical, using automated test software that will rapidly and accurately test candidate components for conformance to HOST standards in form, fit, and function. The Phase I project will determine the feasibility of automating the testing of HOST requirements. It will also define the requirements and architecture for the conformance test tool. If approved, the Phase II project would address the implementation and testing of the conformance tool capabilities. Once implemented, this project would provide the basis for a HOST certification and accreditation authority for the administration of HOST standards, which will also allow significant improvements in the development and interoperability of modern, modular components. This initiative will evaluate the feasibility and define the requirements and architecture, which are necessary to develop the conformance tool. This conformance tool development will draw upon, and employ industry standard, state-of-the-art, engineering best practices. When completed, the tool will validate HOST-conformant COTS components (e.g. General Processing, I/O Processing, Image Processing, Data Storage, and Power Supply architecture segments). HOST conformance test automation will result in a supply of robust components that will enhance current weapon systems longevity at reduced cost and implementation times.

award_title: Hardware Open Systems Technologies (HOST) Hardware Integration Tool Set
research_keywords: OpenVPX,Avionics,Face,multiphysics simulation,Host,design space,system synthesis,model-based systems engineering
abstract: The Hardware Open Systems Technologies (HOST) standard exists to reduce the dependency of system implementations on the details of specific hardware choices, abstracting away these details behind a structured set of logical architecture and interfaces. Successfully configuring of a HOST chassis can be a complex task, requiring many decisions on logical configuration, hardware, interfaces, power systems, and physical layout, the result of which must satisfy many complex constraints. The target system supply sufficient hardware resources such as network/communications, graphics, storage, etc. necessary to execute the application modules required. It must also obey power, thermal and performance requirements of the system, and be cost/performance optimal to meet competitive pressures. We propose to develop a model-based systems engineering tool integration tool to assist the integrator in the development and configuration of HOST conformant systems. The tool will support high-level design capture of the system in a single, consistent model, with automated capabilities for analyzing and simulating performance, physical properties (power, thermal, etc) and synthesis to automate configuration of the target system. Design space exploration tools will assist in selecting the optimal set of HOST conformant components for the target system. Prototyping and stakeholder interaction are leveraged to guide feasibility and market alignment.

award_title: Hardware Open Systems Technologies (HOST) Hardware Integration Tool Set
research_keywords: integration,Embedded Systems,metadata,Modeling,mitigation tool,Hardware Open System Technologies (HOST),Standards,Open System Architecture
abstract: Even though the Hardware Open Systems Technologies (HOST) standard was created to solve hardware component interoperability and portability problems, there are still integration challenges. Currently, system integration efforts are unique to each platform and labor intensive, and involve multi-vendor hardware combinations over a systems lifecycle. Using our expertise in modeling and simulation, software development, and gap analysis, SimVentions proposes to build an interactive, analytic tool set named HOST Hardware Integration Tool Set (HHITS). Through an interactive graphical user interface, the tool will display HOST conformant components, identify potential integration issues, and mitigate any issues by searching for available alternative components based on user specified parameters. HHITS will also offer a HOST component metadata repository that supports the creation, storage, and search capabilities of available assets.

award_title: Hardware Open Systems Technologies (HOST) Hardware Integration Tool Set
research_keywords: UPGRADABLE,scalable,modeling and simulation of HOST system configurations,sustainable,interoperable,HOST Integration Tool Set,Hardware Open System Technologies (HOST),OpenVPX Core Technology Standards
abstract: This Phase I project will determine the feasibility of automating the integration testing and analysis of system-level compliance with HOST standards within the 6U and 3U OpenVPX architecture domains. It will also define the requirements and architecture for a HOST Integration Tool Set that can assist developers in modeling and simulating mission system configurations and functions in order to more effectively integrate systems and select optimal configurations for mission-specific deployment. If approved, Phase II will address the implementation, test, and delivery of the Tool Set prototype. The objective of this initiative is to develop a set of integration test tools, which will support vendor development and automate the verification of system-level software, hardware, and firmware conformance to HOST Standards. The innovation shall consist of a set of automated test software modules that can link to a candidate system and run complete diagnostic tests on the system to assure that its integrated functionality is conformant with HOST standards. The tool set will verify that the system is fully interoperable, scalable, upgradable, expandable, reliable, and sustainable. Specifically this initiative will develop requirements and architectures for modeling & simulating logical interfaces, environmental and mechanical performance, load distribution, and hardware component- and system-level configuration.

award_title: Rapid, Low Cost, High-quality Component Qualification Using Multi-scale, Multi-physics Analytical Toolset for the Optimization of Metal Additive Manuf
research_keywords: Performance Sensitivity,AM Product quality,Design of Experiments,Process Parameter Optimization,Thermo-mechanical model
abstract: We propose to develop an AM Process Parameter Optimizer (PPO) analytical package for AM process for a desired product performance stemming from mechanical and/or functional requirement. Our proposed PPO tool will include an inner multi-scale, multi-physics thermo-mechanical engine, and an outer sensitivity and optimization layer to provide first order input design space for the AM machine settings instead of going through a series of iterations and checks. Furthermore, PPO takes the users desired mechanical and functional requirement for a selected Selective Laser Melting (SLM) process, and provides suggested input process variables and its spread for a particular machine.The key algorithmic developments in PPO are the sensitivity and optimization modules. These will be developed from a simulation based engineering design approach but accounting for inherent variability and uncertainty. TDAs thermomechanical model will also be enhanced in this effort to deal with simulation based design approach as proposed here. Design of Experiments will be carried out to study multiple input factors and their effect on desired output properties. TDAs research partner in this effort is Mississippi State University who will conduct the experiments based on DoE.

award_title: Microstructure-Based Analytical Software Toolset for Optimizing Laser Powder Bed Fusion Processing Parameters
research_keywords: surrogate modeling,laser powder bed fusion,integrated computational advanced additive manufacturing,Data-Driven Modeling,Processing parameter optimization,Microstructure informatics
abstract: Selection of processing parameters for laser powder bed fusion of metallic alloys, such as Ti6Al4V, to satisfy particular requirements for quality characteristics (e.g. mechanical performance, dimensional accuracy, and cost) requires accurate prediction of the macro-scale effects of multi-scale, multi-physics interaction between processing, microstructure, and performance. As such, Materials Resources LLC is proposing to demonstrate a workflow for component-level optimization of AM processing parameters comprising a toolset for microstructure-based prediction of AM processing parameter-properties interactions coupling analytical, numerical, and data-driven modeling along with efficient simulation of macro-scale performance using fast surrogate models.

award_title: Rapid, Low Cost, High-quality Component Qualification Using Multi-scale, Multi-physics Analytical Toolset for the Optimization of Metal Additive Manuf
research_keywords: variability,Microstructure,multi-scale multi-physics simulation,Rapid qualification,quality metrics,residual stress,Powder bed process,Defect Distribution
abstract: The research objective of this proposal is to demonstrate feasibility of utilizing a multi-scale multi-physics analytical toolset to optimize the key process parameters of the direct metal laser sintering process (DMLS) for alloy Ti-6Al-4V and provide support for rapid qualification. The optimization is based on the concept of design requirements and quality metrics for defect distribution, residual stress, dimensional tolerances, stress relief, solidification microstructure, solid state transformations and hot isostatic pressing. Each quality metric is defined in terms of measurable goals or tolerance bounds and the optimization procedure is organized to fulfill each quality metric using analytical modeling. The analytical toolset includes the simulation of melt pool physics, residual stresses, distortion and the modeling microstructure evolution. The variability of the DMLS process is captured using a combination of discrete particle model and melt pool physics simulation. Deposition trials will be performed in order to verify that the optimized parameters comply with each quality metric.

award_title: Rapid, Low Cost, High-quality Component Qualification Using Multi-scale, Multi-physics Analytical Toolset for the Optimization of Metal Additive Manuf
research_keywords: Multi-Scale,Parameters,analytical,Microstructures,homogenization,,multi-physics,OPTIMIZATION
abstract: Additive manufacturing involves complex multi-scale and multi-physics mechanisms and phenomena but has the potential to produce low volume near net products with very little waste of raw materials. But understanding the complex physical mechanisms and interactions using today's simulation tools is too expensive.

award_title: Rapid, Low Cost, High-quality Component Qualification Using Multi-scale, Multi-physics Analytical Toolset for the Optimization of Metal Additive Manuf
research_keywords: Cost Reduction,Multi-Scale,Part Quality,Metal Additive Manufacturing,process optimization,multi-physics
abstract: Additive Manufacturing (AM) is of increasing interest for production of complex geometries and high-performance components for the DoD due to its advantage of design freedom and as-needed production capability. Components of interest to the Navy have a high standard in porosity, surface finish, mechanical properties and dimensional tolerance, etc. However, mechanical properties and part quality variability issues inherent to AM make rapid qualification of metal AM parts difficult. AM processes rely heavily on trial and error experiments for part qualification which is time and cost consuming, and without guarantee of optimized process parameters. 3DSIM is in the process of commercializing AM predictive modeling products capable of predicting thermal histories, residual stress, support structure design and part qualities such as porosity, surface finish, dimensional tolerance and distortion, etc. for metal AM processes. To address Phase I objectives, an analytical software toolset will be developed with integration of new AM part quality optimization algorithms which take into account one or several process parameters and intersection of others. 3DSIM proposes to add the capability of optimizing AM process parameters to enable rapid, low cost, high quality component qualification as the missing link for using predictive modeling in a streamlined qualification environment.

award_title: Multi-stage Shaped-charge Warheads
research_keywords: lethality,angle of spray,light armored vehicles,Shaped Charge,explosively formed projectile,MODELING AND SIMULATION,OPTIMIZATION,follow-through mechanism
abstract: Current shaped charge (SC) warheads and explosively formed penetrators (EFPs) are designed to focus large amounts of high-velocity mass on relatively small areas.While this makes possible the perforation of very thick armor, a side effect is that the warheads generally produce limited post-armor damage.This is particularly true in the case of light armored vehicles, where the penetration capabilities of SC warheads and EFPs far exceed the armor capabilities, but damage after armor perforation is limited to small, concentrated areas.The effectiveness, and value, of these warheads would be greatly improved with the development of a wider post-armor spray angle and tailored lethal effects for light armored vehicles.The initial concept design upon which this work is based derives from experiments on bi-metallic shaped charge warheads that exploited a copper liner to provide penetration, and a follow-through zirconium spray to maximize damage beyond the perforated armor.Corvid will utilize modeling and simulation coupled with material characterization data, to explore the effects of geometric design and material selection to further the initial concept design.The desired goal of this effort will be an optimized warhead that delivers the correct combination of penetration, spray angle, and lethal effects.

award_title: Multi-jet Warhead to Defeat Specialized Targets
research_keywords: Explosives,shaped charges,shaped charge liners,tandem warheads,precursor warheads,Reactive materials
abstract: This research considers innovative technologies to attack and defeat specialized targets and materiel within structures. The goal is to use high levels of explosive energy in the form of shaped charge warheads to generate high temperature environments, and to accelerate lethal fragments and jets against structures, to breach such structures and deposit lethal energy inside the interior against electronic components. To accomplish this goal, a combination of technologies is being utilized. The designs utilize shaped charges having unique liner geometries that breach structures and attack vulnerable components behind the structure. The approach takes advantage of energy release of reactive materials to deposit large amounts of energy against internal targets for their mitigation and destruction. The design incorporates a penetrating precursor warhead, and a secondary warhead so that multiple formed jets can produce dual material effects against the targets of interest. The attack mechanisms include reactive material fragmentation and reactive material liners producing shaped charge jets. This approach produces additional lethality against targets that are not only vulnerable to mechanical damage but thermal damage as well. The new warhead design has application as a new round capability for the MK19 grenade launcher system.

award_title: Munition-Delivered Non-Kinetic Effects
research_keywords: Electronic Warfare (EW),ELECTRONIC ATTACK (EA),Cyberwarfare,hardened electronics,155 mm projectile,Antenna design,artillery payloads,munition payloads
abstract: While Army munitions are typically used as an end to themselves, they can also be used as a means to deliver electronic payloads or Non-Kinetic Effects (NKE). The payloads functionality can include passively gathering intelligence, such as audio or video sensors, or for Electronic Warfare (EW) via RF effects. Many adversarial industrial, civil, and communication infrastructures are vulnerable to electronic attack and cyber intrusion, but require close proximity in order to gain access. Munition delivery of EW NKEs allows them to be deployed very close to the target. This allows the EW to take place at lower RF power levels than it would for long range attacks. This limits the sphere of influence of the device and reduces any unattended consequences to the localized area. Toyon will utilize its experience developing munition electronics and custom RF hardware and antennas to create a prototype EW NKE submunition targeting a 155 mm projectile.

award_title: Informatics Driven Discovery and Design of Deep Eutectic Solvents and Nanomaterials based Supercapacitors for Enhanced Low-temperature Performance
research_keywords: Informatics,Deep eutectic,solvents,Supercapacitor,excalibur,combat ammunition systems,
abstract: Currently available supercapacitors offer relatively low energy densities compared to other energy storage devices. One strategy to improve this situation is to use liquid electrolytes with wider electrochemical windows, high ionic conductivities, low viscosities, and low melting points that can function over a broad temperature range.Deep Eutectic Solvents (DESs) have recently been identified as a new class of ionic liquids and a potential alternative to the aqueous and organic based solvent electrolytes that are currently being used in supercapacitors. DESs are easily synthesized by simply mixing two or more inexpensive raw materials. We propose an innovative discovery and design approach for novel DESs that can be used as electrolytes in military grade supercapacitor applications. Our team will create a discovery pipeline that is built around an informatics-driven, rational research paradigm, and that will tightly couple computational (i.e., first-principles modeling, virtual high-throughput screening, big data analytics, materials informatics) and experimental (i.e., synthesis, characterization) research thrusts. This coordinated research platform will provide an interactive, real-time feedback loop, which will significantly enhance the overall development process. It allow us to rapidly and efficiently explore chemical space, gain insights into relevant structure-property relationships, and identify promising, high-value lead candidates.

award_title: Methods for Determining Threat Level and Intent of Unmanned Aerial Systems
research_keywords: Unmanned Aerial System,Neural networks,Fusion,machine learning,Deep Learning,Multi-spectral,Electronic Surveillance,Countermeasure
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Systems (UASs) poses a growing threat to our national security. Commercially available UASs can now carry explosives, and perform electronic surveillance missions with an increasing range against our military, cities, infrastructure, population and information. Swarm attacks are possible by automated drones and dirty bombs can be dropped in populated areas.Due to the ease of small UAS acquisition and modifications, it is inevitable that future attacks will be carried out by small UASs. A low SWAP-C system to search, detect, identity, track and determine intend (SDITI) of this growing threat is now necessary. We propose a low SWAP-C, man portable fusion approach leveraging the benefits of passive radar, image processing, particle filter tracking and deep learning to maximize SDITI performance and provide a comprehensive solution. In addition, multi-spectral analysis techniques will be incorporated to provide radio frequency characteristics of the UAS and controller. The fusion solution can then be used for intent and threat level assessment and to craft an effective countermeasure. We have successfully applied the above techniques individually for detection, tracking and classification on other programs and are confident that a fusion approach will provide the best low SWAP-C solution to performing SDITI against hostile UASs.

award_title: Spin Compensation for Shaped Charge Liners
research_keywords: Spin compensation,Shaped Charge,Fluted liners,jet formation,OPTIMIZATION,Wave shaping
abstract: The U.S. Army has a requirement for a shaped charge warhead that can maintain its penetration capability while spinning.The current solution, a linear fluted liner, is optimal over a narrow band of spin rates compared to the span of rates experienced by a typical spin-stabilized munition over its effective range.To increase performance on target, a solution that is effective over a larger range is desired. The goal of this effort is to evaluate the performance of multiple spin compensation methods and determine the optimal parameters for each concept to mitigate the penetration reduction due to angular momentum over a broad range of spin rates.Concepts that broaden the effective range over which the spin compensation of the munition is effective will be pursued to further maximize their performance. Corvid will achieve this through a high fidelity computational physics led design and optimization process exploring a number of spin compensation concepts/techniques.Top performing concepts will be down-selected for prototype fabrication and testing in Phase II to support implementation into a tactical configuration.

award_title: Soft-Recovery Module for Precision Artillery
research_keywords: Precision Artillery,Soft Recovery,155mm Howitzer,fuzes,Guidance and Control,ballistic testing
abstract: The development of precision artillery fires has led to the incorporation of advanced electronics, guidance and control systems, and aerodynamic control surfaces into artillery projectiles and fuzes.As part of the development process, individual components, subsystems, and full prototypes must be exposed to the extreme loads generated during gun launch.Current test methods developed by the DOD and industry do not adequately capture the full spectrum of forces an artillery projectile is subject to when it is fired. The proposed soft recovery system will enable the ammunition RDT&E community to expose developmental precision munition components to actual gun launch conditions.Components to be tested are mounted in their operational location on a specially designed 155mm projectile which is fired from a howitzer in a nearly vertical orientation.The soft recovery system deploys while the projectile is in flight and safely lands the components for post-test evaluation.The proposed system will shorten the development time of advanced munition components and substantially reduce the cost of development.

award_title: Test Hardware Module Recovery System (THMRS)
research_keywords: Test Hardware Module Recovery System,THMRS,munitions soft catch technology,155 mm Projectile Soft Catch
abstract: The THMRS concept is a late stage in-flight deployable dynamic air braking system designed to soft land nose mounted test hardware for recovery. There are several significant challenges to overcome but with proper understanding and analysis of the physics involved a successful design ultimately can be fielded. There are two developmental paths that come to the forefront, while each takes a different approach, both have excellent potential. A base deployed recovery module designed to Decelerate, Despin, Orient and Stabilize (DDO&S) a complete projectile is one concept to be considered provided a staged methodology can be successfully modeled and confirmed by simulation. It is envisioned that several soft recovery method after DDO&S is the deployment of either a deployed air bag style bomb retarder, impact airbag, ballute or customized parachute .

award_title: Hiawatha Anti-Helicopter Mine Mitigation System
research_keywords: Anti-Helicopter Mine,Anti-Aircraft Mine,mine countermeasures,Air Defense,countermine,counter-IED,Improvised Explosive Device,Radio Frequency
abstract: Anti-helicopter mines are of increasing concern for helicopter operations, particular for low-flying or landing helicopter at insertion or resupply points.In addition to anti-helicopter mines, improvised explosive devices (IEDs) and man-portable air-defense systems (MANPADS) are also proliferating and a significant threat. Nokomis will leverage its expertise in detecting, identifying, locating, and disrupting electronic subsystems including triggering devices using radio frequency (RF) emissions which has resulted in a deep knowledge base to realize solutions to mitigating mines and IEDs through a feasibility study detailing solution requirements and Concepts of Operation (CONOPS). Nokomis has developed relevant systems to detect the unintended RF emissions of electronics components used as trigger devices, control subsystems, or system payloads, gaining a thorough understanding of the characteristics of these targets as well as the exploitable content of their emissions. The approach of detecting threats through electromagnetic emissions from the threat subsystems (particularly the trigger and control components) and using electromagnetic energy to disable the electronic components has been successful at IED and EO/IR sensor detection, which has been demonstrated at stand-off distances up to 15km or more and can counter a variety of threats and will be successfully leveraged to detect anti-helicopter mines.

award_title: Fused positioning using imaging cameras and digital elevation data
research_keywords: GPS-denied,celestial navigation,INERTIAL TRACKING,altimetry,global positioning
abstract: The modernization of the US Armys fleet of combat vehicles with the Engineering Change Proposal (ECP) program provides a unique opportunity to add new mission capabilities by exploiting upgraded hardware.Aret proposes a four-stage approach, based on previously developed algorithms and techniques, which takes advantage of onboard sensors, databases, and processors to provide a robust estimate of global position without requiring GPS data.The concept is dubbed ASPECT: Assert Position in Environment with Celestial and Terrain Data.

award_title: Fast Image Enhancement via Real-time Capable Encoding (FIERCE)
research_keywords: image enhancement,visually degraded environments,real time,ground transport,OPTIMIZATION,Image Quality Metrics,noise modeling
abstract: When a Warfighter navigating a vehicle is immersed in a highly degraded visual environment (HDVE), they lose the critical ability to visually observe their environment. Warfighters that encounter a HDVE typically must halt, exposing themselves to attack, risking a potentially catastrophic delay in delivery of critical supplies, or allowing adversaries to gain intelligence on the operation. To address these challenges, we propose to design and evaluate Fast Image Enhancement via Real-time Encoding (FIERCE), an image enhancement methodology that leverages robust image processing techniques and convex optimization to produce augmented imagery designed specifically so that Warfighters can safely navigate at a minimum speed of 10 m.p.h. through HDVEs.

award_title: High Definition Long Wave Infrared Spectral Camera
research_keywords: high-definition,Hyperspectral,Multispectral,chemical,Infrared,MWIR,LWIR
abstract: A program to develop a High-definition, Long-wave Infrared hyperspectral imager (HiLI) is proposed.The proposed effort builds upon Surface Optics real-time hyperspectral imaging activities, including our work in MWIR and LWIR spectral imaging technology and our MIDIS hyperspectral image processor.Providing at least 1024 x 1024 spatial resolution with at least 128 bands from 8 um to 13 um, the system is ideal for identifying and tracking various targets, including chemicals of interest to modern warfare.Through a series of trade studies and preliminary design, the proposed program will develop and analyze an optimized design for a high-definition infrared hyperspectral imager; the system will include a rugged LWIR hyperspectral imager plus the real-time hyperspectral (HS) data processor.The proposed effort represents an extension of Surface Optics 25 years experience in hyperspectral imager design, and miniaturization of SOCs patented real-time hyperspectral image processor for real-time hyperspectral discrimination.By building on Surface Optics Corporations experience in hyperspectral imaging system development, sensor development, and algorithm development, the proposed program will produce a new high-definition LWIR hyperspectral imager of unsurpassed capability.

award_title: HIGH DEFINITION LACHI SENSOR
research_keywords: Hyperspectral,Compact,Spectrometer,Sensor,High definition,IMAGER
abstract: The primary goal of this Phase I effort is to investigate, develop, and characterize a new class of high performance, large spatial coverage (high definition), compact LWIR hyperspectral imaging sensors enabled by a high throughput refractive relay design form.The optical properties of these systems, including light gathering capability, spatial resolution, optical distortion, as well as other system parameters will be modeled and characterized, and estimates of performance metrics such as NESR will be predicted, and tradeoffs between data collection rates and performance will be evaluated.

award_title: Digital In-Pixel Uncooled LWIR Bolometer Camera
research_keywords: Digital ROIC,DROIC,Readout integrated circuit,uncooled LWIR,Bolometer,thermal,Infrared,mixed mode
abstract: Bolometer arrays are biased and read out row-by-row, which is performance limiting as array format grows. Nu-Treks digital bolometer features a digital pixel and alternative architecture that enables full frame integration and read out, low noise, large formats, and fast frame rates. The enabling innovation is a mixed mode readout integrated circuit (ROIC) architecture, implemented by 3D wafer integration. A key element of our commercialization strategy is the exploitation of expanded dual use opportunities which will be enhanced through the cost/performance attributes of our unique digital ROIC and the FPAs produced. The performance improvements will further open the application space for uncooled sensors. Nu-Trek will identify transition partners that will assure this enabling technology is made available for both commercial as well as military applications. The further development of uncooled FPAs through the development of this digital ROIC will expand the use of IR uncooled FPAs in key military as well as commercial markets. Targeted military markets due to the SWAP advantages of uncooled FPAs, will be for persistent surveillance applications, especially for small miniaturized drones, distributed aperture sensors and high definition sensors. Targeted commercial applications will be for surveillance and security installations.

award_title: Cognitive Techniques for ISR Data Fusion
research_keywords: Cognitive Processing,Multimodal Fusion,Saliency,Salient Content,VIS/VNIR imagery,thermal imagery,Full Motion Video,hyperspectral imaging
abstract: Cognitive Neuroscience models for human visual path image processing and exploitation are used to extract the salient content of candidate ISR sensor data streams.Fusion occurs at the salient object spatial, temporal, and color content correlations. An autonomous processing architecture is developed for handling multiple modalities of ISR sensors which include VIS/VNIR imagery, Thermal imagery, Full Motion Video, Hyperspectral imaging, and 3D Imaging LIDARS.

award_title: Clock-enabled High-precision Aiding of Receiver Mechanization
research_keywords: Clock aiding,GPS degraded navigation,spoofing mitigation,Interference Mitigation,software defined receiver
abstract: To fully utilize the benefits of precise and stable external oscillators under degraded GPS environments, QuNav is pleased to set forth a technological approach of Clock-enabled High-Precision Aiding of Receiver Mechanization (CHARM). In order to facilitate clock and receiver integration at a deep coupling level, CHARM uses a stable external oscillator to drive the receivers front-end. GPS measurements are then applied for clock calibration, while clock aiding is exploited to improve robustness of GPS signal and measurement processing. GPS integrity monitoring is implemented to mitigate the influence of measurement outliers on position and timing solution. Two key components of the proposed technical approach include: (i) exploitation of sub-centimeter precise GPS carrier phase measurements for clock calibration and integrity monitoring, and (ii) clock aiding for long coherent integration of GPS signals. The mechanization of CHARM will be developed and prototyped using software-defined radio capabilities that have been implemented jointly with Northrop Grumman Corporation. Phase I effort will fully develop the CHARM system mechanization and will demonstrate its technological feasibility using simulated and experimental data.

award_title: ALFRED THE BUTLER: Analytic for Federated Data (ALFRED), Tool for Human Efficiency: Behavior and Updates Tracker for Learning Expectations and Relevance (THE BUTLER)
research_keywords: User-Defined Relevance,Critical Information,machine learning,Centralized Cloud-Based Database,intelligence analysis,Information-Search Burden,Information Needs,Situational awareness
abstract: The intelligence analysts who monitor for asymmetric threats such as improvised explosive devices (IEDs) face a daunting task of information management. They must monitor data from diverse sources, repeatedly circling back for updates, always evaluating content, and aiming to identify critically relevant information when it is first available. These are painstaking processes. The cost of missing critical information is high. To reduce this burden, we propose ALFRED (Analytic for Federated Data) THE BUTLER (Tool for Human Efficiency: Behavior and Updates Tracker for Learning Expectations and Relevance). This tool minimizes the burdens of information-search and information-evaluation encountered by intelligence analysts. ALFRED THE BUTLER monitors a centralized cloud-based database and the users activities to (a) learn work patterns and data-related expectations; (b) anticipate operators information needs through learned definitions of operational-relevance and workflow state; and (c) discretely prioritize and format operator-facing messages to optimize impact and minimize disruption. As a result, ALFRED THE BUTLER facilitates the warfighters timely recognition of situationally-relevant details and activities to preempt threats and prevent casualties from asymmetric war.

award_title: Platform to Generate Advanced Filtration Function in Renal Tissue Scaffolds: A Hemodialysis Graft as Proof of Concept
research_keywords: tissue engineering,Hemodialysis,Implantable Graft,Bioartifical,Regenerative Therapy
abstract: Donor organ shortage is one of the major challenges facing medicine today.Bioengineering tissues and organ grafts of human scale offers the possibility to alleviate donor organ shortage and waitlist mortality.To date this goal has been stymied byinadequate scaffold technology and the inability of researchers and industry teams to create the micro-scale functional architecture necessary for higher level organ function.In the case of kidney tissue,to develop functions such as filtration and concentration of urine, it is necessary to design living filtration membranes with thicknesses of 1-10 micrometers.Up to this point developing architecture on this scale has been impossible.Our company has developed IP for a process to create thick hydrogel-based vascularized tissue constructs which contain vsaculature and adjacent luminal compartments separated by membranes of

award_title: Vascularization of Thick Tissue Constructs for Regenerative Medicine Applications
research_keywords: 3D,Vascular,Thick tissue,Modeling,In Vitro,perfusion
abstract: Lack of ability to develop vascularized thick tissue constructs is a major limitation for use in tissue repair and regeneration in humans. Even though tremendous advancements have been developed over the last decade, significant gaps remain in replicating the in vivo scenario. A key bottleneck, of particular relevance to thick tissues is the mass transfer limitations across the vasculature to the tissue cells, which detrimentally impacts the long term viability and functionality of the tissue constructs.In this context, we propose to develop (design, fabricate, test, and demonstrate) a novel platform for generation of vascularized thick tissue constructs that mimick the desired cell, tissue and organ architecture. During Phase I, we will demonstrate proof-of-concept using a synergistic in silico and in vitro approach to guide the development of the thick vascularized tissues. Both viability and biomarker analysis will be performed to demonstrate viable tissues. In Phase II, we will further characterize the tissue constructs by functional assays and long term maintenance. The developed constructs will be validated against in vivo data for both structural and functional responses. Finally, we will expand the system to mimic additional organs of interest. Process of FDA clearance will be initiated.

award_title: Development of Textiles to Provide Multispectural Camouflage and Concealment of Static Systems- ITAR APPLIES
research_keywords: camouflage,textile,Hyperspectral,concealment,Signature Management,lidar
abstract: Surface Optics Corporation (SOC) proposes a Phase I effort to demonstrate an improved process for multispectral camouflage development, involving extraction of objective operational reflectance and pattern profiles for camouflage fabric from hyperspectral images of local desert, woodland and urban backgrounds.Using physics based software tools designed for low observable paint development, SOC will model candidate fabric designs, then manufacture, test and deliver samples of constructed camouflage textiles meeting these objective criteria for spectrally tailored reflectance.We will also demonstrate augmented reality capability (AR) to visualize measured fabric reflectance on virtual ULCANS systems spectrally rendered in the original hyperspectral backgroundbasically a virtual field test.In parallel with technical development, thermal and lidar signature, and likely operational conformance (durability, weight, cost, non-flammability, etc.) of candidate solutions will also be assessed.

award_title: Development of a Military Hardened Expeditionary, Energy Efficient and Waterless Laundry System
research_keywords: Waterless laundry,Carbon dioxide dry clean,Carbon dioxide footprint reduction,Forward operating base laundry
abstract: Deployable military laundry systems consume large amounts of water and energy.This burden can be measured in the cost of transportation and human capital.The ECBL, CBL, and LADS utilized by Force Provider, Army Medical, and Army Quartermaster Corps exhibit water-efficiency improvements over the M-85 system to varying degrees. Commercially, modest improvements in water and energy efficiency have been made in recent years, but at a sacrifice in their ability to clean and sanitize field laundry to acceptable levels. Expending additional efforts to further improve this type of equipment must therefore be questioned.This SBIR Phase I project seeks to make a quantum leap in water and energy reduction by developing a laundry system utilizing CO2 dry cleaning.This will include harnessing carbon dioxide (CO2) from sources available in theater, or if necessary generating CO2.Since both CO2 dry cleaning and CO2 recovery technologies are a known art, Guild Associates believes we have the understanding and experience to transition these technologies into deployable systems capable of meeting the climatic, transportability, and interoperability requirements needed to support the Force Provider, Medical Corps, and Quartermaster missions.

award_title: Development of a Military Hardened Expeditionary, Energy Efficient and Waterless/Low-Flow Laundry System
research_keywords: Advanced Oxidation Process,Ozone Laundry,Ultrasonication,Water Recycle
abstract: A reduced water flow/low energy consumption laundry system is proposed. The system will use advanced oxidation processing (AOP) coupled with ultrasound assisted conventional laundering. The design will permit disinfection in cold water washing with corresponding energy savings. It will also include a recycled system to reuse 80% of the water. The system will be designed to be self contained and fit within the interior volume of a TRICON container.Additionally, the final design will present an easy to use and flexible interface for the warfighter stationed at remote and resource-constrained basecamps.
