award_title: Lightweight Thin-film Solar Cell with Periodic Optical Nanostructure
research_keywords: Thin silicon,High efficiency,flexible,high specific power,Lightweight,periodic optical nanostructure
abstract: AmberWave, Inc. has developed a method to laminate an ultra-thin (18 microns) monocrystalline Si layer to a conductive and fracture-resistant supporting layer such as a thin steel alloy foil. With this UTSi (Ultra-Thin Si) technology we have integrated front and rear cell processes based on the world-record PERL (Passivated Emitter Rear Locally diffused) silicon solar cell design, and have demonstrated efficiency of nearly 17% .Under the proposed SBIR Phase I project we will integrate a periodic array of metallic nanophotonic light trapping structures into the rear of our solar cell, to demonstrate enhanced light trapping in a 10 micron Si absorber layer.Phase I targets will be to demonstrate at least 12 watts/square foot, and 50 watts/pound, for unencapsulated UTSi solar cells with area of at least 2.5 square inches.In addition we will show a pathway to solar blankets capable of 16 watts/square foot and over 35 watts/pound, utilizing our UTSi solar cells with nanophotonic light trapping.

award_title: Light weight flexible solar cells performance enhanced with nanostructures
research_keywords: solar cells,solar sheets,solar battery chargers,solar powered UAV,Solar lap top chargers,High efficiency,Light weight,flexible
abstract: In the proposed Phase I project, MicroLink and its subcontractor, the University of Texas at Austin, will increase the integrated energy generated over an entire day by employing novel periodic optical nano patterns to optimize light propagation and absorption in epitaxial lift-off (ELO) GaAs solar cells.These nanostructures will enhance the absorption and trapping of light by minimizing surface reflectance and altering light propagation paths to increase optical absorption, particularly for longer wavelengths for which optical absorption coefficients are low.Flexible GaAs ELO solar cells employing optical nanostructures can dramatically outperform the existing II-VI based solar cells such as CIGS and CdTe, or a-Si:H.Photon recycling will be implemented by applying back surface reflectors combined with 2D dielectric gratings, which are ideal for thin ELO solar cells.The nano texturing will be incorporated using thin-film material layers typically employed as antireflection layers to ensure compatibility with existing fabrication processes.At the end of Phase I we will deliver flexible GaAs solar cells with overall energy >25W/lb.In the Phase I Option, MicroLink will develop and deliver a lightweight, high-efficiency, flexible GaAs based solar sheet for use in mobile solar power applications.

award_title: Flame Retardant Nylon 6,6
research_keywords: Nylon 66,Flame retardant,INTUMESCENCE,UL 96 V0,flame retardant Army combat uniform
abstract: Triton Systems and its partner propose two new flame retardant additives that will work synergistically in Nylon 6,6.The new flame retardants will be blended into the nylon 6,6 hot melt to produce flame retardant Nylon with a UL 94 rating of V0.Addition of the additives will not alter the melt flow properties of the Nylon 6,6.Flame tests and Mechanical tests will be performed on coupons of the FR Nylon 6,6and compared to non-FR Nylon 6,6.At the end of the Phase I program we will demonstrate the spinning of fibers and perform flame and mechanical tests on the yarn.Ultimately a Flame retardant 50/50 Nylon/Cotton (NYCO) blend fabric will be woven in order to make a comfortable, durable, low cost flame retardant Army Combat Uniform (FR-ACU).

award_title: Multi-scale Multifunctional In-situ Sensing of Strain in Parachute Cord
research_keywords: Parachute,multi-functional,Strain,Sensor,in-situ,Nylon,Composite,piezoresistive
abstract: Lynntech proposes to develop a novel nylon-nanomaterial composite yarn which will function as an in-situ multifunctional strain sensor and structural element. The yarn will have beneficial peizoresistivity properties, as well as having a modulus and yield stress similar to that of commercial nylon yarn. When used in parachute cords, the material will function as a low-profile strain sensor, while still providing the mechanical strength demonstrated by commericially available nylon yarns. Because the yarn will not have significant increase in weight and volume, relative to commercially available nylon yarn, the sensor will not adversely effect parachute function, nor require modification of packing or deployment procedures. This will allow the yarn to replace one of the core yarns in parachute cord, and provide sensing capability for laboratory and fielded parachute deployments and flights.

award_title: Mortar Technologies for Enhanced Range and Precision
research_keywords: Mortar,Propulsion,Aerodynamics,aeroballistics,pressure,forces,flight dynamics
abstract: Orbital Research, with Raytheon Missile Systems, will investigate the mortar weapon system and ammunition and provide high payoff concepts to increase the range and precision of the mortar.Through a comprehensive and multi-disciplined approach the Team will study the internal and external ballistics of each design solution and allow for down selection of those that have the highest payoff and minimal modification to heritage systems.Orbitals initial concepts include a MET sensor package that will provide up to date meteorological data (wind velocity, air density, air temperature) that will be sent to fire control to increase accuracy/precision of the mortar by up 15-20%.In addition to this, the Team will develop a muzzle velocity sensor that accurately captures launch velocities to provide updated data to the fuze subsystem.This will allow for update fire solutions to the S&A and ensure fragmentation is initiated at the most effective time, location.In addition to external sensors, the Team will study the aft section of the mortar to study how to optimize the tail boom, flash tube and mortar tube.This will result in more efficient combustion and gas dynamics, leading to better propulsion of the round out of the mortar tube.

award_title: Innovative technologies that optimize the range of mortar systems
research_keywords: mortars,Mortar Range Enhancement,Formed Fragments,Mortar Lethality,Aerodynamic Drag,Munitions Design,Multi-Functional Structures
abstract: In this proposal, several novel concepts are presented that have the objective of extending the mortar range while increasing its lethality. With the proposed concepts, the mortar range is to be increased by reducing the total mass of the shell, reducing the friction forces acting on the shell in the launch tube, and by reducing aerodynamic drag forces during the flight. The mortar precision is to be increased inducing spinning through aerodynamic forces without generating any additional drag. The proposed novel composite structure concepts would not only reduce the shell weight but would also allow for aerodynamic formed fragmentation upon detonation to significantly increase lethality. The proposed composite shell structure design also provides the capability of integrating many of the mortar components into the shell structure, such as the proposed very low power actuation devices for terminal guidance or other similar course correction actions to increase lethality. As a result, the space available inside the mortar shell for explosive charges and other components is increased, thereby providing another means of increasing lethality.

award_title: Simple Mortar Augmentation for Repeated Targeting and Enhanced Range (SMARTER)
research_keywords: Mortar,range,glide,AERODYNAMIC,Precision,targeting,Munition
abstract: Barron Associates has developed a simple, low-cost, mortar augmentation to improve range and targeting. The Phase I research will involve simulation analysis to verify the design and performance enhancements.

award_title: Application of Additive Manufacturing Technologies to Produce Entire Munitions
research_keywords: additive manufacturing,3D Printing,munitions manufacturing,40mm,production processes,integrated production,fuze manufacturing,Direct Digital Manufacturing
abstract: This effort will perform a full evaluation of the state of the art in additive manufacturing and how do you create a multimaterial supported process that is truly integrated. This involves understanding of the issues and the identification of the gaps to get to a fully printed munition. Including software that can integrate mechanical models with electrical ones. How do you integrate multimaterials into a production line that requires different feedstock formatsinks, pastes, filaments, pellets and powders and process to fabricate a fully functional munition Logistics of the design, fabrication process and materials. Market drivers of each element of the infrastructure needs to be assessed. Data management and cybersecurity of design and fabrication files will be assessed. All digital controlled processes will be evaluated.This effort will identify the what is state and compare to the desired future state generating a gap analysis in order to identify the missing hard parts and focus attention to these identified elements. The result is a recommended pilot line for printing 40mm munitions. The journey is long but it has begun and the opportunity that this program presents will change how the future of munitions will be manufactured.

award_title: Electrocatalytic Conversion of Nitrocellulose-Based Munition Propellants
research_keywords: Propellant conversion,Pulsed electrochemical processing,Electrocatalytic depolymerization,Electrocatalytic denitration
abstract: Due to their unstable chemical nature, ordnance propellants have limited shelf life. Disposal of expired propellants has been a highly visible problem recently, as exemplified by the large stockpile (over 16 million pounds) of unstable M6 Propellant discovered in 2012 at Camp Minden near Minden, LA.This stockpile is currently in the final stages of controlled, closed-burn disposal; however, conversion of this large quantity of propellant to salable biofuels and/or bioproducts would have provided much more value to the Army.More broadly, the availability of an established technology for end-of-life conversion of propellants to valuable biofuels/bioproducts would enhance the logistics workflow of the Army, as the material would become a process feedstock rather than a waste stream for disposal. In this SBIR program, Faraday and Ohio University will investigate the feasibility of pulsed FARADAYIC ElectroCatalysis for the conversion of the major components of M6 Propellant to biofuels/bioproducts. In particular, electrochemical depolymerization and denitration of the major nitrocellulose component and denitration of the minor dinitrotoluene component will be examined. Both processes have been studied in industrial and academic contexts, but an economical processing route is not currently available on a relevant scale.

award_title: Real-time Wastewater Analyzer
research_keywords: Atlas Scientific,PH,conductivity,patent,ORP,Electrochemical,Sensors,
abstract: Atlas Scientific believes that it will be 100% successful in completing this phase I SBIR.

award_title: Bayes Optimal Wastewater Classification Using Noisy Sensors
research_keywords: wastewater classification,wastewater reuse,wastewater recycle,Data Analytics,Smart control,machine learning,Data Fusion,Wastewater treatment
abstract: At the US Armys bases access to freshwater is vital, yet it often comes with a high price tag.Water supply and disposal poses a logistical challenge, and often involves costly trucking.To avoid such costs, the US Army would like to recycle as much wastewater as possible at its bases, including its smaller and more remote operations. For this reason, the US Army is interested in a wastewater classification device (WWCD) that can assist in proper wastewater management and reuse. We propose to develop a real-time WWCD that would automatically classify both treated and untreated wastewater to assist the US Army in meeting its wastewater management objectives.The sensors we propose to use will be field-deployable, robust, and inexpensive.However, they will also be inherently noisy, especially when compared to standard laboratory measurements.Our WWCD will conduct innovative point-of-device analytics to make accurate classifications, despite being given very noisy data.We will use a novel combination of techniques in machine learning, optimal decision theory, and principles of wastewater treatment to develop a classification algorithm for our WWCD, which can provide results in real-time and for a fraction of the costs associated with laboratory methods.

award_title: Wastewater Heuristic Analyzer &amp; Monitor (WHAM)
research_keywords: Wastewater,water reuse,Sensor,Control system,Gray water,analyzer,AI,WHAM
abstract: FTLs Weighted Heuristic Analyzer & Monitor (WHAM) system is a quick-connect, autonomous inline/online system that includes an integrated processor, specialized smart characterization algorithms, and associated sensors, and is deployable and supportable in forward areas with minimal maintenance, minimal consumables, and using common communication protocols.To maximize return-on-investment to the Army, WHAM requires no reagents, no specialty consumables, and will be designed to survive the shock and vibration environment of worldwide transport over rough terrain.WHAM comprises of both a retrofittable sensor system and associated algorithms that provide actionable water characterization outputs that correlate with reference methods for municipal wastewater treatment and have been verified through individual analyses by water test labs.

award_title: Chemometric Water Monitoring System
research_keywords: Water,Sensor,Greywater,recycling
abstract: Reducing water consumption and greywater disposal has huge benefits in terms of safety and cost savings. However, in order to maximize the amount of water that is recycled at an Army base, an intelligent water monitoring system is needed to ensure that water from various sources on the base is processed appropriately. Mainstream Engineering proposes to develop a chemometric model to fully describe and characterize water prior to recycling or disposal. This technology relies upon statistical methods that relate data to properties of interest. In Phase I, Mainstream will optimize the chemometric model for a variety of waste water sources including laundry, kitchen, shower and latrine. In Phase II, Mainstream will fabricate and test the monitoring system. This will ultimately result in a prototype delivered to the Army for testing within a relevant operational environment (TRL 6).

award_title: Advanced Pretreatment for Greywater Reuse
research_keywords: Grey water reuse,Greywater Recycling,gray water reuse,Advanced Pretreatment,water treatment,reverse osmosis,sustainability
abstract: Oceanit proposes to develop an advanced pretreatment for greywater (shower & laundry), prior to reverse osmosis, in an expeditionary greywater reuse system.

award_title: Low Flow Rate Energy Recovery
research_keywords: Energy recovery,reverse osmosis,Low Cost,Man-Portable,energy efficient,high recovery,seawater
abstract: This proposal utilizes a simple hydraulic energy recovery system developed under a prior Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) contract for hand-held reverse osmosis pumps for individual soldiers.This proposal will scale up this technology for use with small units consisting of multiple soldiers.This light weight device will be injection molded for low cost and to be commercial attractive and to be integrated in a system weighing less than 80 pounds.

award_title: Innovative Low Flow Rate Energy Recovery System
research_keywords: energy recovery pump,reverse osmosis,Desalinization,man portable,brine water pressure recovery
abstract: The lack of potable water is widespread. The Army has portable seawater reverse osmosis (SWRO) desalination systems, however they are bulky, truck portable, energy expensive, and too large a scale for small unit level or the individual soldier.There is a need for a small scale, man-portableSWRO units. One impediment to creating this is the energy demands for SWRO systems. Large scale systems have developed energy recovery devices to reclaim the energy in the SWRO waste, these systems do not scale down to a man portable unit. This proposal outlines an innovative method to recover the SWRO waste energy, keep the system small and light, and allow flexibility for a wide range of water conditions and outputs. Using lightweight materials and nano-composite thin film coatings to both lubricate and protect the system from high salinities we propose a small energy recovery device.The system is driven by wastewater and input seawater pressurized to RO levels with a motor that supplies the necessary power above what is recovered. The system size and weight allows for development of a man portable, adaptable, desalinization system.

award_title: Additive Friction Stir:A Portable, Fieldable Method to Repair and Join Currently Non-Weldable Aluminum Alloys
research_keywords: Al2XXX,Al7XXX,unweldable,repair,additive manufacturing,additive friction stir,Portable,Joining
abstract: Reducing vehicle weight through the usage of non-weldable alloys realizes numerous benefits for the Army - however, these materials lack feasible repair methods for in-theater use.Aeroprobes Additive Friction Stir technology (AFS) can fabricate or repair unweldable metals, yields wrought properties, is portable, and has significantly lower operating costs than other processes.

award_title: Vibration &amp; Pressure Reducing, Soldier Health Seat Cushion Padding
research_keywords: Vibration,Padding,seat,Cushion,Pressure Distribution,damping,Shock,Blast
abstract: Discomfort and fatigue from sitting within ground combat vehicles reduces mission effectiveness and endurance in the short term, while sustained vibration exposure can cause long-term health problems that diminish combat readiness, burden the health care system, and degrade the quality of life for our soldiers.A better cushion must evenly distribute pressure across the buttocks, have damping to lower transmissivity, avoid resonance within the frequency band where humans are most susceptible, and avoid degrading the spinal protection provided by seats in mine blast shock conditions.Safe has proposed a cushion design that addresses all of these needs by combining existing materials in a unique way to generate the necessary pressure, stiffness, and damping properties.Safe has described a test program that demonstrates feasibility within the Phase I Base effort using its in-house drop test capability.Safes project team includes engineers with prior experience developing and testing mine blast seat cushions and aviation seats that reduce vibration effects on people.Safes commercialization plan describes potential avenues for selling the cushion and addresses capacity for high-rate production through teaming with a strategic partner that is an established cushion manufacturer.

award_title: Optically Transparent Near-Perfect Microwave Absorber
research_keywords: meta-surfaces,metamaterials,EMI/RFI attenuation,transparent conductive coating,Microwave absorbing,Graphene,Optical coating,electronic signature control
abstract: The U.S. military systems employs many EO/IR sensors platforms to enhance targeting, situational awareness, intelligence and reconnaissance operations.EMI/RFI and electronic signature control technologies of EO/IR sensors is therefore critical for the operation of the sensors. In addition, for platforms that require stringent RCS signature control, EO/IR sensors require to be placed behind RCS-complaint optical windows. Such platforms include Navy stealth ships EO/IR windows, fixed and rotary wing aircrafts EO/IR apertures, missile dome, and directed energy weapon apertures. Additional requirements include multi waveband operation and high optical transparency from visible to the IR. Current microwave absorbers are either made of optically opaque materials or require a metallic ground plane and thus are not transparent in the optical regime.We will design, fabricate and test a novel optically transparent microwave absorber based on doped monolayer and/or multi-layer graphene. Our technical approach can be tailored to meet specific optical and microwave requirements by design and/or chemically controlling the conductivity by doping. Graphenes conductivity can be voltage-controlled given the possibility for dynamically tunable microwave absorbers. Graphene sheets can be fabricated over large areas making it possible to develop transparent microwave absorbers for large optically transparent window applications for many different military platforms.

award_title: Missile Imaging Corrector (MICOR)
research_keywords: midwave infrared,longwave infrared,MWIR,LWIR,ellipsoidal missile domes,ogive missile domes,image correction,Image processing
abstract: To meet the Army need for a cost-effective method of compensating for the optical effects of new missile dome designs on imaging sensors, Luminit, LLC, proposes to develop a new Missile Imaging Corrector (MICOR). The MICOR will implement a unique kinoform corrector plate in front of the focal plane, enabling complete correction for dome distortion even on gimbaled systems. The MICOR will be fabricated separately for each wavelength range, and will be positioned between the imaging optics and the focal plane. During Phase I we will design the kinoform, perform necessary system trade-offs, and demonstrate the corrector plate improving the image through a sample dome. At the end of Phase I the MICOR will reach technology readiness level (TRL) 3-4. In Phase II we plan to develop the kinoform into a preproduction TRL 6 prototype, designed for a single missile-dome combination.

award_title: Cluster UAS Smart Munition for Missile Deployment- &quot;Killer Bees&quot;
research_keywords: Counter-rotating,ducted fan,Unmanned Aerial System,UAS,Open Architecture,vision based targeting
abstract: Prioria Robotics proposes to pursue this opportunity with an airframe that uses a single set of counter-rotating propellers, to slow, and then lift a 3D printed body containing an avionics housing and a payload volume.This configuration keeps the major components in a straight-line, making it easier to form a cluster made up of many individual units.Crucially, this configuration also eliminates the need for mechanically deployed arms, as you would have with a traditional quad-copter design.This leads directly to a more robust end-product, which is a risk area that has been identified for missile delivered UASs.The cluster will be packaged into a sabot that will be integrated, released, and decelerated from the missile by a rocket/ballute design that has previously been demonstrated for a different application within the Army SBIR program.This deceleration is a critical element of the concept, allowing the sabot to be slowed from supersonic speeds to 10s of kts for the deployment of the UAS cluster.This cluster payload system has been dubbed, Killer Bees.

award_title: Portable Anti-UAS Device
research_keywords: UAS,UAV,Detect,counter,Radar,Jamming,Portable,tactical
abstract: To address the Armys need for a squad level system to detect and counter unmanned aircraft systems (UAS), Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a new Portable Anti-UAS Device (PAN-UAS). The system is based on a new design that combines state-of-the-art airspace monitoring technology with novel UAS countermeasure approaches packaged into a man-packable system. Specifically, the innovation in miniaturizing and ruggedizing radar detection and radio frequency (RF) jamming systems will enable the PAN-UAS system to detect and counter both individual and swarms of UASs while being self-contained in a very portable form factor. As a result, this system offers a tactical, ruggedized solution that is less than 100 in.^3, less than 3 lb, and costs less than $15k, which is appropriate for squad and platoon level operation and directly addresses the Army requirements. In Phase I, POC will theoretically demonstrate the feasibility of PAN-UAS by performing four focused trade studies coupled with select feasibility testing to reach technology readiness level (TRL)-3. In Phase II, POC plans to refine the system design and produce a fully-integrated prototype to use for live demonstration against a UAS, reaching TRL-6.

award_title: Advanced UAV and Mortar Target Detection and Tracking Algorithms for Low Signal-to-Noise Ratio and Cluttered Environments
research_keywords: Infrared Search and Track (IRST),unmanned aircraft system,Track Before Detect,counter-UAS,signal to noise ratio,Detect and Avoid,High Energy Laser,mortar detection
abstract: UtopiaCompression proposes novel machine learning based multi-scale detection algorithm coupled with a novel tracking approach using a Track Before Detect (TBD) paradigm to address the problem of problem of detecting and tracking small Unmanned Aircraft System and Mortars in a low Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR).Small UAS platforms are smaller in size, fly at lower altitudes and are slower in speed when compared to other larger air traffic. Mortars, on the other hand, move in a predictable manner, but have low SNR and small size that makes them harder to detect and track, especially against cluttered background. During Phase I, we will conduct requirements analysis to identify an appropriate Medium Wave Infrared imaging system and a suitable compute platform to support the requested data rates.We will leverage our experience in developing systems for UAS detect and avoid applications to provide a computationally feasible solution to the problem at hand. We will demonstrate the feasibility using modeling and simulation methods and by conducting our own data collection experiments. Finally, we will analyze the computational performance of our algorithm and direct our efforts in identifying suitable platforms to enable real-time detection and tracking of multiple targets in low SNR and cluttered environments.

award_title: Advanced UAV and Mortar Target Detection and Tracking Algorithms for Low Signal-to-Noise Ratio and Cluttered Environments
research_keywords: Infrared Search and Track,IRST,unmanned aerial vehicle,Mortar,detection,signal-to-noise ratio,Signal-to-clutter ratio,cloud background
abstract: Infrared search-and-track systems are common for many military applications. The maximum range of passive thermal infrared sensors (MWIR/LWIR) is reduced when targets are small (sub-pixel), low-SNR, or imaged against high-clutter backgrounds. Aret Associates proposes to leverage its demonstrated expertise in real-time, physics-based image processing and statistical faint-target tracking to improve detection and tracking of low-contrast, pixel- and sub-pixel sized targets in multi-frame MWIR imagery. In this Phase-I effort, Aret will develop and demonstrate hardware-optimized pre-processing, image enhancement, and target detection and tracking. The tracker will ultimately be deployed on custom hardware, and operate real-time on 300+ Hz-frame rate MWIR imagery. This will meet the objective of reducing the minimum detection and tracking range for small UAVs and mortars.

award_title: Reduced Cost, Weight, Size and Power Radar
research_keywords: mid-wave infrared,Reduced CWSaP Radar,unmanned,Sense,and Avoid Radar,Radar Advance Receiver Exciter,Degraded Visual Environments
abstract: CEI will develop a Reduced Cost, Weight, Size and Power (CWSaP) Radar (RCR) sensor capable of acquisition and tracking of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs), rockets, artillery, and mortars (RAM) at a max range of 5km or greater in clear air and DVEs. The proposed system will have a Field of View (FOV) and angular accuracy that would enable replacement of a passive wide-FOV MWIR sensor (>3 FOV;

award_title: Variable Pulsed Parameter Tracking Illuminator Laser
research_keywords: pulsed laser,fiber laser,illuminator laser,Er-doped laser,nanosecond laser
abstract: NP Photonics proposes to design and develop a laser source capable of producing a high energy nanosecond laser with variable parameters and short coherent length by taking advantage of our laser technologies based on highly doped glasses. Tracking illuminator lasers (TILs) have a variety of applications in weapon system engagements including target detection, target identification, pose estimation 3D LIDAR and aim point tracking.A TIL with variable pulse parameters is desired to enable a wide dynamic range of these engagements. The proposed laser source has the advantage of high compactness and reliability. In this Phase I program, we will investigate the feasibility and study the risk to develop a TIL using our highly doped glass laser technologies. A fully functional TIL source will be developed and characterized in Phase II.

award_title: Pulsed Tracking Illuminator Fiber Laser
research_keywords: fiber laser,1.55 micron fiber laser,high pulse energy fiber laser,tracking illuminator,
abstract: Current state of the art tracking Illuminator lasers are insufficient for a wide variety of expected high energy laser weapon system engagements.A tracking Illuminator laser with variable pulse parameters is desired to achieve constant radiometric conditions in the return scattered light from a target to a tracking sensor. We propose to develop a fiber laser system in the 1.55 micron spectral band capable of generating greater than 50 to 300mJ pulse energy, 5 to 50ns pulse width, 500Hz to 5kHz repetition rate, beam quality M2

award_title: Bridge Launch Technology for Ultra Lightweight Combat Vehicles
research_keywords: Lightweight,Composite,Rapid Bridge Deployment,recovery,gap crossing,high mobility
abstract: Materials Sciences Corporation (MSC) propose the development of a technology which will enable bridges to be launched and retrieved from lightweight and ultra-lightweight vehicles, thus providing them with enhanced mobility and the means to cross over gaps encountered during their missions. MSC will conduct feasibility studies, and demonstrate the applicability of the proposed bridge placement and retrieval system concept via physics-based modeling and simulation. When the system is fully operational the bridge deployment and recovery cycle times be less than 5 minutes by day and 10 minutes by night, as well as meeting requirements set out in the Trilateral Design and Test Code for Military Bridging and Gap-Crossing Equipment. The objective of Phase I effort of this work is to refine the bridge deployment and recovery mechanism design concepts, incorporating composite materials to reduce weight, and target durability and maintainability for improvements.

award_title: Integration of variable fidelity models for designing ground vehicle systems
research_keywords: MODELING AND SIMULATION,Fusion,credibility,uncertainty
abstract: nou Systems, Inc. proposes an innovative solution to design methodology and prediction of system performance for systems with inputs of differing fidelity, resolution, assumptions, and other factors.In addition to considering these factors, the solution appropriately accounts for uncertainties in the various inputs to the system, and identifies inconsistencies in inputs, and further adjusts the uncertainties based on these inconsistencies.The particular application for this SBIR is design of ground vehicle systems, and nou Systems is leveraging work done to assess the Ballistic Missile Defense System using Models and Simulations (M&S) of various fidelity and resolution.This solution will have applicability wherever M&S are used, both within DoD and commercially.

award_title: Systematic trade-off strategies for balancing survivability and mobility in vehicle design
research_keywords: set based design,survivability,Mobility,probability tree diagram
abstract: Ground Combat Vehicles (GCV) use a combination of firepower (i.e. lethality), mobility, and survivability to perform safely their expected mission.The Line of Effort 1.2 of TARDECs 30-year strategy focuses on protected mobility and in providing mission appropriate balance of survivability and mobility technologies.Diverse mission profiles must also be considered, representing peer or asymmetric enemies engaged in various battlespaces, and GCV architectures that can adapt to the continuously changing geopolitical threats are desired.A Survivability Assessment Metric (SAM) capability will be developed for providing a holistic view for the ability of a vehicle to survive an engagement.A probability tree diagram will be used for computing the SAM by representing the different phases of an engagement and depicting the possible outcomes for each phase, along with the corresponding probabilities for each of the outcomes.In this research, the SAM will be used by a Set Based Design methodology for fully exploring and morphing the design space while understanding the implications that diverse mission requirements have on the potential solutions.In this manner decision makers can avoid focusing early in a single solution that meets the requirements of a single battlespace but fails under other operating conditions.

award_title: Lightweight Durable Bridge Decking
research_keywords: Lightweight,Durable,Bridge,decking,inflatable,Air,beam,Gap
abstract: NexGen Composites has teamed up with HDT Global to develop and demonstrate a lightweight, durable and rapidly deployable bridge decking system in this SBIR project. The bridge decking is designed to interface with an inflatable air beam structure that can support the passage of a medium unmanned ground vehicle weighing up to 3,500 lbs. over a minimum of twenty-eight feet span. The decking will also be capable of bridging short gaps up to five feet span without the inflatable air beam structure. NexGen will design, build and test several prototype decks using innovative composite panel designs and rapid deployment mechanisms.

award_title: Lightweight Durable Bridge Decking
research_keywords: Core sandwich panel,bridge deck,polyurea wear coating,cored composite truss cores
abstract: The use of core sandwich structure architectures enables loads significantly larger than the weight of the core sandwich structure to be carried in bending.The core sandwich structure will be exploited to develop a lightweight, low cost durable bridge decking system to be used with an inflatable bridge.There will be three types of core sandwich structures developed in the Phase I effort.The first core sandwich structure will be the standard deck section, which will be designed to be used exclusively in conjunction with the inflatable bridge structure. The second type of core sandwich structure to be developed is the enhanced deck section which will be designed to be used either in conjunction with the inflatable bridge or separately as an independent short gap crossing bridge.The enhanced deck section will interface with the ramp in both the inflatable bridge deployment and the independent crossing mode.The ramp will be a core sandwich structure that will fold to reduce to the size of the other bridge decking components.The bridge decking sections and ramps will have integral means of connecting to each other and to the inflatable bridge structure.The travel surfaces will have a tough pliant non-skid surface.

award_title: Tailored Adhesives for High-Strain-Rate Applications
research_keywords: High Strain Rate,Joining,Adhesives,assembly,fabrication,production,engineering,
abstract: Theobjective will be to develop and evaluatean adhesive to improve the integrity and reliability of structural bonded joints to reduce the number of bolts needed for a mechanically joined component. This will increase overall performance, including blast and ballistic impact survivability and allow reduction of fasteners with subsequent savings in cost and weight.UDC will produce room temperature curable carbon nanotube reinforced adhesives and demonstrate high strain rate,improvedshear and bending bond strength relative to the currently used epoxy adhesive. Thedeveloped adhesiveswill be testedin high and low temperature and humidity environmental environment.Adhesives will be characterized for tensile and shear behavior over very high strain rates.Testing will also includeshear strength, hardness, elongation, and tensile/peel strength and crack propagation.A report with results and conclusions will be submitted

award_title: Tailored Adhesives for High-Strain-Rate Applications
research_keywords: high strain rate adhesives,ballistic adhesive,ballistic impact,construction adhesive,HIGH PERFORMANCE,engineering adhesive,lightweight adhesive
abstract: High strength adhesives have been developed by the automotive and aerospace industries that provide a light weight and cost effective alternative to metal rivets and bolts.The current commercially available adhesives fracture at high strain rates due to the rate dependent characteristics of these adhesives.Therefore, there is a pressing need for lightweight adhesives with resistance to ballistic impacts for use in the current and next generation US Army combat vehicles.TIAX proposes to demonstrate the feasibility of a lightweight adhesive formulation that performs well in high strain rate situations, such as ballistic impacts.We will leverage our extensive skills in polymer and adhesive formulation to choose the proper resin system, fillers, crosslinkers and other additives to develop an adhesive that will strongly bond metals and composites to each other, thereby lessen the need for mechanical fastening.The use of our high performance adhesive in place of heavy bolts and rivets will aid the Army in vehicle weight goals, resulting in less fuel consumption, longer travel distances, and faster vehicles.These adhesives will perform well under the harshest conditions without degradation, and will not sacrifice strength and durability for ballistic impact resistance.

award_title: Tailored Adhesives for High-Strain-Rate Applications
research_keywords: adhesive,Epoxy Blend,High Strain Rate,Ballistic,Lightweighting,multimaterial,Armor,manufacturing
abstract: Phase separating blends of epoxy and liquid polymers will be used as impact resistant adhesives.These materials feature a novel mechanism for absorbing mechanical energy that involves local movement of nano-sized strands of highly crosslinked epoxy through viscous liquid polymer domains, resulting in both shear and flow within the liquid.The mechanism is very insensitive to temperature and strain rate and will overcome the limitations of current state of the art epoxy toughening methods.

award_title: Orbital IVT for High efficiency torque multiplication for military ground vehicle transmission
research_keywords: transmission,vehicle transmission,infinitely variable transmission,Torque,torque multiplication,CVT,IVT,
abstract: The patented Lestran L.L.C. Orbital IVT is a novel automotive transmission design that harnesses the power from the centrifugal force of rotating eccentric masses to create the first Infinitely Variable Transmission (IVT) capable of scaling to large vehicle sizes. The unique design combines the high mechanical efficiency of fixed gear ratio transmissions with the high engine efficiency obtained using a Continuously Variable Transmission (CVT) in a lightweight, rugged, and high-torque package.The simple, high-efficiency design of the Lestran Orbital IVT allows the components to be sized for greater endurance and higher power while remaining smaller than competing designs. The high mechanical efficiency of the Orbital IVT eliminates hydraulic fluids and costly lubrication and cooling methods resulting in a dramatically higher maintainability and lower operating cost. The small number of parts and the straightforward parts design drive reduced manufacturing costs in both material and labor and increase reliability.The Phase I project will develop a preliminary design for a target military vehicle, validate existing physics based models, and take test data to verify major performance and efficiency claims.

award_title: Variable Speed Ratio Gear Drive System
research_keywords: CVT,fuel consumption,automatic transmission,Fuel Economy,CO2 emissions,Retrofit,JLTV vehicle platform,carbon footprint
abstract: The proposed vehicle drive system introduces new technology to the ground vehicle sector in the form of a compact and rugged continuously variable transmission (CVT) featuring power transmission through meshing gears.It device can be installed as a stand-alone transmission or retrofitted into existing vehicle platforms.The practical approach packages within existing vehicle powertrain systems with little or no modification and offers more efficient power transfer for rubber tire or track driven vehicles.No maintenance is required beyond typical automatic transmission procedures.

award_title: Linear Armor Positioner and Damper
research_keywords: Linear actuator,Armor,damping,Threat defeat,ground vehicle
abstract: To address the Army need for mechanisms to make ground vehicle armor more adaptive and better defeat threats, Physical Optics Corporation (POC) proposes to develop a new Linear Armor Positioner and Damper (LAPD).The key innovation comes from the arrangement and design of the positioning mechanism to take advantage of the damping characteristics of pneumatic/hydraulic linear actuators during a ballistic shock event.Specifically, the mechanism design reduces the severity of shock events caused by enemy weaponry through the gas/liquid compression in a linear actuator and by increasing the distance these shock events occur from the vehicle interior.As a result, LAPD meets the Army need for adaptive mechanisms to better defeat threats without imposing the significant weight burdens adding armor causes.In Phase I, POC will research and develop the LAPD design, performing stress, thermal, and fatigue analyses.In Phase II, a fully functional LAPD prototype will be manufactured and tested to a subset of applicable tests in Army specification ATDP-2404 such as transport and ground vehicle vibration and cycling, and delivered to the Army.

award_title: Field Instrumentation to measure, quantify, and characterize fuel contaminants
research_keywords: Fuel contamination,particles and bubbles,detection,optical microscopy,Light scattering
abstract: Fuel contamination can be problematic to thermal engine operation, potentially causing engine failure, which may result in the loss of equipment and/or people. The in-line monitoring system designed by our team is based on scattering and imaging methods, and can detect particulate matter and condensed water in the fuel. We propose a refinement of this system to improve detection and sizing reliability, as well as reduce the overall dimension and power consumption of the instrument. This proposal aims at investigating new imaging methodologies to extend the detection capabilities of the instrument under different particle types. Improvements in image processing routines are also planned to take advantage of the new imaging capabilities. As part of the feasibility study, experiments will be carried out to confirm the scattering calculations and assumptions necessary to extract fuel contaminants concentrations. Optional tasks include integrating the scattering methods with the imaging size distribution information toward more accurate concentration measurement and evaluating the potential of a capacitance probe to detect large water presence in the fuel stream.

award_title: Field Instrumentation to measure, quantify, and characterize fuel contaminants
research_keywords: Portable,Fuel,dynamic imaging,particle analyzer,Water,on-line,at-line,
abstract: The objective of the work detailed in this proposal is to demonstrate feasibility of using a portable, dynamic imaging device to detect solids and water contamination in military grade fuels near points of transfer from storage to vehicle. The consequences of contaminated fuel are well known and include clogging of filters, freezing of fuel lines, growth of microbials within the fuel system and the loss of vehicle performance capability. Visual capability allows the instrument to not only measure size and count of particles, but also enables them to be classified according to their shape which allows for the determination of water and gas droplets separate from solids in a fluid stream. The ability of a single instrument to detect and classify the existence of both within fuel streams as they flow can protect poor quality fuel from being transferred into vehicles. This proposal seeks to test the feasibility of the instrument in the field between the pump and fill nozzle. It also will present concepts to miniaturize the instrument to a portable size and weight and to provide a quick connect logic to allow fast hook up and detachment from the fuel line preferably without the use of tools.

award_title: Laser Target and Analysis Board Development
research_keywords: laser testing,airborne lasers,DIRCM,Infrared,Transportable,open-air ranges,laser target board
abstract: The Navy has a need for a transportable, ground-based laser target board to characterize military laser performance at operational ranges in an outdoor environment. Current laser target boards that measure laser power, divergence, and pointing accuracy are not rapidly deployable and easily transported throughout open-air military ranges. Technology Service Corporation (TSC) will leverage its twenty-plus years of experience in developing and fielding infrared test equipment used at open-air ranges for Test & Evaluation (T&E) of Missile Warning and Directional Infrared Countermeasures (DIRCM) systems to develop the Laser Target and Analysis Board (LTAB) system. In the Phase I Base program, TSC will first define the LTAB system requirements, then generate design options and evaluate them through various trade studies including cost versus performance. TSC will then develop a candidate LTAB system, and a plan to implement and demonstrate a pre-production prototype in Phase II. In the Phase I Option program, TSC will continue the development of the prototype system design, and investigate designs for measurement capabilities of additional military lasers.

award_title: Repurposed Software Programmable Radio Technology to Support Flexible Missile Uplink/Downlink Implementations
research_keywords: Software Programmable  Waveform Generation  Modulation Techniques  Solid State Amplifier  Antenna Technology,Software ProgrammableWaveform GenerationModulation TechniquesSolid State AmplifierAntenna Technology
abstract: Data links are critical subsystems in missile platforms. These communication links provide information to the interceptor in flight such as guidance, target type, and other quintessential data required for intercepting the target. Legacy data links utilize modulation techniques such as Amplitude Shift Keying (ASK) to communicate information from the ground to the missile platform. Newer systems require more complex information and are achieving higher data rates through Frequency and Phase Shift Keying (FSK and PSK) techniques. With the advent of common launcher systems for both legacy and evolving missiles technologies, the need for a reprogrammable data link system exists. This proposal addresses this need and provides a potential solution.

award_title: Air to Ground Target System for Engineering Based Airborne Electro-Optics Imaging System Performance
research_keywords: Electro-Optic Sensor Testing,airborne,Infrared Targets,modulation transfer function,Noise Equivalent Delta Temperature,Open-Air,Sensor Characterization
abstract: The Air Force has a requirement to measure the sensitivity and spatial resolution of airborne electro-optical and infrared imaging (EO/IR) sensors.  A ground-based target system is needed to provide the source to test these sensors, since the current syst

award_title: Improved Data Fusion Techniques for Space-Based Remote Sensing
research_keywords: sensor data fusion,OPIR,IR Signatures,IR/Radar Fusion,Trajectory Estimation,Tactical Parameter Estimation,IR Weather Effects,TPE
abstract: In Phase I, Technology Service Corporation (TSC) will demonstrate innovative fusion techniques used for missile and orbital parameter estimation from Overhead Persistent Infra Red (OPIR) data in conjunction with other sensor data (Radar, weather).The Fu

award_title: GMTI Radar Target Classification Using Spectral and Tracking Data
research_keywords: Target Classification,Human Vehicle Animal Clutter (HVAC) Discrimination,Foliage penetration (FOPEN) radar,UHF tower radar,Doppler spectral features,Track Features,GMTI Radar
abstract: TSC will develop Human, Vehicle, Animal and Clutter (HVAC) discrimination algorithms for use in GMTI radars by leveraging research performed on previous DARPA efforts and an ongoing Army program. TSC will focus on the challenging UHF radar problem and develop multiple-CPI processing algorithms in Phase I for application to Army airborne foliage penetration surveillance systems and ground-based UHF radar towers that are under development. TSC will utilize the UHF radar database that it collected on humans and diverse animal species for testing as well as other available radar data with the Armys permission. TSC will determine viable Doppler spectral features for reliable HVAC classification and investigate variants of Support Vector Machines and temporal and statistical processing approaches in the base effort. TSC will also develop methods of estimating the classification accuracy of the HVAC discrimination decision. Algorithm performance will be evaluated for different targets, foliage environments, wind conditions and other factors. In the option effort, TSC will investigate the use of long-term track features for HVAC discrimination and develop methods to recognize multiple targes. In Phase II, TSC will mature these algorithms, expand them to other radar bands, and validate them on collected airborne and tower radar data as available.

award_title: Low-Cost Reduced SWaP RF Sensor in Support of Tactical Weapons Engagements in DVE
research_keywords: AESA,Radar,phased array,Low-Power,low-cost,OpenVPX,T/R Module
abstract: TSC proposes a novel approach to building a low-cost, low-power AESA radar in support of tactical target cueing for Army weapons system when operating in degraded visual environments.Details of the proposed system are presented, as well as how the new technology will leverage and compliment existing mature hardware and software.

award_title: Analysis Tools for Managing Commercial Off-The-Shelf (COTS) Obsolescence
research_keywords: Open Source,SPAWAR,data analysis,Decision Support Aid,COTS Obsolescence,Information Technology,NETWORK,CANES
abstract: Product life cycles, windows available for engineering design, and warfighter platform deployment are critical program elements which dramatically affect the life cycle costs and total ownership cost of DoD systems employing elements of COTS Information Technology (IT). Integrating these elements to make an obsolescence-based program sustainment decision, in a cost-effective decision support construct, is absolutely critical to supporting deployed systems, based on Commercial Off The Shelf (COTS) technologies, at an affordable funding level. Additionally, cyber security is a key driver in the challenge of managing COTS obsolescence due to the threat that unsupported hardware and software poses to Navy networks. The overall Innovative Defense Technologies (IDT) proposed solution is to provide a highly scalable and adaptable solution, suitable for use across an enterprise, which organizes the highly complex and disparate data sources associated with COTS obsolescence into a decision-making construct.

award_title: Transition of Mission Planning Software to a Next Generation Component Based, Open Architecture using Advanced Refactoring Technology
research_keywords: Service Oriented Architecture,Advanced Refactoring,Open Architecture,Reusability,Mobile,artificial intelligence
abstract: IDTs flexible and self-healing Next-Generation Open Architecture (NGOA) will unlock the potential of the mission planning system requirements via an innovative data architecture. Artificial intelligence (AI) based machine learning systems will then be able to use this data in an evolving environment to build, optimize, and deconflict single or multi-agent mission plans in real-time. Transition of the existing mission planning code base to the NGOA will be accomplished via an advanced software refactoring approach. This approach extracts information from the existing code base to build a model-based highly automated transition plan to move the code base from the existing representation to the Next-Generation Open Architecture, enhancing the code during the transition.

award_title: Cyber Resiliency via Virtualization for Combat Systems
research_keywords: Adaptive Response,Virtualization,Redundancy,Heterogeneity,Mission assurance,Coordinated Defense,Cyber resilience,Distributive Allocation
abstract: Addressing cyber resiliency for Navy combat systems, such as AEGIS and SSDS, requires acute awareness of the impact that leveraging key cyber resiliency techniques and technologies will have on mission capabilities. The goal of cyber resiliency frameworks that support mission-critical systems are to minimize the time spent recovering and restoring a system from a cyber-attack and to maximize the time spent with full mission capabilities. In order to successfully endure, recover, and restore the system when faced with a cyber-attack, it is critical to have access to mission capability metrics as well as intimate awareness of the underlying system dependencies. IDTs experience developing a virtualized AEGIS Weapons System has resulted in key insights into how a virtual combat system can take advantage of innovative virtualization concepts and still maintain the integrity of mission-critical capabilities. The robust technology provided by IDTs ATRT suite of test and analysis tools will be a springboard for taking our innovative virtualization concepts, like Revolving Defense Attack Surface (RDAS), and wrapping that capability with Real-Time Risk Assessment (RRA) to deliver cyber resiliency enhancements that are tailored to the needs of a high-availability, mission-critical system.

award_title: Relevant Image Mosaic Image Management Algorithm Development
research_keywords: intelligent image metadata,Image storage,machine learning,automated retention/purging management decisions,optimize the holdings to a given storage limit
abstract: For all fields, especially DOD and mission planners, rapid and accurate intelligence analysis is crucial and an image exploitation system plays an important role in that activity. Currently, however, imagery exploitation systems can quickly fill their available storage, leaving the mission planner or other end users with outdated or missing information. With IDTs proposed Imagery Retention Globally Optimized (IRGO) architecture, users will be able to define filters, logical rule sets, and other constraints that can be used to optimize and prioritize data retention strategies while managing a given storage capacity to satisfy operational requirements as needed.

award_title: Advanced Persistent Cyber Threat Anomaly Detection
research_keywords: Advanced persistent threat,Anomaly Detection,Zero-Day Attack,Cyber Heath and Status,real-time,Threat Engagement Process,Detect-And-Learn,Information Enabled
abstract: The imminent cyber-attack most threatening to Navy IP-based combat system networks is the Advanced Persistent Threat.Characterized by its ability to go undetected on the targeted system for extended periods of time, this adversary looks to compromise data for economic or military advancement.Common predict-and-control cyber defense tactics such as anti-virus and patching are rendered useless against the custom malware and tools leveraged by this advanced adversary.IDTs proposed solution for Cyber Threat Anomaly Detection and Mitigation (CTADM) supports the shift in cyber defense strategy, from predict-and-control to detect-and-learn.Focusing cyber defense resources inside the boundary of the system network enables the defense to monitor anomalous behavior and discriminate threats as they occur in real-time.IDTs ATRT system threads uniquely provide the capability to capture cyber-related system data in the context of expected operational function, an important discriminator in balancing missed detections and false alarms.This increased dimensionality of solution space more clearly reveals the tactics, techniques, and procedures that indicate the presence of an APT on the system.Leveraging these threat indicators for threat engagement, earlier in the kill chain, enables information superiority over the APT to be achieved.

award_title: Reliable Target Area of Uncertainty from an Underwater Acoustic Source(s)
research_keywords: Frequency difference of arrival,Multi-Static Sonar,Multiple Hypothesis Tracking,Joint sonobuoy and target estimation,TIME DIFFERENCE OF ARRIVAL,Gaussian mixture,Anti-Access/Area Denial
abstract: In a multi-static drifting field of active and passive sonobuoys, reducing the area of uncertainty (AOU) around a submarine target is of paramount importance, especially when operating in Anti-Access/Area Denial (A2AD) environments. In order to take advantage of all available information, we use a joint estimation approach that simultaneously estimates all buoy states (position and velocity) and covariances, as well as multiple target states. In a three-dimensional buoy field with 20 to 40 buoys, this means that the joint state vector (and corresponding covariances) are very large. The off-block diagonal portions of the joint covariance matrix contains information that couples estimates between the individual buoy states, as well as the submarine target state. Ignoring the cross coupling simply throws away information that can be used to reduce the AOU of the target. We plan a stepped approach that integrates joint buoy and target estimation with a multiple hypothesis tracking (MHT) algorithm. Our overall objective is to reduce the AOU of the submarine, which ultimately reduces the prosecution time line.

award_title: Algorithms for ground vehicle on-the-move detection of Unmanned Aerial Systems
research_keywords: Kalman Filter,Gaussian sums,Bayesian Discrimination,Remote Controlled Model Aircraft,Image warping
abstract: This proposal addresses the algorithms and processing necessary to use imaging IR sensors for RCMA/UAS (Remote Controlled Model Aircraft / Unmanned Aerial Systems) detection on ground vehicles while stationary and while on-the-move. It also address how the algorithms may be included in a larger architecture, already under development, that includes other sensing modalities as well as threat counters. Key aspects of the effort include:  DA robust image processing detection algorithm for On-The-Move IR image sequences, a motion-compensation process that combines IMU measurements and image-sensed motion, a detection tracking process for both stationary and on-the-move operation, a statistical discrimination process for distinguishing clutter detections from true targets, a context evaluation scheme for evaluating detections based on spatial/temporal correlation to other detections, and an in-line, self-evaluation of performance.
